Submit your article to this journal Article views 666 View related articles Citing articles 3 View citing articles Full Terms Conditions of access and use can be found at Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology 2025 VOL. 55 NO. 16 1249 1272 Zero-carbon solution Microalgae as a low-cost feedstock for fuel production and carbon sequestration Moeen Ali Rashada Farrukh Jamila Murid Hussaina Abrar Inayatb Parveen Akhterc Muhammad Haris Hamayuna Ali Ahsana and Young-Kwon Parkd aDepartment of Chemical Engineering COMSATS University Islamabad Lahore Pakistan bDepartment of Energy School of Engineering Robert Gordon University Aberdeen Scotland UK cDepartment of Chemistry The University of Lahore Lahore Pakistan dSchool of Environmental Engineering University of Seoul Seoul Republic of Korea ABSTRACT The increasing environmental issues driven by the depletion of fossil fuel reserves and excessive carbon emissions have put the world s attention toward finding sustainable solutions. Among various solutions microal gae emerge as a promising zero-carbon alternative addressing both biofuel produc tion and carbon sequestration. This review provides a comprehensive analysis of cultiva tion methods for microalgae biofuel conver sion techniques bioethanol and biodiesel and their role in reducing eliminating green house gas GHGs emissions. Recent develop ments in cultivation methods such as photobioreactors and open-pond cultivation have shown encouraging results regarding the CO2-capturing potential of microalgae. Specific microal gal strains such as Chlorella vulgaris and Chlorella sp. exhibit high biomass productivity 0.4 and 1.21 g L d respectively and CO2 fixation rates 0.49 and 0.25 g L d respectively standing out as the most viable for biofuel synthesis. Additionally this review compares various cultivation systems based on techno-economic analysis TEA with an aim to highlight cost-effective and industrially feasible systems. Among the analyzed strains Nannochloropsis oceanica outperformed the other strains in terms of biodiesel productivity 0.36 g L d production costs 1.5 L and EROI 13.5 . This makes it an excellent choice for large-scale biofuel production. By integrating biofuel production and CO2 sequestration this review identifies key challenges and future research directions for economically feasible microalgal bioenergy solutions. Introduction Rapid urbanization and industrial development such as power plants process industries and oil refineries are prone to the widespread use of nonrenewable energy sources and have flooded the environment with carbon and other pollutants Burrington 2024 . Over the last century all coun tries have had a large influx of ozone-depleting substances and increased CO2 concentration approximately 75 of ozone-depleting greenhouse gases GHGs de_Richter et al. 2017 . Table 1 shows the significant contributors to CO2 emissions worldwide along with the amount of CO2 emissions and megawatt hours of energy capacity. Among the notable contributors China has made significant investments in renewable energy sources and the United States has passed legislation promoting green and renewable energy advancement. To better balance economic development and sustainability India Germany Russia and Japan have focused on increasing energy efficiency and researching more environmentally friendly energy sources Chien et al. 2021 Zhang Kong 2022 . The nonrenewable fossil fuels and the increased use of petroleum products have led to a massive increase in atmospheric CO2 concentrations thus a transition is required to absorb the atmospheric CO2 Wang et al. 2023 . Similarly global fossil fuel consumption exceeded 500 g t of CO2 by November. To maintain stable atmospheric CO2 concentrations until 2050 carbon-neutral energy sources must be adopted to reduce harmful fuel emissions by 50 Rochedo et al. 2021 . Therefore sustainable developments are expected to reduce adverse outcomes for which research ers are working throughout the control cycle to help reduce environmental problems caused by CO2 emissions. To alleviate the effects of climate change carbon capture utilization and storage CCUS objects can be used to reduce carbon in the environment by sequestering it into an insoluble structure or completely transforming it into a usable configuration Yan et al. 2021 . In this regard microalgae have great potential as cheap feedstock for developing zero-carbon solutions and biofuel production. Consequently using microalgae to capture CO2 could be an economic shift to facilitate the commercialization of these frameworks while reducing high global CO2 concentrations Goswami et al. 2024 . These studies have driven attention to numerous aspects of biofuel production via microalgae-based routes to obtain carbon-free fuel production Samartha et al. 2022 . Additionally Table 1. Major contributors to world CO2 emissions Aktar et al. 2021 . No. Country CO2 Emissions million tons Energy Capacity GWh 1 China 10 877.23 8 603 000 2 United States 5414.73 4 059 000 3 India 2648.88 1 927 000 4 Russia 1563.17 1 065 000 5 Japan 1143.05 1 247 000 6 Germany 804.21 639 000 7 South Korea 660.13 654 000 8 Iran 622.39 323 000 Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology 1251 alarming levels of CO2 are an environmental issue affecting how the global economy develops because unusual environmental changes negatively affect a wide range of industries water streams and agriculture Aktar et al. 2021 . Efforts have been made to supply low-cost feedstocks such as CO2 and toxic water streams from industrial sources Abdel-Raouf et al. 2012 Goveas et al. 2022 R. Kumar et al. 2020 . Therefore by the integration of carbon capture and utilization techniques to produce microalgae-based biofuel a closed-loop carbon cycle can be obtained Onyeaka et al. 2021 . With an assumption of absorption capacity of 1.83 kg CO2 kg microalgae the growth of microalgae can be said to be progressive Sajjadi et al. 2018 . Hence an ongoing focus on microalgae as raw materials for bioenergy production is vital. They are the most prom ising raw materials for balancing and regulating the growing demand for biofuels as cheap feed stocks to produce biofuels and other bioproducts by fixing atmospheric CO2 Sadvakasova et al. 2023 . The applicability of microalgae for biofuel production and CO2 sequestration has been reported in the literature. However the reported study focuses on either of these applications lacking an integrated evaluation of these processes. This review aims to fill this gap by offering a compre hensive overview of the current state and understanding the opportunities and challenges asso ciated with a particular focus on the potential of microalgae for zero-carbon applications. Furthermore a comparative techno-economic assessment of various cultivation techniques offering insights into cost-effectiveness and industrial applications is not reported to the best of our knowledge . This review therefore aims to provide a thorough and critical assessment of the existing knowledge and recent developments in utilizing microalgae for biofuel production and carbon sequestration while addressing the challenges and opportunities associated with the technical and economic feasibility and its life cycle. 2. Chemistry of microalgal CO2 fixation O Leary 1988 revealed the mechanism of carbon dioxide CO2 absorption by microalgae. The CO2 absorption involves passive diffusion of CO2 molecules across the microalgal cell membrane which are then driven by concentration gradient into the cytoplasm of cells and fixed in two ways through the C3 and C4 pathways. Most algae use the C3 pathway also known as the Calvin cycle. In this pathway CO2 and a 5-carbon compound ribulose-1 and 5-bisphosphate combine to produce two 3-carbon compounds S. Li et al. 2022 . As part of their photosynthetic cellular activity the key enzyme in the C3 carbon fixation process which is produced by microalgae is ribulose-1 5-bisphosphate carboxylase oxygenase RuBisCO . This enzyme starts the CO2 conversion into a 6-C organic compound from the atmosphere followed by splitting into two 3-carbon compounds 3-phosphoglyceeric acid . Certain microalgae species diatoms and plants like corn sugar cane and millet utilize the C4 pathway for CO2 fixation. The C4 plants use CO2 and three-carbon compounds to produce a single 4-carbon compound oxaloacetate via photo respiration which increases CO2-dependent productivity. The 4-carbon compound is later trans ported to specialized bundle sheath cells releasing CO2 for the Calvin cycle. The overview of carbon capturing mechanisms CCM is vital in understanding the capabilities of microalgae in the field of carbon capture and storage. The role of numerous intracellular and extracellular carbonic anhydrases CAs in microalgal cells is also reported in the literature Zieliński et al. 2023 . With the decrease in the quantity of inorganic carbon in the atmosphere the role of CA becomes interestingly significant. Active transport of bicarbonate ions HCO3 into the cell is another important aspect of microalgae CCM. In their respective cell membranes the bicarbonate transporters are controlled by microalgae which when the levels of CO2 are comparatively low take up the bicarbonate ions in the environment Jensen et al. 2020 . Through these mechanisms within the chloroplast envelope microalgae can produce significant compounds such as polysaccharides lipids pigments proteins nutrients bioactive compounds and cell enhancers as shown in Fig. 1. 1252 M. A. RASHAD ET AL. 3. Microalgae cultivation systems In recent times attention has been diverted toward microalgae systems because of their capa bilities toward sequestering CO2 and for producing biofuels. These microalgae are typically microscopic photosynthetic organisms Jalilian et al. 2020 Kassim Meng 2017 . Because of their various characteristics i.e. ease of cultivation high photosynthetic efficiency rapid growth rates and nutritional requirements microalgae are highly efficient at carbon sequestration Siddiki et al. 2022 . The sequestration of CO2 through microalgae is carried out through photosynthesis i.e. using CO2 water and sunlight to produce organic compounds primarily carbohydrates while releasing oxygen. As microalgae continue to grow through photosynthesis the accumulation of carbon-rich organic matter within their cells results in carbon sequestration from the atmosphere and nutri ents nitrogen and phosphorus from farmland run-off water Peter et al. 2021 . Culturing microalgae in contaminated environments such as wastewater ponds polluted industrial water streams and absorption of CO2 from the atmosphere presents a solution for environmental remediation by sequestering maximum nutrients and CO2 thereby reducing GHG concentrations and limiting global warming and its associated impacts Comley et al. 2024 . The cultivation of microalgae is carried out either in a photobioreactor system heterotrophic or in an open pond system photo-autotrophy which is demonstrated in Fig. 2 Zhu et al. 2019 . To synthesize energy-rich compounds from inorganic carbon sources such as CO2 H2CO3 HCO3 and CO3 2 photo-autotrophy permits them to make use of the sunlight K. Kumar et al. 2011 R. Kumar et al. 2024 . The characteristics of photo-trophy cultivation consist of its ability to tolerate naturally varying temperatures salinity absorption independence from land resources and maintenance of pH. Despite being cost-effective open ponds possess various disadvantages i.e. significant contamination percolation and sand suspension. Due to variations in environ mental conditions and susceptibility to contamination open-pond cultivation is restricted to a limited number of species considering specific soil and environmental conditions Devi et al. 2024 . The open-pond system was designed with various shapes sizes and construction mate rials. It slopes like a paddle wheel undeveloped lagoons round swing arm lagoons and overflow decks with gently sloped beds. Mixing and circulating water at a typical depth of 15 50 cm in the open pond system helps maintain the microalgae cells in suspension. CO2 supply is met naturally at the air water interface but it can also be supplemented by submerged aerators to circumvent carbon limitations Verma et al. 2020 . In contrast photobioreactor systems are closed heterotrophic systems in which a part made of light-transmitting material is specifically allocated to photosynthesis under controlled condi tions Bibi et al. 2022 . Different types of photobioreactors are used for heterotrophic cultivation considering the optimization of the process and maximum yield such as batch systems used in a defined medium volume. Within photobioreactors an air bubble mechanism or mechanical pump circulates the microalgal culture facilitating the exchange of O2 and CO2 between the FIG. 1. Cellular chemistry of CO2 utilization by microalgae. Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology 1253 medium and gas phases Kanna Dasan et al. 2023 . The researchers R. N. Singh Sharma 2012 used different photobioreactor systems such as annular and tubular photobioreactors in which the batches of microalgae pass through long cylinders where mechanical hoods or air droplets generate siphon forces to ensure the maximum exchange of O2 and CO2 between liquid and gaseous media. Flat panel photobioreactors provide higher photosynthetic efficiency and are thus the most valuable type of photobioreactor Kanna Dasan et al. 2023 . Typically the oper ational and maintenance costs of different photobioreactors are high. However increased pro ductivity increased CO2 absorption capacity reduced risk of contamination and the practical scale required for biofuel production can offset these negative factors P. Cheng et al. 2022 . The term mixed hybrid system under photoautotrophic conditions corresponds to two dis tinct approaches a culture system that couples photobioreactors and open ponds or basins that can be either open or transitioned into a closed culture mode based on the amount of CO2 available Chauton et al. 2015 . Mixotrophic development cannot rely solely on photosynthesis because light is not a fully limiting variable as light or natural substrates are available for the product. Besides this fermenters are used for industrial production typically with a large reactor volume allowing biomass production of 20 100 g L compared to 0.5 1.0 g L biomass produced in open systems Condor et al. 2022 . Within this system microalgae can capably grow under controlled growth conditions with maximum CO2 fixation however the costs and availability of microalgae used in the fermenter increase the cost-ineffectiveness of the process. However different microalgal species exhibit variable tolerance to CO2 concentrations Varshney et al. 2020 . In a study involving Chlorella vulgaris optimal growth occurred at 5 v v CO2 whereas a higher concentration of 15 v v CO2 exhibited inhibitory effects C.-T. Li et al. 2021 . The higher levels of CO2 hinder microalgal growth due to acidification within the chlo roplast resulting in the inactivation of enzymes involved in the Calvin cycle and consequently growth is inhibited. It is essential to recognize that an optimal CO2 concentration does not ensure maximum biomass production for all microalgae species. For example Chlorella vulgaris Scenedesmus obliquus and Nannochloropsis oculata exhibited high tolerance to varying CO2 levels 100 80 and 45 respectively however their maximum biomass productivity was observed at 10 10 20 and 5 CO2 respectively Ganesh Saratale et al. 2022 . The 10 15 concentration range of CO2 is significant as certain microalgal species thrive within this range. This CO2 concentration range is often encountered in flue gases from cement FIG. 2. Schematic of different configurations for microalgae cultivation. 1254 M. A. RASHAD ET AL. and coal-fired power plants and constitutes a significant source of GHG pollution Barati et al. 2022 . The production of 100 tons of microalgal biomass allows for the fixation of approximately 180 tons of CO2 Patricio et al. 2017 . Among the major sources of CO2 emissions industrial processes play a key role. Furthermore CO2 sequestration primarily regulates the pH in microal gae cultures. pH of the culture medium increases due to CO2 absorption by microalgae and thus can be used as an indicator of moderate inflows of CO2. This could serve as a promising CO2 control parameter for microalgal cultivation offering potential opportunities for effective carbon capture Vale et al. 2020 . 4. Biofuel and biochar production potential of microalgae At present the energy requirements of the world are met mostly through fossil fuels which are not only limited and nonrenewable but also harmful to the environment by producing GHGs. Microalgae have a promising future as raw materials for producing bioethanol and biodiesel which are considered third and fourth-generation biofuels as well as biochar. Microalgae provide a sustainable economic and feasible solution to cope with the ever-increasing energy demands Malla et al. 2022 . The next part of this article includes an examination of existing literature on biofuels and biochar synthesis from microalgae. 4.1. Bioethanol Bioethanol production has significant potential as a renewable energy source because it can be used as a substitute for gasoline or blended with gasoline to reduce GHG emissions Sydney et al. 2019 . In comparison to traditional crops e.g. sugarcane corn wheat etc. bioethanol production from microalgae has considerable advantages i.e. fixation of CO2 from microalgae at a comparatively faster growth rate than traditional crops therefore within a short span of time bioethanol can be produced. Bioethanol production involves several processes cultivation pretreatment saccharification fermentation and distillation as shown in Fig. 3. The choice of cultivation method for bioethanol production depends on the cost of production the type of microalgae being grown and the desired scale of production. Considering the selection criteria photobioreactors are suitable environments for growth on a commercial scale to fix the maximum amount of CO2. FIG. 3. Process flow for bioethanol production from microalgae with CO2 fixation. Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology 1255 It should be noted however that this procedure frequently involves a vital pretreatment step. This phase is particularly important for breaking down the microalgae s thick cell walls and increasing intracellular glucose availability. Following pretreatment more efficient saccharification of carbohydrates and fermentation of suitable sugars occur resulting in higher bioethanol yields. Chemical pretreatment of microalgal biomass using acids such as H2SO4 HCl and HNO3 or bases such as NaOH KOH and Na2CO3 is efficient because of its rapidity cost-effectiveness and ease of application Saravanan et al. 2023 . However their reliance on high temperatures pressure and acid concentrations is the drawbacks of these treatments. Some carbohydrates from degraded microalgal biomass generate toxic compounds and inhibit yeast metabolism during fermentation for bioethanol production Kusmiyati et al. 2023 . Therefore optimization of the chemical pretreatment conditions is essential for this process. Enzymatic pretreatment is one of the prominent methods of biomass pretreatment. In this method enzymes hydrolase and cellulose act on biomass to convert it into reducing sugars which then include glucose Constantino et al. 2021 . Enzymatic pretreatment has several advantages over chemical pretreatment since it does not leave toxic byproducts does not operate under extreme conditions and yields a higher conversion rate. Temperature pH and inhibitor effects need to be correlated with opti mum enzyme operating conditions to maximize enzyme activity. For chemical and enzymatic pretreatments hydrothermal electric pulse wet oxidation microwaves or ultrasonic techniques can be utilized Agarwalla et al. 2023 . A study on bioethanol production from the biomass of the carbohydrate-rich Chlorella vulgaris FSP-E strain Ho et al. 2013 reported a glucose yield of 90.4 0.461 g ethanol g biomass after pretreatment with 1 sulfuric acid at 140 °C for 30 min and a glucose yield of 93.6 after pretreatment with 3 sulfuric acid at 160 °C for 15 min. After the enzymatic reaction the theoretical yields were 90 and 79 respectively indicating enhanced growth parameters. Using either separate hydrolysis and fermentation SHF or simultaneous saccharification fermentation SSF it is possible to obtain the fermentation of microalgae-based sugars Kusmiyati et al. 2023 . To initiate the fermentation in the SHF process the sugars that is achieved from pretreatment are supplied to the fermenter Huang et al. 2020 . However there are various parameters that can reduce the effectiveness of fermentation processes i.e. high temperature pressure and the presence of inhibitors. On the other hand maintaining a neutral pH can optimize the fermentation process. Followed by fermentation the distillation of the product is conducted to achieve high-purity 99 mol ethanol and for microalgae cultivation the byproduct CO2 gas is reused. For microalgal bioethanol production via the SHF method various studies have been reported identifying the different yields of ethanol from different microalgal species. The researchers Jeyakumar et al. 2022 obtained 0.29 g of ethanol per gram of microalgal biomass. Zymomonas mobilis bacteria were used to convert Scenedesmus obliquus into bioethanol yielding 0.213 g ethanol g biomass and higher growth rates Condor et al. 2022 . Furthermore because of the high carbohydrate content in various strains owing to the absorbed CO2 microalgae are a potential low-cost feedstock. Different microalgal strains have diverse growth conditions Chlorella is best known for its high CO2 absorption and grows in a wide range of temperatures Ashour et al. 2024 . However it is typically grown at a temperature of 20 30 °C and a pH of 7 8. Scenedesmus grows more efficiently in open ponds than in photo bioreactors because in open culture they absorb more CO2 at a temperature of 20 30 °C and a pH of 7 9 Arun et al. 2022 . Spirulina Dunaliella and Nannochloropsis are other dominant strains with high CO2 sequestration used to produce bioethanol. Moreover many studies have used rotary bioreactors with a vertical axis developed to increase the light flux and CO2 absorp tion to deliver the product Han et al. 2022 . Considering the commercialization need for clean cost-effective and robust technologies modified reactor configurations have been used in various studies to lower costs while enhancing yield. Regardless of the advantages discussed earlier there are numerous challenges that are asso ciated with the use of microalgae for bioethanol production. Production cost and delivery to the end user through commercialization are key challenges which need further research to 1256 M. A. RASHAD ET AL. optimize the efficiency of fermentation processes and lipid extraction methods to make them more economically feasible Wiatrowski et al. 2022 . Owing to growing concerns regarding the environmental impact of fossil fuels bioethanol production is estimated to increase significantly despite the limitations in the potential capacity. Bioethanol production capacity from microalgae of 15 and 8 billion gallons from the USA and Brazil respectively are reported de Souza Abud de Farias Silva 2019 . Similarly China India and the European Union are cutting their dependency on fossil fuels by enhancing bioethanol production capacity eventually producing green energy. 4.2. Biodiesel Biodiesel production from microalgae by sequestering CO2 depends on various parameters 1 the efficiency of the conversion process in different process configurations 2 the volume of CO2 utilized from the atmosphere and 3 the strain of microalgae grown. The efficiencies of transesterification and lipid extraction are vital parameters in determining the processes involved in biodiesel production Deshmukh et al. 2019 . Transesterification is also dependent on the molar ratio of the reactants using an alkaline catalyst such as KOH or NaOH which also influences the estimated yield Mittal et al. 2022 . For efficient biodiesel production the potential of various fast-growing microalgal strains each having growth characteristics and a unique lipid profile is also reported in the literature. Their study provided criteria to select the most appropriate species based on the type of reactor and reaction kinetics which significantly affected the scalability of the biodiesel production process. The reaction kinetics can be controlled by 1 using catalysts and 2 adjusting the mixing intensity to increase the potential yield B. Kim et al. 2019 . Furthermore specific microalgal strains must be considered to understand their potential CO2 uptake rate. Some strains with advanced CO2 uptake like Chlorophyceae Cyanobacteria and Euglenophyceae have considerable carbon sequestration potential. Chlorella vulgaris is best known as a promising strain for biodiesel production because of its high lipid accumulation Durvasula et al. 2015 . In another study different strains were used depending on the culti vation technique Scenedesmus obliquus grew well under both mixotrophic and heterotrophic conditions allowing for high productivity with toxic CO2 concentrations Lee et al. 2015 . Likewise Nannochloropsis oculate exhibited a fast growth rate whereas Haematococcus pluvialis produced higher levels of astaxanthin. In another study Neochloris oleoabundans and Nannochloropsis spp. accumulated the highest oil content when exposed to different concentra tions of sodium nitrate Patel et al. 2021 . The researchers Kawale Kishore 2019 reported the pyrolysis results of Oscillatoria to investigate the behavior of the products obtained. In their research TiO2 and ZnO were used as catalysts in a 1 1 ratio in a nitrogen atmosphere at 1 bar and 550 °C. This resulted in a gas-liquid separation that separated the non-condensable gas producing an 87 biodiesel yield through catalytic action. Recent studies have shown that Scenedesmus obliquus can absorb CO2 with better lipid pro duction. Researchers have successfully improved the overall performance of Scenedesmus obliquus using a combination of procedures and strategies that enhanced growth and increased CO2 sequestration which greatly benefits biodiesel production and CO2 removal. In another study researchers targeted biorefining methods for the simultaneous production of biodiesel from different microalgae species. In this regard an exceptional pretreatment strategy using acid hydrolysis was employed to validate the most curative polysaccharides from Scenedesmus sp. to achieve a 90 biomass yield. The researchers Chia et al. 2021 in their study to improve the growth of microalgal strains to produce biodiesel using CO2 from flue gas and wastewater as a nutrient source reported that microalgae have a high capacity to produce biodiesel with an overall efficiency of 87 under the growth conditions of their study. Biodiesel production from microalgae using hydrothermal liquefaction was modeled followed by commercial-scale catalyst upgradation with the extracted biodiesel having a persistence Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology 1257 comparable to that of naphtha and jet fuels. The application of ultrasound in biodiesel produc tion from microalgae has recently been attempted Shrikhande et al. 2021 . On a large scale sonication improves all-switching properties shortens response times and lowers production costs Khan et al. 2021 . However further consideration is required in terms of technical and economic feasibility. The researchers Chang et al. 2020 investigated the continuous production of biodiesel from Chrysophyta and Chlorella sp. in combination with supercritical CO2 extraction lipids were extracted and then processed for final biodiesel production. After decompression the residue could be reused as a raw material for pharmaceutical and nutritional supplements. Observations from these experiments demonstrated that particle size temperature pressure the molar ratio of methanol to oil CO2 absorption capacity and n-hexane affected the trans-esterification bio diesel synthesis process. Another study stressed the strength of the large-scale integration of CO2 fixation sequestration and uptake within microalgal cultivation for biofuel production and environmental benefits in evaluating the economic feasibility of valuable co-product generation Yaashikaa et al. 2023 . 4.3. Biochar Microalgae are considered highly versatile feedstock for producing biochar as they are rich in organic matter. Biochar finds its applicability in various aspects 1 capacity to hold water 2 to enhance the fertility of soil and 3 for retention of nutrients. Thermal conversion processes are involved in the biochar production process. Microalgae must be exposed to high tempera tures typically between 400 and 600 °C when treated in pyrolizers Rajesh Banu et al. 2020 . To produce biochar gasification is a vital process. In this process microalgae are subjected to high temperatures ranging from 600 to 800 °C converting biomass into biochar and gases Aliyu et al. 2021 . The gases produced during the gasification process are effectively used as fuel sources with applicability in transportation processing industries energy production. For thermal conversion of microalgae to biochar the microalgae must be dried to a moisture content of about 10 20 Sarwer et al. 2022 . The optimal time to harvest microalgae is when they have reached maturity under optimal growth conditions and thermal treatment is applied after mois ture content is minimized by centrifugation and filtration as shown in Fig. 4. Moreover an important key step in identifying the suitability of microalgae to produce biochar is their characterization and comparison with biochar derived from terrestrial biomass SundarRajan et al. 2020 . The researchers Bird et al. 2011 provided essential data to evaluate the physi cochemical properties of biochar made from different microalgae strains from fresh brackish and marine environments. Their research used repeated elemental analyses to determine the carbon nitrogen and hydrogen contents using the dry combustion method. The carbonate content was determined by heating at 1000 °C for 1 hr and the organic content was determined at 550 °C for 2 hrs. Additionally the pH cation exchange capacity CEC extracted phosphorus by extraction with bicarbonate electrical conductivity exchangeable bases Na K Mg and Ca and total phosphorus were analyzed. These results were compared with previously published literature and the obtained data was useful to obtain maximum yield conversion on a commercial scale Bora et al. 2024 . Studies have shown that different microalgal strains such as Dunaliella can produce up to 10 g L and Chlorella and Spirulina can produce up to 20 30 g of dry biomass L culture in large-scale production which produces significant quantities of biochar followed by thermal processing Cuevas-Castillo et al. 2020 . In another study various microalgal species were ana lyzed for biochar production. All the species were shortlisted based on various important criteria 1 bioprocessing potential 2 ease of cultivation and 3 adaptability to different environments. Based on these parameters Cladophora Coelothrix Kützing Chaetomorpha Linum Cladophora Patentiramea Cladophoropsis sp. and Chaetomorpha Indica were selected for their study Binda et al. 2020 . All the samples were washed squeezed dry and oven-dried at 65 °C for 48 hrs. 1258 M. A. RASHAD ET AL. After pretreatment at 105 °C microalgae feedstock was loaded into a tubular-type vessel sealed inside a furnace and allowed to cool for 20 min after holding for 60 min. At each temperature three replicates of the microalgae-derived biochar demonstrated more than 3 induced weight loss in all microalga types. They indicated considerable potential for biochar production because it constantly demonstrated desirable characteristics under varying conditions Law et al. 2022 . Recently it was recognized that the CO2 sequestration potential of microalgae-derived biochar is at least 25 greater than that of biochar obtained from other sources of biomass Mona et al. 2021 . By considering the carbon sequestration potential of biochar it was found that biochar pyrolyzed at 500 °C can mitigate up to 380 g L of carbon Mohit Remya 2023 . Low-temperature- derived biochar decomposes faster than high-temperature-derived biochar although the former sequesters more CO2 through decomposition. According to research approximately 10 25 kg of microalgal biomass yields 23 kg of biochar in 1 hr of pyrolysis using a combination with ammo nium bicarbonate. Therefore they are perfect substitutes for fertilizers because they provide a substrate for enhancing microbial activity De Bhowmick Sarmah 2020 . 5. Microalgal potential for capturing carbon dioxide Given the current state of the environment worldwide finding ways to mitigate CO2 emissions which contribute significantly to global warming and climate change is vital. Microalgae used for capturing CO2 sequester enormous amounts of CO2 from the atmosphere and help reduce the overall atmospheric concentration of CO2. Microalgae can capture CO2 from soluble car bonates air smokestacks and industrial exhaust because they adapt to different conditions Sanchez et al. 2015 . 5.1. Factors affecting microalgal absorption of CO2 The researchers Verma et al. 2020 concluded that photoautotrophic strains of microalgae accumulate CO2 10 50 times more efficiently than terrestrial plants because of their extraordinary FIG. 4. Microalgal CO2 sequestration different production processes and products obtained. Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology 1259 ability to fix CO2. This capacity of microalgae to absorb CO2 can be exploited for preventing environmental emissions by introducing CO2-rich flue gas from industrial facilities or power plants into ponds or photobioreactors using flue gas bubbling systems designed to mix the flue gas with microalgal cultures H. M. Singh et al. 2019 . CO2 tolerance varies from species to species Chlorella vulgaris shows the highest growth at 5 v v CO2 concentration but its growth is inhibited at 15 v v CO2 Mittal et al. 2022 . The most promising microalgal strains for CO2 sequestration are Nannochloropsis oculata Chlorella vulgaris Botryococcus braunii and Scenedesmus obliquus Kandasamy et al. 2022 . In addition to the influence of microalgal cul tivation systems CO2 fixation by microalgae is affected by physicochemical parameters during growth. Usually microalgae growth at moderate CO2 concentrations is inhibited by acidification. Many microalgal processes cannot be scaled up efficiently because of the failure to recycle resources by reusing wastewater phosphates and nitrates during the cultivation stage Chu et al. 2021 . Another factor is the energy and resources required for microalgal cultivation such as water nutrients and light which can strain local resources and contribute to environmental degradation. The pH of the microalgae cultivation medium significantly regulates nutrient uptake photo synthetic efficiency and carbon sequestration with pH 6.5 8.5 being optimal for satisfactory growth Herold et al. 2021 . However a slightly alkaline pH benefits higher CO2 absorption because an alkali increases the CO2 supply within the cultivation medium. Bicarbonate HCO3 is also a carbon carrier within the inorganic cultivation medium. By carbonic anhydrase HCO3 can be converted to OH increasing pH and eventually changing the equilibrium of various inorganic carbon species Kupriyanova et al. 2023 . It is well known that exhaust gas containing excessive CO2 10 20 vol. acidifies the algal cultivation and suppresses algal growth. Temperature is an essential element for increasing and improving photosynthesis in organ isms. The optimum temperature for growth varies from species to species and the optimal temperature for Nannochloropsis is 293 K and Chlorella vulgaris is 303 K Brindhadevi et al. 2021 . Low temperatures inhibit carbon sequestration in microalgae by decreasing the enzymatic activity of carboxylase five-bisphosphate Rubisco and ribulose-1 these enzymes play an essential role in photorespiration and photosynthesis. However high temperatures alter photo respiration and metabolic activity Shan et al. 2023 . The adverse effects of temperature on microalgae are visible above 313 K which includes partial inactivation of oxygen-evolving potential. Temperature is inversely related to CO2 dissolution inside the liquid medium whereby an increase in temperature reduces CO2 dissolution in the algal cultivation medium Y. W. Cheng et al. 2021 . In addition low- and high-light intensities alter photosynthetic mechanisms. Table 2 presents details of several microalgae strains and their responses to CO2. Two strains Chlorella vulgaris and Nannochloropsis oculata have shown high CO2 fixation rates 0.49 g L d and 0.39 g L d respectively contributing to their strong CO2 removal efficiency 92.1 and 67 . In contrast Chlorococcum littorale and Haematococcus pluvialis demonstrated lower fixation rates 0.13 g L d and 0.143 g L d because of limitations in their growth. The available data Table 2 demonstrates the necessity of enhancing less successful strains and the ability of some microalgae to sequester CO2 efficiently. 5.2. Challenges Despite the significant progress in using microalgae for CO2 capture several limitations must be overcome to fully realize the potential of this technology. One of the primary limitations of microalgal technology is the lack of economically viable commercial methods for harvesting microalgal biomass at a steady-state scale. Various biological contaminants such as predators along with parasitic fungi and other microorganisms diminish sustainable microalgae cultivation by causing significant reductions in biomass. Recent studies focus on developing techniques which address these problems in microalgae cultivation. Studies have shown that sodium 1260 M. A. RASHAD ET AL. dodecylbenzene sulfonate SDBS applied at 10 mg L concentration effectively controls predatory flagellates alongside ciliates populations in Chlorella mass cultures Nordio et al. 2024 . The implementation of synthetic chemicals is associated with various problems i.e. they harm the environment as well as pose risks to unintended species. The increasing interest in plant-derived pesticides occurs because these substances represent a sustainable alternative to conventional synthetic pesticides El-Sheekh et al. 2025 . Pulsed electric fields PEF represent one of the multiple physical methods which researchers are testing to eliminate protozoan contaminants specifically. PEF treatment of industrial photobioreactors decreased active protozoan numbers by 87 during 6 hrs of operating time before eliminating all protozoa within several days without affecting microalgal growth rates Paladino Neviani 2025 . There are also some chemical barriers to the utilization of CO2 streams Chia et al. 2021 . Both sulfur dioxide SO2 and nitrogen compounds such as oxides NOx can be unfavorable to microalgae growth productivity and even the pH of the microalgal growth medium. The streams of CO2 also contain other chemical factors such as Pb Cd and Hg which can alter algal metabolic pathways Chia et al. 2018 . The wastewater streams containing heavy metals and nitrogen- and phosphorus-containing compounds such as nitrite NO2 ammonia NH3 and nitrate NO3 alongside various industrial effluents pose a serious risk toward the quality of water and can even suppress some microorganisms Ahmed et al. 2022 . Not all the metals are harmful as they can assist in cell growth but the media in which these cultures are grown possess a certain concentration of these heavy metals to aid in growth which can be challenging Cheah et al. 2015 Zhao et al. 2023 . The high cost of producing and maintaining photobioreactors and the associated equipment to provide sufficient light and nutrients to support microalgal growth can limit their use in certain regions Zuccaro et al. 2020 . Additionally the photosynthetic processes of microalgae depend on mass transfer temperature regulation and natural reactions Mohamadnia et al. 2022 Wu et al. 2023 . Currently various approaches are used including physical and organic shift methods each under specific conditions for CO2 fixation Sarwer et al. 2022 . The impact of temperature pH and light on CO2 fixation rates particularly under foaming conditions has been investigated with a focus on CO2 absorption in various experimental conditions. A note worthy gap exists between thermodynamic and kinetic studies Sathya et al. 2023 . This defi ciency undermines the empirical basis of the experimental results impeding industrial design and control efforts which is a major commercial challenge. Table 2. Kim et al. 2017 Critical Reviews in Environmental Science and Technology 1261 6. Life cycle assessment LCA Concerning microalgal biofuels the LCA discussion focuses on large-scale energy generation especially nutrient supplies cultivation resources energy inputs water use nitrogen and phos phorus constraints and the life cycle of other materials products and by-products involved in the process of biofuel production by sequestering carbon Moradiya Marathe 2023 . By examining the environmental implications of biofuels produced from microalgae and their effec tiveness for utilization as zero-carbon solution several LCAs have assessed cultivation and inventories S. Li et al. 2023 . A comprehensive life cycle analysis is conducted by Saranya and Ramachandra from cradle to grave Saranya Ramachandra 2020 . The cradle-to-grave analysis demonstrated that GHGs can be reduced to 80 by using microalgal biofuels instead of using conventional fuels. However this efficacy is linked with higher energy requirements for culti vation and processing. Cultivation harvesting and conversion processes play a key role while doing the life cycle assessment LCA of biofuels based on microalgae for important parameters i.e. energy and CO2 sequestration. S. Li et al. 2023 . Microalgae play a vital role in the uptake of nutrients and to produce energy and their nutritional requirements are affected by stressors that affect carbohydrate and lipid metabolism. Across different strains and under ambient normal conditions the phosphorus and nitrogen requirements vary ranging from 2.5 2.6 to 11 70.7 g kg respec tively Gumbi et al. 2022 . To increase these nutrients and to minimize the requirements of energy partial or complete utilization of wastewater can also be made Maktabifard et al. 2023 . Various parameters affect the results produced from life cycle analysis 1 cultivation location 2 species 3 methodologies etc. de Assis et al. 2023 . Through specialized cultivation setups production rates can reach remarkable levels ranging from 100 to 1536 g m3 per day Wimmerova et al. 2022 . Various methods are used to supply CO2 for microalgal cultivation which are aimed at saving energy Kazemi et al. 2023 . The direct injection of flue gas into the culture medium without prior enrichment or pressurization with substantial gas compression impacts efficiency with lower energy requirements. This method reduces the utilization of gasoline or fuels for trans portation and eventually the environmental impacts and costs associated with gas purification and transportation. This method involves drying the biomass to a moisture content ranging from 50 to 98 of the dry mass before co-burning S. Li et al. 2023 . The environmental impact of this approach depends on whether the heat required for biomass drying is derived from flue gas recovery Braud et al. 2023 . A comparative LCA study using two cultivation methods showed that net energy gain and CO2 sequestration efficiency were higher for the photobioreactor cultivation 3.12 MJ MJ as compared to the open pond 2.26 MJ MJ Pankratz et al. 2020 . The total energy input for cultivation is about 2476 MJ m2 y less than the energy requirement for ethanol production from corn 3335 MJ m2 y Mat Aron et al. 2020 . Besides studies have revealed lower land require ments for microalgal culturing compared to other biofuel crops due to their high productivity. In this context the researchers Morales et al. 2019 reviewed renewable sources of electricity like wind and solar which can be a considerable source of reduction in environmental impacts. The study indicates the fact that net energy gain from biofuel production is more likely than that in the case of renewable electricity use. It can help diminish GHGs and fossil fuel depletion by 70 Shelare et al. 2023 . Different microalgal strains have altered features such as growth rate nutrient requirements lipid content among others. This means that the comprehensive bioenergy and CO2 analysis of the biofuels is different. In a study six strains were analyzed and LCA was done. The net energy gain was observed to be 0.24 3.72 MJ MJ while CO2 cap ture efficiency was 0.11 0.23 kg CO2 kg biodiesel performing better than fossil fuels Collotta et al. 2017 . The researchers Xue et al. 2021 scrutinized LCA using Chlorella sp. Scenedesmus sp. and Nannochloropsis sp. They found that the energy consumption and environmental impacts of cultivation and conversion were higher for Nannochloropsis sp. than for Chlorella sp. and 1262 M. A. RASHAD ET AL. Scenedesmus sp. However the CO2 capture efficiency was higher for Chlorella sp. than for Nannochloropsis sp and Scenedesmus sp. 7. Techno-economic analysis TEA The techno-economic assessment of microalgae-based biofuels is of utmost importance since it measures the economic value of various methods of biomass growing harvesting and converting into fuel. The researchers Hoang et al. 2023 argue that significant capital and operational expenses pose major boundaries toward the TEA of microalgae biofuels. As shown in Table 3 various researchers have demonstrated that microalgae cultivation comes with a heavy infra structural cost. The energetic region of cultivating water-harvesting and processing of microalgae and biochar adds up to the total productive cost thus creates an economic challenge. In turn bioeconomic viability is largely reliant on how inexpensive these practices are and how profitable enhanced co-products like protein and biochar fertilizer from microalgal biomass are Venkata Subhash et al. 2022 . More recently biochar derived from microorganisms has been demonstrated to serve as an organic soil amendment synergistically with other biofertilizers and as food sup plementation. Further it contributes to economic benefits while making investments through the use of microalgae-based biofuel economically feasible Arora et al. 2021 Llamas et al. 2021 . Several TEA approaches have been proposed including deterministic models sensitivity analyses and Monte Carlo simulations Batan et al. 2016 Das Kumar 2022 Van Schoubroeck et al. 2021 . The researchers Lim et al. 2022 suggested that deterministic models help evaluate the cost-effectiveness of different biofuels as alternatives to conventional fossil fuels and their production. At the same time Monte Carlo simulations were reported to be more appropriate for assessing the overall economic risk associated with large-scale commercialization Bhatt et al. 2022 Gutiérrez Ortiz 2020 . One of the critical prospects for improving economic feasibility is the development of biorefineries for large-scale production. Several innovative approaches have been proposed including using wastewater as a nutrient source using photobioreactors for high-density cultivation and using flocculants for low-cost harvesting. In addition the availability of substructures such as storage facilities and transportation networks and economic factors such as the price of feedstock and energy inputs affect the economics of biofuel production. The researchers Roles et al. 2021 used commercial and pilot plant data to study biofuel production s economic provisions. A distinct model was used to calculate productivity and an alternative model was used to calculate the energy efficiency of the three selected facilities from 1 to 4 with a maximum potential of 9 . The coefficient of direct energy consumption was 0.06 whereas that of indirect energy consumption was 0.74. In their study the supply of CO2 harvest pump energy nitrogen supply costs total capital costs and overheads were calculated which affected the energy consumption and ultimately increased the cost of the end product. However potential improvements to reduce energy consumption costs are vital increased annual productivity direct flue gas use wastewater use reduced equip ment size installation costs and reduced labor and management costs. Researchers pointed out that biofuels from microalgae face economic hurdles and the pro duction process becomes less economically viable yet combining valuable bioproduct outputs makes the production system financially viable Stephy et al. 2025 . The production of biofuels biohydrogen and various high-value products from microalgae supports the development of a circular bioeconomy system. Scientists are applying synthetic biology advancements to upgrade microalgae strains with improvements in the cultivation processes increasing revenue streams to fulfill the market potential beyond economic hurdles Novia et al. 2025 . According to the latest study the U.S. could maximize microalgae biomass production to 152 million tons annually while effectively using 268 million tons of CO2 per year for biofuel production at scale. The combination of biofuels with high-value compound extraction through a biorefinery method clutches for increasing microalgae-based biofuels economic sustainability Kashif et al. 2025 . Several TEA studies have been conducted to compare the feasibility of biofuels derived from microalgae with those derived from other biomass and conventional fuels Fu et al. 2023 Kargbo et al. 2021 Ranjbari et al. 2022 . A U.S. National Renewable Energy Laboratory report estimated the average price of algal biodiesel to be 2.11 L significantly higher than that of soybean biodiesel and corn bioethanol Nagarajan et al. 2013 . However promoting renewable energy and achieving carbon reduction goals can positively affect the viability of these ventures. Furthermore biodiesel production rates would be more competitive than petroleum diesel if renewable energy could be used in parallel with solar power for harvesting and lipid extraction Severo et al. 2019 . The cost-effectiveness of studying the potential of 288 microalgal farms in producing biodiesel and bioethanol within the European Union was examined. The results indi cated that biofuels have the lowest nonpublic value for road transport in Europe and given that CO2 sequestration in growing algae is a significant burden the risks of equity issues were raised at a high price Moreira et al. 2021 . 8. Conclusions and future implications After a thorough analysis of microalgae as a low-carbon feedstock for carbon sequestration and biofuel production it was evident that it has the potential to aid in reaching a zero-carbon solution while also supporting a sustainable and renewable bio-circular economy. Nonetheless efficient cultivation and processing techniques must be developed to make microalgae-based biofuels profitable. Microalgae are classified as a high potential source for GHG mitigation because of their high lipid content high growth rate and carbon capture utilization and storage abilities. The financial viability of industrial production of biofuels is determined by the capital costs production costs and the biofuels market. The microalgae biofuel environmental sustain ability should also address the impacts of the cultivation and processing methods employed. The adoption of a bio-circular economy model where the waste from microalgae-based fuel production and carbon capture processes is used for other industrial processes can mitigate environmental impacts and create new revenue streams. Furthermore the necessity to reduce carbon emissions and mitigate climate change should not be ignored. More benign and ecolog ically sound solutions are possible due to advanced technologies that involve the use of microalgae as carbon sinks during biofuel production. However further developments and improvements are necessary to make these options low-cost and long-term. High-yield cultivation techniques genetic engineering strain development bioreactor design isolation technologies and metabolic engineering are significant advancements that require further focus. Further research and devel opment in this area can pave the way for a sustainable zero-carbon future and reduce the impact of climate change on the economy environment and current and future energy systems. B978-0-12-817536-1.00002-3', 'A review on sustainable microalgae based biofuel and bioenergy production Recent developments Abdul Raheem a b 1 Pepijn Prinsen c 1 Arun K. Vuppaladadiyam a b 1 Ming Zhao a b Rafael Luque c a School of Environment Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China b Key Laboratory for Solid Waste Management and Environment Safely Ministry of Education Beijing 100084 China c Departamento de Química Org anica Universidad de C ordoba Campus de Rabanales Ediﬁcio Marie Curie C-3 Ctra Nnal IV-A Km 396 C ordoba Spain a r t i c l e i n f o Article history Available online 18 January 2018 Keywords Microalgae Biofuels Bioenergy Biosequestration Metabolic engineering a b s t r a c t Climate changes induced by anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions mainly carbon dioxide is one of the major threats of the modern era. Primary causes are the high reliance on fossil fuels for power generation transportation manufacturing and the intensive land usage deforestation . The current share of renewable biofuel production in the overall fuel demand has been found insufﬁcient to replace fossil fuels. Microalgae can deliver a sustainable and complementary biofuel platform with some important advantages. This review aims to offer a state-of-the art review of algal biomass conversion methods into various biofuel products including biodiesel syngas biogas bioethanol. Emerging more sustainable biofuel bioenergy production technologies are highlighted. Attention is also paid to sus- tainable cultivation methods including wastewater treatment and bioremediation to capture CO2 and ﬁx nitrogen and phosphorus produced from industrial agricultural and municipal sources. Finally a light is shed on the important role of algae metabolic engineering. 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. 1. Introduction The interference of anthropogenic activities in biogeochemical cycles and the extensive use of fossil fuels are the primary cause of the imminent global climate change. This scenario is expected to further deteriorate in the coming years since the human popula- tion is expected to increase up to 9 billion by 2050 Godfray et al. 2010 . Goli et al. 2016 recently reported that around 87 of the global CO2 emitted by anthropogenic activities result from the us- age of fossil resources with coal oil and natural gas contributing 43 36 and 20 respectively. It has therefore become crucial to reduce the carbon emission by using sustainable energy resources on a global scale but integrated at local scale. Over the last decade biomass has drawn increasing attention in our society as a source of bioenergy and bioproducts. Various biomass sources including ﬁrst second third and fourth generation feedstocks such as edible and non-edible energy crops wood agricultural residues and algae have been exploited so far for the development of bioenergy pro- duction methods. 1.1. Microalgae vs. plants Microalgae derived biomass exhibits some important advan- tages over plant derived biomass Naik et al. 2010 Lam and Lee 2012 Rawat et al. 2013 . Most importantly microalgae do not depend on fertile land availability and in many cases they can be grown in wastewater or in seawater. Typically the production of 1 kg of microalgae biomass requires 1.83 kg of CO2 Chisti 2007 . Compared to plants microalgae have in general higher photosyn- thetic efﬁciencies. They convert ca. 3e8 of the solar energy during cellular metabolism against 0.5 typically for terrestrial crops. Microalgae can exhibit exceptional fast growth rates and can be produced more continuously as compared to plants. Microalgae derived biomass is typically enriched in lipids ca. 4.5e7.5 ton ha 1 y 1 Tsukahara and Sawayama 2005 compared to soybean 0.4 ton ha 1 y 1 rapeseed 0.7 ton ha 1 y 1 Chisti 2007 and jatropha 4.1 ton ha 1 y 1 Lam and Lee 2011 . Finally they hardly contain the Corresponding author. Corresponding author. School of Environment Tsinghua University Beijing 100084 China. E-mail addresses M. Zhao R. Luque . 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Journal of Cleaner Production journal homepage 0959-6526 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 recalcitrant lignin which facilitates the conversion methods from carbohydrates. In these aspects microalgae bioreﬁnery can clearly contribute to environmental social and economic more sustainable biofuel production systems. 1.2. From ﬁrst to fourth generation biofuels Most of the current biofuels are produced from the grains of edible crops via a wide range of processes which include Brown and Brown 2013 Lee and Wilson 2015 fermentation using yeast strains bioethanol bio catalytic transesteriﬁcation bio- diesel and chemical solid acid base catalysts. Lü et al. 2011 demonstrated how the cultivation of edible crops for ﬁrst genera- tion biofuels can have detrimental effects on food security induce deforestation and show poor energy balances. They also require fresh water fertilizers and a vast area of arable land area for their cultivation. This can even result in a further increase of net carbon emissions Gonz alez et al. 2015 . Besides the excessive use of pesticides and fertilizers in such open cultivation systems arable land can lead to the accumulation of harmful contaminants into the atmosphere volatile organic compounds ammonia and nitrous oxide and in groundwater non-volatile organic compounds ni- trates and phosphates . Lignocellulosic materials as second gener- ation feedstock can address this fuel vs. food dilemma. Still especially at large scales biofuel production the transport of biomass and the development of cost-effective pretreatment and conversion methods make that today s commercial second gener- ation biofuel production remains limited. The third and fourth generation biofuel production entails algae-to-biofuels technol- ogy whereas the former deals with the conversion process itself from microalgae to biofuels the latter sets the focus on the development of microalgal biotechnology via metabolic engineer- ing of microalgae genomes Lü et al. 2011 Dutta et al. 2014 in which genetic material is altered in a speciﬁc and selective manner to co-opt photoautotrophic algal strains which may lead to the maximization of the biofuel yield and or minimization of the associated process costs. Currently various studies demonstrated promising results related to increased carbon capture capacity biomass production and lipid accumulation after successful incor- poration of the adapted genomes in microalgae cells Dutta et al. 2014 Levitan et al. 2014 Beacham et al. 2017 Shumbulo and Ki 2018 . The role of algae based biotechnology may become very important for biofuel production and to make the overall conver- sion more cost-effective and sustainable. In addition recently solid waste particularly municipal solid waste MSW often containing solid materials such as plastics paper food scraps textiles card- boad and wood materials has been considered by Boesch et al. 2014 and Arena et al. 2015 as a potential source for sustain- able energy production and recovery of valuable resources. The main advantage of using MSW is their wide and abundant avail- ability throughout the year and they are very low cost Aracil et al. 2017 . 1.3. Microalgae bioreﬁnery Analog to lignocellulose microalgae based bioreﬁnery aims to develop sustainable production technologies of bioenergy and bioproducts including chemicals fuels and even food or animal feed and is actually Gonz alez et al. 2015 a very attractive research ﬁeld Fig. 1 . Microalgae are rich in lipids carbohydrates and proteins primary metabolites but also can contain consid- erable amounts of secondary metabolites and minerals. That is why actually different bioreﬁnery schemes are considered Rizwan et al. 2015 depending on the target product. Ruiz et al. 2016 recently demonstrated how important to is to distinguish production sys- tems at high scale bio-energy and biofuels and at low scale high added-value products HVPs . Techno-economic assessment studies have shown better projections for the near future for the production of high-value products in optimized conditions pro- teins and secondary metabolite production as compared to large scale biofuel production scenarios lipids in optimal growth con- ditions. An important technical constraint is the fact that up-scaling of microalgae cultivation methods often occurs in modular units which means that the cost reduction is rather low economy of scale effect . Data on production costs on larger scale are rather limited and the uncertainty on the projections is high as demon- strated already some time ago by Sun et al. 2011 and addressed again more recently by Laurens et al. 2017 . Further decreasing the algae biomass production costs cultivation is one of the chal- lenges for the near future. Biomass production efﬁciencies highly depend on algae strain CO2 supply light regime and nutrient feeding Vanthoor-Koopmans et al. 2013 Aravantinou and Manariotis 2016 . Further studies in this research ﬁeld similar to Doucha et al. 2005 Langley et al. 2012 and Wilson et al. 2014 are highly desirable to locate the optimal distance from the ﬂue gas point source to maximize the carbon capture capacity and the biomass production yield while sustaining the stability of the algal culture in function of the pollutant nutrient concentrations tem- perature pH and light intensity proﬁles and minimizing the transport puriﬁcation and storage costs of the ﬂue gases. Recently many efforts are reported to use municipal agricultural and in- dustrial wastewater sources to recover valuable nutrients from these streams especially phosphor and nitrogen nutrients for the production of fourth generation algal biofuels Cho et al. 2011 Kesaano and Sims 2014 Komolafe et al. 2014 Chen et al. 2015a Quiroz Arena et al. 2015 Luo et al. 2017 . Next to algae cultiva- tion itself harvesting the biomass produced in suspension is also part of the bottleneck as it contributes considerably in the overall biomass production cost Naghdi et al. 2016 . The harvesting and dewatering of microalgae biomass reaches up to 50 of the total biomass production cost Mata et al. 2010 Sahoo et al. 2017 . The key methods currently used in the harvesting of microalgae include ﬂocculation centrifugation ﬁltration gravity sedimentation elec- trophoresis ﬂotation and combinations of these. So far Vandamme et al. 2013 proposed aggregation through ﬂocculation and coag- ulation as the most cost-effective microalgae harvesting alterna- tive. Centrifugation should be considered as a ﬁnal stage dewatering step as centrifugation technologies face large initial capital investments and considerable operational costs Dassey and Theegala 2013 . Aggregation through the production of microbial Fig. 1. Microalgae bioreﬁnery concept for bio-energy and biofuel production. A. Raheem et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 43 pellets in cultivar consortia with fungi and bacteria bio- ﬂocculation is another route considered to enable efﬁcient sepa- ration of microalgae cells Zhou et al. 2012 Muradov et al. 2015 . Moreover the development of such microbial consortia can enable higher biofuel production yields through metabolic symbiosis be- tween respiring bacteria fungi yeasts and photosynthesizing microalgae and also important could open the pathway to the use of lignocellulosic feedstocks which are not available for pure algal cultures Gomez et al. 2016 . Despite these important advances natural harvesting methods such as simple gravity ﬁltration and solar drying should be further optimized on larger scales to make microalgae harvesting and drying more environmentally friendly and more cost-effective. Other important contributors in the cost breakdown analysis are pretreatments required to improve sub- sequent extraction steps . Conventional pretreatments such as milling pressing sonication homogenizers mechanical and os- motic shock or cell lysis with acid base chemical can result in high costs especially when multiple steps are required Rizwan et al. 2015 Ruiz et al. 2016 . Also important in bio-reﬁnery schemes are the development of valorization methods for co-products. The applications of mild separation methods which do not imply high pressure and solvents are signiﬁcant for the production of the desired compounds without damaging other fractions Vanthoor- Koopmans et al. 2013 . 2. Research methodology This review aims to resume the up-to-date progress on micro- algae conversion methods and recent developments in the ﬁeld of fourth generation biofuel production systems. In the ﬁrst stage of the research insight was attained in all aspects of microalgae bio- reﬁnery based on reviews from the past and on recent works which report signiﬁcant progress in different areas. This in-depth study of the literature available on microalgae has showed us very clearly on a cost breakdown analysis basis that improvements are needed in nearly all bioreﬁnery areas including cultivation harvesting extraction and conversion methods. Nevertheless it was also concluded that new emerging strategies are currently being considered to overcome some limitations and to provide more sustainable production systems. These ﬁndings are the guideline of this review. The ﬁrst part describes thermochemical and biochemical conversion technologies for the production of bio- energy and biofuels. The second part describes emerging biofuels and technologies. Special attention is also paid to wastewater treatment and bioremediation to capture CO2 phosphorus P and nitrogen N from industrial agricultural and municipal sources. Finally the importance of microalgae biotechnology for the development of microalgae bioreﬁnery is highlighted. 3. Microalgae biofuel production Microalgae derived biomass can be converted into biofuels via four pathways thermochemical conversion Raheem et al. 2015 biochemical conversion transesteriﬁcation and photosynthetic microbial fuel cell processes Naik et al. 2010 . Thermo-chemical conversion technologies utilize heat and catalysts to convert algal biomass into intermediate products which are further converted into biofuels via chemical and biological routes. Biochemical con- version technologies involve the utilization of micro-organisms or enzymes for the hydrolysis of pretreated biomass to obtain fermentable sugars. Biochemical processing of biomass to biofuels is often more selective and greener but is associated with higher production costs as compared to thermochemical processing Brennan and Owende 2010 . The development of a suitable con- version approach is one of the key challenges for the economic viability and the sustainability of biofuel production. 3.1. Thermo-chemical conversion Thermo-chemical conversion involves a combination of thermal breakdown and chemical reformation of the organic constitutes into biofuels via gasiﬁcation pyrolysis hydrothermal liquefaction and combustion. Table 1 resumes the operating conditions of thermo-chemical conversion methods. Next to a conversion method for whole algae feedstocks thermo-chemical technologies also hold an important valorization way for co-products in biofuel production systems. One example is the valorization of defatted residue remaining after conversion to biodiesel via trans- esteriﬁcation Mutanda et al. 2011 . This residual algae biomass is mainly comprised of proteins carbohydrates and unutilized lipids which can be utilized to produce gaseous and liquid biofuels and biochar depending on the experimental conditions used Pradhan et al. 2017 . 3.1.1. Pyrolysis The pyrolysis of algae biomass is usually done at elevated tem- peratures ranging from 300 to 700 C but may accomplished at lower temperatures when a catalyst is present. To isolate the oils the generated vapours need to condensed by cooling leaving behind a solid residue char . The amounts of gas oil and char isolated from algae biomass can vary considerably Table 2 . Recent studies pointed out that algae based pyrolysis oils may have slightly lower caloric values but higher stability than lignocellulose derived oils Babich et al. 2011 Campanella et al. 2012 Chaiwong et al. 2013 Chiaramonti et al. 2017 Du et al. 2011 Wang et al. 2013a . But it still contains chemically dissolved water solids and substantial amounts of nitrogen containing compounds which requires catalytic upgrading via cracking and hydrogenation to remove them. The heating rate is an important parameter during pyrolysis. Common methods include slow pyrolysis 0.1e1 C s 1 fast pyrolysis 10e200 C s 1 and ﬂash pyrolysis 1000 C s 1 . Slow pyrolysis is easier to carry out but in general lower oil yields with some exceptions are obtained and with different composi- tions Campanella et al. 2012 Chaiwong et al. 2013 Wang et al. 2013a . Important amounts of long carbon chain compounds with an oxygen content ca. 30 wt were found in the bio-oil with a Table 1 Operational conditions of thermo-chemical conversion methods Brennan and Owende 2010 Naik et al. 2010 Raheem et al. 2015 . Raheem et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 44 Higher Heating Value HHV ca. 19e25 MJ kg 1 Campanella et al. 2012 Chaiwong et al. 2013 Pan et al. 2010 Wang et al. 2013a similar to lignocellulose derived slow pyrolysis oils Nanda et al. 2014 . The gaseous product consists mostly of CH4 and CO2 Vardon et al. 2012 . Heat exchangers can be used to recover en- ergy from the gaseous product to dry the algae feedstock or for heating the pyrolysis chamber which both demand a considerable energy input. Fast pyrolysis can reduce the amount of biochar Dickerson and Soria 2013 . Important differences were found between algae biomass from phototrophic and heterotrophic C. prothothecoides cultures. While in the former a bio-oil with 12 MJ kg 1 HHV was isolated a 3.4 times higher HHV value was measured for the heterotrophically grown algae derived bio-oil Miao and Wu 2004 . Demirbas also used C. prothothecoides biomass and found the bio-oil yield to increase with temperature 6e55 from 255 to 500 C with HHV 40 MJ kg 1 Demirbas 2006 . Flash pyrolysis drastically increases the amount of liquid product even exceeding 90 . 3.1.2. Gasiﬁcation Gasiﬁcation is a versatile chemical technology that accepts a wide range of carbon feedstocks. The process involves partial oxidation with controlled amounts of air oxygen or steam at 700e1000 C producing a mixture of gases known as syngas mainly composed of H2 CO CO2 and CH4 . Syngas has a low caloriﬁc value of 4e6 MJ m 3 and is mainly suitable as a fuel for heating gas engines and turbines electricity generation . It can also be rearranged to produce hydrogen via water-gas-shift WGS reaction and liquid hydrocarbon fuels via Fischer-Tropsch synthesis such as methanol gasoline and diesel fuels Sanchez-Silva et al. 2013 Sutton et al. 2001 . The WGS reaction can be optimized to produce H2 enriched syngas by employing sorption enhanced reforming Naik et al. 2010 Raheem et al. 2017 . Hirano et al. 1998 gasiﬁed Spirulina at 850e1000 C and obtained up to 0.64 g methanol g 1 biomass. The overall energy balance was ca. 1 1 ratio of methanol energy produced to the total required en- ergy . When using steam for the gasiﬁcation of Nannochlorophsis gaditana the product got enriched in H2 CO and CO2 and depleted in CH4 as the WGS process shifted and methane reforming became prominent Sanchez-Silva et al. 2013 . Microalgae biomass can also be co-feeded with coal for gasiﬁ- cation Kucukvar and Tatari 2011 Qadi et al. 2017 . However microalgae with high ash content are not recommended to avoid accumulation. Yang et al. 2013 compared the co-gasiﬁcation of Spirulina platensis pellets with wood pellets using a bubbling ﬂu- idized bed reactor. Closer to 1 1 feed ratios the product became enriched in CO2 and CO. The ash content in microalgae pellets were found to be higher as compared to woody biomass pellets which may cause sintering in the gasiﬁcation Asadullah 2014 . In some cases ash can contain catalytic active particles. L opez-Gonz alez et al. 2014 studied the steam gasiﬁcation of Scenedesmus almer- iensis Nannochloropsis gaditana and Chlorella vulgaris at analytical scale TGA-MS . The main products from the gasiﬁcation were CO2 H2 CO and smaller amounts of CH4 C2H2 and C2H5. Scenedesmus almeriensis showed the highest gasiﬁcation yields attributed to its higher content of catalytic elements such as K and Mg. The gas mixture was entriched in H2 favored by the WGS reaction and steam reforming. In the presence of Ru TiO2 catalyst C. vulgaris was completely gasiﬁed at 700 C Chakinala et al. 2009 . The gas mixture was enriched in H2 ca. 10 mol per kg algae at a gasiﬁcation efﬁciency of 85 . Nickel based catalysts dolomite and potassium carbonate are other examples of catalyst assisted gasiﬁcation Patil et al. 2008 . Finally air is by far the cheapest gasifying agent but it causes increased tar formation. Khoo et al. 2013 gasiﬁed Nanno- chloropsis sp. in a ﬁxed bed gasiﬁer at 850 C and obtained 59 wt char tar 28 wt syngas and 14 wt bio-oil. By increasing the ﬂow rate char tar formation can be surpressed to some extent. An overview of results obtained from co- gasiﬁcation of algae is shown in Table 3. 3.1.3. Hydrothermal liquefaction HTL After the cultivation the obtained microalgae slurries are designated for harvesting. These slurries have high moisture con- tent ca. 70e80 which is one of the key obstacles in algae based processing related to the high energy input for pumping dew- atering e.g. centrifugation and drying of the biomass Chen et al. 2015b . As hydrothermal liquefaction HTL occurs in water extensive dewatering processes are avoided Chiaramonti et al. 2017 . This advantage has led to a tremendous expansion in HTL research for the last 5 years Elliott 2016 Saber et al. 2016 . Table 2 Oil gas and char yields from pyrolysis of different algae species. The product distributions range typically between 10 and 73 8e20 and 0.2e0.5 wt of biocrude gas and char Brand et al. 2014 Ross et al. 2010 Shuping et al. 2010 . During liquefaction some compounds are extracted from the biomass others are depolymerized to oligomers and monomers followed by further decomposition through cleavage dehydration decarboxylation and deamination to produce small unstable fragments which rearrange by condensation and cyclization to form new com- pounds. Carbohydrates can rearrange to aromatics and proteins to piperidine pyrrole and amide compounds while TAG are mostly hydrolysed to fatty acids Raza 2014 . Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 46 diesel and has similar characteristics such as HHV cetane number ﬂash point and kinematic viscosity Azadi et al. 2014 Singh and Olsen 2011 . The standards used for biodiesel quality are ASTM D6751 American and EN 14 214 European . FAME can be pro- duced from oleo rich crop derived oils with yields ranging between 5 and 100 m3 oil ha 1 year 1. They can also be produced from FA rich waste streams e.g. cooking oils. High oil yields can also be isolated from microalgae with minimum land usage as illustrated in Table 5. At ﬁrst sight the high lipid content in microalgae makes them a potentially appealing source for biodiesel production. However high microalgal biomass production cost e.g. depending on the type of photobioreactor scalabality limited growth rates and the need of applying environmental stress to enhance lipid production are the key bottlenecks for industrial scale biodiesel production from algae Lü et al. 2011 . The stress control is typically established by monitoring the growth parameter conditions such as temperature pH phoshate and nitrogen contents etc. to regu- late microalgal cells from growth regime to stress regime to induce high lipid secretion for their adaption to the varying environment Savage et al. 2008 . Two main microalgae cultivation systems exist open ponds OPs and photo-bioreactors PBRs . PBRs inherently offer better control and highter productivity compared to OPs. Nevertheless PBRs incur higher cost in terms of installation operation and maintenance compared to OPs. Albeit OPs are cost- effective easier to construct and to operate they have to deal with poor light utilization evaporative losses and susceptibility to microbial contamination. Advances in microalgal cultivation sys- tems may not only improve the quality composition and produc- tivity of the algal biomass upstream but also may have profound effects on downsteam process technology and its associated costs . A recent technoeconomic study has shown that bringing down the biodiesel production costs to a level that would facilitate commercialization is exceptionally challenging Ruiz et al. 2016 . Future research and development will not only persuade im- provements in down-stream processing but also upstream wards e.g. through enhancing biodiesel production yield via recombinant DNA technology . Some algae species contain signiﬁcant amounts of TAG varying between 25 and 77 on dry cell weight which is remarkably higher than that of oleo enriched terrestrial crops Chisti 2007 . The TAG feedstocks with chain length of C15-C22 and low unsaturation level are most suitable for biodiesel production. The FA composition of many microalgae species exhibit this chain length however the extent of unsaturation can be an obstacle in certain species as it can negatively affect oxidative stability heat of combustion and cetane number Williams and Laurens 2010 .
