Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 47 transesteriﬁcation in supercritical methanol Patil et al. 2011 Wahlen et al. 2011 while in conventional homogenous biodiesel production polar lipids can affect the processing and quality of the biodiesel Liu et al. 2011 . Biodiesel production with acid or base catalysts in homogeneous phase employs a two-step method oil extraction using solvents followed by transesteriﬁcation resulting in high water consumption and energy input. Table 6 shows the process conditions catalyst and yields obtained from biodiesel production in homogeneous phase from various algae species via transesteriﬁcation. Acid-catalyzed transesteriﬁcations are less sensitive to the presence of water and free FA and therefore mitigate saponiﬁcation and emulsiﬁcation risks enhancing the product recovery Xu and Mi 2011 . Though acid catalysts have these advantages they are currently not preferred due to their lower activity compared to alkaline catalysts. Higher temperatures and longer reaction times are therefore generally required. Nevertheless acid catalysts are more applicable to the transesteriﬁcation of different lipid feed- stocks. For this reason heterogeneous acid catalyts are currently being developed. Sulfated and non-sulfated zirconia as Lewis acids and sulfonic groups as Br onsted acid groups are among the most active catalyst centers for both TAG hydrolysis and FA esteriﬁcation Lee and Wilson 2015 Luque and Clark 2011 . Heteropolyacids such as H3PW12O40 also have shown promising results as solid acids while Mg-Al hydrotalcites and doped transition metal oxides as solid bases. Recently the focus is set on the development of porous hierachical ordered catalysts due to the bulky and viscous character of the substrates for operation at lower temperatures. Progress in the use of plug-ﬂow reactors using heterogeneous catalysts have shown recently their advantage compared to conventional ﬁxed bed column reactors especially in the use of multiple feedstocks for the production of biodiesel Dimian and Rothenberg 2016 . In situ transesteriﬁcation in contrast is a single-step concept which avoids the costly dewatering drying or oil extraction steps from living algal cells. The supercritical extraction process of lipids can be coupled with a transesteriﬁcation reaction to enable a one-pot approach. Supercritical methanol or ethanol is employed as both the oil-extraction medium and the transesteriﬁcation reagent Vieitez et al. 2008 . In the case of catalyst-free supercritical ethanol positive effects from water were observed up to 10 wt which is encouraring as water plays an important role in the saponiﬁcation process lowering the yield. Finally the use of bio- catalysts such as lipase for the transesteriﬁcation of TAG offers an environmentally more attractive option to the conventional pro- cesses reduces the energy-input and facilitats the removal of glycerol Cantrell et al. 2008 . Recently many researchers have explored the potential of lipase biocatalysts for producing diesel fuel via transerteriﬁcation Antczak et al. 2009 Guldhe et al. 2016 . The application of lipases as biocatalyst for trans- esteriﬁcation eliminates the need for separation recovery of by- products including glycerol soaps and diacylglyceroals which are the main by-products when chemical catalysts are used for industrial biodiesel production but also algae derived lipophilic compounds including pigments Antczak et al. 2009 . Lipases are capable of catalyzing both esteriﬁcation of free fatty acids and transesteriﬁcaiton of TAG. Together these features make lipase biocatalsyts a promising alternative to conventional chemical ones Antczak et al. 2009 Khan et al. 2009 . The design of a suitable co- solvent system and low operational temperature are essential to prolonge their activity Su and Wei 2014 . 3.3. Fermentation 3.3.1. Biogas Biogas is mainly composed of CH4 and CO2 with traces of other gases such as H2S. Organic feedstocks and waste streams with high moisture content 80e90 are suitable for anaerobic digestion AD Demirbas 2010 . This is a very important advantage as drying of algae slurries is very energy intensive. The conversion to methane occurs via hydrolysis to soluble sugars followed by fermentation to alcohols volatile fatty acids acetic acid and gaseous products. These are then converted by a complex microbial ecologic system methanogenesis to H2 and CO2 which in turn are partially metabolized to CH4 65e75 and CO2 25e35 Ward et al. 2014 . The biogas yield and quality composition depend on the feedstock composition temperature pH solid and hydraulic retention time and feeding rate. An overview of biogas yields from various microalgae is available in Table 7. The C N ratio plays a crucial role for an effective and stable AD process. The optimal C N ratio for biogas production ranges between 20 1 and 30 1 whereas the lower C N ratio causes nutritional imbalance and lower biogas production Hidaka et al. 2014 . Too low C N ratio can be by-passed via co-digestion of algae biomass with a nitrogen poor organic substrate such as paper waste and sewage sludge. Yen and Brune 2007 found the CH4 production rate to be doubled from 0.6 to 1.2 mL L 1 day 1 when algae biomass was co-digested with paper waste as compared to the pure algae biomass feedstock. Likewise Costa et al. 2012 reported a 26 CH4 production rate increase by co-digesting Ulva sp. with manure and sewage sludge. The micro- algae cell wall is a complex structure and is typically composed of cellulose hemicelluloses and pectin which limits the accessibility to bacteria. Pretreatment to deconstruct the microalgae cell wall structure could speed up the digestibility and in principle also the bacterial methanogenesis activity. Raheem et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 48 biomass for biogas production via microwave pretreatement. The maximum yield of 307 mL biogas g 1 VS was achieved at optimal microwave conditions compared to 172 mL biogas g 1 VS without any pretreatment Passos et al. 2013 . In addition microalgae cultivation designated for the production and isolation of proteins or peptides goes in hand with AD of the residue obtained after protein extraction as the latter presents a more optimal C N ratio Bravo-Fritz et al. 2016 . AD of algae biomass residues to energy and bio-fertilizers is an important option to be considered as the energy-input is much lower compared to other conversion methods Naik et al. 2010 . Recently Criddle et al. demonstrated the conversion of methane to poly hydroxybutyrate blends as a way to increase the biogas value Myung et al. 2015 . Further research on carbon rich substrates for co-digestion and on effective pretreatments is indispensable to make the AD process more valuable and cost-effective. 3.3.2. Bioethanol While in the last 10 years the focus was set on the lipid fraction for biofuel production more recently research is being conducted for the conversion of microalgae carbohydrates e.g. to ethanol Fig. 3 Laurens et al. 2015 . Bioethanol production from algae biomass typically occurs over 3 stages 1 recovery of fermentable starch stored in the algae cells which requieres the deconstruction of the cell walls 2 starch hydrolysis using a-amylases and 3 fermentation of released sugars to ethanol using yeast strains. In the ﬁnal stage ethanol separation and puriﬁcation is done usually by distillation-rectiﬁcation-dehydration of the diluted alcohol product 10e15 ethanol McKendry 2002 part 2 . The puriﬁed ethanol ca. 95 is then extracted and condensed. As the feedstock cost represents ca. 55e80 of the ﬁnal alcohol market price it is important to valorize the biomass residue e.g. by gasiﬁcation to syngas Lam and Lee 2011 Petrou and Pappis 2009 . Microalgae contain a wide range of polysaccharides Chen et al. 2013 Markou et al. 2012 . Still it remains not completely under- stood which of them can be fermented to ethanol. Micro-organisms capable of fermenting laminarin and mannitol have been identiﬁed and partially characterized by Horn et al. 2000a b . Alginate brown algae is less suitable for ethanol fermentation because the redox balance favors formation of pyruvate and biogas as the end product Bird and Benson 1987 . This was the case for Laminaria hyperborea and Ascophyllum nodosum which are commercial spe- cies cultivated in Norway. Although the digestion of these algae occurred in very smooth conditions as the cell walls of these species do not contain lignin and cellulose polyphenols did hamper the yields signiﬁcantly. Algal biomass extracted in supercritical me- dium can be used as a substrate for ethanol production as demonstrated by Harun et al. 2010 . Bioethanol titers and yields have been reported between 3.6 and 11.7 g L 1 and 197e260 mg ethanol g 1 dry cell. In 2013 Aikawa et al. 2013 achieved 6.5 g L 1 and 350 mg g 1 using glycogen containing cyanobacteria. This corresponded with 1.1 L bioethanol L 1 medium day 1 and a theoretical bioethanol yield of 86 . Several algae such as red and green algae contain both starch and cellulose which can be exploited together for ethanol production after succesful hydrolysis John et al. 2011 . Kim 2009 fermented red algae Gelidium amansii for bioethanol production on commercial scale with sul- phuric acid and obtained 89 theoretical bioethanol yield after 72 h. Fig. 3. Production of carbohydrate derived bioethanol via fermentation. A. Raheem et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 49 3.3.3. Photobiological hydrogen production Hydrogen H2 is a substantial energy carrier and has minimal environmental impacts Hosseini and Wahid 2016 . In recent years photobiological H2 production from algae biomass has become a novel research ﬁeld. Note that dark H2 production is classiﬁed as a fermentation. H2 is a respiration metabolite formed by hydroge- nases Fan et al. 2016 Hosseini and Wahid 2016 . Several micro- algae species can modulate their genetic enzymatic and metabolic expression to produce H2 Ghirardi et al. 2000 . In photosynthet- ically grown microalgae water molecules are converted to oxygen O2 protons Hþ and electrons e by means of solar energy Fig. 4a and recombines the derived Hþ and e into chemical en- ergy by assimilating them in metabolic systems such as hydroge- nase Fig. 4b or nitrogenase enzymes to produce H2 Fitch and Kemker 2014 Trchounian 2015 . H2 production from water via solar energy proposes the maximum theroretical photon conver- sion effeciency. However attaining high efﬁciency in converting the electrons in water to electrons in H2 is practically challenging due to the high O2 sensitivity of the hydrogenase system. Co-production of O2 is considered as a limiting factor as it inhibits the hydrogenase pathway Fan et al. 2016 Su and Wei 2014 Zhang et al. 2012 . A customized cell lines and production system may allow a simulta- neous but separated production of H2 and O2 to overcome the aformentioned drawbacks Melis et al. 2000 . Otherwise micro- algae cultures need to be grown in anaerobic conditions for H2 production Antal et al. 2015 . Scoma et al. 2012 and Volgusheva et al. 2013 have reported the highest bio-H2 production efﬁ- ciencies for microalgae. As shown in Fig. 4a microalgae capture solar energy via light-harvesting complex LHC proteins during the photosynthesis process. Those proteins are categorised as LHCI or LHCII based on their prevalent interaction with either photosystem I PSI or II PSII respectively. The excitation energy transmitted to PSII by LHCII Fig. 4a runs the photosynthetic water splitting re- action which transforms H2O into Hþ e and O2. One way to accelerate the H2 production is to cultivate the microalgae in me- diums deprived from oxygen and or sulfur phosphor or nitrogen Philipps et al. 2012 . This approach gradually decreases the photosynthetic capacity due to inactivation of the photosystem PSII as the respiration is upheld Fig. 4b . It causes the depletion of O2 the expression of hydrogenase genes and ﬁnally the release of H2. Another approach employs carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenylhy- drazone CCCP to drive the equilibrium to H2 production Yang et al. 2014a . But by suppressing the PSII activity of algae the light conversion efﬁciency decreases and subsequently the supply of electrons is cut which in turn limits the hydrogenase catalyzed H2 production. Research on hydrogenases Ghirardi 2015 Zhang et al. 2012 and oxygen tolerance Fan et al. 2016 Flynn et al. 2002 of hydrogen-producing algae species has been published. Recently signiﬁcant progress was demostrated in this ﬁeld Das et al. 2015 . The authors reported a 20 times higher H2 produc- tion from immobilized C. reinhardtii microalgae in continous ﬂow regime as compared to previously reported batch production. This way the microalgae do not need to be replaced for prolonged times with possible applications as artiﬁcal leaf systems in sheet-like devices. 4. Emerging microalgae biofuels and integrated technologies 4.1. Renewable diesel and naphtha Considering the relative high amount of ashes in microalgae and the composition of their lipids FA unsaturation degree and carbon number and presence of other lipids such as sterols as compared to plant vegetable oils the manufacturing of biodiesel results more challenging with respect to the quality standards and the cold ﬂow properties Stansell et al. 2012 . The hydrocarbon analog of bio- diesel is renewable or green diesel Fig. 5 which is a non- oxygenated parafﬁnic fuel produced by hydrotreating of bio- derived fats or oils through reduction of unsaturated bonds and hydrodeoxygenation of carboxyl groups. Algal lipids can also be used to produce blendstocks for jet fuel. Renewable diesel and jet fuel blendstocks do not have oxidative stability related problems as severe as those of biodiesel. Algae lipids can provide straight-chain hydrocarbons which improve the cetane number. Unless they are heavily isomerized branched they also might suffer from cold weather performance problems comparable to those experienced with biodiesel and are more likely to be destined for blending with petroleum fuels. The saturation degree of the algal lipids is an important factor for the economics of the hydro treatment and in the transportation stability of intermediates. Triacylglycerol TAG and FA waste feedstocks suit well for conversion to renewable diesel and jet fuel but for naphtha these straight chain alkanes are poor starting materials as they provide relatively low-octane numbers. Addi- tional isomerization steps or blending with high-octane feedstocks are needed in this case. Most of the hydrotreating processes rely on the use of supported metal catalysts under hydrothermal condi- tions. Likewise glycerol co-product from TAG can be converted to propane useful as a feedstock for liqueﬁed petroleum gas. The hydrotreating should minimize additional CO2 CO losses and reduce the supply of H2. Vardon et al. 2014 used the glycerol by- product to generate H2 in situ to reduce external H2 supply. Moreover renewable diesel actually tends to decrease engine-out NOx emissions in modern diesel engines at least from diesel pro- duced from hydrotreated vegetal oil Lehto et al. 2011 . Crude algal oil may contain high levels of phosphorous from phospholipids nitrogen from extracted proteins and metals especially Fig. 4. Photosynthetic production of bio-hydrogen from water in a aerobic and b anaerobic media. Adapted from Oey et al. 2016 . Fig. 5. a Biodiesel b renewable diesel and c renewable naphtha production from triacylglycerides TAG . A. Raheem et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 50 magnesium from chlorophyll . Further research in crude algae oil puriﬁcation together with the development of tolerant hydro- treatment catalysts is therefore imminent. When using algae HTL oil as a feedstock the advantage is that energy intensive drying steps are by-passed as the lipids are not required to be extracted ﬁrst Rogers et al. 2014 . The residual aqueous phase can be gasiﬁed and recycled to the algae nutrient feed. 4.2. Integer biomass valorization Further efforts to maximize the complete biomass utilization are highly desired. For instance industrial scale production of biodiesel from microalgae would generate important amounts of lipid- extracted biomass LEB . LEB can be used as a feedstock for gasiﬁ- cation pyrolysis and biological fermentation as well as a food source for livestock and aquatic life. Ou et al. 2015 described the production of biofuels from defatted algae via thermo-chemical conversion methods showing competitive production costs as the cost of defatted microalgae feedstocks is much lower as compared to whole microalgae feedstocks. Another process strat- egy as demonstrated by Laurens et al. 2015 consists of an acid- catalyzed pretreatment for integrated lipid- and carbohydrate- based biofuel production Fig. 6 . More than 90 of the available glucose was recovered in the hydrolysate liquor from the pre- treatment of Scenedesmuss biomass. Besides obtaining ethanol from this fraction the access to the lipid fraction in subsequent conver- sion of the solid residue becomes signiﬁcantly improved resulting in 97 recovery of the FA present in the biomass. This way 97 gasoline gallon equivalents gge of combined biofuel was pro- duced from a 143 gge theoretical fuel potential. TEA analysis for the combined biofuel production showed that the cost can be reduced with 33 as compared to lipid-based biofuel production only. One of the key challenges in the production of biofuels is the development of suitable valorization methods of the co-products left over after recovery of the lipid and or carbohydrate derived products. This remaining fraction is typically enriched in proteins. Commercial products from algae proteins not mentioning R D still remains poorly described. The main reason for this is the high cost associated for their extraction and puriﬁcation. Vanthoor- Koopmans et al. 2013 proposed an algae bioreﬁnery scheme in which ﬁrst hydrophilic components proteins and carbohydrates are extracted followed by extraction and fractionation of lipids and ﬁnal recovery of insoluble components. Ruiz et al. adopted this scheme to preserve their functionality Ruiz et al. 2016 and esti- mated the costs for cell disruption followed by aqueous two phase extraction with polyethylene glycol and potassium phosphate Cunha and Aires-Barros 2002 followed by membrane ﬁltrations in a cascade process Gerardo et al. 2014 . However these pro- cesses also lead to a high cost 70e80 of the total reﬁnery cost . Another important market of algae derived proteins is animal food Subhadra 2011 . In contrast to plant derived biofuels or bio- products microalgae do not compete for fertile land in the food production chain. Along with vegetable protein sources e.g. soy bean and canola meal they must replace traditional protein sour- ces used in meat production chains Doran 2000 Sekar and Chandramohan 2008 Skjånes et al. 2013 . Considering the un- sustainable expense of water and energy in animal protein pro- duction it is important to mention the current global need to move to plant derived protein production systems. Bacterial production systems are more productive but cannot compete in price Kusnadi et al. 1997 . The current production cost of algae proteins is esti- mated ca. 3 USD kg 1 Costa et al. 2012 Ruiz et al. 2016 which is competitive with plant derived proteins Doran 2000 . Aquacul- ture is the fastest growing food production industry reaching 132 million tons of ﬁsh and shellﬁsh and 43 million tons of seaweed by 2020 Gjedrem et al. 2012 . Algae play an important role in aqua- culture to recover phosphates and as a direct nitrogen source as part of ﬁsh diets or after treatment with yeasts Farrelly et al. 2013 . Algal meal can provide an ideal replacement for ﬁsh meal in animal feeds because algae offer twice the protein of soy on weight-basis and offer a higher micronutrient content and lower level of inor- ganic pollutants such as mercury Doran 2000 . Currently ﬁsh meal and algal meal are produced in similar volumes 5.8 million tons and have similar commercial value 1.2e1.8 USD kg 1 Subhadra 2011 Subhadra and Edwards 2011 . Some secondary metabolites have high added-value in a wide range of industrial medical and nutritional applications. However positive health effects of some algae metabolites are still not completely understood and their market niches and volumes are limited. Still as they have a high commercial value a better valo- rization of residue streams in the production of algae derived bio- fuels is the key to reach proﬁtability in large scale plants Bravo- Fritz et al. 2016 Rizwan et al. 2015 Skjånes et al. 2013 . The problem here is that the production of large amounts of secondary metabolites generally is induced by growth-stress conditions after optimal growth conditions which goes not in hand with micro- algae cultivation for biofuels. Recently Skjånes et al. 2013 reviewed which secondary metabolites can be produced compat- ibly with the production of H2 which is a biofuel that is produced under anaerobic stress conditions especially under sulfur depre- viation and typically in green algae such as Chlamydomonas rein- hardtii. Deprivation from sulfur leads to a degradation of PSII components inhibiting the oxidation of water creating anaerobic conditions while respiration proceeds. When the Calvin cycle is no longer active in CO2 reduction the reductive pressure is released by transferring electrons from ferredoxin to hydrogenase that con- verts this reductive energy to form hydrogen which can easily be released from the cell. 4.3. Integrated technologies CO2 biosequestration and wastewater treatment The rapid rise in population coupled with an increasing urban- ization and industrialization has increased the production of both wastewater and carbon dioxide emissions. To more forward to more sustainable production systems it is important to develop these systems adapted to existing and established industrial sites Fig. 6. Acid pretreatment of algae slurries for the integrated production of bioethanol and renewable diesel. A. Raheem et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 51 such as wastewater treatment plants cement industries and power plants which would largely simplify the supply chain of the algae cultivation resources. As shown in Fig. 7 integrated microalgae cultivation approaches can be implemented in CO2 point-sources CO2 biosequestration and in wastewater treatment sites to recover phosphorus and nitrogen or for bioremediation of con- taminants resulting from industrial agricultural or municipal sources. Today still a large proportion of electric energy generation oc- curs in coal-ﬁred power plants and is unequivocally related to increasing climate change concerns Kucukvar and Tatari 2011 . Various research and development strategies for cost-effective CO2 capture from ﬂue gases are being conducted throughout the globe Bhujade et al. 2017 . Biological CO2 sequestration via algae is a novel concept in CO2 mitigation strategies. Co-locating microalgae production facilities can utilize CO2 from ﬂue gases emitted from various stationary combustion sources such as fossil fuel-ﬁred po- wer stations cement plants ethanol plants etc. Supplemental CO2 feeding to algae cultivars has long been known to increase algal growth rate Langley et al. 2012 . Several studies have testiﬁed that algae cultivations aerated with ﬂue gas supplemented with some intermediate CO2 amounts 4e7 v v tend to increase biomass productivity Anjos et al. 2013 Bhola et al. 2011 Mattos et al. 2012 . A good control of the CO2 ﬂux within the system enables a good pH management which can reduce the risk of microbial contamination and may improve the metabolic ﬂux Selvaratnam et al. 2014 Wang and Curtis 2016 . However transportation of ﬂue gases is costly. Pure CO2 transportation via pipelines is the most cost-effective method for carrying large amounts of CO2 over longer distances Leung et al. 2014 . The level of impurities such as moisture nitrogen oxides NOx sulfur oxides SOx mercury Hg oxygen O2 particulate matter and hydrogen chloride HCl make transportation also more costly by enhancing the total volume required to be pumped to the algae cultivars and due to high corrosion rates Venteris et al. 2014 . The effect of aforementioned impurities on algal biomass growth is not fully understood some investigations have found that SOx and NOx perform as nutrients supplements whilst others have reported them to be toxic at higher concentrations Kao et al. 2014 Zhao and Su 2014 . Considering the low CO2 mass transfer rate in algae suspensions the CO2 feeding should be carefully optimized. Moreover bio- reactors design should be capable of prolonging the CO2 retention time and so the mass transfer efﬁciency especially in open ponds in order to evade the loss of CO2 into atmosphere. Li et al. 2013 proposed a closed raceway pond through a normal open raceway pond with a unique transparent cover touching the algae culture s surface to increase the CO2 utilization rate. The results showed 95 CO2 ﬁxation efﬁciency under intermittent CO2 supply. Important for further improvements is to acquire a better understanding of biological CO2 concentration not only to curb the soaring CO2 emissions from coal-ﬁred power plants but also to propose a wider base of biofuels supplies at large scale. Enriched sources of waste carbon such as from ethanol and ammonia plants have compa- rable cost to purchasing medical-grade CO2. Natural gas-ﬁred po- wer plants can also be considered as a source of CO2 for algae production although the concentration in the output emissions 4e6 is so dilute that the algae facility needs to be practically co- located to avoid excessive gas transport costs. During night time CO2 emissions seem to be unavoidable but methods have been developed to store CO2 so that it can be used by algae during daylight hours. Global Algae Innovations USA suggested that the overall emission utilization could be increased using a CO2 absorber Fishman et al. 2010 . The ﬂue gas from an adjacent power plant is captured for 24 h a day on a 3.3 ha cultivation farm. Excess CO2 is stored and used when the power plant is not operational or when warm and sunny days present. Their system based on 90 utili- zation efﬁciency can capture 80 from ﬂue gas sources with low CO2 concentrations 4e5 and up to 90 from higher- concentration sources coal . More recently Global Algae In- novations has been able to operate their farm without the need for gas distribution and control. Duarte et al. 2017 demonstrated a biological CO2 capture using closed Erlenmeyer ﬂask-type photo- bioreactors at Presidente Medici coal based electric Plant in Brazil via two algae species i.e. chlorella fusca and spirulina sp. . Chlorella fusca was found more efﬁcient by ﬁxing 2.6 times more CO2 compared to Spirulina sp. The optimum CO2 ﬁxation with Chlorella fusca 360 1 mg L 1 day 1 corresponded with a speciﬁc growth rate of 0.17 day 1 from coal fuel gas was achieved. Olia and Quchan 2016 recently conducted a feasibility study of microalgae-based CO2 removal technology in an open pond system at Tous Fer- dowsi Gas Power Plant located in north east of Iran. The technol- ogy was claimed to be more economical compared to conventional carbon capture and storage methods such as pre-combustion during-combustion and post-combustion. National Aluminum Company NALCO successfully demonstrated carbon capture and storage using an open pond algae cultivation system in Captive Thermal Power Plant at Orissa India Styring et al. 2011 . The re- sults showed 70e90 CO2 up take efﬁciency and an algal biomass recovery of 22 tons acre 1 year 1 was achieved. The use of algae to capture CO2 from power plant emissions deﬁnitely deserves further research. 4.4. Microalgae biomass conversion to bioelectricity The microalgae-microbial fuel cell mMFC offers an attractive option to produce bioelectricity and treat the wastewater via a biological pathway allowing algae to handle a range of substrates at various concentrations Lee et al. 2015 . Many studies reported the successful application of microalgal biomass as biocathode in mMFC either in suspended or attached form Del Campo et al. 2013 Liu et al. 2013 Mohan et al. 2014 . Recently research has been conducted on the possibility of zero-carbon electricity pro- duction by using microalgae grown in a cathode chamber as a substrate to the bioﬁlm in the anodic chamber Cui et al. 2014 Kondaveeti et al. 2014 Rashid et al. 2013 . The applicability of mMFC as bioremediation unit of pollutants was recently reported Jiang et al. 2012 Powell et al. 2011a 2011b . Research and ad- vances on design of new materials catalysts and substrates has lowered the overall cost increased the applicability and efﬁciency of mMFCs Baicha et al. 2016 . The application of Chlorella vulgaris Fig. 7. Schematic illustration of microalgae cultivation integrated with thermal power plants for CO2 biosequestration and with wastewater recycling for nutrient recovery and bioremediation. A. Raheem et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 52 as biocathode was tested by Powell et al. 2009 . It was reported that algae acted as an electron acceptor and was able to grow using CO2 generated at the cathode. Proper operating conditions could help to sustain the continuous electron ﬂow and could generate continuous electrical energy. The major advantage of using microalgae in mMFC is that it can be used as an electron donor and simultaneously as donor and acceptor when they are in both anodic and cathodic chambers . Moreover mMFC generates current both in dark and light conditions Xu et al. 2015 . However the introduction of microalgae in mMFCs is quite recent. Their conﬁg- urations can be grouped into single chamber double chambers or photosynthetic sediment Fig. 8 . Sensitivity to seasonal variation optimal design lack of data regarding symbiotic relationships with bacterial species and light source constraints are signiﬁcant chal- lenges still to be addressed Cui et al. 2014 Saba et al. 2017 . 4.5. Metabolic engineering Microalgae are still not a fully explored from a biotechnological point of view. It is believed that out of 10 000 species exiting only a few 1000 are explored a few 100 are examined for the production of bio-active compounds and other value-added products and very few are cultivated in industrial large scale quantities. The need for screening microalgae strains in natural environments is an obvious research area for instance strains that withstand high CO2 con- centrations suitable for application in industrial ﬂue gases which resist higher temperatures or that digest contaminants in waters and soils etc. On the other hand instead of seeking for strains in natural environments one can try to design algae cells making them to shift their metabolism to the area of interest by introducing recombinant DNA to trigger the target algae metabolites produc- tion. Genetic manipulation of cyanobacteria is generally more advanced than that of eukaryotic algae because many of the tools developed for bacterial genetics are applicable in cyanobacteria Fishman et al. 2010 . For example spontaneous transformation double-homologous recombination and protein tagging are routine in some cyanobacterial systems Vermaas 1998 . Next to fermentation certain products e.g. ethanol can also be produced directly as an algae metabolite which can be secreted in the growth medium. Bioethanol production via hydrolysis and fermentation usually involves extensive downstream processing and is an important obstacle for the commercial scale production of algae based biofuel Hammed et al. 2016 . Through cultivation of strains that are able to produce volatile alcohols or aldehydes as metabolites that can be secreted out of the cell way less time and energy is spent. Bioethanol can be produced from photosyntheti- cally formed starch or by feeding sugar carbon sources to the algae dark anaerobic fermentation . Examples of such strains are Chlorella vulgaris and Chlamydomonas perigranulata Daroch et al. 2013 Hon-Nami 2006 . The heterotrophic method was demon- strated in closed PBR utilizing seawater with metabolically engi- neered cyanobacteria being resistant to high temperature salinity and ethanol levels Hirayama et al. 1998 . The volatile products in the headspace can be condensed to liquid biofuels. Because of its good volatility and well-established puriﬁcation technologies ethanol would be the preferred product. Other products like cel- lulose and sucrose Nobles and Brown 2008 isobutanol Atsumi et al. 2009 ethylene Eckert et al. 2014 and free fatty acids Rufﬁng 2014 were also produced by direct secretion using transgenic methods. Alkanes and alkenes including isoprene as the basic unit of synthetic rubber also have been produced in engi- neered strains of Synechocystis Wang et al. 2013b Lindberg et al. 2010 . The ethanol titres obtained are rather low 1 wt for Chla- mydomonas reinhardtii Hirano et al. 1997 . The direct conversion to ethanol involves pyruvate decarboxylase pcd and alcohol de- hydrogenase adh Kimmerer 1987 Yang et al. 2014b . Deng and Coleman 1999 reported the cultivation of an autotrophic cyano- bacterium Synechococcus sp. PCC7942 introducing bacterial pcd and adh genes from Zymomonas mobilis to induce the direct syn- thesis of bioethanol up to 5.5 g L 1 titers. The use of ampicillin as a selectable marker during the cultivations implied serious envi- ronmental concerns although this issue was addressed later in 2009 Dexter and Fu 2009 . Nevertheless this approach might result inefﬁcient over longer time as the manipulations were found to destabilize culture growth by metabolic reprogramming of the cells rather than growth inhibition by ethanol. But after all the role of pdc and adh genes for a direct route to bioethanol producing algae with the help of metabolic engineering cannot be ignored as an attempt to bypass multiple time-consuming processes. Algenol Biotech LLC USA claims to manufacture up to ca. 25 m3 ethanol year 1 on 0.4 ha of algae cultivar using the direct-secretion process and CO2 from a power plant to accelerate the algae growth Fishman et al. 2010 . Metabolic engineering techniques also have been applied to increase the production of biodiesel. Lipid accumulation is crucial here. In 1990 Roessler and Ohlrogge 1990 isolated and Fig. 8. Schematic illustration of algae-based-MFC systems a algae as a carbon source for micro-organisms in the anodic chamber and b algae in the cathodic camber to capture the CO2 produced. A. Raheem et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 53 characterized for the ﬁrst time a full-length gene which encodes for acetyl-coenzyme A carboxylase ACCase in Cyclotella cryptica. In 2015 De Bhowmick et al. 2015 reviewed the improvements in this ﬁeld including overexpression of rate limiting enzymes partici- pating in the lipid biosynthesis increasing the accessibility of precursor genes such as ACCase blocking and or down regulating the rival pathways and lipid catabolism by RNAi-mediated silencing and lowering the fatty acid insaturation proﬁle followed by opti- mizing the chain length with thioesterases. In fact the knockdown of a Chlamydomonas citrate synthase which incorporates acetyl- CoA into the citric acid cycle competing with FA synthesis led to a major increase 169 in TAG content providing strong evi- dence for the hypothesis of substrate competition carbon parti- tioning for TAG and starch synthesis in green algae. A very recent study has cleared out the biological functioning of starch Krishnan et al. 2015 which can explain some negative physiological effects with sta6 mutant algae Breuer et al. 2014 . One such an effect is a distorted cell wall cells which resulted in higher TAG contents . Metabolic engineering is also used as a tool to overcome kinetic constraints within the photosynthetic electron transfer apparatus and the Calvin-Benson cycle that impact the efﬁciency of light utilization. Notably research was conducted for engineering the photosynthetic antenna pigments to improve the light harvesting yield in general and in bulky algae cultures in particular Huesemann et al. 2009 Beckmann et al. 2009 Barry et al. 2015 De Mooij et al. 2015 . More recently the discovery of a red-shifted chlorophyll in cyanobacteria opens opportunities to extend the light quantum yield Chen and Blankenship 2011 Gan et al. 2014 . Other constraints include the coupling of proton to electron transfer associated with plastoquinone PQ reduction and oxida- tion the slow turnover numbers of Rubisco and limiting concen- trations of enzymes Kumar et al. 2016 . For example increasing the PQ pool size could buffer transients in fast PSII and slow cyto- chrome electron transfer rates. Increasing the activity or levels of the cytochrome bef complexes may also accelerate electron transfer rates. In addition the importance of optimizing Rubisco efﬁciency by concentrating CO2 at the active site requires greater cyclic photophosphorylation activity to produce sufﬁcient ATP for active bicarbonate uptake. Finally it cannot be neglected that the current status of algae biotechnology is still not fully developed and adopted. It is important to dispose of selective screening tools for mutants. Typically this is accomplished by introducing an antibiotic resis- tance gene as a selectable marker along with the transgene in the organellar or nuclear genome Dunahay et al. 1995 . Since in most cases antibiotic resistance is not directly linked to transgene expression it may not be necessary to maintain antibiotics at large- scale if the transgene is stably integrated into the genome or if counter-selection methods have been used to remove the antibiotic resistance cassette Cheah et al. 2013 . However recent studies have demonstrated that the long-term stability of transgene expression in the absences of direct selection can be impacted by the copy number of the transgene Kumar et al. 2013 . Recently other interesting detection alternatives have been demonstrated by Manandhar-Shrestha and Hildebrand 2013 and Terashima et al. 2015 e.g. inositol polyphosphates and TOR kinase for the rapid detection of desired properties such as lipid accumulation Xie et al. 2014 . Gene identiﬁcation either by partial or complete nu- clear genome sequencing and transcriptomic proﬁling of potential production strains has elucidated the gene expression under nutrient deprivation Carpinelli et al. 2014 Jia et al. 2015 Mansfeldt et al. 2016 . For a review on current technologies employed to probe and edit the Chlamydomonas reinhardtii nuclear genome see Jinkerson and Jonikas 2015 . New sequencing tech- nologies enable a comprehensive coverage of mRNA transcripts. Small RNA also has been identiﬁed in microalgae and should be considered in investigations of gene expression regulation espe- cially with regard to translational regulation Lopez-Gomollon et al. 2014 . 5. Conclusions Microalgae guard a still under-exploited potential for the bio- based reﬁnery due to multiple challenges in different ﬁelds. The most diﬁcult one is related to their inherent algae cell biology direct sunlight energy greatly exceeds the photosynthetic capacity of the cells at light saturation levels. The challenges in the ﬁeld of microalgae cultivation are mainly related to their scalability oper- ational stability and associated costs. The challenges in harvesting and extraction of microalgae is mainly related to the energy input especially concentrating and drying of the diluted algae cultures. Conversion methods that directly act on diluted wet algae biomass are highly desired such as hydrothermal liquefaction. Other thermo-chemical conversion methods include gasiﬁcation and pyrolysis. Transesteriﬁcation of algae derived lipid oil results in the production of biodiesel whereas biochemical conversion methods proceed via fermentations to biogas bioethanol and other prod- ucts. Recent developments show that algae lipid oils are prefen- tially converted to green diesel and naphtha via hydrotreating as their composition and structural characteristics are not optimal for commerical biodiesel production. Current developments in microalgae research also tend to improve their valorization by considering their three main fractions lipids carbohydrates and proteins. Acid hydrolysis of algae slurries at moderated tempera- tures recently showed promising results in this sense. Further research in cost-effective reﬁning of these fractions are highly desired not only to maximize the biomass utilization but also because the better valorization of residue streams or co-products are the only way to make better projections for the proﬁtability of commercial algae production plants. Research in protein char- acterization extraction and valorization is clearly under- investigated and needs to be further developed as they do show to be cost-competitive with proteins from plant and bacterial pro- duction systems. The cultivation of algae in the vecinity of point sources like power plants as a biosequestration strategy for CO2 mitigation and the application of algae in nutrient recycling and environmental remediation are also becoming prominent research ﬁelds. Finally metabolic engineering of algae cells is a promising tool to tune algal biochemical factories in the direction of interest. However progress in this ﬁeld has to further break through as the biotechnological tools for algae are not that widely established and adopted yet as compared to bacteria and yeasts. Journal of Cleaner Production 181 2018 42e59 59', 'Biofuel production from microalgae challenges and chances Anh Tuan Hoang . Ranjna Sirohi . Ashok Pandey . Sandro Nizˇetic . Su Shiung Lam . Wei-Hsin Chen . Rafael Luque . Sabu Thomas . Mu slu m Arıcı . Van Viet Pham Received 30 October 2021 Accepted 30 March 2022 Published online 2 May 2022 The Author s under exclusive licence to Springer Nature B.V. 2022 Abstract The inherent capability and increased efﬁciency of microalgae to convert sunlight into solar chemical energy are further enhanced by the higher amount of oils stored in microalgae compared to other land-based plant species. Therefore the widespread interest in producing biofuels from microalgae has gained considerable interest among leading energy experts and researchers due to the burgeoning global issues stemming from the depletion of fossil fuel reserves future energy security increasing greenhouse gas emissions and the competition for limited resources between food crops and conven- tional biomass feedstock. This paper aims to present the recent advances in biofuel production from microalgae and the potential beneﬁts of microalgae in the energy and environmental sectors as well as sustainable development. Besides bottlenecks and challenges mainly relating to techniques of cultivation and harvesting as well as downstream processes are completely presented. Promising solutions and novel A. T. Alternatively the role of microalgae in the circular economy is thor- oughly analyzed indicating that the potential of scaling up current microalgae-based production could beneﬁt from the waste-to-energy strategy with microalgae as a key intermediate. In the future further research into combining different microalgae biomass pretreatment techniques separating the microalgae feedstock from the cultured media developing new species and optimizing the biofuel production process should be carried out to reduce the prices of microal- gae biofuels. Keywords Microalgae Biofuel Bottlenecks Beneﬁts Circular economy Introduction Along with the extraordinary pace of technological advances the twenty-ﬁrst century also faces incredi- bly difﬁcult global challenges such as overpopulation climate change food scarcity depletion of fossil fuels etc. Hoang et al. 2021c Bhushan et al. 2020 Nayak and Mishra 2016 . Indeed the growing reliance on nonrenewable sources of energy has prompted a growing interest in ﬁnding more sustainable solutions to meet the increasing global energy demands this lesson could be observed more clearly from the shifting progress to clean energy and energy crisis after the COVID19 pandemic Steffen et al. 2020 Chen et al. 2021 . Among the renewable and clean energy sources solar power presents a vast amount of renewable energy harnessed from the sun through photosynthesis plants use sunlight to grow and mature Udayan et al. 2022 Hariskos and Posten 2014 . Therefore plant biomass-derived carbonaceous mate- rials present a promising and widely available source of feedstock for biofuel production such as microal- gae crop residues and organic wastes Hoang et al. 2022 Papathoti et al. 2021 Alami et al. 2021 . The conversion of widely available biomass into promising sources of renewable energy such as biofuels has been a popular topic among current scientists and energy researchers Chen et al. 2022 Aissi et al. 2021 Hoang and Pham 2021 . Biofuels are commonly classiﬁed into three different categories including ﬁrst second and third generation. Biofuels produced from food crops are considered ﬁrst-generation such as bio- ethanol made from starch. For biofuels that are derived from non-food crops such as lignocellulosic biomass can be grouped into the second-generation category. Last but not least biofuels derived from microalgae and microbes are considered the third generation category Sirohi et al. 2022a SB et al. 2022 . One of the major challenges facing the production of biofuels is the inadequate and inconsistent supply of biomass feedstock Koyande et al. 2019 . Further- more the conversion of ﬁrst-generation biofuels from food crops also raises the controversial food versus fuel debate as they compete for the same amount of arable land and freshwater resources. Recently dif- ferent species of microalgae have received much attention for their potential of being a promising feedstock for the production of third-generation bio- fuels Mishra et al. 2017 . Due to the incredibly fast growth rate and high carbon efﬁciency microalgae present major beneﬁts as a substrate for biofuel production. Examining the structure of microalgae one can ﬁnd the presence of several bioactive com- pounds such as lipids proteins carbohydrates and fractions of anti-oxidants Kusmayadi et al. 2021 Yu et al. 2021a . Besides the potential as a biofuel feedstock microalgae are packed with a signiﬁcant amount of nutrients that can be utilized in food R. Pham PATET Research Group Ho Chi Minh City University of Transport Ho Chi Minh City Vietnam e-mail 123 1090 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 supplements and animal feed. Microalgae also have a special role in dye products cosmetics and the pharmaceutical industry. Furthermore studies also have found the beneﬁt of microalgae as an effective pollution control agent Aliyu et al. 2021 . Among major industries such as biochemical engineering food production and pharmaceutical there has been an increasing trend in the use of microalgae as a solution to address the burgeoning issues of sustain- able production and consumption of food feed and fuel as shown in Fig. 1. Compared to other biofuel alternatives microalgae-derived biofuels demonstrate a higher potential and practicality Kazemi Shariat Panahi et al. 2019b . Depending on the species of microalgae the efﬁciency of bioethanol can be signiﬁcantly increased when there is a higher content of carbohydrates e.g. up to 30 of dry weight Kazemi Shariat Panahi et al. 2019a . Using sunlight via photosynthesis microalgae are capable of converting nutrients in the water to bioactive compounds that make up the primary cell structure Verma et al. 2020 . As microalgae they feed off the nutrients e.g. nitrogen phosphates and trace elements when converting CO2 into organic compounds with the energy provided from sunlight. Considering this characteristic alone microalgae present a likely solution for wastewater treatment and CO2 bioremediation in industrial processes Cunha et al. 2020 suggesting that microalgae could be a key and critical link in the progress of converting waste to energy. Another signiﬁcant advantage in the farming of microalgae is that it does not compete for the same resources required for the cultivation of traditional food crops. Furthermore provided with high concentrations of CO2 microalgae can grow at a rapid pace while utilizing and offsetting the CO2 source such as ﬂue gas from thermal power plants Singh et al. 2019a Sirohi et al. 2021 . Furthermore the technologies utilized in the production of biofuels from microalgae also have a lower carbon footprint Fig. 1 Potential application of microalgae in various ﬁelds 123 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 1091 and lower negative impacts on the ecosystem because the equipment used in microalgae-based biofuel technologies has a low-energy consumption level Bwapwa et al. 2017 Khoo et al. 2020 . Due to this reason promoting the use of microalgae-derived biofuels can yield a positive sustainability effect on the environment since it is considered carbon neutral thus there is a signiﬁcant beneﬁt in pursuing this promising source on the path toward a higher sustain- able energy future based on the circular economy and carbon neutrality Javed et al. 2019 . Despite extensive progress in the development of microalgae technology signiﬁcant challenges remain surrounding the techno-economic viability of microal- gae-derived biofuels. Among the current obstacles cultivation techniques need further research to improve the biomass concentration of microalgae grown in suspended culture as well as ﬁnd an adequate supply of CO2 and affordable growth medium for industrial-scale farming Suparmaniam et al. 2019 MT et al. 2022 . Notably high concen- trations of nutrients and different variety of salts are needed in the culture medium to support the growth of microalgae Baicha et al. 2016 . Moreover increasing cost is a signiﬁcant issue in the operation of microal- gae cultivation systems in suspended cultures Tan et al. 2015 . Upon harvesting the next step is to decide which conversion method that depends signiﬁcantly on the conditions of the farmed biomass and the desired biofuel products Kumar et al. 2020 . Overall there are reasons and gaps to have further studies of the development of biofuels production from microalgae due to several advantages and value-added products. Indeed this review paper explores existing practices while reviewing the bio-processing of microalgae also known as bio-reﬁnery of microalgae. This current work also attempts to provide an overview of the current development of third-generation biofuels derived from microalgae. Furthermore this review paper also addresses the current issues facing the implementation of microalgae bio-reﬁnery and future opportunities for the industry. On the one hand the paper summarizes the recent development in terms of strategies employed in the production of biofuels from microalgae. On the other hand it also focuses prospects opportunities and challenges on the path toward scaling up microalgae-based biofuel produc- tion and improving widespread market penetration. More importantly this review paper aims to provide insights and inputs in the strategic decisions by various stakeholders such as researchers legislators ofﬁcials environmental organizations private sectors in advancing the progress of the biofuel industry overall and improve the viability and cost-effectiveness of the microalgae-based biofuel products speciﬁcally. Microalgae properties and CO2 ﬁxation capacity Compared to various land-dwelling species of ﬂora microalgae have a signiﬁcantly higher concentration of light-harvesting pigment known as chlorophyll which results in more effective photosynthesis Kumar et al. 2021b . Several factors can inﬂuence the cellular structure and make-ups of different species of microalgae. Among these inherent conditions such as species growth media environmental factors and the coexistence of multiple strains within the same culture are examples of factors that can affect the nature and characteristics of microalgae Kim et al. 2014 . Provided with metabolic versatility microalgae are capable of being converted into a wide range of value- added products via various processing pathways. For certain species of microalgae with high concentrations of carbohydrates e.g. 37 55 such as Chlorella Chlamydomonas Dunaliella Scenedesmus and Tet- raselmis the starch-rich components are mainly found in the chloroplasts and cell walls made of cellulose Dragone et al. 2011 . Besides the lipid contents in microalgae can range between 2 and 77 of the biomass volume for certain species under favorable growth conditions. Lipids in microalgae are grouped based on the end-product from the conversion process namely biofuel and nutrient supplements Mimouni et al. 2018 Ho et al. 2020 . For the latter category microalgae present a potentially good source for the manufacturing of omega-3 fatty acids in which common microalgae species used in the production of omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids include Bacil- lariophyta Chlorophyta Cryptophyta Haptophyta Haptophyta and Rhodophyta Ryckebosch et al. 2012 2014 . Last but not least proteins which are considered an essential product in the bioreﬁnery process of microalgae make up a signiﬁcant compo- nent. Depending on the species they can range anywhere between 50 70 of the biomass volume in microalgae. Proteins extracted from microalgae 123 1092 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 have different uses such as in food supplements and animal feeds e.g. aquaculture and husbandry Bertsch et al. 2021 . Furthermore pigments and other bioactive compounds can also be extracted from microalgae. For example several chemical processes often utilize chlorophylls phycobilins and carote- noids that are extracted from several microalgae species such as Porphyridium cruentum Synechococ- cus sp. and Chlorella Ummalyma et al. 2020 . Given the high concentration of biological mole- cules contained in the biomass microalgae present an attractive option to be used as a substrate in energy conversion. The production of speciﬁc biofuel relies heavily on the biochemical make-up of the microalgae substrate. For example various species of microalgae with a higher mass fraction of lipid content provide optimal feedstock for biodiesel production Brind- hadevi et al. 2021 . On the other hand microalgae that have higher carbohydrate content are more suitable for the production of fermentative alcohol Phwan et al. 2019 . Notably researchers have found ways to modify the biochemical structure of microalgae species with the help of genetic engineering tech- niques to improve the characteristics of certain strains. Furthermore the growth rate of selected species of microalgae can be signiﬁcantly enhanced with the development and application of photobioreactors in the cultivation process Sirohi et al. 2022b Ran- ganathan et al. 2022 . Moreover microalgae species with high concentrations of fatty acids have been regarded as potential sources to supplement conven- tional petroleum-based fuels and ﬁsh oils. Depending on the strains of microalgae the productivity of biomass and lipid content can vary signiﬁcantly when they are used as inputs for edible oil production Shin et al. 2018b . Despite the fact that the investigation into optimal culture conditions to increase the lipid content from microalgae has been conducted it is unlikely to achieve equally desirable results if the chosen strains are not suitable for the conversion to edible oil Piligaev et al. 2015 . Hence it is important to consider the microalgae species as it is the major factor affecting the productivity and composition of major components such as fatty acids carbohydrates lipids and proteins Xue et al. 2021 . Figure 2 provides nutrients of different microalgae species for the purpose of biofuel production. Previous studies have examined different species of microalgae for biofuel production such as Chlamydomonas sp. Scranton et al. 2015 Chlorella sp. Guccione et al. 2014 Senedesmus sp. Nan- nochloropsis sp. and a combination of various cultures included both fresh or wastewater strains Sajjadi et al. 2018 . Biological molecules found in microalgae biomass namely lipid protein and car- bohydrates as well as the entire cell structure can be converted into biofuels through proven techniques. All in all the development of microalgae as a potential biomass feedstock for third-generation biofuel pro- duction presents a signiﬁcant opportunity and viable solution for achieving a more sustainable energy future. As reported microalgae are found to have a higher growth rate as well as they could ﬁx CO2 with higher capacity compared to aquatic and agricultural plants and traditional forests. More interestingly without any evolution beyond the cells microalgae could adapt to popular conditions of the environment and have a strong growth in the long term Singh and Ahluwalia 2013 . In the growing process photosynthesis is known as the critical basis in the ﬁxation and storage of CO2 of microalgae. Many studies indicated that the efﬁciency of the photosynthesis process for microal- gae could reach 10 20 Li et al. 2008 even microalgae could perform 50 of the photosynthesis process on the Earth Singh and Singh 2014 . How- ever the level of CO2 ﬁxation depends much on the types of microalgae and the environmental conditions of cultivation Ho et al. 2011 . For example Chlorella species were found to have strong CO2 ﬁxation capacity when CO2 concentration ranged from 5 to 20 Tang et al. 2011 . In another case Spirulina species could ﬁx CO2 at a high rate value of 37.9 De Morais and Costa 2007 . Besides it was reported that the use of N. oculata for CO2 ﬁxation in ﬂue gas produced from a coal-ﬁred power plant could offer a high efﬁciency that around 1 3 of CO2 could be removed from ﬂue gas Cheng et al. 2015b . In addition to traditional microalgae many novel microalgae have been developed to provide excellent capacities in ﬁxing CO2. In a study by Aghaalipour et al. 2020 they found that Psammothidium and Monoraphidium contortum species could show a good capacity of CO2 bioﬁxation at concentration 10 . In another report based on the experimental results obtained from 20 microalgae species Gleocystis ampula was observed to have the highest growth rate and CO2 ﬁxation capacity 0.281 g l.d 123 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 1093 Derakhshandeh et al. 2021 . Also many studies reported that a large number of unfamiliar microalgae could offer excellent capabilities in ﬁxing CO2 and producing biomass Song et al. 2020 Ding et al. 2020 Tamil Selvan et al. 2020 Jin et al. 2021 Rodas- Zuluaga et al. 2021 Sung et al. 2021 . In general a critical route from the ﬁxation process of CO2 by microalgae to biofuel production could be depicted in Fig. 3. Critical route for biofuel production from microalgae The existing bioreﬁnery process of microalgae has the potential to yield many high-value products that can be grouped into fuel and non-fuel categories Chandra et al. 2019 in which common biofuels include bioethanol or biobutanol biodiesel biogas and bio-hydrogen. In general Fig. 4 provides examples of advanced methods utilized in the conversion of microalgae biomass to different end-products. Thermochemical conversion Thermochemical liquefaction is a technique that can be utilized at low temperature and high-pressure conditions to convert wet microalgae biomass to bio- oil. In this method the use of a catalyst is optional Arvindnarayan et al. 2017a . Such an approach beneﬁts from the elimination of the energy-intensive drying process. Through liquefaction biomolecules such as lipids carbohydrates and proteins in microal- gae biomass are processed into crude bio-oil. Several factors can affect the efﬁciency of the process such as temperature pressure reaction time catalyst and the natural structure and composition of the microalgal biomass Hong et al. 2021 . Pyrolysis is another Fig. 2 Nutrients of different microalgae species Singh and Gu 2010 123 1094 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 commonly used technique to yield bio-oil syngas and charcoal from the combustion of biomass at medium to high temperatures 350 700 C without the pres- ence of oxygen Yang et al. 2019 . For fast pyrolysis the process occurs at a medium temperature range of approximately 500 C with a really short hot vapor residence time of 1 s. The process has the potential to obtain up to 95 5 bio-oil yield Venderbosch 2019 . In contrast to slow pyrolysis fast pyrolysis has a lower overall energy consumption due to its fast reaction while yielding a higher amount of bio-oil outputs. Furthermore bio-oil obtained from the fast pyrolysis process has a lower viscosity compared to its coun- terpart obtained from slow pyrolysis Tan et al. 2015 . Hence the fast pyrolysis process is more appropriate for the production of liquid bio-fuel in general and much larger industrial scales speciﬁcally Hoang et al. 2021b . After microalgae biomass undergoes either the pyrolysis or hydrothermal liquefaction HTL process the dark brown liquid output is determined as bio-oil. The main difference between these two methods is that the former can only occur under dry conditions i.e. less the 5 of moisture contained in the biomass feedstock while HTL can be conducted using any type of microalgae biomass Toro-Trochez et al. 2019 . Within these methods depolymerization of organic compounds takes place without the presence of oxygen Sun et al. 2020 . The microalgae biomass feedstock is ﬁrst broken down into smaller molecules through various thermophysical processes such as dehydration dehydrogenation deoxygenation and decarboxylation. One of the most signiﬁcant factors Fig. 3 a Microalgae cultivation from various CO2 sources and microalgae processing Zhang and Liu 2021 b Photobiochemical mechanism of ﬁxing CO2 in microalgae Zhao and Su 2014 With permission from Elsevier through LN 5262961242136 123 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 1095 driving the difference in the yield and quality of bio- crude is microalgae biomass constituents. According to Arvindnarayan et al. 2017b there is a high potential in obtaining high energy content from the pyrolysis of Chlorella species of microalgae. Further- more bio-oil obtained from microalgae biomass can be easily blended with conventional transportation fuel without the need for major modiﬁcations to existing engines. According to the experiment reported by Jena and Das 2011 the pyrolysis of Spirulina platensis at 350 C yielded 39.7 23.8 and 19.2wt. of biochar bio-oil and gases respectively. According to Shakya et al. 2017 an experiment was conducted when subjecting nine species of microalgae to hydrothermal liquefaction at 280 C and 320 C in operating temperature and 0.7 MPa of pressure. The study conﬁrmed the highest yield of bio-crude output from the conversion of lipid-rich Nannochloropsis at 320 C. Furthermore a series of investigations by Zhu et al. 2016 utilized microalgae biomass of two different species namely Scenedesmus and Spirulina to produce bio-oil. The authors compared the results from the application of hydrothermal liquefaction 300 C and 10 12 MPa and the pyrolysis method heating to 450 C at a rate of 50 C min to the above microalgae strains. As a result both approaches yielded comparable results in terms of bio-oil output. Notably the experiments obtained 24 45 of bio-oil with a high heating value 35 37 MJ kg . Hence the outputs of the pyrolysis of microalgae biomass depend on the species and the pyrolysis conditions. Moreover the researchers also conﬁrmed the advantage of hydrothermal liquefaction over the pyrolysis method in terms of energy consumption ratio. When the moisture content of wet biomass exceeded 80 the ECR values of hydrothermal liquefaction and pyrol- ysis were measured in the range of 0.44 0.63 and 0.92 1.24 respectively. Recently researchers have made signiﬁcant progress on the development of microalgae biomass pyrolysis to convert microalgae into biofuels. For example one study has successfully obtained nearly 54.4 wt. wt. yield of bio-oil from microwave-enhanced pyrolysis subjected to a CO2 environment when using freshwater microalgae blooms naturally occurring in lakes as the main feedstock Zhang et al. 2016 . In another instance the hydropyrolysis of the native microalgae consor- tium was observed to yield up to 31 of bio-oil under 200 C operating temperature Choudhary et al. 2017 . Recent studies have explored the use of heterogeneous catalysts to enhance the conversion efﬁciency in the hydrothermal liquefaction of microal- gae Xu et al. 2019a Kohansal et al. 2019 . In their study Saber et al. 2016 conducted low-temperature hydrothermal liquefaction using Nannochloropsis as the primary biomass feedstock. The experiments were conducted using three different catalysts including nano-Ni SiO2 synthesized zeolite and Na2CO3 under three different temperatures 210 230 and 250 C . Among these catalysts nano-Ni SiO2 yielded the highest amount of bio-oil 30 wt. followed by Na2CO3 24.2 wt. and zeolite 24 wt. . In another comparable work the hydrothermal liquefaction at 300 C of Nannochlopsis in the presence of Ni supported TiO2 obtained a 48.23 yield of bio-crude Wang et al. 2018 . Under low-oxygen conditions biomass can be heated at relatively high temperatures 800 1000 C to yield combustible gas mixtures in a process known as gasiﬁcation Clark and Deswarte 2014 . The output of syngas typically contains several common gases such as CO H2 CH4 and CO2 Hoang et al. 2021a . Although syngas has a low energy density 4 6 MJ m3 it is highly suitable for domestic heating and cooking by combustion in gas engines or gas turbines McKendry 2002 . In a study by Zhu et al. 2016 they conducted an experiment utilizing both wood biomass and microalgae with a 9 1 ratio in a co-gasiﬁcation process. Compared to only using wood biomass the co-gasiﬁcation of microalgae and wood yielded higher H2 CO and CH4 by 3 20 6 -31 and 9 20 respectively. Likewise Raheem et al. 2015 per- formed the gasiﬁcation of Chlorella biomass at 950 C yielding H2 CO and CH4 up to 2.9 22.8 and 10.1 wt. of biomass respectively. In a study by Liu et al. 2017 they found that the gasiﬁcation process exhibited an overall 81.6 efﬁciency with a combus- tion gas yield of 1.05 Nm3 kg. The authors also conﬁrmed the factors inﬂuencing the cold gas efﬁ- ciency such as steam and moisture content in the feedstocks as well as the mixture of the microalgae substrate to a lesser degree. More importantly the most signiﬁcant factor is the moisture content in the gasiﬁcation and biomass feedstock that affects the composition of the syngas output Azadi et al. 2014 . A study conducted by Diaz-Rey et al. 2015 also has shown the potential to obtain hydrogen-rich precursors with measured HHV up to 25 MJ Nm via gasiﬁcation 123 1096 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 of microalgae. Such a process still faces major obstacles in dealing with the high concentration of nitrogen and minerals found in microalgae feedstock. One way to reduce the ash content in the output has been suggested by Liu et al. 2019b that could eliminate the amount of ash by 67.6 when acid washing the microalgae feedstock with HCL. Other studies also pointed out that the elevated concentration of potassium in microalga ash could enhance gas yield while the presence of calcium could activate carbon capture and deamination Liu et al. 2020a Lo pez-Gonza lez et al. 2014 . Table 1 provides a summary of different studies on thermochemical conversion of microalgae into biofuels. Biochemical conversion Anaerobic digestion is considered to be a popular biochemical conversion of biomass into biofuels. Biogas which makes up mainly of CH4 and CO2 along with a small amount of H2S is the output of the anaerobic digestion process in which microbes break down and convert the organic biomass of microalgae. Typically a constant temperature is maintained throughout the anaerobic digestion process to ensure the optimal condition for the growth of the microbes. The temperature range can be classiﬁed as mesophilic 30 42 C and thermophilic 43 55 C . Most anaer- obic digesters are constructed based on the character- istics of the former operating conditions given their prevalence and stability in the treatment of different types of biomass Gonzalez-Fernandez and Mun oz 2017 . Commonly there are three main stages of anaerobic digestion including hydrolysis fermenta- tion and methanogenesis. Initially simple sugars are obtained from the hydrolysis of complex polysaccha- rides in biomass. Then the fermentation process takes place to transform sugars into alcohols acetic acid volatile fatty acids and traces of H2 and CO2. The gas mixture is further transformed into CH4 60 70 and CO2 30 40 in the presence of methanogens Cantrell et al. 2008 . The measured energy content of the biogas product is 20 40 of the lower heating value of the biomass feedstock. Brennan and Owende Brennan and Owende 2010 have observed the suitability of wet biomass containing 80 90 of moisture as feedstock in an anaerobic digestion process. Several studies have attempted to use microalgae as the primary feedstock for the production of bio-methane via anaerobic digestion. Microwave-induced pyrolysis 550 Syngas 16 vol Borges et al. 2014 123 1098 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 the process achieves very low yields due to the inability of bacteria to break down the outer cell structure of microalgae. Furthermore the presence of free ammonia due to the low carbon to nitrogen ratio further inhibits the formation of methane Chandra et al. 2019 . In a study by Zamalloa et al. 2011 they conﬁrmed relatively lower increases in methane output from the digestion of Scenedemus obliquus and Phaeodactylum tricornutum under mesophilic 0.296 L CH4 g and thermophilic 0.462 L CH4 g . According to Trivedi et al. 2015 higher biomass yields are observed in microalgae biomass compared to biomass obtained from terrestrial plants e.g. Jatropha curcas . However the latter has a lower feedstock cost which improves its economic viability. To convert microalgae to bio-alcohol major biomass constituents such as sugars starch and cellulose are ﬁrst degraded in the presence of yeast or bacteria. Further distillation is often required to achieve higher concentrations of diluted alcohol Alves et al. 2020 . Carbohydrates are mainly found in starch reserves in cell bodies as well as cellulose polysaccharides in the cell walls. Jo nsson et al. 2016 have observed a high degree of difﬁculty in fermenting carbohydrates found in biomass in the presence of microbes. Hence it is necessary to break down these carbohydrates into monomeric sugars via hydrolysis using either chemical or biological agents enzymes before further processes Lin et al. 2019 . Neverthe- less enzymatic hydrolysis is less favorable due to the high costs associated with enzyme procurement and the required pre-treatment of microalgal biomass Tan et al. 2015 . As part of the alcoholic fermentation process the monomeric sugars derived from initial treatments of biomass are further processed into the desired outputs. De Farias Silva and Bertucco de Farias Silva and Bertucco 2016 have observed the conversion of sugars found in Saccharomyces and Zymomonas into bioethanol under an oxygen-free environment. Furthermore the fermentation process can occur in two different routes in which hydrolysis and fermen- tation can take place separately or simultaneously in the same reaction chamber. According to Brennan and Owende Brennan and Owende 2010 the conversion of Chlorella vulgaris which contains 37 of starch per dry cell weight results in nearly 65 of ethanol output. In another study Choi et al. 2010 were able to produce 0.235 g of bioethanol from each gram of C. reinhardtii biomass via the separated hydrolysis and fermentation method. Compared to other conventional fermentation methods the use of anaerobic fermenta- tion to convert microalgae biomass into bioethanol is considered a relatively more simple process. In one study Daroch et al. 2013 investigated the use of genetically modiﬁed species of microalgae e.g. Chlamydomonas perigranulata that revealed positive results in terms of bioethanol production due to the presence of self-ferment carbohydrates. To improve the yield of ethanol starch-rich microalgae such as Chlorella vulgaris is one of the most popular strains with the potential to achieve up to 65 conversion efﬁciency and a high bioethanol yield can be obtained from dark fermentation of microalgae at 30 C Javed et al. 2019 . To produce biobutanol the conventional method typically involves the conversion of sugars into a combination of acetone butanol and ethanol ABE Veza et al. 2021 . Theoretically under a controlled fermentation process the optimal ABE yield is 0.41 g per gram of sugar which is slightly lower than 0 5 g of bioethanol per gram of sugar. A mixture of CO2 and H2 gas is also obtained as by-products in the process. The common product ratio of these components is 3 6 1 respectively. Hence butanol accounts for the largest portion of the outputs Bellido et al. 2014 . According to Chen et al. 2015 there is lower productivity in the production of biobutanol due to the strong resistance of degraded substances resulting from the initial steps of the fermentation process. Table 1 continued Microalgae types Thermochemical method Temperature C Biofuel types Yield Heating value Reference Scenedesmus sp. Flash volatilization 600 Syngas 16 vol Gholkar et al. 2019 Porphyra Gasiﬁcation 450 Syngas 87 vol Adnan et al. 2020 123 Phytochem Rev 2023 22 1089 1126 1099 Furthermore there is only a single species of microal- gae i.e. Clostridium spp. that can be converted to biobutanol leading to the lower efﬁciency of the conversion process. Given the fact that Clostridium spp. is saccharolytic the conversion process of starch- rich microalgae into biobutanol is relatively easy as that of bioethanol. In another instance Ellis et al. 2012 utilized biomass obtained from microalgae grown in wastewater with Clostridium saccharoper- butylacetonicum N1 4 in an ABE fermentation pro- cess. In this experiment microalgae that were pretreated with acid and basic chemicals resulted in 2.74 g L of total ABE from the fermentation process. On the other hand a much higher yield of 9.74 g ABE L when enzymatic hydrolysis xylanase and cellu- lases was applied. As reported ABE biofuel has more beneﬁcial physicochemical properties than those of fossil fuel indicating that it could be used as the potential biofuel for engine applications Veza et al. 2019 2020 . Biohydrogen is produced biologically as a result of the metabolic reactions of microbes. Renewable biohydrogen presents a more attractive option com- pared to other biofuel productions. Regarded as a potential alternative fuel biohydrogen is regarded to be cleaner and more sustainable while having a relatively high energy content 142 MJ kg . Biohy- drogen can be produced via different biological techniques including photo-fermentation dark fer- mentation and electro-bio-hydrogenation. There are major pros and cons associated with each of these methods in terms of feasibility sustainability and energy efﬁciency Kadier et al. 2018 Sivagurunathan et al. 2017 . Microalgae have recently gained the interest of researchers as the potential third-generation biomass feedstock for the production of renewable biohydrogen. Studies have reported the use of differ- ent species of microalgae in the generation of biohy- drogen such as Scenedesmus Chlorella Synechocystis Anabaena Nostoc and Tetraspora harbor hydrogenase Eroglu and Melis 2011 Anwar et al. 2019 . Naturally some microalgae strains can use sunlight and water as the source of electrons and energy respectively to produce photo-biological bio- hydrogen. Moreover hydrogen and carbon dioxide can be obtained when subjecting microalgae biomass as the organic substrate in the photo-fermentation process with the help of photosynthetic micro-organ- isms Arun et al. 2020b . In another study a 200 ml L.h hydrogen production rate was observed when using Clostridium butyricum in the dark fermentation of C.vulgaris biomass which contains a high level of carbohydrate in which biohydrogen also accounted for 66 of the total volume of biogas produced in the above process Liu et al. 2013 . In addition biological hydrogen is also a potential power source for electric- ity produced from fuel cells Ban et al. 2019 Eroglu and Melis 2016 He et al. 2017 . In general biofuel yield achieved from the biochemical conversion of microalgae is summarized in Table 2. Chemical conversion Microalgae-derived bio-oils inherently have a higher viscosity compared to diesel oils it is thus necessary to perform a transesteriﬁcation process on the microal- gae oils to lower their overall viscosity before applying to engines Akubude et al. 2019 . To improve the efﬁciency of biodiesel from microalgae the direct transesteriﬁcation method is deemed more favorable. Notably alcohol acts as both the reactant and solvent in a transesteriﬁcation process. Due to its affordability and easy access it is common to use methanol in this process over other types of alcohols e.g. methanol ethanol propanol butanol and amyl alcohol . Given that alcohol is hardly soluble in different kinds of oils the presence of a catalyst is also important due to its enhancing the solubility of alcohol. The direct appli- cation of lipid contained in wet microalgae biomass is another cost-effective strategy to reduce the cost associated with drying and extracting moisture content from the biomass feedstock. Therefore researchers have explored the development of advanced wet lipid extraction techniques Lakshmikandan et al. 2020 . Moreover to penetrate and break down the cell wall of microalgae within the lipid extraction process researchers have applied different pretreatment tech- niques to the biomass feedstock such as high-pressure homogenization ultrasound sonication microwave irradiation Howlader and French 2020 osmotic shock liquid hot water Triton-X-100 application shake mill Ramola et al. 2019 . According to Singh et al. 2019b solvothermal methods were applied to obtain lipids from Spirulina in a microwave environ- ment with a capacity of 750 W at 60 C for 30 min. Furthermore mixing an equal amount of hexane and methanol has been proven to be effective in large-scale operations Shin et al. 2018a .
