Ultraviolet UV mutagenesis is flexibly controlled and does not require any genetic information Liu et al. 2015 . For example the UV mutant strain S. obliquus WUST4 showed excellent tolerance to high concentrations of CO2 and fixation efficiency Li et al. 2011 . After mutagenesis mutant strains even showed better growth characteristics under high CO2 conditions 15 v v for mutant C. vulgaris than under normal conditions Qi et al. 2016 . Gamma rays γ-rays lead to the generation of free radicals which disrupt biomacromolecules and cause changes in genetic characteristics Cheng et al. 2019c . Free radicals also stimulate C3 compound gen eration and activate RuBisCo thereby enhancing CO2 capture affinity Zhang and Liu 2021 . Haematococcus pluvialis mutants acclimated to 15 CO2 showed increased astaxanthin production and dry weight Cheng et al. 2016 . The CO2 fixation rate and biomass yield of an Arthrospira platensis strain mutated through irradiation with γ-rays from 60Co increased by over 20 Zhu et al. 2020 . Although many successful examples are listed above mutagenesis remains incompletely controllable and might lead to undesired base paring transversions and frameshift mutations Li et al. 2022a . Some technologies such as UV mutagenesis present other exigent disadvan tages such as low mutation rates high toxicity and radiation risk Sun et al. 2021 . 3.3. Genetic engineering strategies Genetic engineering set off a revolution in the microalgal industry and has recently attracted increasing attention because novel and pre cise genetic techniques for obtaining microalgal strains suitable for specific biorefinery scenarios have become available. Ideal photosyn thetic carbon sequestration stands on three major cornerstones the availability of CO2 the activity of RuBisCo as a carboxylase and the optimal intensity of light. Thus the genetic engineering of carbon- sequestrating microalgae currently focuses on i improving the effi ciency of the carbon sequestration pathway ii amending energy- capture complexes and iii designing additional carbon sequestration pathways. 3.3.1. Enhancing the efficiency of the carbon sequestration pathway The improvement in carbon sequestration efficiency relies on the enhancement in the activity of CCM and the expression levels of key Calvin cycle enzymes. Enhancing the expression of CCM-related genes especially those encoding CAs is undoubtedly the most straight-forward strategy for increasing CO2 availability at RuBisCo active sites. In microalgae the genetic engineering of CA demonstrated the positive role of its overexpression which supports the effective capture of sur plus CO2 Effendi and Ng 2019 . The carbon fixation rate of the genetically modified strain Synechococcus elongatus PCC7942 improved by 41 Chen et al. 2012 . Mesorhizobium loti with high CA activity was engineered as the expression vector of the highly overexpressed M1CA gene then transformed into C. vulgaris and Chlorella sorokiniana. The receiver displayed improved carbon capture and fixation rates biomass and lipid yields and protein contents Lin et al. 2018 . LCIA was found to be essential for HCO3 transport and cell accli mation to low CO2 conditions. The yield of H. pluvialis with self-cloned LCIA increased by 1.5-fold relative to that of wild strains Sharon-Goj man et al. 2017 . HLA3 also facilitates carbon uptake under CO2 limi tation. When introduced into microalgae such as Chlamydomonas sp. the artificially designed effector dTALE acted as the synthetic tran scriptional activator that activated the expression of HLA3 and increased biomass yield and growth rate as well as the activity of Ci transporters under low CO2 concentrations Gao et al. 2015 . As mentioned above the crucial rate-limiting step of the Calvin cycle is the reaction driven by RuBisCo in the first assimilation of CO2 into the organic compound 3-PGA the primary step of carbon sequestration Ng et al. 2017 . A number of studies have worked on the genetic modification of RuBisCO to increase carboxylation capability and RuBisCO overexpression is one of the most direct tools for reinforcing carbon sequestration in most photosynthetic organisms. For example in Nannochloropsis under ambient CO2 the overexpression of RuBisCo activase increased the level of the RuBisCo large subunit protein by 45 and the accumulation of biomass by approximately 46 Wei et al. 2017 . Liang and Lindblad 2017 overexpressed RuBisCo in the cyanobacterium Synechocystis PCC 6803. This approach increased RuBisCo activity and content activated carbon fixation and photosyn thesis and elevated biomass and ethanol production levels in vitro. RuBisCo in Synechococcus PCC 7002 could be overexpressed through natural transformation resulting in the stimulation of pyruvate PYR metabolism and fatty acid biosynthesis De Porcellinis et al. 2018 . Photosynthetic CO2 fixation efficiency is tightly associated with key Calvin cycle enzymes especially those determining the regeneration capability of RuBP. Aldolase overexpression has been demonstrated to promote RuBP regeneration and photosynthetic energy transport. An experiment cloned the cyanobacterial fructose bisphosphate aldolase FBA enzyme into C. vulgaris and showed that the overexpression of FBA promoted photosynthetic metabolic capacity by 1.2-fold Yang et al. 2017 . Sedoheptulose-1 7-bisphosphate SBPase is another functional enzyme regulating RuBP regeneration. The targeted over expression of SBPase increased the levels of Calvin cycle intermediates CO2 fixation activity and glycerol and biomass productivity in Duna liella bardawil and Euglena gracilis Priyadharsini et al. 2022 . Similarly the biomass of C. reinhardtii with the pyridoxal kinase gene which controls biomass accumulation from E. coli was double that of that the wild type and the CO2 fixation rate of this mutant reached the highest level of 1.183 g g 1 DW Lin et al. 2021 . Kanno et al. 2017 introduced conjugation modifications into the Calvin cycle and glycolytic pathways of S. elongatus PCC 7942 these modifications accelerated growth and 2 3-butanediol production. In terms of recent research trends the ge netic engineering of pathways related to the Calvin cycle especially exogenous gene overexpression still displays infinite opportunities for microalgae. Although several genetic strategies have been successfully applied to microalgae the precise editing expression and integration of crucial genes involved in the carbon fixation pathway remain an arduous task Priyadharsini et al. 2022 . 3.3.2. Modification of the light-harvesting photosynthetic apparatus Well-founded studies have confirmed that the photoconversion ac tivity and CO2 fixation capability of microalgae are upgraded with the enhancement in light irradiation Melis 2009 . As described above although peripheral antennae in the chloroplast are responsible for harvesting light energy their photon absorption rate becomes excessive at high solar intensities and the excess photons that cannot be used by photosynthesis timely are lost and dissipated in the form of fluorescence or heat leading to a decrement in photosynthetic productivity Li et al. 2022a . In addition to the optimization of light intensity for photosyn thesis genetic engineering has been utilized to weaken the possible negative effects of photoinhibition Zeng et al. 2011 . Large light-harvesting antenna complexes LHCs evolved in micro algae to enhance light capture in stressful environments and shrinking the LHC antenna could reduce photoinhibition Kirst et al. 2014 . In H. pluvialis the self-cloning of the nabI gene the active translational repressor of LHCII proteins increased photosynthetic efficiency Sharon-Gojman et al. 2017 . The LHC gene family of C. reinhardtii could be downregulated through the RNAi technique and higher photosynthetic quantum production instead of photoinhibition was observed under high light conditions Mussgnug et al. 2007 . Theo retically genetic engineering can also be combined with other emerging technologies to truncate the chlorophyll antenna incompletely relieving light overabsorption and simultaneously reducing energy dissipation Carvalho et al. 2011 . Nonphotochemical quenching NPQ could optimize light signaling pathways and greatly promote cell resistance to oxidative stress. NPQ Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 8 refers to the thermal dissipation of chlorophyll singlet excited states and the modification of the NPQ system can enhance carbon uptake and increase cell tolerance to high light intensities via heat dissipation Hines 2016 . 3.3.3. Development of additional carbon fixation pathways Amplifying carbon assimilation is a promising approach to minimize CO2 and energy losses. Rather than solely attempting to improve the carboxylase activity of RuBisCo in Calvin cycle phycologists have recently proposed some respiratory metabolic pathways and corre sponding carboxylating enzymes that can alternatively achieve carbon sequestration. For example reversible reductive carboxylase 6-phospho gluconate dehydrogenase acts as an ideal alternate exhibiting consid erably higher carbon fixation rate and yield than RuBisCo Bar-Even et al. 2012 . But mainstream studies tend to incorporate one or more complete alternative metabolic pathways instead of one single carboxylase. In addition to the Calvin cycle naturally available carbon fixation pathways include the reductive TCA rTCA pathway Wood Ljungdahl pathway WL pathway dicarboxylate 4-hydroxybutyrare cycle Di- 4HB cycle 3-hydroxypropionate bi-cycle 3HP bi-cycle and 3-hydrox ypropinate-4-hydroxybutyrate cycle 3HP-4HB cycle Priyadharsini et al. 2022 . Similar to the Calvin cycle the 3HP and 3HP-4HB cycles involve aerobic reactions. By contrast the rTCA WL and Di-4HB pathways occur anaerobically. Synthetic alternative pathways also offer customized metabolic routes for CO2 fixation among which the three most representative are summarized in Fig. 4 Berg 2011 . For example the malonyl- CoA oxaloacetate glyoxylate MOG pathway consumes less ATP but has a 2 3 folds higher CO2 fixation rate than the Calvin cycle. It also involves catalytically rapid PEPC enzymes with over 10-fold higher specific activity than RuBisCo 3.5 U mg 1 in the anaerobic conversion of OAA into PYR then into PEP. The crotonyl-CoA ethylmalonyl-CoA hydroxybutyryl-CoA CETCH cycle assimilates CO2 into organic com ponents via the action of crotonyl-CoA carboxylase reductase which has a specific activity of over 130 U mg 1 Claassens 2017 . While the Calvin cycle consumes 7 ATP to fix CO2 into one PYR CETCH cycle requires only one ATP to produce one PYR molecule. Similarly malate thiokinase and malyl-CoA lyase participate in the malyl-CoA glycerate MCG pathway to supply one CO2 equivalent to aid the conversion of C3 metabolites into two acetyl-CoA molecules thus realizing 100 CO2 conservation in photorespiration in theory Yu et al. 2018 . Some emerging complementary cycles also show the potential to trigger car bon assimilation. The formate assimilation pathway in which formate is Fig. 4. The metabolic routes of three synthetic alternative pathways. Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 9 oxidized into CO2 in the presence of formate dehydrogenase then con verted into serine now has a highly effective synthetic substitute in the ribulose monophosphate pathway and reductive glycine pathway Bar- Even 2016 . Alternatively the introduction of an additional NADPH consumption pathway can increase CO2 fixation efficiency and biomass accumulation. Genetic engineering in accordance with this approach was performed on Synechocystis sp. which showed enhanced NADPH consumption and significantly increased photosynthetic efficiency Zhou et al. 2016 . Synthetic biology is an interdisciplinary science that designs mod ifies and reconstructs biomolecules biological devices and differenti ation processes aiming to construct bioactive components systems and artificial cells or organisms for useful purposes. Genetic engineering can be utilized as the basic research and engineering approach of synthetic biology and genetic transformation methods for different microalgal cells have also been developed and studied to a certain extent. Until now the most extensive mutant library of microalgae is for C. reinhardtii its whole genomic sequence was well-studied and released in 2007 the genome-scale network was constructed afterward Gomes de Oliveira Dal Molin et al. 2011 . The genome sequence supported gene design molecular toolkits development and reconstruction of genome-scale networks Hlavova et al. 2015 . The chloroplast genome of C. vulgaris had been already sequenced in 1997 and the annotation of genes pro vides more opportunities to access genetic and metabolic engineering Cecchin et al. 2019 . Guided by a holistic biological perspective syn thetic biology can certainly realize the modification and optimization of microalgal carbon sequestration. For instance in addition to the above three ways the efficiency of carbon sequestration can be further improved by enhancing the flow of carbon skeleton to specific target products rather than to the underlying metabolites. However the maturation of this discipline requires the discovery of genome-wide and metabolic information of more algae species. Genetic engineering now receives close attention due to the widely available of new powerful genetic tools the genome can now be edited more precisely than ever before to meet our needs. Despite its time and cost input genetic engineering remains the primary tool for strain improvement. In particular the development of more carbon fixation pathways deserves attention as a promising approach to ideal microalgal strains with robust CO2 assimilation phenotypes for sustainable large- scale carbon-fixation biorefinery. 4. Advancements in process regulation for reinforcing carbon sequestration In real-time scenarios bred microalgae have photosynthetic and carbon sequestration efficiencies that usually do not match their esti mated values despite their excellent theoretical CO2 fixation rate. The comprehensive enhancement of CO2 fixation requires not only micro algae with high CO2 assimilation capability after screening and modi fication but also suitable cultivation conditions including nutrients light temperature pH salinity and PBR configuration that are directly linked to CO2 concentration and flow rate. Considerable advancements in process regulation approaches for reinforcing microalgal carbon sequestration have been achieved over several decades of research and discussion. 4.1. Photobioreactor design for enhancing CO2 dissolution CO2 is the prominent element for microalgal growth and fixation. The comprehensive enhancement of CO2 fixation requires not only the high CO2 assimilation capability of microalgae after screening and modification but also sufficient carbon availability in the microalgal suspension. Sufficient carbon availability could be realized by the careful design of cultivation configurations. Large-scale industrial photosynthetic carbon sequestration is commonly conducted in PBRs which are responsible for maintaining suitable environmental conditions particularly CO2 and light levels for microalgal growth and carbon sequestration. CO2-enriched gas is injected into the microalgal suspension through gas aerators. CO2 molecules are captured by microalgae only after they cross the gas liquid interface and dissolve in the medium. Therefore appropriate Ci solubility in the microalgal sus pension is essential for strengthening carbon availability and overall fixation efficiency. Among dissolution characteristics CO2 diffusivity and solubility are synergistically affected by factors including but not limited to the CO2 volume fraction concentration mass transfer coefficient MTC gas liquid contact area bubble diameter retention time and PBR structure Olsen et al. 2017 . Blindly increasing CO2 concentration might cause the acidification of the culture medium and should be prudently used Fu et al. 2019 . As shown in Table 2 scientists now enhance Ci availability via gas aerator retrofitting and PBR installation. The CO2 bubble diameter gas retention time and gas liquid contact area mainly depend on the structure of the gas aerator which injects CO2 gas into the microalgal suspension Cheng et al. 2018 . Multipore rubber pipes are the most common aerators in commercial CO2 fixation refineries owing to their simple structure and aeration reliability Xia et al. 2018 . However they cannot provide a sufficiently small bubble diameter and cannot ensure the vertically uniform distribution of bub bles due to their longitudinal pressure drop. Plate aerators with round stomata are suitable for cylindrical PBRs and provide more stable and uniform bubble diameters larger gas liquid contact area and higher CO2 MTC up to 11.72 h 1 than multipore rubber pipes Huang et al. 2017 . A newly designed 3D-printed fibrous diaphragm aerator with micropores can realize uniform gas distribution thereby improving CO2 MTC by 40 Cheng et al. 2019b . However such an excessively small pore diameter requires high driving pressure thus increasing the energy cost of gas diffusion. The energy input problem was solved through the construction of a magnet-driven aerator. This installation produced bubbles with diameters as small as 2.0 mm and an average rising rate of 0.22 m s 1 Li et al. 2022b . While most designers opt to reduce the outlet diameter of gas aerators to achieve the ideal CO2 bubble diameter the pore blockage increase in manufacturing cost and shortened service life accompanying this choice are issues that need to be taken into account. A promising approach is to design additional functional PBR struc tures to enhance the two-phase flow of CO2 without sacrificing the service life of the aerator. For example optimizing the gas flow channel structure can prolong the gas retention time and changing the gas hy drodynamic behavior can help break bubbles into small ones Huang et al. 2017 . A CO2 dissolver was designed to prolong bubble retention time by inducing the spiral-ascending flow trajectory of CO2 bubbles within horizontal tubular PBRs Xu et al. 2020 . However the helical baffles and other complex internals utilized in PBRs increase operational complexity and manufacturing cost and can easily cause microalgal cell adhesion largely limiting CO2 dissolution in large-scale applications Sirohi et al. 2022 . Given the damage caused by shear force to microalgal cell walls the streamlined design of gas channels with reduced shear force strength was taken into consideration. Combining alkaline absorbents with membrane modules in PBRs can also enhance the MTC of CO2. The former alleviates excess acidity and filters toxic compounds and the latter offers a large gas liquid contact area. Zheng et al. 2016 designed a polydimethyl siloxane hollow fiber membrane that directly delivered CO2 molecules absorbed in K2CO3 solvent to the microalgal suspension. Although the utilization rate in this system exceeded 90 microalgal cells easily blocked the fiber mem branes. An optimized medium in a PBR with 0.01 mmol L 1 zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 nanoparticles was proposed and was found to increase the CO2 MTC to 3.85 and elevated carbon fixation rate by 25.5 relative to the bare case Xu et al. 2021 . However the utilization of absorbents causes potential environmental risks and the mismatch be tween the rates of cell CO2 consumption and CO2 adsorption complicates efficient absorbent recycling thus restricting its applications in practical Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 10 scenarios. Prolonging the bubble retention time is another solution to inade quate Ci dissolution. The retention time is affected by the rising pathway and velocity of bubbles. Most studies in recent decades have tended to place the aerator at the bottom of PBRs or the open ponds to prolong the bubble rising path and retention time the highest carbon fixation effi ciency obtained through this approach could reach 56 Fu et al. 2019 . Alteration into a closed raceway pond further increased carbon fixation efficiency which reached the record of 95 under intermittent operation 10 s 10 s . Several closed PBRs for prolonging retention time have been newly constructed. Ye et al. 2018 designed an airlift column PBR equipped with a string lantern-shaped draft tube which had a bent shape that extended the rising path of CO2 bubbles. Generally speaking these approaches have the common shortcoming of exorbitant aeration costs owing to the involvement of an airlift-driven PBR or a raceway pond with supersized volume. Microbubbles refer to bubbles with a diameter of 20 C leads to the low solubility of CO2 in micro algal suspensions thus directly limiting Ci uptake availability. From a biochemical standpoint temperature participates in regulating cyto plasmic viscosity enzymatic activity protein uptake affinities and a series of metabolic processes. Low temperature could inhibit the affinity of RuBisCo to CO2 and decrease photosynthesis and biosequestration rates by over 30 Zeng et al. 2011 . An early review emphasized that although the common temperature range for microalgal culture is 15 C 30 C with optimal values at 20 C 25 C the optimal operating temperature is strain- and environment-dependent and requires targeted investigation therefore a general industry standard cannot be easily provided Ras et al. 2013 . For example Heo et al. 2015 found that the optimal temperature for CO2 sequestration in Parachlorella sp. cultivated in ambient air was 30 C but decreased to 24 C 25 C with CO2 injection. The influence of pH on carbon sequestration efficiency is derived from its regulation of dissolved Ci species CO2 HCO3 and CO3 2 microalgal CCM system performance and RuBisCo catalytic activity. Under alkaline conditions pH 9 11 Ci prevalently exists in various carbonate forms among which HCO3 is bioaccessible to microalgal uptake transporters. Meanwhile the rise in pH was assumed to result in the increase in the activity of photosynthesis-related enzymes such as extracellular CAs which further stimulated CCM function efficiency Kassim and Meng 2017 . The greater selectivity of RuBisCo for CO2 instead of O2 at the pH of 7.5 results in excellent carboxylase activity and HCO3 uptake consumes less energy when the pH is further increased to 8.5 Veaudor et al. 2020 . The pH optima and tolerance are species- dependent. Normally microalgae are cultured under neutral-to-slightly alkaline conditions pH 6 8.3 but some organisms prefer extreme conditions Morales et al. 2018 . Spirulina grows and accumulates neutral lipids under highly alkaline conditions pH 9 11 whereas acidic conditions are suitable for the growth of Ochromonas sp. Chlamydomonas acidophila Euglena mutabilis and some filamentous algae Novis and Harding 2007 . Furthermore pH varies in relation to Ci dissolution conversion and uptake. Microalgal CO2 uptake and photosynthesis can promote the increase in pH owing to the release of hydroxyl ions OH during the conversion of HCO3 into CO2 by CAs Shiraiwa et al. 1993 . When using flue gases as the CO2 source the dissolution of acidic chemicals such as SO2 or NOx contributes to the reduction in pH value Morales et al. 2018 . Consequently pH control is critical for microalgal carbon fixation culture. Although the adoption of buffers or neutralizing agents is feasible the design of CO2 injection strategies is a more economic approach. 4.3.2. Medium composition The culture medium whether specially formulated or recovered from inexpensive bioresources offers abundant nutrients to algal cells and makes effect on stimulating CO2 fixation. The major essential components include nitrogen phosphorus cyanocobalamin vitamins biotin and diverse metals Table 4 . An adequate supply of nitrogen as the second major component of microalgal growth guarantees the primary metabolite production and cell growth of microalgae Ma et al. 2020 . Inadequate nitrogen supply limits chlorophyll biosynthesis badly affecting photosynthesis. How ever given that high concentrations of nitrogen especially NH4 + might be toxic to cells the appropriate selection of the nitrogen source and concentration is a necessary task Razzak et al. 2017 . The carbon ni trogen ratio is another important issue. Bilanovic et al. 2009 proposed that the maximal biomass production and carbon fixation rate of freshwater algae was observed at the nitrogen concentration of 285 427 mgN L 1 and CO2 concentration of 70 . Phosphorus is significantly associated with photophosphorylation and energy transport because it is an indispensable component of ATP phospholipids and the proteins involved in photosynthesis especially Table 4 Nutrient composition functions in microalgae Zeng et al. 2011 . Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 13 RuBisCo Wang et al. 2008 . Although many studies have proven that nitrogen or phosphorus limitation stimulates the storage of compounds with high energy content it limits the specific CO2 capture rate. Furthermore the appropriate supply rate of nitrogen and phosphorus concentrations N P greatly influences microalgal growth. Fu et al. 2016 constructed a novel PBR with anion exchange membranes to control the stability of N P ratio. Nitrogen and phosphorus are the nu trients most readily available from low-cost substrates a vary of in dustrial by-products and wastewater were utilized as inexpensive medium. Ermis et al. 2022 used anaerobic liquid digestate to grow microalgae from Diphylleia Synechocystis Cyanobium and Chlorella species and their polyunsaturated fatty acids contents were found increased significantly which was explained by a beneficial response to extreme conditions. Metals such as iron magnesium calcium and copper are consid ered to be indispensable for maintaining cellular metabolism and functions in microalgae Gallo et al. 2020 . Iron is an essential nutrient in all photosynthetic organisms. It participates in nitrogen fixation DNA synthesis respiration and most importantly the fundamental enzy matic reactions of photosynthesis Sajjadi et al. 2018 . Mg2+ is a structural component of chlorophyll molecules and its level affects the in vivo activity of acetyl-CoA carboxylase and the PYR dehydrogenase complex which directly regulate central carbon metabolism Volgush eva et al. 2015 . Calcium participates in the signal transduction of environmental stimuli and intracellular Ca2+ levels can mediate lipid biosynthesis Sajjadi et al. 2018 . Copper participates in signal trans duction as an element of photosynthetic electron transport proteins and induces the overexpression of antioxidant enzymes that catalyze the synthesis and storage of carbon metabolites Guo et al. 2021 . All the metals mentioned above can be recovered from industrial wastewater at low cost as an effective way to simultaneously treat wastewater pollu tion. Although heavy metals such as cadmium chromium lead mer cury and arsenic could impair photosynthesis and inhibit enzyme activity some previous studies have emphasized their potential to stimulate microalgal carbon sequestration You et al. 2022 . Le on-Vaz et al. 2021 proposed that in C. sorokiniana cadmium leads to the upregulation of photosynthetic metabolism and antioxidant reactions. Microalgae can bioremediate heavy metals by converting them into specific complexes such a capability is a very competitive feature in wastewater treatment industry. Supplying phytohormones among which indole-3-acetic acid has an outstanding effect at low concentrations 10 8 10 5 mol L 1 can also improve CO2 fixation and promote microalgal growth rates Chen et al. 2023 . The effects of phytohormones on microalgae are specific to species and strains. For example Chlorella sp. displays the most signif icant regulation by phytohormones. Generally the investigation of the contributions of phytohormones to microalgal carbon sequestration is accompanied by the optimization of light conditions and nitrogen sources. In conclusion medium formulation plays a decisive role in micro algal growth rates and productivity and has an important role in large- scale industrial carbon sequestration. An ideal nutrition formulation should take into account carbon sequestration efficiency operational difficulty economic costs and potential environmental risks and sub stantial efforts should be made to develop waste and by-products to offer inexpensive nutrients. 5. Sustainable microalgal biorefinery While achieving efficient carbon sequestration microalgae bio refinery is also encouraged as the powerful supplier of bioenergy and multiple bioproducts for human society and production Sun et al. 2021 . An appreciate end-product export of microalgae biorefinery is also essential for enhancing its economic benefit and finally forming a complete commercial chain. Governments of various countries have shown positive support for microalgae biorefineries in 2022 China has 150 related microalgae companies while Europe has about 480 and the US has many more. This section summarized the beneficial micro algal biorefinery products that extensively participate in human life Fig. 5 and the latest research progress of the approaches for improving output value. 5.1. Microalgal biorefinery for energy supply The exploitation of bioenergy has entered the limelight as a prom ising solution to dealing with CO2 excess emission and the energy crisis. China the European Union EU and the US have all introduced policies to encourage the usage of bioenergy and China implements a policy of excise tax exemption and 70 Value-added Tax VAT return for bio diesels that meet national standards. Microalgal biorefineries can harness solar energy to fix CO2 as organic energy materials in forms of biodiesel bioalcohol biochar biohydrogen and biogas or generate electricity via photosynthesis riding into the forefront of sustainable bioenergy resources Tanvir et al. 2021 . 5.1.1. Liquid biofuels Microalgae commonly used in carbon sequestration such as Chlor ella and Chlamydomonas display remarkable lipid and carbohydrate contents and have sparked wide interest as promising biodiesel and bioalcohol sources. Biodiesel has highly similar physical and chemical properties as crude oil-derived diesel Rodionova et al. 2017 . Microalgal refineries can deliver lipid-rich biomass as the novel substrate for biodiesel pro duction with strong commercial competitiveness Voloshin et al. 2016 . Strains from Chlorella Scenedesmus Chlamydomonas and Nanno chloropsis are favored for biodiesel production because of their high lipid contents Ho et al. 2014 . N. salina was indicated to have a lipid content up to 50 of its DW. In terms of energy efficiency the net energy ratio NER of N. salina biodiesel was calculated to be 0.93 megajoule MJ of energy consumed per MJ of energy produced expressed as MJ MJ . This indicated that N. salina biodiesel required approximately 30 less energy input per unit of product compared to soybean-based biodiesel Tanvir et al. 2021 . A number of studies have been devoted to species improvement and culture strategy intensification to enhance biodiesel production. Inhibiting the activity of ADP glucose pyrophosphorylase elevated triacylglycerol production by 10-fold Tanvir et al. 2021 . Mutant Thalassiosira pseudonana with lipase phospholipase acyl transferase knockout exhibited a 3-fold higher lipid productivity than the wild type Trentacoste et al. 2013 . In process regulation nitrogen stress and high initial iron concentrations are beneficial to increase lipid content. In a practice case regulating nitrogen-limitation severity was effective to induce triacylglycerol accumulation Rai et al. 2021 . The team of National Renewable Energy Lab of the US found that the NER of Galdieria sulphuraria cultured in photobioreactor and covered pond systems were respectively 2.21 and 0.25 MJ MJ and displayed global warming potential of 339 and 9.1 g CO2-eq. MJ 1 on a well-to-wheels basis Somers et al. 2021 . Nonetheless the production cost of micro algal biodiesel 1.19 L 1 was 2.42-fold higher than that of petrodiesel mainly attributed to extracting technologies involving energy-intensive methods Wu et al. 2022 . Microalgal-derived low-cost alcohol shows outstanding fuel quality and heating values 19.6 MJ L 1 for bioethanol and 29.2 MJ L 1 for biobutanol while consuming less energy for production than biodiesel Chen et al. 2015 . Ideal bioalcohol substrates especially Spirulina Chlorella Scenedesmus Chlorococcum Chlamydomonas and Porphyridium species have impressive carbohydrates accumulating capacity particu larly glycogen for cyanobacteria and starch for eukaryotic algae John et al. 2011 . For example C. vulgaris can afford 40 w w ethanol productivity on the basis of its biomass Lee et al. 2011 . With algal biomass as the fermentation substrate bacteria or sepa rate enzymes are employed for bioethanol or biobutanol generation. For example Chlorococcum infusionum biomass was utilized by the Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 14 hydrolytic reagent NaOH. The biomass was then subjected to fermen tation using Saccharomyces cerevisiae resulting in a bioethanol yield of 26.1 g ethanol g biomass Tanvir et al. 2021 . Similarly biobutanol synthesis can occur via acetone butanol ethanol fermentation by sac charolytic butyric acid-producing microorganisms Abomohra and Elshobary 2019 . To increase energy efficiency a direct bioethanol synthesis pathway can be established in microalgae by gene cloning technique. Dexter and Fu 2009 integrated the PDHC and alcohol de hydrogenase II genes from Zymomonas mobilis to transform Synechocystis sp. and found that the created Synechocystis PCC 6803 strain displayed enhanced carbon utilization and unprecedented self-production capa bility for bioethanol. Scientists also proposed a strategy to produce biodiesel and bioethanol simultaneously from the biomass of Saccharo myces bayanus in which lipids and carbohydrates were divided before fermentation Harun et al. 2010 . On the other hand the major draw back of bioethanol industry is the by-production of CO2 which obvi ously decreases the overall carbon sequestration efficiency. 5.1.2. Gaseous biofuels Fresh or lipid-extracted microalgal biomass can be utilized for gaseous biofuel production. Hydrogen H2 gas is distinguished by its renewability pollution-free combustion product only water and heating value of up to 142 MJ kg 1 or 10.1 MJ L 1 when liquefied Khetkorn et al. 2017 . During photosynthesis microalgae release H2 via direct Eq. 3 or indirect biophotolysis Eqs. 4 5 and the latter is mediated by nitrogenase-based systems Junior et al. 2020 Klinthong et al. 2015 . Botryococcus Chlamydomonas Chlorococcum Chlorella Scenedesmus Nostoc and Anabaena are the star producers in biohydrogen factory and the last two species also exhibit nitrogen-fixing capacity Eroglu and Melis 2011 Khanna et al. 2016 . Anaerobe fermentation can also be established to produce biohydrogen from microalgal biomass enriched with carbohydrates. The employed anaerobes such as Clos tridiaceae and Enterobactericeae light-independently synthesize hydrogen from glucose starch or arabinose Ardo et al. 2022 Walig orska 2012 . 2H20 + Light O2 + Fd reduced + 4e Fd oxidezed + 2H2 3 6H2O + 6CO2 + Light C6H12O6 + 6O2 4 C6H12O6 + 2H2O 4H2 + 2CH3COOH + 2CO2 5 Various biotechnology approaches have been used to improve hydrogen production. For example the hydrogen-uptake hydrogenase of nitrogen-fixing cyanobacteria was inactivated to improve net H2 productivity Khetkorn et al. 2017 . The redirection of electrons to the hydrogenase enzyme could elevate hydrogen productivity by 5-fold Rumpel et al. 2014 . The C. reinhardtii tla1 strain CC-4169 with a truncated light-harvesting antenna showed 4 6 times higher H2 output than its parental strain Kosourov et al. 2011 . In consideration of the extreme O2 sensitivity of hydrogenase sulfur-deprivation stress was applied to increase respiration rates to reduce oxygen sensitivity Shuba and Kifle 2018 . Microalgal immobilization for example immobiliza tion using alginate films could enhance hydrogen production by restricting O2 diffusion into the matrix Nagarajan et al. 2017 . Despite its sufficient theoretical feasibility the commercial applica tion of biophotolysis is still in a rather early research state and holds low technology readiness level. The use of expensive equipment and com plex processes to achieve the best productivity has been proposed but will undoubtedly increase operating costs. Even under optimal condi tions biohydrogen production costs 3 6 USD kg 1 whereas traditional methane gas production only costs 1 USD kg 1 Kosourov et al. 2011 . Biogas is a renewable energy source highly accord with carbon emission reduction principle. When combusted methane the main component of biogas releases 21-fold higher heat energy than CO2. The first attempt at obtaining microalgae-derived biogas dates back to the early 1950s when scientists found that residual microalgal biomass for lipid extraction could be utilized for methane production through anaerobic digestion Baicha et al. 2016 . Microalgae provided 7 13 higher methane yield than corn the typical source of biogas Zabed et al. 2020 . Biogas factories require microalgae with high growth rates thin cell walls high environmental adaptability and sufficient cyto plasmic components as digestion substrates Tijani et al. 2015 . Strains of Chlamydomonas Synechococcus Dunaliella Euglena Spirulina platensis and cyanobacterium A. platensis showed great biogas yields Baicha et al. 2016 . Strain screening biomass pretreatment and digestion condition regulation technologies affect biogas production to a large extent Zabed et al. 2020 . Although numerous studies have been carried out to optimize biogas yield and total carbon fixation contribution biogas production remains at the pilot-scale step and its commercialization is yet to be exploited Su et al. 2017 . Its major drawback is the expensive Fig. 5. Sustainable microalgae biorefinery participates in net zero carbon cycle. Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 15 biomass harvesting dewatering and concentration costs. The eco nomics and energy consumption of the latest optimized recovery methods remain unaffordable. Additionally given that this biotech nology is generally combined with industrial wastewater treatment its potential nutrient limitation and toxic risk cannot be neglected Zabed et al. 2020 . 5.1.3. Solid biofuels Given that microalgae-derived biological liquid and fuels involve complex downstream stages that cannot avoid CO2 emissions and energy expenditure microalgal bioenergy production for carbon neutrality is now shifting to another field direct biomass combustion Clarens et al. 2011 . The use of Scenedesmus sp. Oscillatoria sp. Stigonematales sp. Rhizoclonium spp. or C. vulgaris biomass as solid biofuels has been recognized as a simple method for obtaining high utilization efficiency with low net CO2 emissions Yang et al. 2022 . This technology directly simplifies the downstream processes associated with carbon re- emissions and shows great potential in terms of energy and carbon emission reduction Choi et al. 2019 . 5.1.4. Microbial fuel cells Since the early 1990s microbial fuel cell MFC devices have received algologists attention because of their simultaneous efficient energy production and wastewater treatment capacities. In contrast to other bioenergy technologies fuel cells offer direct and reliable energy production by avoiding the combustion process and do not require additional energy sources or expensive feedstock storage and exert a low pollution impact Sarathi and Nahm 2013 . Under light illumination microalgal organisms can be used as substrates at the anode to capture the CO2 generated at the cathode and transform the chemical energy of organic matter in wastewater into electricity via photosynthesis Walter et al. 2015 . Meanwhile phototrophic microalgae at the cathode can contribute to oxygen production and capture generated CO2 as carbon sources. Many advances have been achieved in terms of new materials chamber design low-cost catalysts and substrates to reduce the oper ating costs and expand the application range of MFCs. An MFC con structed with S. cerevisiae in its anodic chamber and C. vulgaris in its cathode can utilize the CO2 generated in the cathode for algal growth and finally produce 2.7 mW m 2 cathode energy Baicha et al. 2016 . Similar to biophotolysis the research depth of MFC is rather immature. As a result of the novel advancements in biorefinery techniques carbon-fixing microalgae have become desirable substrates for a clean and renewable bioenergy supply. However the comprehensive planning and evaluation of specific production strategies are needed before formal commercialization to identify their commercial viability and environmental and economic benefits. Many factors should be consid ered if the optimal productivity of microalgal-based biofuels is required. In general the future prospects of microalgae-based biofuels mainly depend on advancements in the field of genetic engineering. 5.2. Microalgal refinery for high-value products Microalgal cells accumulate abundant bioactive compounds through carbon sequestration and assimilation. This capacity endows microalgal refineries with positive capacity to become the source of value-added products in the fields of food nutritient supply medicine agriculture chemistry and cosmetics. Some of the major applied species include Spirulina Chlorella Dunaliella and Isochrysis. 5.2.1. Health-care products Carbon fixed in microalgal biomass exists in the forms of diverse bio- compounds which have all been deeply excavated for their biological activities and physiological effects including antioxidant anticancer neuroprotective immunity boosting and adjuvant therapeutic effects in multiple diseases Halperin-Sternfeld et al. 2022 . The addition of these bioactive compounds to food dietary supplements or even medicine for their potential health benefits is desired by the public. China the US and the EU have established strict management regulations and execution standards for food additives or nutrient supplements from conventional microalgae species including Chlorella Spirulina Dunaliella Nanno chloropsis Aphanizomenon and Nostoc. For example the approval and usage of microalgal extracts as new resource foods and additives are subject to the New Resource Food Approval Regulation EU 2015 2283 and the New Resource Food Regulation EU 2018 102 in the EU. The protein and essential amino acid contents of microalgae have been reported to be similar to those of animal-based sources. Chaeto ceros Anabaena Chlorella Dunaliella Scenedesmus and Synechococcus sp. show excellent protein content and quality Becker 2013 . Micro algal proteins with abundant health benefits can be processed into intact cells protein concentrates hydrolysates or bioactive peptides and added to food or pharmaceutical products Soto-Sierra et al. 2018 . Carbohydrates are the main products of photosynthesis. Strains from Porphyridium Isochrysis Dunaliella salina and Spirogyra sp. have particularly prominent carbohydrate contents Rizwan et al. 2018 . Polysaccharides from Dunaliella Haematococcus Porphyridium Chlorella and Spirulina exhibit antioxidant immunomodulatory antitumor hypolipidemic antiasthmatic and anticoagulant properties Colusse et al. 2022 . Algologists have also become aware of the potential of microalgae polysaccharides as prebiotic compounds Camacho et al. 2019 . Under certain culture conditions high C N ratios temperatures or salinity levels or nitrogen starvation microalgae can accumulate a considerable amount of lipids approximately 30 50 of their DW . Microalgae have long been recognized as a suitable alternative producer of essential fatty acids especially docosahexaenoic acid DHA and eicosatetraenoic acid EPA which is a critical bioactive nutrient endowed with multiple health benefits Mason et al. 2020 . The EPA- and DHA-enriched alga Nannochloropsis oculata has been applied in the pharmaceutical field on a large scale by Aurora Algae of the US Liu et al. 2022 . Crypthecodinium Tetraselmis Isochrysis Thalassiosira Nannochloropsis and Ulkenia sp. are also suitable for competitive in dustrial DHA production Suganya et al. 2016 . Natural pigments which are synthesized and accumulated in cells are major participants in microalgal photosynthesis and oxidative stress regulation. Carotenoids have strong antioxidant and colorant ability and have maintained a high market price over several decades Yusof et al. 2022 . β-Carotene and astaxanthin currently the carotenoids with the greatest market preference display outstanding free radical scavenging ability and are now industrially produced on a large scale by the microalgae D. salina and H. pluvialis respectively Sun et al. 2023 . Lutein is another carotenoid that offers multiple health benefits and is produced in abundance from Chlorella Parachlorella Scenedesmus and Auxenochlorella Zheng et al. 2022 . Chlorophyll is the necessary pigment in most photosynthetic microalgal organism it is recommended as a by-product of multiproduct biorefinery and the chlorophyll- extracted biomass can be further used for pigment-free protein pro duction. Phycobiliproteins PBPs are the major light-harvesting element of cyanobacterial photosynthesis and are maturely developed as commercial colorants and functional health-food addictive Li et al. 2019 . Spirulina is the main source of commercial phycocyanin a PBP worth at least 250 USD kg 1 and is most likely to be commercialized in the near future. Other PBPs can be extracted from Spirulina Synecho coccus and Nostoc sp. Some microalgal species can be natural sources of vitamins phenols phytosterols and other bioactive substances that are usually present at small amounts. Some researchers optimistically believe that microalgae can perform better as natural sources of bioavailable vitamins than terrestrial plants this situation represents another promising direction for microalgal application in health-related industries Del Mondo et al. 2020 . The common vitamins and vitamin precursors obtained from microalgae include α- β- and γ-tocopherols ascorbic acid and ribo flavin. The production of microalgae-derived essential vitamins is Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 16 associated with the sources concentrations and availability of nitrogen during cultivation Bonnet et al. 2010 . Phytosterol which has multiple recognized health benefits has been widely used in the health industry. Although the investigation of microalgal phytosterols is still in its in fancy microalgal phytosterols are believed to possess great potential as a functional food supplement in accordance with previously reported information. Spirulina sp. was reported to produce clionasterol which aids cardiovascular disease prevention Barrow and Shahidi 2007 . Phenolic compounds are secondary metabolites with clear biological activities and microalgae have been found to be rich in phenolic com pounds and considered as a promising natural source of these com pounds Del Mondo et al. 2021 Levasseur et al. 2020 . However current research on these substances is insufficient and the market de mand for these compounds is far less than that for mainstream bioactive substances. Nevertheless their natural production by microalgae is still regarded as a promising project worthy of investment. In summary the biological activities of the above high-value com pounds from microalgae have been explicitly confirmed and their future application as health-care products is positively expected. Nevertheless caution should be taken because the high biosafety and stability demanded of these bioproducts require precise and possibly energy- intensive production processes. On the other hand relevant regula tions and standards for health products derived from more microalgae strains need to be established and improved. 5.2.2. Agriculture Given that some microalgal refineries choose open culture systems and simple biomass harvesting methods to control production costs their products generally exhibit quality that is insufficient to meet market regulatory requirements for food or other health products despite their high nutrient contents. In this context these biomass products which are mostly in the form intact dried cells are often used as aquatic or animal feeds to transfer high-value nutrients indirectly to human bodies through the food chain. Chinese government actively encourages and supports the development of new plant-based feed proteins including microalgae. At present six kinds of algae and their processed products have been listed in China s feed raw materials cat alog including Schizochytrium Spirulina Nannochloropsis Chlorella Euglena and H. pluvialis. Microalgae are one of the important nutrient providers in the food chain of aquaculture animals and is decisive for the growth and external appearance of aquaculture animals Rizwan et al. 2018 . Microalgae especially Chlorella Tetraselmis Isochrysis Pavlova Phaeodactylum Nannochloropsis and Thalassiosira sp. are widely used as feeds or ad ditives for freshwater and marine aquatic animals Apt and Behrens 1999 Rizwan et al. 2018 . Brightly colored D. salina Spirulina and H. pluvialis are used as feed additives and natural pigments for culturing salmonid fish prawns and ornamental fish. Microalgae can also improve the breeding stability and immune systems of fish Pulz and Gross 2004 . Some zooplankton such as brine shrimp cladocerans and rotifers are farmed as the food sources of crustaceans and fish and microalgal biomass can also be utilized as fish and crustacean feed Borowitzka 1997 . Algologists have confirmed the capability of microalgae to be used as animal feed supplements. Poultry feed can be supplemented with 5 10 microalgae as a protein source. Worldwide 30 of current microalgal biomass products are used as animal feed or supplements Rizwan et al. 2018 . For example S. platensis and Chlorella pyrenoidosa as feed supplements for cows were found to significantly improve the rumen performance and microbial protein production Desmosdesmus sp. as a feed additive in chicken ration increased body weight and feed ef ficiency while decreasing feed intake Almomani et al. 2023 . Over 50 of cultured Arthrospira is used as feed for farmed animals ornamental birds and pets to support healthy development. Similar to crop biomass microalgal biomass can be converted into biochar via pyrolysis. In addition to being used as a carbon-negative bioenergy product biochar can be adopted as a high-quality bio fertilizer such an approach is also recognized as an ideal carbon sequestration solution Marris 2006 . As a biofertilizer source blue- green algae can improve crop yield and protein content provide nitro gen nutrient and thereby reduce fertilizer usage. Furthermore when used as soil conditioners microalgae improve soil physicochemical properties including pH electrical conductivity and residual soil ni trogen and carbon contents Rizwan et al. 2018 . The microalgal genera Aulosira Anabaena Nostoc and Tolypothrix are used for paddy crop farming because they fix atmospheric nitrogen into organic forms. Scientists believe that the techniques for microalgal feed and bio fertilizer production are sufficiently simple and adaptable to commercial-scale bulk production and that the agricultural market is suitable for generating additional income for microalgal carbon-fixing factories. 5.2.3. Bioplastics Algologists have discovered another application for microalgal biomass generated from carbon-fixing cultivation it can be used to produce biological materials instead of channeled into the food chain. Bioplastics the most common biomaterials can be synthesized from lipids protein or carbohydrates thus implying the application potential of microalgal organisms Laurens et al. 2017 . In the commercial-scale production of different bioplastics the microalgae Spirulina Nostoc Oscillatoria Synechocystis and Calothrix are recommended for poly hydroxyalkanoate PHA production while Chlorella sp. Scenedesmus sp. and Synechococcus sp. with considerable carbohydrate content are better for polylactic acid PLA production than other microalgal species Zhang et al. 2019 . The yield of these PHA and PLA products is often enhanced under nutrient-limiting culture conditions. For example Nostoc muscorum Agardh Nostocaceae was reported with a PHA pro duction yield of 69 under phosphate-limited conditions Bhati and Mallick 2015 . Recently genetic modification has also been proposed to induce bioplastic production. In a practical case the poly hydroxybutyrate yield of Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 overexpressing native biosynthetic genes was 2.6-fold higher than that of the wild type 10 of DW Khetkorn et al. 2016 . When considering all the recent advances in microalgal applications one undoubtable perspective that can be found is that extracting valu able compounds from microalgal biomass is an attractive field in line with the concept of sustainable development. Its ecological and eco nomic profits have been increased to a degree that cannot be ignored in the microalgal carbon sequestration field and are attracting the interest of numerous scholars for further optimization and commercialization. 5.3. Microalgal refinery for environmental mitigation and remediation Another exigent contribution of microalgal refinery to the global ecological construction is the wastewater and flue gas purification ca pacity. In this process microalgae use residual organic compounds for growth and biomolecule synthesis. This situation not only decreases the cost demand of cultivation but also provides the possibility of a profit able atmospheric and water remediation approach. 5.3.1. Wastewater remediation systems Municipal agricultural livestock rearing and industrial wastewa ters are enriched with a variety of nutrient components and have been demonstrated to be nontoxic and safe substrates for microalgal biomass production Ahmad et al. 2017 . Microalgal wastewater purification is based on three different mechanisms biosorption bioaccumulation and biodegradation. Living or dead algal cells can biosorb contaminants which often are often present in wastewater enriched with heavy metals or pharmaceuticals Hena et al. 2021 . The former usually employs strains of Chlamydo monas Chlorella Scenedesmus Nannochloropsis and Parachlorella whereas the latter involves Scenedesmus Chlorella Chlamydomonas and Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 17 Mychonastes sp. Bhatt et al. 2022 Hena et al. 2021 Spain et al. 2021 . The bioaccumulation of microalgal cells is mainly used to remove heavy metals pesticides phosphates and nitrates from wastewaters and is particularly suitable for decreasing agricultural pollutant load. The accumulated compounds are later retained or metabolized by cells Mustafa et al. 2021 . Microalgae can remove toxic organic pollutants by degrading them into simple non-noxious substances. The related technology involving Chlorella Scenedesmus Aphanocapsa Chlamydo monas and Nannochloropsis species has been adopted in the treatment of oil wastes pyrene phenol and lindane in wastewaters from petroleum refineries and heavy industries Touliabah et al. 2022 . Algal strain selection should be contingent on the wastewater source. Generally indigenous microalgae screened from original wastewater often display great pollutant removal capability and environmental adaptability Jeong and Jang 2020 . Several strains of Chlorella Acu todesmus and Desmodesmus sp. have been cultured in municipal waste water and demonstrated successful nitrogen and phosphorous removal along with lipid-rich biomass production Lage et al. 2021 Purba et al. 2022 Zhao et al. 2018 . For example Chlorella sp. could remove total phosphorus total nitrogen and ammonia in wastewater by 80.9 89.1 and 93.9 respectively Almomani et al. 2023 . Furthermore mixing categories of municipal wastewater is recom mended to balance nutrient concentrations and ratios You et al. 2022 . Wastewaters from agricultural applications especially livestock rearing contain fertilizers residual feeds and feces providing abundant pro teins fats nitrogen ammonia potassium and phosphorous for feasible microalgal growth Zhao et al. 2022 . A previous study used wastewater from a palm oil mill as the medium for Chlorella growth and reported a reduction of 80.9 in nitrogen content and efficient CO2 capture Hariz et al. 2018 . In another case C. vulgaris was cultured in poultry wastewater wherein lipid-rich biomass was produced along with the removal of 95 of the chemical oxygen demand COD Guti errez- Casiano et al. 2022 . In the industry microalgae have been applied to treat textile pharmaceutical petroleum refinery and food manufacturing effluents. C. vulgaris successfully removed 76.23 of the COD of textile wastewater and simultaneously solved the problem of intractable decolorization e.g. 98 removal of methylene blue Fazal et al. 2021 . Petroleum refinery effluent usually contains a variety of metals and organic compounds and has been remediated through the biomass accumulation of Scenedesmus and Spongiochloris species Chen et al. 2021 . Dairy wastewater which contains lactose proteins and lipids has been commonly employed for microalgal cultivation mainly involving strains of Chlorella Scenedesmus Acutodesmus Chloromonas and Desmodesmus Costa et al. 2021 Goveas et al. 2022 Kusmayadi et al. 2022 . As highlighted by algologists microalgal-mediated wastewater treatment deserves vigorous promotion because it represents an important approach for executing the principles of circular bioeconomy while synchronously saving the operating cost of microalgal cultivation. However this technology requires the comprehensive consideration of microalgal remediation efficiency and the potential harmful factors for microalgal growth. Moreover the complex effects of the micro alga bacterium symbiotic system cannot be ignored. 5.3.2. Flue gas circulation system Similar to wastewater treatment microalgal refineries can also be supplied by CO2-rich flue gases to achieve the dual purpose of cultiva tion cost reduction and cyclic carbon source utilization. Flue gas is emanated by industrial combustion facilities. It contains combustion products and residual substances with numerous adverse effects on human health. The efficient and harmless treatment of flue gases is eagerly desired as a component of national environmental protection programs. Over the past few years microalgal refineries with flue gas aeration have been actively introduced into bioenergy industries all over the world. For example a company in Israel has used microalgal refineries to culture the phototrophic microalgal species of Phaeodactylum Duna liella Chlorococcum Tetraselmis and Nannochloris for bioethanol bio diesel and omega-3 FA production Gotovtsev et al. 2019 . Many studies have confirmed that the presence of SOx and NOx from unfil tered coal-fired flue gas might exert negative effects on cell growth previously attributed to the decrease in pH Rawat et al. 2013 . Thus appropriate treatments before aeration into the medium are necessary. Carbon sequestered from industrial flue gas can be converted in the sustainable production of biodiesel because lipid-rich microalgal biomass can be harvested from this system and processed into high- quality biodiesel Aslam et al. 2018 . Biogas also contains high concentrations of CO2 which impose a cost burden on transportation and compression and counter the carbon- negative emission aim of this bioenergy technology Kao et al. 2012 . A study used Chlorella to capture the CO2 in biogas produced through the anaerobic digestion of pig effluents and observed the capacity of Chlorella to capture and use CO2 for biomass accumulation. This process elevated CH4 concentration by 10 and yielded biogas with upgraded quality Li et al. 2022a . Other studies also verified the feasibility of biodiesel production from microalgal biogas fixation. A zero-emission process system established on this premise boosted CH4 content and upgraded biogas and oil production Tongprawhan et al. 2014 . In short flue gas aeration in microalgal cultivation is encouraged to guide microalgal resource management and mitigate anthropogenic atmospheric contamination. On the basis of the sustainable develop ment concept scholars are now devoted to achieving zero emissions with flue gas fixation and wastewater treatment as the starting points and microalgal refineries are believed to be competent profitable sus tainable and ecofriendly technologies for the CO2 biomass bioresource cycle. 6. Life cycle assessment and techno-economic analysis Microalgal biorefining is a futuristic approach consistent with the world s net-zero emission principle. When facing its promising applica tion prospect the public attention has been inevitably attracted by the progression of its commercial feasibility. The techno-economic assess ment TEA and life cycle assessment LCA are widely used as foun dation approaches for assessing the economic and environmental impacts of microalgal biorefineries and generating the alternative pro cessing technologies to achieve commercial viability. 6.1. Life cycle assessment Environmental impact assessment of the microalgal biorefineries is a considerable indicator to evaluate whether they are in compliance with sustainable development goals and can provide cost minimization guidance for industries. LCA is a comprehensive assessing tool of the potential impacts to the overall environmental load throughout the life cycle of microalgal biorefineries i.e. from algae cultivation via dew atering extraction conversion production of bioproducts to waste disposal and recycle Mu et al. 2020 . The outstanding environmental friendliness of microalgae biorefining is reflected in the comparison with the productive process of conventional diesel and chemical products. Bennion et al. 2015 obtained a LCA model using GREET Model 2013 and investigated the NER and GHG emission of microalgal bioenergy production through hydrothermal liquefaction were respectively 1.23 MJ MJ and 11.4 g CO2-eq. MJ 1 while the bioenergy production via pyrolysis obtained NER 2.27 MJ MJ and 210 g CO2-eq. MJ 1 GHG emission. On the contrary in another case Spirulina and Chlorella pro duce worse environmental impacts compared to traditional food feed protein sources due to high energy consumption in culture and down stream processing but the current conclusion is believed to be over turned with the advancement of technology Smetana et al. 2017 . In addition microalgal biorefineries show low impacts for eutrophication and land use which is explained by the high biomass yield and usage of Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 18 wastelands. Also these biorefineries has less impacted soil acidification and human toxicity owing to the lack of fertilizer and pesticides usage Banu et al. 2020 . Making full use of resources and simplifying the production process particularly the PBRs energy consumption are the crucial segments to realizing economic feasibility. A LCA study conducted by Porcelli et al. 2020 systematically evaluated the environmental impacts of PBRs infrastructure microalgae cultivation flocculation filtration and biomass drying the result revealed that cultivation in PBRs had poten tial to reduce environmental impacts but still exists obstacles like high costs on artificial illumination and CO2 aeration. These obstacles are believed to be solved by integrating wastewater and flue gas. When microalgae utilize costless CO2 and nutrients this process also contrib utes to greatly relief environmental burden of flue gas decarbonization and water remediation. A LCA of bioreactor for algal biodiesel produc tion detected the obvious reduction in environmental impacts with minimum GHG footprint with wastewater usage for cultivation and transesterification via biocatalyst Saranya and Ramachandra 2020 . In summary microalgal biorefinery has a positive effect on reducing GHG emission energy economy and environmental remediation but its environmental impact is not entirely positive at this stage. Furthermore the LCA of the overall cycle is also sensitive to availability of renewable sources and the demand for final products. Further analyses are required to be conducted on the strain characteristics steady state production and climate suitability to thoroughly evaluate the LCA. 6.2. Techno-economic analysis TEA creates comprehensive analysis of direct connection between economic and technical aspects of microalgal biorefinery via investi gating the operational costs the risks in every processing phase and the economic practicability of downstream bioproducts Mu et al. 2020 . For microalgae biorefining the most vital aspect of economic impact analysis is the expense of processes and devices employed. The choice of cultivation structure determines the economics of microalgae biorefining to a large extent and the commercial viability of biorefinery systems in open ponds OPs flat panel PBRs vertical PBRs and horizontal PBRs have been analyzed. Comparatively OPs consist of simpler construction and operations leading to 2 10 times lower capital and operation costs compared to PBRs attributing to lower installation and process maintenance costs Chia et al. 2018 . However PBRs have greater advantage in terms of light illuminating efficiency nutrient uptake efficiency culture density biomass productivity and controlla bility. At the current stage developing the easy-to-operate PBRs with simple structure and practical functions is still the key objective. Different PBR type scale and design parameters lead to significantly diverse cost ranging 2.82 30.97 USD kg 1 Khetkorn et al. 2017 . The flat-plate reactor is a classical and relatively inexpensive option for microalgae cultivation but it may require more maintenance cost. The tubular reactor is considered as the most expensive approach and is typically implemented on a pilot scale Ting et al. 2017 . The economic feasibility of microalgae cultivation is greatly influenced by the selection of substrate. For instance the cost of using acrylic-based tubes is twice as high as that of using glass. In biofilm PBRs different substrate materials are available and PVC sheeting is often preferred due to its durability and affordability. The membrane photobioreactor MPBR is widely recognized as a highly promising technology for microalgae cultivation and harvesting Xu et al. 2014 . It has been found that microalgae cultivated in MPBRs exhibit higher biomass productivity compared to other types of photo bioreactors Gao et al. 2021 . In addition the operation and mainte nance costs associated with MPBRs are significantly lower than those of traditional PBRs Sheng et al. 2017 . While MPBRs offer numerous advantages their scale in terms of submerged membrane modules has not yet reached the requirements of industrial standards. Hybrid PBR systems which combine elements from traditional cultivation systems have shown great potential in achieving higher operational efficiency and productivity at a lower cost and energy consumption Singh and Sharma 2012 . Several studies using a LCA approach have also demonstrated that hybrid PBR systems can help mitigate environmental impacts and reduce expenses associated with microalgae cultivation in wastewater Kohlheb et al. 2020 . Since PERs are generally coordinated with artificial light source the effective regulation of light illumination is a positive way of cost reduction. Unsuitable illumination leads to cellular inadaptability and decreasing CO2 fixation and also causes massive energy loss due to energy dissipation. Maroneze et al. 2016 revealed that a suitable photoperiod with light dark cycle of 0.5 0.5 s can reduce 33 reduction of electric energy demand for per unit production period. While CO2 can be saw as free resource the supply of other nutrients still accounts for 1 10 of total microalgal biorefining cost. As mentioned for many times nutrients utilization from waste resources is one of the most viable approaches to decrease economic cost. The usage of food feed waste landfill leachate agricultural wastewater and in dustrial flue gas as nutrients source instead of commercial nutrients can well reduce economic burden of microalgae cultivation. Sun et al. 2022 investigated the economic impact of wastes as a medium on microalgae production by employing TEA and indicated that culturing microalgae in wastes could significantly reduce the total production expenditure. Judd et al. 2017 suggested that 36 95 of microalgae lipids production cost could be reduced by using waste resource as nu trients source and using flue gas as CO2 source. Simultaneous synthesis of value-added products is the most cost- effective and feasible method to decrease manufacturing cost and offer possibilities for commercial feasibility of microalgae biorefineries. To achieve this goal it seems easy to think of genetic engineering and synthetic biology strategies for undergone significant development to improve value-added products output. However such methods did not always work. A techno-economic evaluation of biodiesel production from genetically engineered Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803 showed that lipids productivity enhancement as sole regulating target was not able to valorize overall biodiesel investment since the cumbersome and cost- intensive downstream biodiesel transesterification greatly elevated its cost Lopes et al. 2019 . Instead it is more essential to seek for the most suitable and complete utilization of biomass products for each bio refining industry in which the composite exploitation of cellular com pounds is encouraged to maximize the economic benefit and minimize the cost of by-product treatments. For example Algal biodiesel pro duction can become economical sustainable by producing biodiesel from lipid and synthesizing bioethanol enzymatically from the remaining de- oiled biomass Kouzuma and Watanabe 2015 . In the situation of an urgent global environmental and energy crisis the process of reducing carbon emissions has already started. Microalgal biorefineries carry the burden of achieving both high commercial output and high environmental returns which of course cannot be satisfied perfectly in the short term. By adhering to a carbon neutral label microalgal biorefineries can benefit from an enhanced image that gives them a competitive edge. The question at hand is whether it is worth to chase for carbon net-zero emission and also how much does it cost to achieve this goal. Numerous researches and analyses have clarified that although the commercial returns are not satisfactory at this stage welcoming novel microalgal biorefinery is a great step in the right di rection as prioritizing environmental sustainability outweighs the cost of doing nothing. 7. Challenges and future perspectives While the theoretical feasibility of the action of microalgae in carbon sequestration has been proven in detail the lack of a biosequestration technology that simultaneously satisfies the efficiency and economy of large-scale sequestration is the major developmental obstacle to commercialization. Y. Wang et al. Science of the Total Environment 901 2023 165546 19 The bioaccessibility of CO2 the major removal target directly affects the fixation efficiency to a large degree. The proportion of CO2 aeration demands precise regulation instead of blind increases because excess aeration would cause cell vitality exhaustion and unnecessary energy costs. Biotechnologies particularly advanced genetic tools that enhance the carbon uptake capacity of microalgal strains are enthusiastically promoted. Although many microalgal strains have been bred with great CO2 tolerance and uptake capacity only a minority of these strains display stable phenotypes between multiple generations. On the basis of previous experience future studies could explore this issue further by genetically strengthening the activity of the carbon sequestration pathway. Establishing additional pathways in certain species with considerable receptiveness can also be another option. After all the construction of these biological approaches imposes increased re quirements for the in-depth investigation of algal CCM systems and the employed functional structures. Improper illumination results in undesirable effects on cellular car bon conversion. In the absence of accurately designed PBR devices adverse light transfer and uneven light distribution in the medium might cause a reduction in superficial cell growth due to photo-oxidation damage and downregulate the CO2 fixation rate of cells in light- deficient interior areas. On the other hand light transfer efficiency can be considered to be another major challenge. Although the amendment of the light-harvesting photosynthetic apparatus has been proposed recently the photosynthetic efficiency of improved strains in large-scale cultivation has not been verified. Nevertheless related ge netic engineering in this field may constitute the object of future studies. Although improvement engineering for new strain generation has promising prospects its possible threats to the ecosystem and human health make it controversial. From a practical perspective the improvement in cultivation processes may equally promote the microalga-based carbon sequestration industry by focusing on rein forcing economic feasibility and market competitiveness. The current research in this field mainly focuses on the design and improvement of PBRs and aerator installations which are tightly associated with CO2 and light supply for microalgal carbon sequestration. From this stand point the adoption of closed PBRs instead of open ponds is the pre vailing trend and multiple optical engineering techniques have been developed to optimize the uniformity of illumination and CO2 distri bution in culture systems. Previous experience illustrates that light transfer uniformity CO2 bubble diameter and retention time are the direct elements for assessing the quality of PBR installations and are the controllable factors for improving carbon fixation efficiency. However most of the present PBRs have a common defect Their complex internal structure leads to heavy operating costs and energy consumption thus hindering the implementation of bioeconomic principles. As a conse quence additional theoretical and practical works are needed to support the design of simple and effective PBR devices. In response to the policy of the circular carbon economy the biomass products of microalgal carbon fixation refineries are expected to bring profits in the form of sustainable biological resources. Although micro algal bioproducts have considerable potential for catering to the demand of a variety of markets they involve undesirable energy-intensive downstream processes. In consideration of the high biosafety and sta bility demands for some bioactive products cultivation should be per formed under strictly controlled conditions. Moreover the optional approaches for downstream processing are limited. All these issues un doubtedly lead to increased cost and energy consumption and are sug gestive of a sorely urgent demand for further advancement in related sciences technologies engineering and product processing. The coupling of contaminant treatment with microalgal refineries is another topic for future research. The cultivation of microalgae in wastewater medium or under flue gas aeration has already been realized on a large scale and is worthy of further exploration particularly in terms of downstream bioenergy output. Approaches to the pretreatment of contaminants require deep investigation to guarantee optimal conditions for algal growth and carbon sequestration. The implementation of Internet of Things IoT and artificial intel ligence AI technology in other agriculture and industries has stimu lated the intelligence of microalgae biorefinery. Precise monitoring controlling and predicting of microalgae growth can achieve the control and promotion of their carbon sequestration process and improvement of bioproduct quality clearer than ever before. Particularly the involved essential parameters in microalgae biorefinery require precise moni toring to ensure effective carbon sequestration and biomass productiv ity. Yan et al. 2021 developed an operational microalgae growth forecasting system equipped with an ensemble data assimilation that could improve the 7-day forecasting skill by 85 . The accuracy of this and similar forecasting systems could inform real-time operational de cisions such as pond operation and harvest planning for commercial- scale production. However the intelligence of this biorefinery is still in the infancy phase for the commercial microalgae farming has yet to maturely incorporate with IoT and AI technology the application of these approaches is necessary and worthwhile to be further studied. To summarize microalgal carbon sequestration is an incipient technology facing multifaceted obstacles to its development. Further academic research and practical exploration are certainly required to overcome its bottlenecks. We confidently believe that the environ mental economic and social benefits brought by this technology will far exceed the initial investments. 8. Conclusions In the long run microalgal biorefining is a feasible and profitable solution of GHG emission and environmental crisis and its commercial application has also attracted extensive attention of economists. Previ ous works have reported the excellent carbon fixation capacity of microalgae and the underlying mechanism of CCM systems and carbon fixation pathways in various algal species has also been largely discov ered. As highlighted in this article multiple biological technologies especially genetic engineering can be adopted for further strain improvement to improve fixation efficiency of biorefineries. Cultivation processes also require regulation for optimized conditions that match algal carbon sequestration properties and meanwhile suppress the running cost. Microalgal refineries exhibit outstanding contributions as the biopump enforcing zero-carbon circular bioeconomy because their output algal biomass can be circulated as a valuable bioresource in a variety of markets. This sustainable bioresource helps partially alleviate the energy crisis and create remarkable economic income. The advancement of innovative technologies using CO2 and nutrients from waste resources is strongly recommended to take a great step toward final commercialization of microalgal biorefineries. Guided by the principles of sustainable development the ecological and economic impacts are not ignorable in every single segment. On guarantee of remarkable practical contribution on net-zero emission goal more ef forts should be made to promote the formation of energy-efficient pro cessing strategies and meanwhile a benign bioeconomy loop of biorefineries.
