Bello et al. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 2 LCA studies of algae to biofuel process focusing on a specific processing unit but neglecting important factors in the synthesis integration operation control and management stages of the overall production system Slade and Bauen 2013 Chamkalani et al. 2020 Carneiro et al. 2017 . Effectively there is no consistent framework for the conduct of LCA due to variability in key factors influencing the results such as the system boundaries time frame for the assessment may influence the evaluation of greenhouse gas and many environmental factors and sys tems boundary allocation as well as lack of focused area such as a ho listic and comprehensive optimization of algae to biofuel process with full integration of upstream and downstream activities plus environ mental cum economic as well as social and management considerations. 3.2. Material and energy balances Mass and energy balances are starting points for the economic evaluation of biofuel production. The energy balances cover a much wider range of activities such as energy efficiency intensity process emissions and supply chain while material balances encompass material sourcing demand handling disposal land and water management fugitive emissions fleet and logistics. As such the overall energy con sumption must be monitored at different levels of detail with energy management applications. The actual benefits that can in practice be realized by biofuel depend crucially on the energy content and carbon balances which indicate the magnitude of fossil fuel impacts and related greenhouse gas GHG emissions relative to subsequent fossil fuels to current commercial sources of energy. In other words for the assessment of renewable energy sources it is necessary to weigh various conversion processes and biofuel produced with respect to their ability to produce useful work and to identify their impact on the environment bearing in mind that input and output energy are two factors that determine the economic and ecological usefulness of a fuel or its production technol ogy. In fact the sustainability of microalgae production depends on both the energy content of input material and the process pathway Esra Sorguven 2010 Slade and Bauen 2013 Rocca et al. 2015 . Moreover assessing the inputs and outputs are key issues sur rounding the current trends in algal sustainability. A corresponding variance where energy input exceeds energy output energy return on energy invested or EROI can threaten the feasibility of algal biofuel technology. The energy return on investment EROI is a measure of sustainability. EROI is the ratio between the energy from a certain en ergy resource and the exergy spent to obtain that resource. In the case of EROEI 3 is desirable for a fuel to be a sustainable energy source Saad et al. 2019 . Many inputs are required to scale up the production of algal fuels such as constructing the facility chemicals pumps cooling CO2 pipelines filters harvesting centri fuges storage surface structure for open ponds pH salinity extraction and conversion transport recycling water and nutrients and delivering fuels effectively the embodied energy will be critically high. The esti mated EROI for algal biofuels produced in either open ponds or photo bioreactors is 0.13 0.71 Hall et al. 2011 Saad et al. 2019 Sills et al. 2012 . Moreover the detailed design or specification of process equipment can begin only when the material and energy balances are complete and the life cycle assessment LCA is based on science and engineering energy balances coupled with mass balances of unit operation approach rather than LCA on accounting procedure Pfromm et al. 2011 . The most important issues to take into account are the usage of fossil fuels in production and the resultant release of fossil-derived CO2. The minimization of energy inputs incorporated in materials of plant construction nutrients used electricity needed for mixing and pumping and natural gas for drying must be maintained or improved. Moreover waste materials must be recycled to the process and the energy recovered from the waste product Scott et al. 2010 3.3. Scalability Various microalgae production processes have been under investi gation ranging from different types of cultivation methods to harvest ing extraction purification and conversion. There is still much needed research to be conducted in these areas considering the cost and levels of scale achieved in these unit processes Van beilen 2010 . A concrete dependable and reproducible figure is required for each unit process to convert algae to a specific concentration. This has not yet been demonstrated on a commercial scale and thus remains a significant challenge DOE 2010 . Scalability has often recapitulated the incremental production vol ume required to meet the larger demand congruently maintaining effi ciency and quality to a significant level. Most of the sustainability challenges in algal biofuel production centred towards sustaining optimal growth conditions efficient resources supply and effective harvesting techniques at larger scales. Having an algal biofuel constructively competing with fossil fuels and other renewable energy sources as well as cost reduction strategies is highly critical for achieving scalable production. The essential questions here are simply what are the energy and material inputs coupled with the associated cost required for algal cultivation harvesting and or drying process And what are the limits of such requirements Only when these questions have been answered will the process of system engineering plant design begin. These questions will however initially depend on the economics of algal technology such as the cost associated with algal biomass growth harvesting dewatering and extraction. Other economic considerations include capital equipment investment operations and maintenance while project costs may include acquiring permits infrastructure prep arations installation and integration cost of nutrients CO2 distribution utilities components replacement contractor fees labour cost and cost of the land where applicable Singh and Gu 2010 Singh and Olsen 2011 . In synopsis scalability challenges still remain the major obstacles for the speedy commercialization of algal biofuel and are often found in the upstream process which includes the algal selection and cultivation methods the nutrients requirements energy input for maintaining closed photobioreactors water requirements and footprints and sensi tivity of algae towards environmental stressors such as changes in pH water quality and increased concentrations of some chemicals and contaminants. Downstream process scalability issues are associated with efficient harvesting and drying techniques of algal cells effective lipid extraction methodologies algal biodiesel conversion technologies algal biofuel quality and the potential to diversify algal biofuel production from lipid-extracted algae residue Lam et al. 2019 . In addition social considerations include income generation job opportunities healthy conditions for workers and education and access to public service support. Therefore until large-scale systems are built and operated over a number of years many uncertainties will remain. 3.4. Sustainability and regulation Sustainability is the ability of resources to be used in such a way not to be depleted but replenished to meet the needs of today without compromising the needs of tomorrow Lovett et al. 2010 Naik et al. 2010 . The growing interest in the use of algal biofuels has generated yet another issue regarding their sustainable use in the global market. This has resulted from the possibility of negative ecological impacts as well as the socio-economic impacts of GHG emissions. Thus the successful deployment and commercialization of algal biofuels is tied to regulatory frameworks pertaining to National and International guidelines and standards on environmental management systems. More often than not standards such as air emissions land use water usage and discharge as well as safety and health standards on workers are regulated. Govern ment mandates subsidies and tax incentives as well as incentives M. Bello et al. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 3 promote or hinder the development of algal biofuels. Compliance issues are the major hurdles for algal biofuel producers and form the basis for gaining public and government support. Many governments scientists and others have already recognised the importance of setting standards and certification schemes to main tain the sustainable production of biofuels. The schemes entailed criteria that have to be fulfilled for the certification of a product or production process and the mechanism for its sustainability indication van Dam et al. 2008 . Sustainability objectives are statutory instruments in the UK and biofuels are part of the 2007 RTFO order. The RTFO order is aimed at meeting the 5.75 renewable transport fuel target for 2010 and the 10 target for 2020 in the 2009 European Fuels Directive. The RED is formulated at the EU level to require producers to comply with a set of sustainability criteria to count towards the EU biofuel target. Sustainability criteria of the RTFO include carbon emissions environment agriculture economic activities and sustainable develop ment. On the global scale RSB a multi-stakeholder initiative of the UNEP has also developed sustainability standards for biofuels Lovett et al. 2010 . 3.5. Technical maturity There are many processes involved in the production of algal bio fuels such as culturing harvesting dewatering oil extraction and conversion processes. This set-in motion an overview of the supply chain technology required to derive energy from microalgae as shown in Fig. 1. Thus substantial improvement is highly desirable in microalgal productivity through various technological improvements see Fig. 2 . Additionally numerous options exist for processing algal biomass to the desired end product. This means that different processing scenarios would have evolved and different resource requirements. Therefore the selection of effective processing technology would solely depend on the available resources algae species being cultivated and particularly the maturity of the evolving technology since the classification of biofuels depends on the species used and the existing maturity of the technology. Categorically among other important issues such as resource demand sustainability and scalability the Technology Readiness Level TRL is a significant issue that needs to be considered for the evaluation and integration of algal-based biofuel systems. TRL is a certification scheme which quantifies the maturity levels of evolving technologies and uses a predetermined requirement standard in helping to produce biofuels in a sustainable manner. Under this method a technology is assigned a readiness level from 1 to 9 based on TRL criteria van Dam et al. 2008 . Generally speaking the purpose of timely and accurate technology readiness assessments is to inform management and support decisions as part of the implementation of advanced technology system development projects. The Technology Readiness Levels have been defined to provide a common metric by means of which knowledge of new technology s maturity might be communicated among program executives system developers technology researchers and among individuals from different organizations. The TRL are therefore not linked to a specific technical discipline. In addition the use of TRLs can provide a needed foundation for developing and communicating insight into the risks involved in advancing a new system and its constituent new technology components. In fact algal biofuel technology be its cultivation system e.g. open Fig. 1. Various production harvesting and processing technologies for microalgae bio-refinery. Fig. 2. Systems technology tools in the design of bio-refineries Kokossis and Yang 2010 . M. Bello et al. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 4 pond closed photobioreactors and or conversion system e.g. trans esterification and lipid extractions processes hydrolysis and thermo chemical conversions such as hydrothermal liquefactions and pyrolysis is still in the development and demonstration stages and its potentials are continually being explored for optimization and large-scale pro duction. The maturity of these evolving technology is intertwined with its scalability which has a direct bearing on efficiency cost-effectiveness and thus sustainability. Algal biofuels have been reported to have environmental benefits may provide a positive energy balance and could improve resource land water and energy management and minimize the ecological footprint of the production pathways Subhadra and Edwards 2010 Ayhan 2009 . However there exist many technical and non-technical issues related to the implementation and large-scale commercializa tion of bio-refineries. Major technical obstacles anticipated are the intertwined biomass and lipid productivity minimum economic returns with maximum cost of production coupled with feedstock supply and logistics. Other technical issues may include production systems opti mization harvesting transportation and storage. 3.6. Economic analysis Economic analysis is the pivot on which the progress of any project depends and is the stepping stone for convincing investors confidence. It is paramount in assessing financial viability and other costs and benefits for operating a project. Several factors came into play when envisaging the sustainability of microalgal biorefinery. The most important factors include the technical input such as algae biomass yield oil content lipid extraction efficiency and conversion cost. These parameters are extremely important because they directly affect eco nomic viability by interceding the productivity of algae biofuel. Other important factors include financial assumptions and or inputs which are critical for economic analysis as they directly affect the final results such as project lifetime discount rate tax and other overhead costs if microalgal venture is being evaluated and the best courses of action is selected. Reducing the cost of production through more efficient microalgal cultivation harvesting extractions and conversion processes needs to be streamlined to make it sustainable and cost-effective as well as competitive with petroleum-based fuels. A multidisciplinary approach involving system biology strain development scale-up pathway an integrated production chain and logistics is required to overcome this issue Zhang et al. 2017 . In the recent decade techno-economic analysis TEA and life cycle assessment LCA gained importance due to their ability to assess the economic feasibility and socio-environmental suitability of the biofuel production from microalgae. These techniques help to prioritize the research s targets and direction to continue and support biofuel and bioenergy production and their performance. The economic aspect of setting up and running the biofuel plant hinders the capabilities of biofuel. Thus tools such as techno-economic analysis provide informa tion about the finances involved in setting up and running the plant for a long time. Also these studies suggest methods for cost reduction of biofuel production. TEA requires a detailed and clear mode of assessment analysis which can enable to identify best biorefinery in view of both technically and economically. However most of the literature on techno-economic assessment follows a set of guidelines that were previously imple mented in previous studies. Operational labour maintenance and capital costs are included in the techno-economic assessment this methodology precisely estimates net present value NPV and accord ingly minimum fuel selling price MFSP are calculated. Along with MFSP and NPV the parameters such as discounted cash flow and sensitivity analysis are also considered for a fail-proof decision on economic viability and play a crucial part in assessing the sustainability of the biorefinery. Commercial or open-source software such as Aspen Plus or SuperPro Designer can be used for detailed process flow sheets for the biorefinery under study. Juneja and Murthy 2017 studied the techno-economic analysis of the hydrothermal liquefaction of Chlorella vulgaris C. vulgaris which has shown a high potential for wastewater treatment during its growth. It has a high growth rate with resistance to high concentrations of gasses such as CO2 SOX and NOX which makes it to grow in open ponds with waste water as its nutrient source and flue gasses as its carbon source. This process model was developed for incoming wastewater of 227 million litres day using SuperPro Designer software. A 20 algal con centration was used in this study and optimal HTL process conditions were used for maximum oil yield 37 . Renewable diesel biofuel costs around 6.62 Gallon. Ranganathan and Savithri 2019 studied liquid fuel production from wastewater-based microalgae. This model consists of 800 Million Litres M L day of wastewater input for the treatment process including pri mary treatment grit removal and sludge sedimentation secondary treatment activated sludge process and tertiary treatment. The treated water was used for microalgae production in open raceway ponds. A hydrothermal liquefaction process was employed to convert waste water-based microalgae to liquid fuels. This procedure happens at a certain temperature of 350OC and at 20 MPa the preheated algal slurry was pumped to the HTL reactor at subcritical conditions. The algal slurry in the HTL reactor converts into gas aqueous biooil organic phase and solid residue ash and char under the subcritical hydrothermal condi tion. The HTL effluent after solid residue separation is sent to a three-phase separator to separate liquid organic and gas phases. The process was simulated using Aspen Plus software in which all the ma terial and energy flows in an integrated wastewater-based biofuel pro duction plant were carried out. Soave- Redlich-Kwong SRK thermodynamic equation of state was used to model phase equilibria thermodynamic property for each component in different phases. The size of the equipment was determined using the results of a steady-state simulation which was used to compute the mass and energy balances. The minimum selling price MSP of liquid fuels was determined using a discounted cash flow analysis approach which is the price of fuel determined under zero NPV. The MSP of liquid fuels was calculated as 4.3 USD GGE. The several products produced by this process diesel jet fuel gasoline and H2 are normalized based on their greater heating values to create gallon gasoline equivalent GGE . Ranganathan 2023 studied the techno-economic analysis of renewable fuel produced from sewage sludge through the hydrothermal liquefaction process. This process includes wastewater treatment for which sewage was collected a hydrothermal liquefaction unit for bio fuel production hydro processing unit for crude oil upgradation and hydrogen production. The author studied 800 million litres day wastewater treatment capacity and subsequent renewable fuel produc tion. During wastewater treatment grit removal and sludge sedimen tation were considered as primary treatment and activated sludge treatment as a secondary process the primary and secondary sludges were dewatered and pumped into an HTL reactor for biooil production and by using a 3-phase separator biooil was separated and sent into hydro processing unit for upgradation to renewable fuel and subsequent hydrogen production through steam reforming method. A steady-state process simulation was performed to observe mass and energy flow through the process components of the plant. The simulations were performed using process flow commercial sheeting software Aspen Plus. Soave-Redlich-Kwong SRK thermodynamic phase equilibrium state was considered for each component during the simulation. Energy and mass flowrates were utilized for the calculation of sizing of equipment with the help of Aspen Plus Economic Analyser APEA software for the calculation of equipment sizing which is necessary for calculation cap ital expenditure CAPEX and operating expenditure OPEX of the plant under study. CAPEX and OPEX were utilized to calculate the MSP of renewable fuel using discounted cash flow analysis and to ease com parison of biorefinery Nth plant assumption is considered. Plant lifespan assumed to be 20 years tax rate of 40 10 Internal Rate of Return M. Bello et al. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 5 IRR and 330 total operational days. The MFSP is 4.04 US GGE 1.15 US litre . A life cycle assessment was performed on the hydrothermal lique faction of Chlorella vulgaris C. vulgaris for producing renewable diesel Juneja and Murthy 2017 . A well-to-pump cradle-to-gate life cycle assessment was performed for the production of renewable diesel RD using GREET. Energy used for the production of RD was 241.6 MJ per 1000 MJ of energy produced which is 80 lower than the mineral diesel formed from crude oil. 110 kg of CO2 equivalent per 1000 MJ 3.73 Kg CO2 eq. Lt. RD of energy produced greenhouse gasses GHG is emitted from RD. When well-to-wheel cradle-to-grave is considered LCA has performed a total GHG emission of 31 kg CO2eq per 1000 MJ RD. GHG emission during the algae growth harvesting stage is nega tive 111.5 kg CO2eq. per 1000 MJ RD due to CO2 sequestration. A life cycle assessment LCA was performed on a biodiesel pro duction plant using freshwater microalgae Chlorella Vulgaris C. Vul garis in a hybrid cultivation system Adesanya et al. 2014 . This system is a two-stage process that couples both raceway ponds with airlift tubular photobioreactors for increased biomass growth and lipid accu mulation. Based on the 1ton of biodiesel produced have around 42 savings in GWP as compared to fossil fuels and 38 savings in Fossil energy requirements FER as compared to fossil fuels derived diesel these results show that microalgae-derived fuels have less environ mental impacts as compared to the fossil fuel derived diesel. Maga 2016 discussed the LCA for the municipal wastewater-based microalgae biorefinery. GaBi software was used for this study on LCA. A functional unit of 1m3 was considered to analyse the environmental impacts of the biomethane to be used as an alternative vehicle fuel 1 MJ CNG was used as the functional unit. A cradle-to-grave approach was used in this study. The energy balance of all gas plants was performed and 50 30 000 MJ day of primary energy consumed by algal bio refinery was observed for only 5000 m3 output. Greenhouse gas emis sion from wastewater-treated algae biorefinery was observed to be 0.28 kg CO2 eq. m3 and GHG emissions from regular wastewater treatment plants was around 0.47 kg CO2 eq. m3 shows a 40 reduction in GHG emissions due to the implementation of the algal biorefinery concept. The global Warming Potential GWP of 1 MJ biomethane used as a vehicular fuel was calculated as 0.02 kg CO2 eq. MJ and GWP for con ventional CNG as a vehicular passenger fuel calculated as 0.08 kg CO2 eq. MJ. All gas approaches for biomethane formation protect the envi ronment from fossil depletion ozone depletion minerals and metal depletion. More land requirement 10 ha for the construction of HRAP High-Rate Algal Ponds requires more space than a conventional wastewater treatment system. Particulate matter emissions from the transportation of residues and exhaust from biomass boilers also contribute to the impacts on human health along with GHG emissions see Table 1 . 3.7. Commercial industries There are numerous companies involved in the algal to biofuel process utilizing various methods such as open pond cultivation hy drothermal processes fermentation process genetic engineering as well as controlled environment systems to produce algal biofuels commer cially. These companies are listed with their production methods adopted for commercial production as in Table 2 below. 3.8. Nutrient minimizing methods for large scale production of algae The potential for nutrient recycling is thought to be essential for the economic development of large-scale microalgae cultivation. Imple mentation of various nutrient recycling minimizing steps could improve resource efficiency and enhance the sustainability of the process. Onsite recovery from biomass and waste stream utilization should be integrated and maximized to reduce fertilizer requirements avoid competition with food production and overcome other sustainability issues. Different approaches have been utilized to minimize nutrients for sus tainable cultivation of algal biomass such as 1 nutrient recovery sys tems from spent algae biomass and wastewater nutrient technologies 2 close-loop cultivation system where nutrients are continuously recycled within the system 3 nutrient balancing systems to monitor the efficient utilization of nutrient so as to minimize excess accumulation 4 using efficient harvesting techniques such as flocculation and centrifugation to concentrate algae biomass and retain nutrient for the purpose of recy cling and 5 the integration with nutrient recycling technology from the residual biomass such as the biological process that involves Anaerobic digestion and various Hydrothermal treatment processes is necessary to obtain a sustainable production of algal biomass Arora et al. 2023 Barbera et al. 2018 . Hydrothermal treatments have been used in the conversion of algal biomass which is fraught with the possibility of processing wet micro algae directly 5 20 solid content avoiding the energy-costly drying step. Different hydrothermal processes such as hydrothermal gasifica tion HTG hydrothermal liquefaction HTL hydrothermal Carbon ization HTC and flash hydrolysis can be used depending on the operating conditions to generate an aqueous phase AP rich in nutri ents which therefore has the potential to be recycled as cultivation medium for algal growth. Anaerobic digestion AD which is a commercially developed technology that involves the biological con version of complex organic matter into biogas and methane has been proven feasible using both whole biomass WB and the residue remaining after lipids extraction LEA for the cultivation of algae biomass Arora et al. 2023 . Moreover different strategies which include direct recycling the use of AD liquid digestate as well as an aqueous phase from hydrothermal treatments have been employed to recycle nutrient obtained from either AD and or HT processes. However their bio-availability utilization efficiency and possible toxicity effects need to be carefully evaluated. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 6 Various life cycle assessment LCA studies have been conducted to evaluate the associated implications of nutrient demand on the eco nomic and environmental issues of commercial-scale microalgae culti vation Bello et al. 2017 Venteris et al. 2014 Pate et al. 2011 . Assessment of nutrient supply and resource sustainability for Chlorella growth comparing various technologies and their impact on the opti mization of algal biofuel production have been conducted by Wigmosta et al. 2011 . A regional-scale resource analysis of open pond systems and site-specific analysis for a photobioreactor has been investigated by Pate et al. 2011 and Quinn et al. 2012 and concluded that the resource sustainability is potentially a serious limitation for a successful deployment of the algal biofuel industry. However most of the studies conducted on nutrient recycling are obtained at a laboratory scale mostly in batch operation mode. There fore technological efforts should be directed towards scaling up the processes considered and optimizing the performances under contin uous operation mode to improve nutrient recovery and energetic profitability before industrial-scale applications can be effectively implemented Arora et al. 2023 . The feasibility of integrating waste water with microalgae cultivation as a source of water and nutrients for microalgae growth as well as effective wastewater treatment has been established by Arora et al. 2023 Barbera et al. 2018 and Rosch et al. 2012 but such studies have not extended results to scalability. Despite the knowledge gained through previous techno-economic and life cycle analysis and resource assessments a need remains for a thorough evaluation of the nutrient demand of large-scale biofuel production. 3.9. Sustainable designed and supply routes of algal biorefinery The development of microalgae upstream activities and downstream processing has set in motion complex and enormous decision-making problems connecting a distinctive array of process development that needs to be faced boldly and systematically. Several key issues are considered such as cultivations systems optimal location waste water utilization for resource efficiency harvesting systems techniques optimization energy use processing logistics local transportation supply chain integration and sustainability metric Yadala et al. 2020 . Bringing issues of bio-refinery design configuration thermodynamics process integration processing paths re-engineering initiatives holistic evaluation of techno-economic trade-offs and supply chain integration will champion the basis for an effective economic representation. Kokossis and Yang 2010 2010 have reported some significant fea tures that represent the information flow that can be used to assess new technologies and re-engineering initiatives coupled with designing an integrated bio-refinery depicted in Table 3. For instance a conceptual energy-driven biorefinery considering a four-platform configuration biogas biomethane oil electricity and heat biorefinery using algae for biodiesel biomethane electricity heat and glycerine Omega 3 and fertilizer can thus be demonstrated as in Fig. 3 below. 3.10. Upstream technologies 3.10.1. Microalgae cultivation Open and closed systems are often used for the cultivation of microalgae. Open ponds simply recapitulate open tank or natural ponds that grow profusely in suitable climatic conditions and adequate nutri ents with minimal control of the environment that require a certain level of construction and maintenance. Microalgae biomass cultivation is presently carried out in an open system for commercial purposes. This may stem from the basic reason that open ponds are easier to build and operate less expensive and more durable with a large production ca pacity susceptible to commercialization in comparison with closed systems. To overcome the technical and biological difficulties faced by open systems photo-bioreactors are now developed. They are culture systems for phototrophs and have the capacity to enhance the cultivation of microalgae with higher efficiency and biomass concentration due to combined enhancement of a thin boundary layer and short light dark fluctuations at high turbulences. The provision of cultivation under different environmental conditions without contamination water loss by evaporation and more rigorous process control is a high priority of closed photo-bioreactors. Closed photo-bioreactors have the ability to maintain a consistency in biomass and liquid productivity and allow the cultivation of a single strain in an optimum growth condition coupled with extremely process control. Xu et al. 2011 have listed the following issues for effective culture systems a Effective illumination area b optimal gas-liquid transfer c easy to operate d low contamination e low capital and production cost and f Minimal land requirement. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 8 technological advancement of various cultivation technologies issues are discussed below. 3.10.2. Open pond technical prospects The open pond production platform is currently the most common production system used for microalgae growth. It is popularly described as a raceway shallow or circular pond culture system that is currently employed in most countries of the world USA China India Thailand and Israel for the cultivation of microalgae. Environmental conditions land and water and the location of the ponds are an important factor to determine the success and the type of pond to be selected the intrinsic properties of algae species being cultivated and the amount of light for the photosynthesis process Harun et al. 2010 . Lee 2001 reported that the severity of the culture environment has made it possible to grow only a limited number of resistant algal species such as Dunaliella-high salinity Spirulina-high alkalinity and Chlorella-high nutrition . Generally open systems entertain large areas for cultivation relatively easy to build and operate with low energy input requirements Brennan and Owende 2010 Amaro et al. 2011 . The biomass productivity of an open system ranges between 0.1 and 0.5 g L Lardon et al. 2009 . However open pond systems are associated with some difficulties concerning contamination requirements of large areas of land efficient CO2 utilization poor mixing excessive evaporative losses temperature and light control issues and difficulty in growing algae over long pe riods of time Brennan and Owende 2010 Chisti 2007 Richmond 2008 Singh and Olsen 2011 Williams and Laurens 2010 . Open sys tems are associated with difficulties in maintaining their stable envi ronmental conditions due to temperature fluctuations and achievable cell density is hard to attain due to shading effects Amaro et al. 2011 . The raceway pond is constructed as an endless loop in which the culture is circulated by paddle wheels. They are lined with plastic or cement 0.2 0.5 ha in size and are about 15 35 cm deep to ensure adequate exposure to light. Paddle wheels provide the motive force while water nutrients and algae circulate around a racetrack. The construction and design of an open pond system depends essentially on local conditions and available materials at disposal. Materials for con struction of the side walls range from simple clay to cement and to expensive PVC glass fibers or polyurethane. The materials used to build walls bottom and lining determine the pond s performance viability and cost implication. For the lining most commercial plants use long- life plastic membranes of 1 2 mm thick UV resistant PVC or poly ethylene sheets Mata et al. 2010 . The performance as well as the durability depend upon the material used to design raceway ponds. The biomass productivity of an open system is reported between 0.1 and 0.5 g l Lardon et al. 2009 . Brennan and Owende 2010 reported various inconsistencies associ ated with the productivities of raceway ponds. The biomass production rates of 30 37 tonnes per year using data from producing biomass dry weight ranging from 8.2 gm-2 to 25gm-2 and biomass concentration amounting to 1 g l to 10 g l. It has been reported cultivation of Microalgae uses shallow water depth of 0.2 0.3 m areal dimensions range from 0.5 to 1 ha for raceway to greater than 200 ha for extensive ponds in Australia for D. salina production. The use of water depends on the intensity of operation and CO2 is added due to its stripping-out effect under control pH-stat. Flocculation and or centrifugation can be used for harvesting operations Greenwell et al. 2010 . Optimization with respect to raceway configuration operation and cost is very important for microalgal biofuel production Slade and Bauen 2013 . Khoo et al. 2011 reported an energy input of 1.152 MJ per kg of dry biomass output and an estimated energy amount of 4.608 MJ kg of biodiesel for raceway system. The total life cycle energy for the culti vation of microalga Nannochloropis sp. in the raceway pond in Brazil was reported by Jorquera et al. 2010 as 45 GJ year for 100 tonne year algal biomass. Moreover 6.5 GJ tonne biodiesel was a total life cycle energy associated with production of biodiesel from fresh alga Chlorella vulgaris in the raceway in UK Lardon et al. 2009 . In the open system Nitrogen is removed during biomass growth and CO2 is diffused to the atmosphere. Photo-bioreactors have superior quality upon open systems in terms of nitrogen biomass uptake and organic matter utilization for biomass growth via CO2 uptake Fern andez et al. 2012. With the exception of CO2 nutrients requirement is assumed to follow stoichiometric based on carbon nitrogen phos phorus C N P composition of 10 10 1. The requirement is based on elemental composition rather than nitrogen fertilizers since using Ammonia nutrients requirement attracts upstream energy balance because they rely on the manufacture of ammonia Barbera et al. 2018 . 3.10.3. Photobioreactor technical prospects Photobioreactor PBR systems are developed with the motive of reducing some technical difficulties associated with open systems coupled with enhancing the biological and physiological characteristics of a particular grown microalgae species. PBR culture platforms are flexible and have the capacity to manipulate variables and essentially control parameters such as light temperature nutrients and pH compared to the open platforms. Hence the cultivation of microalgae with greater efficiency and biomass concentration is due to the rigorous process control and the provision of cultivation under different envi ronmental conditions without contamination and water loss by evapo ration. Different designs of PBR systems exist with distinctive throughput based on the mode of operation and design. Efficiency of photo-bioreactors is also assessed based on nutrient removal organic matter utilization and biomass chemical profile. Closed system tubular photo-bioreactor showed a higher cell N content compared to open system. The different designs tested in the laboratory or in a pilot scale include a various forms of tubular reactors b horizontal vertical in clined or spiral reactors and c annular reactors and arrangement of plastic bags. However these designs are associated with varying scaling- up costs and inconsistent reports in terms of cost and productivity Amaro et al. 2011 Tubular reactors are cheap and have large illumination area with good biomass productivity. Vertical bubble columns and airlift cylinders have high mass transfer good mixing and low energy consumption with a good surface volume ratio. Vertical plate is much better in terms of productivity and ease of operations than bubble columns. A biomass productivity of 1.9 g L-1 d-1 for continuous batch operation in tubular PBRs was also reported Mata et al. 2010 . Moreover airlift PBR design is more suitable for carbon sequestration from flue gas with effective gas transfer coupled with low hydrodynamic stress and ease of control. Integrating airlift with tubular PBR systems will produce interesting features of surface to volume ratio Kumar et al. 2011 . However PBR systems have some limitations in terms of cost overheating oxygen accumulation due to CO2 depletion and oxygen saturation. Addition ally fouling affects light intensity and causes abrasion leading to a shorter PBR lifespan. Even though PBR systems are more effective in terms of nutrients and biomass utilization achieving optimal growth requires correct composition Carvalho et al. 2006 Fern andez et al. 2012 . Open systems are often thought to be used for large-scale outdoor productions in the near future despite the advantages of closed photo bioreactors over the open system. The higher cell density and biomass productivity attainable in a closed system may not compensate for its excessive capital and operating costs Mata et al. 2010 . The most important parameter to assess larger photo-bioreactor design is areal productivity which is reported as an average 12 14 g dw m 2 day-1. High oil species of microalgae culture in growth- optimized conditions of photo-bioreactors have the ability to produce 19 000 to 57 0000 L of microalgal oil per acre per year Lam et al. 2019 . Photo-bioreactors have higher efficiency and biomass concen tration 2 5 g L shorter harvest time 2 4 weeks and higher surface to volume ratio 25 125 m than open ponds Wang et al. 2014 . Lehr and Posten 2009 reported that biomass yields up to 200 t per hectare and year could be achievable with improved photobioreactors. PBR can be operated in batch semi-continuous or continuous systems coupled with M. Bello et al. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 9 incorporated automation and feedback subsystems to stabilize the in ternal conditions Greenwell et al. 2010 . A newly designed tubular or flat plate PBR configuration offers shorter optical paths under illumi nation Lam et al. 2019 . Airlift photo-bioreactor is the most promising reactor for carbon sequestration from the flue gas with characteristics qualities of high gas transfer low hydrodynamic stress and ease of control. More desirable qualities of surface to volume ratio and scal ability will be recorded on integrating a tubular loop with airlift Lam et al. 2019 Kumar et al. 2011 . Ideally the auxiliary energy needed for mixing and gas transfer should not exceed 2 W m2 and biomass concentration should be 20 g l at photobioreactor cost of 40 m2 Lehr and Posten 2009 . However 2.5W m2 with biomass 118 t ha calculated from energy balance and Areal energy harvest of 7.5W m2 for bubbled and airlift photo-bioreactor and 50 70 W m3 for flat plate reactor was reported Lehr and Posten 2009 . Fern andez et al. 2012 reported photosyn thetic efficiency PE ratio that relates the energy produced as biomass with regard to the supplied energy as irradiance as efficient for both closed 9.3 and open systems 8.6 . Total life cycle energy of 199.5GJ tonne of biodiesel was obtained for the hypothetical produc tion of biodiesel from Chlorella vulgaris cultivated in a conventional tubular photobioreactor in UK Stephenson et al. 2010 . Singapore experienced 0.56 MJ cultivation + harvesting + dewatering total life cycle energy of hypothetical integrated PBR-raceway for the production of microalgae Nannochloropsis sp. conversion of microalgal lipids to biodiesel via trans-esterification Khoo et al. 2011 . A Net Energy Ratio NER of 2.38 was obtained for offshore microalgae cultivation for biofuel production via flocculation Singh et al. 2014 For the development of a photoautotrophic production system in closed photo-bioreactors achieving optimal growth requires correct composition. An ideal mixture is nutrient sufficient so as to check minimal cost and waste since the process of optimized media is specie and product specific. The use of nitrogen phosphorus potassium cal cium magnesium and Sulphur is sustained thus the application of phosphate is no longer sustainable due to the upstream energy cost of ammonia production and environmental implications. The quantity and quality of nutrients to be used in running a photo-bioreactor is based on elemental balance analysis and this implies that nutrient recycling is becoming an important issue Stephens et al. 2010 . Now the life-cycle quantities of nutrients without harvest water recycling are nitrogen 0.33 phosphorus 0.71 potassium 0.58 magnesium 0.27 and Sulphur 0.5 kg kg-biodiesel. However the amount of these nutrients reduces by approximately 55 when the harvested water is 100 recycled. Using sea wastewater can reduce nitrogen usage by 94 and eliminates the need of potassium magnesium and Sulphur. Decreasing the recycling rate of water automatically increases nutrient usage Yang et al. 2011 . Efficiency of photo-bioreactors is also assessed based on nutrient removal organic matter utilization and biomass chemical profile. Closed system tubular photo-bioreactor showed a higher cell N content compared to the open system. In the open system Nitrogen is removed during biomass growth and CO2 is diffused to the atmosphere. Photobioreactors have superior quality upon open systems in terms of nitrogen biomass uptake and organic matter utilization for biomass growth via CO2 uptake Fern andez et al. 2012 Fern andez et al. 2012 It looks so easy though very difficult to compare the effectiveness and efficiency of open ponds with closed ponds stemming from the interplay of various factors as there are various reporting productivity conventions such as volumetric productivity which is defined as the biomass productivities per unit reactor volume gC m-2 d-1 and areal productivities which refers to as the biomass produced per unit ground area occupied by the reactor gC m-2 d-1 Mata et al. 2010 . Biomass productivity however depends on the area illuminated being the most significant factor and can be deduced based on any combination of depth optical volume and concentration provided the depth and or con centration are enough for optical extinction to occur. Therefore optical depths and dilution rates a factor of cell concentration are important bioreactor design and operation criteria that are crucial for commercial purposes Flynn et al. 2010 . Greater optical depth of the reactor re quires less space for installation with a lower temperature fluctuations and evaporation losses. While lower dilution rate will create a dense culture with lower expense of growth media preparation effectively decreasing cell concentration and de-watering costs. A high dilution rate will result in low concentration leading to lower productivity as well. On the downside higher optical depths promote light limitation while low dilution rates are linked to low production rates Flynn et al. 2010 Malek et al. 2015 . Therefore appropriate optimal dilution rates and optical depths 0.1 m considering local climate are thus required for the balancing system areal and volumetric productivity Flynn et al. 2010 Kenny and Flynn 2015 Moreover volumetric productivity is only higher in closed ponds than in the open system with no glaring advantages in terms of areal productivity over the open system Richmond 2008 Mata et al. 2010 . However for a biorefinery application that recapitulates optimal commercial operations it is paramount to balance areal productivity and volumetric productivity to maximum levels so as to maximize land use minimize resources water and nutrients consumption and har vesting costs Flynn et al. 2010 Kenny and Flynn 2015 . Balancing volumetric productivity with areal productivity through manipulating pond depth and volume parameters has been demonstrated by Kenny and Flynn 2015 concluding that efficient biofuel productions require the combinations of a fast-growing strain and nutrient deficiency which can be promoted by shallow optical depth and relatively slow dilution rates. These aforementioned differences generated interest in comparing the throughput of open systems with closed reactors listed in Table 4. 3.11. Downstream technologies 3.11.1. Harvesting technologies and their technical prospects Microalgae are the most rapidly growing algae species that are difficult to harvest because it is very small 0.3 5 g l and often motile unicells 2 40 μm see Table 5 . Hence there is a strong relationship between the development of the harvesting technique and the selection of algae species for mass culture. Moreover the selection of harvesting techniques is dependent on the properties of microalgae such as density and size which determines how easily the species can be settled and filtered coupled with the value of the desired product. The cost of harvesting recovery of algal biomass is also a challenging issue because of a very low mass fraction in culture broth and negative polarity and thus accounts for 20 30 of the total cost of production Chen et al. 2011 Brennan and Owende 2010 . The aim of harvesting is to obtain slurry with at least 2 7 of algal suspension on a dry matter basis . Singh et al. 2011 . In short the main stimulating engineering demand rests in reducing the energetic consumptions of separating or isolating the microalgal cells from the culture medium which ultimately de termines the cost of production. The cost of harvesting is fundamental to microalgal biomass production accounting for 20 30 of the total cost. After aqueous cultivation of microalgae dewatering to produce dry algal biomass is a preparatory stage to deliver algae to the next stage Khoo et al. 2011 . The aim of harvesting is to obtain slurry with at least 2 7 of algal suspension on a dry matter basis and can be categorized as Singh et al. 2011 . 1. Bulk harvesting the aim is to separate the microalgal biomass from the bulk suspension. Using this method the total solid matter can reach 2 7 using a concentration factor of 100 800 times applying flocculation flotation or gravity sedimentation Brennan and Owende 2010 . 2. Thickening filtration centrifugation and ultrasonic aggregation harvesting techniques are used in this method to concentrate the slurry. The process is more energy-intensive than bulk harvesting Brennan and Owende 2010 . M. Bello et al. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 10 The main harvesting techniques for microalgae are. Filtration and related-mechanical harvesting using filtration by means of strong membranes such as microscreens and microstainers. Settling and sedimentation-gravity and centrifugal sedimentation. Chemical Methods-chemical and or biological harvesting such as by means of flocculants e.g. auto-flocculation chemical coagulation inorganic coagulants organic flocculants combined flocculation electrocoagulation and ultrasonic aggregation. Centrifugation-algae can also be harvested using centrifugation. Flotation-froth floatation is a method whereby the water and algae are aerated into froth with the algae then removed from the water and Table 4 Technical prospect and areas for development of microalgae cultivation systems. Microalgae and Cyanobacteria posed an outstanding filtration challenge because most strains considered for energy feedstock have cell diameters less than 10 μm rgy.gov. Conventional filtration process is suitable for harvesting rela tively large 70 μm microalgae such as Coelastrum and Spiruli. It cannot be used for microalgae species 30 μm like Scenedesmus Dunaliella and Cholorella Brennan and Owende 2010 Menegazzo and Fonseca 2019 Sedimentation is applicable to open pond systems and usually with algae that have high intrinsic sedimentation rates in the water treatment process. Settling characteristics is a function of the density and radius of algae cells and sedimentation velocity as defined by Stokes law. Gravity sedimentation is mainly applied to harvesting microalgae in wastewater treatment because of the large volumes treated and the low value of the biomass generated Brennan and Owende 2010 . Gravity sedimentation is simple with low-cost energy. Sedimentation is a simple and very low process 0.1 2.6cmh-1 that can t be maintained at high-temperature environment Greenwell et al. 2010 . Gravity sedimentation is suit able to large microalgae ca. 70 μm such as Spirulina. For poorer sedimentation force flocculation is induced through the addition of chemicals or culture flocculation. But centrifugal sedimentation requires high energy cost higher maintenance requirements and harvesting ef ficiency of 95 and an increase in slurry concentration by up to 150 times for 15 total suspended solids is technically feasible. Flotation process by sedimentation is however very fast it requires few minutes for sedimentation. Capital and operating cost are also low but the ef ficiency is poor in shallow-depth ponds Singh et al. 2011 Brennan and Owende 2010 Wang et al. 2013 . Following the poor sedimentation properties of some algae strains due to inherent sizes and density chemical methods of harvesting can be used successfully for harvesting purposes. Flocculation is the collection of dispersed particles into an aggregated mass as a result of pH adjust ment usually involving chemical additives. If aggregation is a result of electrolyte addition is regarded as coagulation whereas aggregation as a result of polymer addition is termed as flocculation. Various flocculation methods may include Auto-flocculation bio-flocculation and Chemical coagulation. Chemical additives such as carbonates and hydroxides NaOH can induce physiochemical reactions between algae and pro mote auto-flocculation as a result of carbonate precipitation in elevated pH effectively depleting photosynthetic CO2. Culturing microalgae with another microorganism that promotes sedimentation can also induce bio-flocculation. An example is the use of microbial flocculants for harvesting mass culture of Chlorella vulgaris from Paenibacillys sp. AM49 was identified Chen et al. 2011 . Organic inorganic and poly electrolyte flocculants can be added in various solid-liquid separation processes to distinctive types of microalgae. Addition of inorganic co agulants such as iron aluminium or iron-based coagulants will disrupt the established microalgae system to enable harvesting. Organic flocculants can induce efficient flocculation of fresh water at low dosages between 1 and 10 mg l. Naturally organic substance such as chitosan polymer of glucosamine that is used for water treatment is also used as a flocculant with varied concentrations 40 mg l to 150 mg l in different algal strains Tetraselmis chui Thalassiosira pseudonana and Chaetoceros muelleri respectively due to its non-toxicity effect. Cationic polyelectrolyte and aluminium sulphate are the most promising and potentially tested flocculants. Non-ionic and anionic polyelectrolytes are regarded as ineffective flocculants due to electrostatic repulsion in teractions resulting in a bridging mechanism. The flocculants should be non-toxic inexpensive and effective in low concentrations and should have a positive effect on further downstream processing. Advantages of flocculation include the method is relatively cheap and contains high volume processing. While its disadvantages are the low solids contents of the biomass harvest 1 000K s short residence time 0.5 1s and very fine particles 100 MW . Sulphur emissions of 0.05-0.2 wt are reported upon direct combustion of biomass used for domestic stoves and boilers Raheem et al. 2015 . It is reported that a LCA of coal-algae co-firing could lead to lower GHG emissions and air pollution Goyal et al. 2008 Kosowska- Kosowska-Golachowska and Luckos 2022 Naik et al. 2010 . In another study a life-cycle assess ment LCA showed CO2 emissions can be decreased in conventional coal-firing power plants when even 1 of coal consumption is substituted by dried microalgae. have asserted that the direct combus tion strategy is expected to amplify negative emissions of microalgal energy systems through high energy yield and CO2 fixation which were confirmed by BP and CFP respectively. 3.11.5.2. Biochemical conversions. Chemical trans-esterification is a conversion technology that is employed to convert triacylglycerols extracted from algae biomass to fatty acid methyl esters FAME which is simply a displacement of an alcohol from an ester by another alcohol under the influences of supercritical fluids enzymatic acid-catalysed or alkali-catalysed Costa and De Morais 2011 DoE 2010 . Following M. Bello et al. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 17 transesterification reaction the two phases glycerine and esters that are produced are separated by evaporation decanting and centrifuging. The processing routes used different heating systems and catalysts such as acid-catalysed H2SO4 HCL or H3PO4 and base-catalysed methanol ethanol and sodium ethanolate . Heating systems include microwave which increases the kinetics of esterification Refaat and El Sheltawy 2008 . But Motasemi and Ani 2012 reported that microwave pro cessing may be cost-intensive. Other methods of heating that may reduce the reaction time reaction temperature and energy input include ultrasonic and cavitation methods even though achieving scalable production via ultrasonic devices requires significant research and innovations DoE 2010 . Another processing route to convert biomass into green diesel fuels that are compatible with petroleum-derived diesel fuels is also focused on the esterification of oils with methanol to produce fatty methyl esters FAME . The process uses hydro-treating of vegetable oil that is based on catalytic saturation hydrodeoxygenation decarboxylation and hydro- isomerization. This technology is applicable for a variety of bio-oil feedstock to produce an isoparaffin-rich diesel aromatic and sulphur- free substitute with a very high cetane blending value and good cold flow properties. The higher quality diesel is readily blended with diesel fuel and therefore does not depend on process configuration and or feed origin in contrast to fatty methyl esters Naik et al. 2010 . Amin 2009 reported the achievable efficient conversion of triglycerides to biodiesel 98 and indicated that the produced biodiesel can be compatible with conventional petroleum derived diesel with a much lower cold filter plugging point of-11 in comparison with that of fuel diesel. Microalgal species Chlorella and Botrycoccus can reach up to 50 and 80 lipid productivity respectively and thus can be excellent sources of biodiesel. Biofuel from microalgal C. protothecoides and Microcytic aeruginosa has calorific values of 30 MJ kg and 29 MJ kg due to their high carbon and hydrogen content and low oxygen content which indicates that the level of stability for biofuel-obtained microalgae is high compared to biofuel from the plant Naik et al. 2010 . Costa and De Morais 2011 reported mean annual productivity of microalgal biomass in a tropical climate region as 1.53 kg m 3 day-1 with a mean 30 of lipids extracted from the biomass the concentration per hectare of the total area is around 123.0 m3 for 90.0 of the 365 days of a year. He thus calculated the yield of biodiesel from microalgae as 98.4 m3 ha-1. And suggested a possible scenario even if the concentration of lipids in the microalgal biomass was 15.0 of dry weight for the production of 5.4 billion m3 of biodiesel an area of approximately 5.4 Mha must be calculated which represents only 3.0 of the area currently used for the cultivation of plants for biodiesel. Microalgal anaerobic digestion AD is a process very similar to the intent of biogas generation. AD is the conversion of organic wastes into a mixture of methane and carbon dioxide commonly termed as biogas. Attention is paid to this conversion system due to the increasing cost of energy production. The major components of biogas include methane and carbon dioxide plus atmospheric nitrogen oxygen and traces of organic compounds are collectively known as landfill gas LFG . LFG is a low-quality gas that requires purification from volatile organic con taminants and CO2. LFG is used for electricity generation use in an in ternal combustion engine turbines and microturbines and direct use in boilers dryers kilns greenhouse and cogeneration Naik et al. 2010 Vargas-Estrada et al. 2022 Zabed et al. 2020 . Brennan and Owende 2010 described the three sequential stages of AD hydrolysis fermentation and methanogenesis. Breaking down of complex com pounds into soluble sugars occurred in the hydrolysis step followed by the conversion of sugars into alcohols acetic acid volatile fatty acids VFA and gas containing H2 and CO2 by fermentative bacteria which is metabolised into methane CH4 60 70 and CO2 30 40 by methanogens. AD process has a greater propensity for nutrient recycling and energy recovery Sialve et al. 2009 . Basically the throughput depends on the substrate employed for digestion optimal operating conditions for biogas production can be defined such as pH 6.8 7.5 temperature 30.0 35.0 C C N ratio 20 30 total solids 7.0 9.0 and time 20 40 days . The AD operating process is affected by organic loadings temperature pH retention time in reactors mesophilic con ditions 35 C and thermophilic conditions 55 C Harun et al. 2010 . But Vergara-Fern andez et al. 2008 showed that biogas with methane concentration 50 65 can be generated from marine algae which can be used as a fuel gas and also can be converted to generate electricity Harun et al. 2010 and can also be used onsite to assist some of the processes that require thermal energy e.g. drying the algae Harun et al. 2010 Zabed et al. 2020 . Various authors in the literature have discusses immensely the potentials of microalgae as the biogas feed stocks screening and selection approaches of potent strains of micro algae technological aspects of microalgal biogas production reactor design for anaerobic digestion AD operational conditions affecting AD strategies for improving strains and biogas yield biogas upgrading kinetics modelling value added product and as well as economics life cycle assessment LCA coupled with the integration of AD process with microalgae biofuel production using AD processes Gonzalez-Fernandez et al. 2015 Vargas-Estrada et al. 2022 Zabed et al. 2020 . The solid residual biomass after digestion can be further utilized for bio-fertilizer production incinerated or used in animal feed Costa and de Morais 2011 . AD process is particularly suitable for high moisture 80 90 organic waste which can be useful for the optimization of wet algal biomass. AD process can be utilized to generate liquid fuel and biofertilizers for agricultural production Brennan and Owende 2010 Costa and de Morais 2011 Naik et al. 2010 . Currently research attention has been diverted to the production of liquid fuels methanol rather than gaseous fuels methane from anaerobic digestion. This is because of the inherent cost connected to methane purification and collection. The advantages of methanol production include a Produc tion of low Sulphur and low ash fuels in commercial quantities and b Liquid fuel is much easier to handle store and transport than gaseous products Naik et al. 2010 . Zamalloa et al. 2011 has estimated the cost range of biomass to be 86-124 ton 1 DM available for bio-methanation under the premise of achievable up-concentrations of 0.2 0.6 kg m-3 to 20 60 kg dry matter DM m 3 plus effective bio-methanation of the concentrate at a loading rate of 20 kg DM m 3 d 1. Algae biomass-total energy module would be in the order of 0.170 0.087 kWh 1 considering carbon credit of about 30 ton 1 CO2 eq Zamalloa et al. 2011 . Photo-biological hydrogen production is a two-stage photosynthetic production of hydrogen in which the second stage is subjected to anaerobic conditions for consistent production of hydrogen. The process efficiency involved either two-stage production or simultaneous pro duction of hydrogen. In the two-stage process photosynthetic oxygen production and H2 generation are spatially separated such that algae are grown initially and photosynthetically in a normal condition followed by Sulphur deprivation under anaerobic conditions to consistently produce hydrogen Brennan and Owende 2010 . In the second type of production electrons that are released upon photosynthetic H20 oxidation are fed directly into the hydrogenase-mediated hydro gen-evolution process. Brennan and Owende 2010 . The hydrogen productivity in the two-stage process is more optimistic than the Simultaneous approach due to severe hydrogenase inhibition due to the photosynthetic oxygen produced in the process Brennan and Owende 2010 . Saifuddin and Priatharsini 2016 have reviewed the production of hydrogen from microalgae biomass describing the four effective methods that are involved direct bio-photolysis photo-fermentation dark fermentation and indirect bio-photolysis. Even though sulphur deprivations techniques are involved to enhance the hydrogen yield but challenges due to low biomass concentrations and significant processing costs present a stumbling block for the industrial viability of the process and thus require further research for its realization. It is paramount to appreciate that bio-hydrogen production from microalgae is more energy-efficient than conventional methods and advocates for M. Bello et al. Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 18 integrating hydrogen production with high-value products for sustain ability. There is a greater need for understanding the biological pro cesses and enzymes involved to advance sustainable hydrogen technologies from microalgae biomass. 4. Conclusion Presently there are many evolving and potential microalgae tech nologies that are under investigation but the challenge that remains for various algal-to-biofuel technologies is demonstrating their efficacy in large-scale production for commercial application. More often than not the most viable technologies for microalgal biofuels and bio-chemical productions are evaluated in terms of their throughput cost energy requirement scalability resources requirement and environmental performance. Various technical challenges such as microalgal biomass cultivation systems harvesting and drying processes and algal biofuel conversion methods are still not matured but are in the early stage of research and development R D . Intensive ventures in R D are vigorously needed to ensure the technical viability and commercial feasibility of the algae-to-bioenergy system. From the techno-economic standpoint recent trends have indicated that the algal-to-biofuel process is still considerably expensive in comparison to what is being envisaged in terms of other renewables and compared to fossil fuels thus strong political support is needed to catalyse the commercial viability of the algal biofuel process so as to be able to compete constructively in the global biofuel market. More often than not multidisciplinary research and development approaches in algae-to-energy systems could help in achieving the desired progress including genetic modification for high oil content and selection of algae strains mixed algae cultivations in tegrated with wastewater for high biomass yield and low cultivation cost the multi-product integrated biorefinery approach intertwined with new technologies for maximum oil recovery such as hydrothermal liquefaction process. This is a clear indication that optimism for using algal biomass to produce alternative fuels has been pampered and thus advanced improvements are needed to address the industrial sustain ability of utilizing this renewable feedstock for commercial application.
