Journal of Environmental Management 370 2024 122208 21', 'Review article Advancements in sustainable production of biofuel by microalgae Recent insights and future directions Muhammad Abdullah a b 1 Zain Ali b 1 Muhammad Talha Yasin b 1 Kinza Amanat b Fatima Sarwar c Jallat Khan b c Khurshid Ahmad d a Industrial Biotechnology Division National Institute for Biotechnology Genetic Engineering P.O. Box 577-Jhang Road Faisalabad Pakistan b Institute of Biological Sciences Khwaja Fareed University of Engineering Information Technology 64200 Rahim Yar Khan Pakistan c Institute of Chemistry Khwaja Fareed University of Engineering Information Technology 64200 Rahim Yar Khan Pakistan d State Key Laboratory of Marine Food Processing Safety Control College of Food Science and Engineering Ocean University of China No. 1299 Sansha Road Qingdao Shandong Province 266404 PR China A R T I C L E I N F O Keywords Microalgae Pretreatment Saccharification Transesterification Biofuel LCA A B S T R A C T Microalgae is considered as sustainable and viable feedstock for biofuel production due to its significant ad vantages over terrestrial plants. Algal biofuels have received significant attention among researchers and energy experts owing to an upsurge in global energy issues emanating from depletion in fossil fuel reserves increasing greenhouse gases emission conflict among agricultural crops traditional biomass feedstock and potential fu turistic energy security. Further the exploration of value-added microalgae as sustainable and viable feedstock for the production of variety of biofuels such as biogas bio-hydrogen bioethanol and biodiesel are addressed. Moreover the assessment of life-cycle energy balance and environmental impacts of biofuel production from microalgae are briefly discussed. The present study focused on recent advancements in synthetic biology metabolic engineering tools algal bio refinery and the optimization of algae growth conditions. This paper also elucidates the function of microalgae as bio refineries the conditions of algae-based cultures and other oper ational factors that must be adjusted to produce biofuels that are price-competitive with fossil fuels. 1. Introduction Consumption of fossil fuels emits greenhouse gases GHGs which impact the global climate risking both human life and ecological sys tems Duan 2023 Lelieveld et al. 2019 . Currently fossil fuels account for 90 of the energy requirement worldwide which has led to several serious issues such as energy crises and environmental challenges Martins et al. 2019 . These concerns need to be addressed by finding more sustainable renewable and efficient energy sources. The origi nation of biofuels from biomass which is considered one of the most practical energy alternative sources to reduce reliance on fossil fuels. Biofuels are considered superior to fossil fuels in several ways including sustainability non-toxicity biodegradability and incredibly low carbon dioxide CO2 emissions Malla et al. 2022 . The preparation of biofuel from biomass has several advantages i.e. they produce renewable en ergy reduce environmental pollution and climate change. The primary cause of global warming is the release of greenhouse gases as a result of combustion of fossil fuels. Wang and Azam 2024 Soeder 2021 Petroleum-based fuels have negligible oxygen levels with substantial sulfur emissions whereas biofuels particularly algal fuels have oxygen levels of 10 45 and extremely low sulfur emissions. To optimize en ergy generation and low cost the development of feedstock is an essential cost-limiting step in the production of biofuels. The choice of biomass for biofuel synthesis has a direct impact on economic envi ronmental sustainability and greenhouse gas emission Cerri et al. 2017 . Biodiesel and bioethanol are commonly used in crop-based biofuels rapeseed palm sugarcane corn and so on are made from lipid-based substrates Wang et al. 2022 . These biofuels also known as first-generation biofuels recent issues about the use of first-generation biofuels are mostly due to the issues related to ecosystem imbalance and the requirement for greater area of cultivable land to produce a sufficient amount of crop-based biofuels Barr et al. 2021 . On contrary to that a cultivable crop causes less issues due to attaining efficient area Corresponding author. E-mail addresses M. Abdullah Z. Ali M.T. Yasin . 1 Authors contributed equally to this work. Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Environmental Research journal homepage Received 31 May 2024 Received in revised form 27 August 2024 Accepted 30 August 2024 Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 Available online 31 August 2024 0013-9351 2024 Elsevier Inc. All rights are reserved including those for text and data mining AI training and similar technologies. and several factors such as cropping seasonality quality of soil water availability and fertilizer supply fluctuations. Furthermore several non-edible feed-stocks including agricultural residues and waste or spent cooking oils have been effectively transformed into bioethanol and biodiesel respectively. These are referred as second-generation biofuels. Non-edible feed-stocks continue to possess a limited capacity to satisfy the world s total energy needs Jamil 2023 . Green algae can survive in a variety of aquatic environments such as rivers lakes sea and even in wastewater. They grow independently or in association with other species Salvatore et al. 2023 and they have the ability to endure a wide range of unfavorable circumstances including reservoirs and deserts as well as variations in different external stimuli Barsanti et al. et al. 2008 . Algae are classified into three general groups Phaeophyta brown algae Chlorophyta green algae and Rhodophyta red algae . They are further divided into two distinct categories macroalgae and microalgae. Seaweed also known as macroalgae which is large multicellular algae that can be seen with unaided eye Abdelfattah et al. 2023 single-celled algae that can be either eukaryotic like green algae Chlorophyta or prokaryotic such as cyanobacteria Chloroxybacteria . According to reports 1 kg of algal biomass exchange 1.83 kg of CO2 moreover certain species employ nitrogen-oxides NOx and sulfur-oxides SOx as feedstock in addition to CO2 Gendy and El-Temtamy 2013 . Half of the dry mass of algal biomass is made up of CO2. The benefits of microalgal as a source of biofuels involve their higher photosynthetic efficiency their growth on non-cultivable land their utilization of salty and wastewater sources. Additionally short life cycles enable almost constant harvesting Larkum et al. 2012 . Microalgae that are capable of flourishing on waste materials and possessing an abundance of lipids could offer a practical choice for sourcing biomass as they will not interfere with the availability of food resources during the production of biofuels Ali et al. 2023 . Microalgae have gained a lot of interest among other biomass types for usage as a possible feedstock because of their high lipid and carbohydrate content quick growth rate and resilience to changing environmental circumstances Bhattacharya et al. 2022 . Moreover the development of molecular biology techniques such as zinc-finger nucleases ZFN transcription activator-like effectors TALEs clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats CRISPR and genetic transformation are being used for the design and synthesis of new biological systems to make advances in the production of biofuel. These advancements have also made it possible to decipher novel metabolic pathways within algal cells Larkum et al. 2012 Bhattacharya et al. 2022 . Microalgae have other extensive feasible applications also such as biological remediation and the production of See Fig. 1 valuable products De Souza et al. 2019 . The world need for energy keeps increasing due to the rapidly growing population Dey et al. 2021 . Fossil fuels such as coal diesel and petrol account for a large portion of the energy consumed worldwide. Nevertheless the primary causes of the deterioration of air quality are environmental pollution climate change global warming and the depletion of the ozone layer driven by the burning of fossil fuels. By 2030 global energy consumption is expected to spike by 50 as projected by the Interna tional Energy Agency IEA Dey et al. 2021 . To solve critical issues like global warming and environmental pollution the suggested solution is the production of algal biofuel. The main concepts of biofuel genera tions challenges and future perspectives associated with micro-algal based biofuels are emphasized. This study will be helpful for future development advancement of efficient and economically feasible technology for microalgae-based production of biofuel. 2. Biofuel generations 2.1. First generation biofuels Biofuels can be classified into first- and second-generation technol ogies. First-generation biofuels involve liquid and gaseous fuels comprising biodiesel bio-ethers bio-alcohol and vegetable oil. The first-generation G1 feedstock comprises oil-bearing seeds and food edible crops such as starch sugarcane rapeseed sunflower palm and animal fats Ganesan et al. 2020 . Triglycerides which are connected to an ester molecule are able to be transformed into biofuels by several methods such as transesterification anaerobic digestion fermentation and pyrolysis. The first-generation biofuels can be utilized either in their pure form or enhanced by blending Nanda et al. 2018 . Edible crop oils such as mustard lemon seed wheat germ rice bran coconut soybean rapeseed sunflower almond and pistachio are used in the manufacturing of biofuels Dey et al. 2021 Hazrat et al. 2019 . Bio diesel plants are employed in Europe North America South America and Asia while maize and sugarcane are considered highly profitable industries in nations such as India the United States France Germany Australia and China. Although first-generation fuels contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gas GHG emission and air pollution they can have nega tive effects on food security and lead to societal disputes. The future viability of first-generation fuels is a matter of concern particularly when taking into account stakeholder perspectives in the assessment and ranking of certain generating technologies Ganesan et al. 2020 . The growing significance of utilizing crops for biofuel has led to the ongoing food versus fuel controversy as these crops have become more in demand for food production. Moreover the surge in the need for crops such as maize for the purpose of fuel generation resulted in a rise in the market price of these food items Nazari et al. 2021 as shown in Fig. 2 . Fig. 1. Potential applications of microalgae in various fields. M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 2 2.2. Second generation biofuels Second-generation biofuels are produced by combining lignocellu losic biomass from agriculture and agro-industrial leftovers with other waste streams from the food sector such as wheat bran fats from ani mals and waste cooking oil. Non-food plants growing in wastelands such as the drought-tolerant shrub and Jatropha curcas potentially be a viable source Kumar and Sharma 2008 . These biofuels avoid changes in agricultural land usage and cannot compete with food supplies. Second-generation waste streams on the other hand often comprise complex feedstocks that can include chemicals that limit fermentation efficiency demand extra pretreatment processes and increase process time and costs Malode et al. 2021 . The commercial production of first and second-generation biofuels was observed in 2019 with respective outputs of 4 and 96 Abdullah et al. 2019 . As an example Clariant s Sunliquid is a cellulosic ethanol made from straw and other underused agricultural byproducts. The first commercial ethanol plant industry in Romania began operations in 2022 producing 50 000 tons of ethanol a year from 250 000 tons of domestically obtained agricultural leftovers Cavelius et al. 2023 . Microbial lipids produced by organisms like the yeast Cutaneo trichosporon oleaginosus can also be used to make second-generation biodiesel. This is because these organisms can make up to 90 lipids per biomass via fermentation Malode et al. 2021 Abdullah et al. 2019 . Second-generation biodiesel can also be produced from oil res idue using catalytic cracking and hydrogenation however there are downsides such as partial conversion and coke production Cavelius et al. 2023 Fuchs et al. 2021 . Biobutanol is usually made from lignocellulose material and other waste streams using Clostridia fermentation which is one of the oldest and most well-known ways to make butanol through fermentation. Several Clostridia are natural butanol makers with the capacity to metabolize a wide range of substrates. However the method is inef fective and has weak butanol titers and product inhibition Younes et al. 2020 Zhang et al. 2022a . Although cell-free isobutanol production via a planned artificial metabolic route has been created commercialization remains prohibitively expensive. At the moment commercialization of this technology is not economic Guterl et al. 2012 . 2.3. Third generation biofuels Primary source of third-generation biofuels is biomass derived from cyanobacteria and microalgae which are naturally capable of producing lipids and alcohols that can be converted into biodiesel or other fuel products. Algae produce biomass more rapidly than terrestrial plants because their photosynthesis rates are 2 4 times greater than other plants Li et al. 2008 Rabbani et al. 2024 . Some of the unique characteristics of algae include a their ability to absorb carbon dioxide during growth which helps to reduce the greenhouse impact b their small growth requirements in comparison to other food crops c their ability to adapt to saltwater and d a high lipid content Mathimani and Pugazhendhi 2019 Pandey et al. 2011 Policastro et al. 2024 . In freshwater and aquatic environments microalgae are the foundation of life. There are sixteen groups and 72 500 species. The three primary groups are diatoms Chlorophyceae and Chrysophyceae. The most researched groups for biological implications include diatoms cyano bacteria and cyanophyceae Patel et al. 2022 . These algae can with stand extreme climatic conditions and develop swiftly forming a baggy layer on the water s surface. Research and cultivation of algae for the production of high-value goods are being conducted in several nations Jacob-Lopes et al. 2019 . A few examples of algae that have received research attention are Chlamydomonas reinhardtii 21 lipids 48 Fig. 2. The evolution of biofuel from 1st generation crops to 4th generation genetic engineering . M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 3 sugars Spirulina platensis 8 lipids 60 sugars Chlorella sp. 19 lipids 56 sugars Ranjbar and Malcata 2022 Mathimani and Pugazhendhi 2019 and the composition for other algal strains is listed below in Table 1. Algae for their production do not need either culti vable land or clean water. Waste water brackish water or salt water can also be used to cultivate a plethora of different kinds of cultures which is both economical and avoids conflict with farming Melcher et al. 2021 . The most critical component for effective algal growth is a direct supply of carbon dioxide which can be obtained from either industrial sources or atmospheric carbon capture. In conventional cultivating systems approximately 70 of the provided carbon dioxide is utilized for photosynthesis and thus biomass generation Cavelius et al. 2023 . Algae culture is an extremely important and flexible step in the development of algal biofuels from a financial perspective. Since algal bioreactors do not rely on environmental conditions or geographic location they can potentially run almost anywhere. Biofuels and other low-priced high-volume goods are often made from algae cultivated in open ponds. Open-pond systems are less expensive but they have problems such as excessive loss of water and a lack of temperature control which reduces biomass output. For high-priced low-volume items such as cosmetic components the utilization of closed photo bioreactors is encouraged. These bioreactors provide more accurate regulation of process parameters which in turn increases output Pandey et al. 2011 Raut et al. 2015 . In contrast to higher plants which tend to have their lipids concentrated in certain areas like rape seeds algae have the potential to store a large quantity of lipids in every cell making their oil manufacturing process more effective overall Lee et al. 2015 . However the culture conditions have an impact on the lipid content of microalgae. By maximizing the growth-determining parameters the lipid content can potentially be raised beyond the average by over 80 Rodionova et al. 2017 . The cell walls of microalgae usually contain cellulose protein lignin pectin hemi celluloses and other carbs. These can be broken down into monomers using acids or enzymes to make bioethanol Neto et al. 2019 . However since microalgal cells are sensitive to pH fluctuations and have a small size and density harvesting creates a challenge Lee et al. 2015 . In the European Union in 2021 Araujo Araújo et al. 2021 identified 447 production units for algae and the cyanobacteria Spirulina . Commer cial usage of biofuels accounted for a negligible fraction of the biomass directed by these enterprises the majority of which went toward food feed and associated products. The commercialization process requires more technical advancements in upscaling and lowering manufacturing expenses Cavelius et al. 2023 . 3. Microalgae cultivation and harvesting for biofuels via sustainable approach Microalgae are capable of storing an abundance of energy-dense substances like triacylglycerol starch and proteins See Fig. 3 when they are allowed to thrive in optimal conditions Schüler et al. 2017 . These molecules are packed with energy and are capable of being changed into biodiesel bioethanol and biogas Khoo et al. 2023 . These Biofuels are commonly referred to as third-generation biofuels indi cating that they represent a whole new category in the area of renewable bioenergy Rafa et al. 2021 . Algae cultivation Algae are a great option for use as a primary source for biofuel production due to their fast growth rate. Algae can be cultivated in either open or closed systems. Open systems such as ponds and lakes are generally suitable for enhancing production simply because they are technically less complicated compared to closed systems Borowitzka and Vonshak 2017 . The optimal layout of the cultivation system would allow the maximum amount of sunlight to reach every single algal cell. Open ponds have a significant production potential but their yield is lower compared to closed systems due to a number of factors including water temperature moisture losses the diffusion of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere and the risks of contamination. Photobioreactors which are closed systems provide a controlled and regulated cultivation environment with a lower chance of contamination. Additionally more light penetrates the algae on a broad surface area. On the contrary better agitation opportunities in a closed photobioreactor lead to an enhancement in the fixation of CO2 functionality over an open system. Closed systems also provide greater heat retention than open systems but there are some downsides to scaling them up. Thus it tends to be more expensive than open growing systems and size limitations Andersson et al. 2014 . Photosynthesis-driven biomass accumulation develops in nitrogen- rich environments whereas lipid development in microalgae takes place under stressful situations like inadequate nutrient availability Udayan et al. 2023 . This contradiction significantly disrupts the ongoing production of lipids hence impacting the economic stability of the system. The fed-batch procedure is significantly considered as an optimal approach for cultivating microalgae owing to its ability to Fig. 3. Nutrients of different microalgae species. In research done by Zheng Zheng et al. 2013 it was shown that the lipid concentration and algal biomass had a significant rise with the application of fed-batch bioreactor. Furthermore research has demonstrated that the provision of light in both phototrophic and mixotrophic processes during the fed-batch culture leads to enhanced production of lipids Cheirsilp and Torpee 2012 . 3.1.1. Open-pond systems Open-pond cultivation is considered a financially viable approach for the large-scale cultivation of microalgae due to its straightforward na ture minimal energy requirements and capacity for expansion Costa and De Morais 2014 . It can be used in aquatic bodies such as lakes and ponds non-natural water bodies such as circular and raceway ponds and containers such as tanks. However due to the low cell concentration of microalgae in freshwater an effective collecting technique is required Tan et al. 2020 . Microalgal productivity in open water bodies can be substantially impacted by various challenges including rainfall discharge bank erosion and contamination by protozoa and bacteria Siddiki et al. 2022 . To overcome these concerns microalgae can be cultivated in severe alkaline or saline environments where just a few pollutants can persist. Furthermore since the system is open it is not possible to manage some growth factors such as temperature and light intensity which can influence the growth rate of microalgae. Despite these obstacles open-pond cultivation is still a common method for growing microalgae Tan et al. 2020 . The potential solutions or im provements have been made to mitigate these issues in open-pond sys tems such as mixotrophic cultivation technique utilizing multiple algal strains and internet of things. The Mixotrophic Cultivation technique integrates both photosyn thetic and heterotrophic growth modes which improves productivity and nutrient consumption making the method more effectual. Utilizing multiple algal strains can enhance the resilience of systems against environmental changes and contamination resulting in more stable and productive systems Qin et al. 2019 . Automated monitoring and control systems that are implemented in algal growth can maintain optimal conditions for growth such as pH temperature and nutrient levels. Lastly the Internet of Things IoT can provide real-time data and remote management capabilities which can improve the overall effi ciency and scalability of open-pond systems Fabris et al. 2020 . The earliest artificial ponds utilized for large-scale microalgal farming were circular ponds. These circular-shaped tanks are 30 70 cm deep and 45 m wide with a spinning agitator in the center. The agitator enables proper mixing and prevents algal biomass from sedimenting. The size of the pond however limits the design because larger ponds have more water resistance which can put strain on the stirrer s me chanical components Tan et al. 2020 . Furthermore the design con sumes a lot of energy during the agitation process and has significant construction costs Hamed 2016 . A practical example has been observed in Japan and Taiwan for the cultivation of Chlorella Tan et al. 2020 . 3.1.2. Photo-bioreactors closed-system A photo-bioreactor is a bioreactor system that is used to cultivate phototrophs such as microalgae in a tightly enclosed environment thereby overcoming the usual limitations of pond cultivation systems. Its tiny size and carefully regulated growing conditions enable more effective utilization of space as well as improved nutritional and meta bolic efficiency resulting in increased biomass output per unit of sub strate Tan et al. 2020 . However due to design problems photobioreactors have limited scalability making them costly for large-scale manufacturing Gupta et al. 2015 . Tubular photobioreactors are made up of prolonged transparent tubes made of glass or polymers that are stacked in different orientations to maximize sunlight collection. A filter system with cooling attachment is present followed by a mechanical pump which is used to spread microalgae culture inside the loop Fig. 4 . The primary disadvantage of tubular photobioreactors is poor mass transport throughout the system which lead to variations in substrate and product concentrations. In Germany and Israel large-scale tubular photobioreactors are utilized to cultivate Haematococcus and Chlorella Tan et al. 2020 . Similarly vertical column bioreactors are used to cultivate Chlorella zofingiensis in Guangdong China Huo et al. 2018 whereas Algamo a firm in Krkonoe Czech Republic uses flat-plate photobioreactors to manufac ture astaxanthin Koushalya et al. 2022 . Open-pond setups for microalgal culture are cheap and simple to operate making them suited for large-scale operations owing to their simple design and dependence on natural sunlight which results in cheaper startup and ongoing expenditures Baldev et al. 2022 . They use less energy for stirring and maintaining temperatures which further reduces operational costs Narala et al. 2016 . However they confront obstacles such as increased contamination threats from external sources and a reliance on meteorological conditions which can reduce pro ductivity Xiaogang et al. 2022 . On the other hand closed systems or photobioreactors provide a regulated environment that reduces contamination concerns and allows for constant output resulting in increased biomass productivity. These systems have a higher initial cost and running expenses due to the need for artificial lighting temperature control and more complicated infrastructure. Furthermore closed sys tems use more energy to sustain ideal growth conditions and need more technical knowledge to operate and retain Koushalya et al. 2022 . Ultimately the decision between open-pond and closed systems is based on unique operational requirements available assets and the ideal equilibrium of cost level of complexity and efficiency. 3.2. Algae harvesting Algae harvesting is the process of separating or detaching algae from medium in which they grow. The characteristics of the chosen micro algae such as their size and density as well as the particular needs of the end products and the potential for reusing the growing medium all have a major impact on the harvesting technique Fabris et al. 2020 Hamed 2016 Gupta et al. 2015 . Algal harvesting techniques that are now accessible often rely on chemical biological mechanical and electrical principles. However to get a greater level of microalgal separation at a lower price it is feasible to use two harvesting methods combined. Employing the sequential downstream processes of flocculation sedi mentation and centrifugation can significantly reduce processing costs Fabris et al. 2020 Hamed 2016 . The primary methods executed for microalgal harvesting are centrifugation filtering flocculation sedimentation flotation and electrophoresis Ananthi et al. 2021 . 3.2.1. Flocculation Flocculation refers to the act of separating solute granules from a liquid by forming clumps called flocs Mubarak et al. 2019 . Microalgal harvesting techniques using flocculation include four mechanisms that can occur either in pairs or individually i The charge neutralization process involves the adsorption of charged microalgal cell surfaces by oppositely charged ions polymers or colloids. ii The electrostatic patch mechanism functions when polymers with opposite charges hold the charge on the surface of an algae cell. This creates patches that connect microalgal cells with opposite charges and cause them to stick together. iii The bridging process occurs when charged colloids or polymers adhere to the membrane of two distinct microalgal cells creating a bridge. iv Sweeping flocculation in which the particles that precipitate in the culture medium capture microalgal cells Vandamme 2013 . Due to the negative charge of algae cells they can be counter acted by introducing flocculants such as cationic polymers and multi valent cations observed in the liquid Matter et al. 2019 . M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 6 3.2.2. Flotation The process of flotation is employed to harvest microalgal cells on a commercial scale and works on the concept of the separation of bubbles connected to destabilized particles rising to the top and concentrating when mixed with flocculants Esteves et al. 2020 . Biological compo nent recovery was accomplished in a single step by utilizing surface-active components to absorb them into the air bubble surface at a higher concentration coefficient Phong et al. 2017 . The microalgae cell surface is also hydrophobic which makes it easy to separate the biomass from the culture by adding a surfactant. Floating efficiency is affected by several factors such as the following the size of particles floating rate pH medium ionic strength air tank pressure hydraulic retention time water recycling rate surfactant type and concentration Pooja et al. 2022 . The low-density microalgal cells have self-floating properties making this type of separation quicker and more effective than sedimentation Xu et al. 2021 . 3.2.2.1. Dissolved air flotation DAF . Algal cells are removed from the top of the solution using air-dissolved flotation an energy-intensive technique. This method increases the effectiveness of flotation by add ing supersaturated water at low pressure. In order to separate flocs bigger bubbles are required Park et al. 2011 . When it comes to algae the efficiency of the separation using Poly-DADMAC is 95 but with cationic CTAB and metal coagulant aluminum sulfate it s 60 63 Ananthi et al. 2021 . 3.2.2.2. Dispersed air flotation. The flotation cells are powered by airflow that passes through porous materials such as spargers or dis persers using a technique called foam or froth flotation. This method demands costly equipment for producing air bubbles and uses a low amount of energy while operating at high pressure Nguyen et al. 2013 . According to Kurniawati Kurniawati et al. 2014 and Park Park et al. 2011 when certain synthetic and natural collectors like sodium dodecyl sulfate SDS chitosan saponin and N-cetyl-N-N-N trimethy lammonium bromide CTAB are added to the flotation process it be comes even more effective. Researcher Phoochinda Phoochinda and White 2003 discovered that Scenedesmusquadricauda floated 90 of the time with the use of CTAB which increased the rate of aeration and decreased the size of air bubbles. In 2014 Kurniawati Kurniawati et al. 2014 discovered that using 20 mg L of saponin and 5 mg L of chitosan as flocculants helped separate more than 93 of microalgae cells using the flotation method. In a study conducted by Garg Garg et al. 2015 it was shown that the use of a sophisticated flotation apparatus in conjunction with collector dodecyl pyridinium chloride DPC resulted in a 23-fold increase in algal concentration and a 99 rate of recovery of marine microalgal cells. 3.2.2.3. Filtration. Filtration harvesting is a technique that relies only on gravity forces and operates in a vacuum or under pressure Fasaei et al. 2018 . There are two possible states for this process continuous and discontinuous. Aside from hoovers and pressure filters several in dustrial filters use gravitational forces to screen bigger particles through a mesh or a layer of coarse particles similar to sand. Filter aids can be applied before filtering pre-coat to keep thepermeability which helps prevent the creation of thick and impermeable cake that plugs the filter media. Several applications have been designed to satisfy the demands of industrial equipment taking into account the scale of the equipment. Filtration under low pressure or gravity forces is also employed to Fig. 4. Algal biomass production in a Tubular Photobioreactor closed-system . M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 7 harvest all microalgal cell cultures including filamentous algal species such as Arthrospira spirulina. The membrane filtering method produces the most suitable biomass with no chemical intervention and it has the fewest disruptions to the cells compared to the other harvesting methods Fabris et al. 2020 Vandamme 2013 . 3.2.3. Centrifugation In centrifugation a centrifugal force is used to speed up the move ment and separation of particles. Separation is based on the change in density between the particles and the medium around them. Centrifugal force is often used to enhance productivity decrease gravity sedimen tation and accelerate the settling process. Disc stack centrifuges which have a gravitational force ranging from 4000 to 14 000 times are the most popular industrial centrifuges. Although they use a lot of power these centrifuge machines can concentrate 0.02 0.05 of microalgal cells that are 3 30 mm in size Ananthi et al. 2021 . According to Koyande Koyande et al. 2022 the anticipated harvesting cost for algal cellharvesting is approximately 20 30 .According to Milledge Milledge and Heaven 2011 centrifugation in biodiesel production consumes a lot of energy with little yield. The disc-stack solid bowl hydrocyclone tubular and multi-chamber centrifuges are the most common types of centrifuges that are currently effective for harvesting algal biomass Najjar and Abu-Shamleh 2020 . 4. Pretreatment of algal biomass The pretreatment of the algae biomass involves breaking down or disrupting the biomass in order to transform accumulate and utilize the carbohydrates and lipids that are present in it. Large-scale pretreatment of biomass is an expensive and constricting stage in the production of biofuels Khan et al. 2018 . According to recent research the produc tion of bioethanol and biofuels requires a variety of novel cell disruption approaches and procedures Yoo et al. 2012 . Researchers worldwide are currently developing pre-treatment pro cedures for microalgae in order to produce more effective lipid products. The cell-disrupting method involves the breakdown of cells to extract the intercellular products. Research has shown that pre-treatment techniques utilize an immense quantity of energy while breaking down cells Krishnamoorthy et al. 2022 . Certain microalgal species possess inherent qualities that make them suitable for effective lipid extraction however this characteristic is not universal across all forms of algae. To achieve substantial cell disruption it is crucial to choose the appropriate pre-treatment strategy that maximizes the efficiency of disruption Yoo et al. 2012 . Before fermenting the algal biomass undergoes pretreatment which involves the disruption of the algal cells in order to release the carbo hydrates held within the cells Bhushan et al. 2023 . The next phase involves the conversion of the accumulating sugars into monomers by saccharification. This process is essential because fermenting microbes can only metabolize sugars in their fermentable forms which often include disaccharides and monosaccharides particularly hexoses and pentoses while the end product of this process of transformation is ethanol Althuri et al. 2018 . The ever-increasing demand for biodiesel has created a need for new pretreatment processes and technologies Yoo et al. 2012 . The range of pretreatment methods utilized for cell disruption is primarily categorized into mechanical thermal physical biological and chemical methods shown in Fig. 5. 4.1. Mechanical pretreatment methods Mechanical pre-treatment methods such as high-pressure homoge nization high-speed homogenization and bead milling are used in order to disrupt cell walls using shear forces Patel et al. 2018 . They are efficient in removing lipids for the synthesis of biofuel by decreasing the size and crystallinity of cell wall particles as the cells break down Tedesco et al. 2014 . By using these techniques the risk of cell contamination and damage during cell rupture is effectively avoided. They enhance the cell s surface area and disruption efficacy hence increasing their effectiveness in the production of biofuel at the indus trial level Krishnamoorthy et al. 2022 . High-pressure homogenizers HPHs are used for the disruption of algal cells because they can operate continuously and can be scaled up to produce a large amount of wet biomass Ekpeni et al. 2015 . Studies have shown that the HPH approach is more effective in extracting lipids from microalgae by breaking up the cells. Various valve seat configu rations are accessible to enhance the efficacy of cell disruption. High-pressure homogenizers HPHs can make microalgae concentrates that are damp and have 25 W W solids. This makes it possible to extract lipids effectively without much energy consumption Lee et al. 2012 . Pre-treatment techniques using high-pressure homogenizers HPHs are used in several sectors to disrupt seaweed and yeast cells hence enhancing the production of lipids Lee et al. 2010 . Bead mills are commonly employed for the extraction of lipids in microalgae cell disruption providing exceptional disruption efficiency in a single operation Lee et al. 2017 . There are two sorts of vessels Fig. 5. Methods of pretreatment for biofuel production from algae biomass. M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 8 agitated vessels and shaking vessels. By causing the whole vessel to vibrate shaking vessels be utilized to disturb cells while in agitated vessels a rotating agitator is employed packed with cell culture and bead pellets. Several factors including microalgal cell biomass bead size and cell stiffness determine the rate of cell disruption Halim et al. 2013 . Upon the imposition of shear force the cells in the regions of bead collisions are disturbed leading to the transfer of energy from the beads to the cells Han et al. 2023 . It is recommended to use beads larger than 0.5 mm in order to get more efficient outcomes. However their substantial energy requirements and running expenses render them less favorable for industrial applications Doucha and Lívanský 2008 . 4.2. Physical pretreatment methods The physical cell breakdown approach employs either microwave or ultrasonic pre-treatment methods devoid of any chemical involvement. Microwave pretreatment techniques employ electromagnetic waves of optimal frequency ranging from 0.3 to 300 GHz in order to generate heat in specific regions thereby enhancing the kinetic energy of water mol ecules until they attain the state of boiling Rodriguez et al. 2015 . The temperature rises as a result of the thermal radiation caused by the alignment of polarized macromolecules around the pole of the electro magnetic field leading to the disintegration of hydrogen ions Patil et al. 2013 . Microwaves can generate sufficient pressure and heat en ergy to cause damage to the cell walls and membranes of algae Carpentieri et al. 2021 . Cell disruption is the result of microwaves interacting with water-based molecules leading to the formation of free radicals. Microwaves exhibit better temperature uniformity during heat transfer compared to conventional heating which makes them prefer able to bead milling and ultrasonic techniques Talati and Haghighi 2022 . Although both techniques have benefits these processes lack extraction yield and lengthy solvent usage times Krishnamoorthy et al. 2022 . The ultrasonic technique employs in liquids and encourages the cell to disintegrate. This method includes emitting ultrasound into a liquid medium which causes microbubbles to develop when liquid molecules move because of acoustic vibrations Shi et al. 2021 . Cavi tation during ultrasonication enhances micro-turbulence effects visco sity pressure and shockwaves which accelerate the breakdown of microalgae cells for optimal lipid extraction. It has been used to improve biodiesel production by rupturing microalgae cells and other forms of biomass material such as animal fat waste non-edible vegetable oils and sludge. Ultrasonic pre-treatment improves the general efficiency of breaking down algal cells because it creates emulsions and cavitations between systems where the liquids don t mix Onumaegbu et al. 2018 . It is primarily used to shorten the time required for microalgal cell disruption during pre-treatment for the production of lipids. In the absence of alternative pre-treatment approaches ultrasonic pre-treatment boosts biodiesel output using canola and palm oil and can be utilized swiftly and constantly to disrupt bacillus spores and vege table oils Van Manh et al. 2011 . Microwave pre-treatment is partic ularly efficient owing to its quick heating capabilities along with its capacity to boost biogas generation but scaling it up for industrial purposes can be expensive Chen et al. 2024 Li et al. 2024 . How ever ultrasonic pre-treatment is more cost-effective and successful at scaling up because it employs sound waves to create bubbles in the sludge. These bubbles are then popped break down particles and pro mote solubilization Golbabaei Kootenaei et al. 2022 Wang et al. 2024 . While both techniques work well ultrasonic pre-treatment is particularly advantageous due to its scalability and affordability for massive operations. 4.3. Thermal pretreatment methods Some thermal pre-treatment techniques like steam explosion or autoclaving add temperature to the surfaces of algae biomass to break up cell bonds make solubilization better and extract plenty of biomass with minimal energy consumption Cabeza et al. 2023 . The autoclaving technique for microalgae biomass is a heat treat ment process requiring 121 C of temperature at a pressure of 15 psi Pˆojo et al. 2021 . This mechanism ruptures microalgae cells increasing the release of lipids. According to research autoclave pre-treatment of Nannochloropsis oculata biomass enhances lipid production over non-pre-treatment biomass Surendhiran and Vijay 2014 . Lee et al. 2010 also verified amazing oil recovery from Chlorella vulgaris by adopting an autoclave method. Surendhiran and Vijays work on Nan nochloropsisoculata revealed a high lipid output of 29.34 after 30 min of autoclave pre-treatment Surendhiran and Vijay 2014 . Heat explosions process involves exposing the material to elevated temperatures ranging from 160 to 260 C while simultaneously keeping the pressure at a consistent range of 1.03 3.45 MPa Cheng and Timil sina 2011 . Cell disruption takes place when there is a decrease in pressure under typical conditions during pre-treatment. It is important to carry out this process at moderate temperatures to avoid lipid degradation Nurra et al. 2014 . Nurra et al. 2014 showed this idea by employing heat explosion pre-treatment on the biomass of Nanno chloropsis gaditana sp. Medina et al. 1998 confirmed that the extraction of carotenoids results in a yield of 15 increase as a result of elevated pressure during heat explosion pre-treatment. 4.4. Chemical pretreatment Chemical pretreatment methods include the use of chemicals such as alkaline and organic solvents hypochlorites detergents chaotropes antibiotics and chelating agents to improve the process of cell disrup tion. Alkaline pre-treatment techniques such as the use of potassium sodium hydroxide and calcium are utilized on algal biomass within a pH range of 9 12. Acid pre-treatments consist of treating substances with H2SO4 and HCl at reduced pH values. Antibodies remove lipids from cell membrane constituents by internally blocking them whereas chelating chemicals link cell membrane molecules together to induce rupture. Detergents interact with membrane molecules causing them to dissolve and penetrate the cell membrane and cell wall Park et al. 2011 Patil et al. 2013 . Oxidizing chemicals such as hydrogen peroxide and ozone have the ability to disturb the structure of cell walls Kendir and Ugurlu 2018 . However the energy required to increase the amount of biomass using these agents is relatively low compared to other approaches. Chemical pre-treatment techniques are less prevalent in microalgal biomass production compared to physical or thermal procedures. These substances have corrosive properties are toxic and can release inhibi tory components that can result in contamination Gonzalez-Fernandez et al. 2018 . Research has shown that Scenedesmus and Chlorella biomass exhibited pH enhancements ranging from 9 to 11. However elevating the pH to 13 resulted in negative impacts on microalgal cells due to excessive alkalinity Bohutskyi et al. 2014 . Ozonation pre-treatments significantly enhanced energy efficiency increasing it from 6 to 66 across several phases Carde na et al. 2017 . 4.5. Biological pretreatment Biological enzymes have distinct properties such as biological spe cialty moderate working conditions minimal energy consumption and a high degradation rate Xiao et al. 2019 . These enzymes have signif icant potential for cell disruption. Glycoside hydrolases Saumonneau et al. 2023 peptidase Phong et al. 2018 lipase Balduyck et al. 2019 and glucanase Zhang et al. 2022b enzymes have been utilized to break down and degrade different types of microalgae. In lysis the enzyme selectively binds to certain molecules on the cell membrane or wall in order to dismantle them. Nevertheless the length of the process is extensive and the efficacy of disruption is comparatively limited compared to mechanical or chemical disruption approaches Li et al. M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 9 2022 . Moreover the primary constraint for biological enzymes is their high price and the limited variety of enzymes accessible for the disruption of microalgae cells Zhang et al. 2022c . 5. Enhancing lipid synthesis and yield through genetic manipulation of green microalgae 5.1. Recapitulation of genetic engineering applied to microalgae In the past decade a lot of research has been conducted with microalgal species from the genera Chlorella Phaeodactylum Dunaliella and Nannochloropsis for a broad range of applications. Neutral lipids are elevated in these organisms when they are starved of nutrients Fu et al. 2019 . By transesterification these neutral lipids like TAGs are sub sequently transformed into biofuels. Simultaneously microalgal-based lipids are becoming more and more popular particularly in the food sector since they could substitute fish oil and serve as a unique supply of polyunsaturated fatty acids PUFAs such as omega-3 and omega-6 which are beneficial to human health and nourishment Ghiffary et al. 2019 . Although the potential advantages of microalgae the ex penses associated with upstream as well as downstream processing make it challenging to turn out these commodities or chemicals on a signifi cant scale. In order to develop a method or system that is commercially practical research in fields like DNA engineering and biological engi neering synthetic biology must continue to improve. Consideration is being given to use strain modification through indirect or direct genetic engineering to enhance microalgal genera for biofuel lipid production Radakovits et al. 2010 . It therefore makes sense to enhance the quality of the lipids being produced in addition to using metabolic engineering to improve the total quantity of microalgal lipids. Some efforts have been made to improve the quality of lipids by changing the length of the fatty acid carbon chain and its degree of unsaturation Medina et al. 1998 Miranda et al. 2012 . As natural mutagenesis needs sexual reproduction in the particular species and is often accomplished by crossing mutants to other strains. Sexual reproduction occurs naturally in higher plants so need of mutagenesis fulfil easily but it can occa sionally be difficult to occur in algae since the strains are often main tained asexually and the circumstances necessary for sexual reproduction are occasionally unknown. This barrier can be addressed in fundamental research by comparing the next-generation sequencing of the mutant genome to that of the original strain Dutcher et al. 2012 . An effective way to maximize the productivity of microalgal lipid and lower the cost of producing microalgal biofuels is to optimize environmental parameters and regulate the environment to enhance the synthesis of microalgal lipid. Therefore developing strains that can collect lipids without compromising growth or biomass output be accomplished by manipulating genes. Significant work has been done over the past ten years to develop genetically engineered strains and genetically modified tools. Adaptive laboratory evolution ALE random mutagenesis and direct genetic engineering are the methods used to modify genomes. To induce random mutations in microalgae researchers are examining the use of ALE chemical mutagens ethyl methanesulfonate EMS and N -nitro-N nitrosoguanidine NTG and physical mutagens such as x-rays gamma-rays and UV radiations Mu noz et al. 2021 . The bacterial adaptation CRISPR-Cas9 system which was discovered in 2013 is gaining a lot of interest. CRISPR RNA crRNA trans-activating crRNA tracrRNA or single synthetic guide RNA sgRNA precede the protospacer adjacent motif PAM in a simplified version of the type-II CRISPR-Cas9 system from Streptococcus pyogenes. This allows the Cas9 nuclease to lead the DNA double-strand breaks DSBs in genomic DNA Ng et al. 2017 . In the subject of microalgal biotechnology Chlamydomonas rein hardtii nuclear transformation marked the first significant advancement in 1990. Cells were agitated in the presence of glass beads coated with DNA which allowed friction to create micropore-sized holes in the outer layer of the cell thus making it more direct for DNA molecules to penetrate the cell Kindle 1990 . Green algae are mostly unicellular organisms that belong to the phylum Chlorophyta and are typically found in fresh aquatic environ ments. Green algae are distinguished from red and brown algae by the kinds of chlorophyll that each of them possesses. The numerous forms of chlorophyll present in algae impact the algae s physical appearance such as color. All algae are composed of chlorophyll a green algae are made up of chlorophyll b and red and brown algae are comprised of chlorophyll d and c respectively La. Although it cannot be found in every photosynthetic organism chlorophyll B helps plants absorb a greater spectrum of sunlight for photosynthesis Khoo et al. 2023 . Because of their substantial population densities and rapid growth rates green algae have become a favorite in the production and extraction of biofuel especially biodiesel Rastogi et al. 2018 . It has been discovered that whereas other algae have many acces sory pigments greater than their number of chlorophylls green algae have a comparatively higher number of chlorophylls in comparison to other pigments. This demonstrates that green algae outperform other forms of algae in terms of photosynthetic efficiency. Lipids make up more than 50 of the dry weight of biomass in certain green algae. The vast majority of the lipids in green algae are composed of TAGs as well as DAGs with additional substances including oil constituents and carot enoids McKie-Krisberg et al. 2018 . The neutral lipids preferred in the synthesis of biodiesel are TAGs and DAGs as the last and final step for lipid production and enhancement is the TAG development in algae Ng et al. 2017 . So the TAG synthesis pathway involves metabolic engi neering. Glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase G3PDH in microalgae initiates the transformation of dihydroxyacetone phosphate DHAP to glycerol-3-phosphate in the cytosol. Subsequently glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase GPAT induces the conversion of glycerol-3-phosphate to lysophosphatidic acid lysophosphatidic acid acyltransferase LPAAT converts lysophosphatidic acid to phosphatidic acid phos phatidic acid phosphatase PAP catalyzes the process of phosphatidic acid to diacylglycerol and last but not least diacylglycerol acyl transferase DGAT stimulates the transformation of diacylglycerol to triacylglycerol TAG in the endoplasmic reticulum ER Korkhovoy and Blume 2013 . In order to increase the lipid buildup in microalgae Hsieh Hsieh et al. 2012 employed an array of gene expression methods Hsieh et al. 2012 . As Saccharomyces cerevisiae and or Yarrowia lip olytica s G3PDH GPAT LPAAT PAP and DGAT were all overexpressed in concert Chlorella minutissima s lipid synthesis rose twofold as compared to cells of the wild type Hsieh et al. 2012 . Nowadays scientists tend to focus on genetic engineering pathways that seek to lengthen the chain of fatty acids by overexpressing genes related to fatty acid synthesis and simultaneously suppressing genes associated with lipase hydrolysis and β-oxidation. In a few years these advancements would enable the cost-effective manufacturing of algae biodiesel while simultaneously growing the output Chang et al. 2016 . Throughout the years fatty acid oxidation-related genes fatty acyl CoA dehydrogenase acyl CoA synthase cacyl CoA oxidase and arniti neacyltransferase I have been the subject of investigation as has overexpression of acetyl-CoA carboxylase ACCase which is involved in fatty acid production Liang and Jiang 2013 . Microalgae present a challenge for genetic engineering because methods of modification vary depending on the species and cannot be employed exactly due to codon occupancy defensive mechanisms such as methylation and restriction enzymes nucleic acid uptake and cell porosity. Consequently in order to modify microalga for the intended generation of biofuel a thorough understanding of the genetic makeup of each species is required Banerjee et al. 2018 . In order to use microalgae as a robust and renewable energy sub stratum on an industrial scale microalgal biotechnology emphasizes on three main areas a increasing the photosynthetic efficiency of the M. The objective of lipid engineering in microalgae is to create TAG that has improved cold flow characteristics which would make them a more suitable substrate for the generation of biodiesel. The ratio of C12 to C14 short-chain fatty acids was raised in the diatom P. tricornutum through higher levels of thioesterases sourced from multiple plant sources Radakovits et al. 2011 . Analogous endeavors have been conducted on C. reinhardtii wherein the fatty acid profile has been modified to enhance its fuel qualities Gong et al. 2011 . Recent research used reverse genetics to rationally modulate type II diacyl glycerol acyl transferases in Nannochloropsis oceanica resulting in the generation of TAG designer oils with a broad range of degrees of unsaturation Xin et al. 2017 . Through the insertion of desired metabolic pathways ge netic engineering not only enables researchers to change or modify metabolic pathway s but also reprograms cells. It is possible to adhere to the enzymatic potential in this case by transferring the relevant route from one organism to another Wheeldon et al. 2017 . By rewiring heterogeneous channels within a host system new metabolic networks are established. This allows for the building of efficient cell factories and produces desirable phenotypes by reorienting the cell s priority from growth to targeted output. Precursors of many biofuel molecules such as ethylene 1-butanol isoprene 2-methyl-1-butanol acetone and fatty acids have been effectively synthesized using such insertions. The findings listed above unequivocally demonstrate the potential contri bution of synthetic routes to the field of improving algae-based biofuel. The creation of computational tools like pathway prediction systems PPS makes pathway synthesis easier and can be applied to a variety of operations like the breakdown of xenobiotic chemicals and the gener ation of biofuel Jagadevan et al. 2018 . The TCA cycle in microalgae has been studied in detail recently revealing particular enzymes and flow control points that have aided attempts to increase energy gener ation and biofuel yield. Studies has reported that in order to boost photosynthetic activity Synechocystis 6803 s TCA cycle has been designed to redirect 10 of the carbon that is fixed into ethylene Xiong et al. 2015 . Furthermore in order to achieve increased acetate production an engineering method has been applied to the PP pathway channeling over twenty percent of carbon into the triose sink. NADPH and ribose-5- phosphate are produced by the PP pathway which works in tandem with glycolysis. Redox equilibrium and nucleotide synthesis depend on it. Researchers have found the PP pathway s essential enzymes and regulatory nodes offering new information on the metabolism of microalgae and their possible applications. Study revealed that Tha lassiosira pseudonana engineered a multifunctional lipase phospholi pase acyltransferase has a lipid content that is 3.3 times higher Trentacoste et al. 2013 . The two biochemical routes that result in the creation of isoprenoids are the methyl-erythritol-4-phosphate MEP pathway which is found in plant plastids and is of prokaryotic bacterial source and the mevalonic acid system which functions in the cytoplasm of eukaryotes and archaea. The ability to precisely catalyze the final dedicated step in isoprene biosynthesis is not present in cyanobacteria. Their expression of the MEP pathway and use of the related enzymes allows them to synthesize a wide range of essential terpenoid-type compounds. Plants produce isoprene because of the isoprene synthase IspS gene a nuclear gene that codes for a protein located in the chloroplast which triggers the synthesis of dimethylallyl diphosphate DMAPP to isoprene. To offset the expenses microalgae are genetically modified to enhance yield and product quality. This approach focuses mostly on altering metabolic pathways to either overexpress or suppress specific genes in order to improve biomass and achieve the intended product yield. A microalgae cell develops through the production of other mol ecules such as proteins through the encoding of genes found in DNA. DNA encompasses genetic information which is translated into RNA. Proteins are created from RNA and these complexes and catalysts serve the organism as an entire entity. In order to alter a gene toward a buildup of the intended products and results the network connecting genomes is being examined Neto et al. 2019 Norashikin et al. 2018 . The first step in the genetic engineering method is to choose and gather a gene with a desirable characteristic from the donor organism s DNA that typically carries the particular gene. The vector plasmid DNA is then extracted from a different organism usually a bacterium. Following that the enzyme that fragments DNA is combined with the donor and plasmid DNA. The DNA fragments unite chemically resulting in a new fully functional plasmid. This gene from the donor organism is now present in this plasmid DNA. The new plasmids containing the new gene are then either implanted or transformed into the bacterial cells. Later when the new gene-containing bacteria are cultivated in enormous quantities the intended outcomes become apparent Huang et al. 2022 . It is evident that green algae possess the identical job as bacteria in this scenario. Further genome editing which includes gene insertion deletion mutations knockout and knockdown is an essential component of ge netic alteration Fayyaz et al. 2020 . Recombinant nucleases are incorporated by the Clustered Regularly Interspaces Short Palindromic Repeat CRISPR to produce DSBs. A guide RNA gRNA and the nuclease Cas9 protein interact to create a complex. The Cas9 gRNA intricately searches for the target sequence that has to be altered when the gRNA identifies it Moreb and Lynch 2021 . The target sequence was identified by Saey Musunuru 2021 the Cas9 protein breaks down it and a DSB forms at the location. After that DSB is repaired by a process known as non-homologous end joining NHEJ which results in cleavage site modifications. In addition Cas9 and gRNA complexes can be introduced into cells forming ribonucleo proteins Cas9 RNPs to lower the likelihood of cytotoxicity and off-targeting Jeon et al. 2017 . Biofuel through transesterification process It is assumed that the direct transesterification method offers greater benefits in terms of boosting the efficiency of microalgae-derived bio diesel. Alcohol is notable because it acts both as a reactant and a solvent in a transesterification process. Because methanol is more readily available and less expensive than other types of alcohol it is often used in this process. The limited solubility of alcohol in various oils makes the use of a catalyst more important. Borugadda and Goud 2012 Stumborg et al. 1996 . Transesterification with lipases Compared to acid and alkali procedures lipase-catalyzed trans esterification produces glycerol with a greater level of purity. The sole known instance of lipase-catalyzed biodiesel generation from algal biomass is follow-up research on a large-scale biodiesel project using heterotrophically growing C. protothecoides. An effective attempt to produce biodiesel through enzymatic transesterification with Candida sp. 99 125 lipase immobilized on macroporous resin Malihan et al. 2012 Zhu et al. 2018 was complemented by an outstanding scale-up investigation involving biological reactor generation from high-lipid-producing algae Li et al. 2007 from a 5 L bench-top reactor to a 11 000-L commercial bioreactor operated in batch mode. The ideal parameters for this reaction are relatively similar to those found forother feedstocks Koçer and Ozçimen 2018 Rold an-San Antonio and Martín 2023 a high catalyst load a 3 1 methanol-to-oil ratio restriction and the application of n-hexane as the co-solvent to shield the enzyme from methanol poisoning. Over the course of a 12-h process the catalysis temperature was maintained at 38 C and the pH at 7.0. These numbers should be optimized for every enzyme because they are extremely lipase-dependent. Nevertheless the primary obstacle to the commer cialization of lipase-catalyzed biodiesel synthesis is the high cost of the catalyst which prohibits this method from being produced on a large scale. Supercritical transesterification Triglycerides combine with supercritical alcohols mainly methanol and ethanol in a process known as supercritical transesterification to produce biodiesel. Manufacturing costs are high because of the excessive use of alcohol at a molar ratio of 42 1 instead of 3 1 as is the case with typical procedures. Biogas production using microalgae Biogas is a flammable and toxic gas generated from organic waste biomass such as lignocellulose waste grass and plant waste aquatic trash microbiological waste kitchen waste and macro-algae. The biomass utilized in the anaerobic digestion process in addition to its operating conditions such as pH pressure temperature and acidity usually dictate the chemical makeup of biogas however methane carbon dioxide N2 H2 water and residues of hydrogen sulfide H2S are typically present in biogas Pooja et al. 2022 Hosseini et al. 2020 . Biogas made from algal wastes is gaining popularity due to its high volatile solids content which allows for large-scale production of renewable energy with minimal carbon footprint and adverse environ mental effects while remaining economically feasible Jafari Olia et al. 2022 Ramanan et al. 2016 . Several steps of producing biogas utilizing algae biomass are involved including the algae pre-treatment process stage and the anaerobic digestion stage which begins with anaerobic digestion in the anaerobic unit to produce digestate and biogas. Carbon dioxide is put into ponds as a source of carbon for algae cultivation. While algal oil is transesterified by employing syngas to supply the required methanol the algae require CO2 to thrive. In the absence of oxygen microorganisms break down sludge or manure in an anaerobic digester bioreactor . The processes of hydrolysis acidogenesis aceto genesis and methanogenesis are continuous simultaneous reactions that convert the original material carbohydrates lipids and proteins into both carbon dioxide and methane gasses Rold an-San Antonio and Martín 2023 . 7.1. Anaerobic digestion The process of anaerobic digestion AD converts algae like seaweed into biogas that can be used to remediate wastewater Jafari et al. 2021 Assemany et al. 2020 . Through this process organic biomass which includes plants and algae is converted into a carbon dioxide and methane mixture that can be employed as an environmen tally friendly fertilizer. In sustainable agriculture digestate which is also created during anaerobic digestion can take the place of inorganic fertilizers. For the purpose of valorizing wet materials with a high moisture content like algae anaerobic digestion operates efficiently. Bacteria break down organic substrates into gases primarily carbon dioxide and methane with trace amounts of N2 O2 NH3 hydrogen sulfide siloxanes and halogenated hydrocarbon Hagos et al. 2017 . Bacterial anaerobic digestion results in the production of CO2 water Table 5 Bioethanol production by selected micro-algal strains under controlled conditions of temperature and duration. Microalgae have drawn interest for being capable of recovering nitrogen from AD effluent and upgrading biogas. They enable the bioremediation of digestate and nutrient-rich liquid digestate. Compared to cultivate algae individually co-cultivating bacteria and microalgae can generate biomass more efficiently and remove more nutrients Roberts et al. 2020 . However diverse microorganisms metabolisms can impose limitations on one another creating a complicated environment. Important operating parameters need to be selected in order to optimize an anaerobic digestion process Zhang et al. 2020a . Biogas production can be increased by pretreatment techniques such as mechanical ther mal microwave and enzymatic. The present focus of the study is on improving biogas from swine wastewater treated with AD by employing microalgae. Microalgae are a possible method for upgrading biogas because it has been demonstrated that they can eliminate over 99 of hydrocarbons from biogas Abusweireh et al. 2023 . Bio-hydrogen production from microalgae Methods for producing biohydrogen from microalgae are fermenta tion and photosynthesis. Direct photolysis H2 photo-dark fermenta tion H2 indirect photolysis H2 and dark fermentation H2 come in order of highest yield and output produced by modified genetically designed strains. The photosynthetic system s PSII dependence on H2 generation nutritional deprivation of H2 production and anaerobic biohydrogen synthesis during dark fermentation are the three mecha nisms for biohydrogen production. Since sulfur shortages reduce both PSII activity and the rate at which oxygen is produced it has been proven to be the most efficient method of producing biohydrogen. Because oxygen is used up during normal mitochondrial respiration hydrogenase is activated in an anaerobic state in order to catalyze the production of biohydrogen Wang et al. 2021 . There are various methods to boost biohydrogen production efficiency such as algae-bacteria coupling Iqbal et al. 2022 and immobilization of microalgae cells to improve light utilization Ruiz-Marin et al. 2020 . 7.3.
