The objective is to make hydrogenase more resistant to oxygen however so far this has not been accomplished through modification of the structure of hydrogenase. Because pyruvate oxidase in Escherichia coli catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate which utilizes O2 hydrogenase activity can be sustained in the absence of oxygen. So the scientists put the pyruvate oxidase and catalase genes from Escherichia coli into the chloroplast genome of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii. This created the new transgenic algae strain which produces three times as much biohydrogen Xu et al. 2011 . O2 can suppress the expression and functioning of the hydrogenase gene HydA in the PSII system resulting in enhanced biohydrogen yields. Inhibiting PsbO gene expression inhibits the release of oxygen while inducing HydA in the PSII system. By eliminating the PsbO gene the rate of biohydrogen synthesis is increased about 9 times Lin et al. 2013 . To achieve a balance between photosynthesis and respiration photosynthesis must be minimized while respiration is enhanced Ghirardi et al. 2018 . Furthermore by preventing phosphorylation activation glycolaldehyde can impair the Calvin Benson cycle enabling cells to stay anaerobic for biohydrogen evolution. Hydrogenase s structure is capable of being altered to boost resistance to oxygen with scientists changing particular amino acids to prevent oxygen from entering through the pathway and protecting the active core Christenson and Sims 2011 Hoh et al. 2016 . A bioengineering ferredoxin coupled with hydrogenase has been developed to increase the rate of biohydrogen generation Wang et al. 2021 . Inhibiting RuBisCO weakens the Calvin-Benson cycle which pro motes electron-to-hydrogenase transfer. RuBisCO large and small sub unit mutants had faster biohydrogen evolution rates than S-deficient regular forms Antal et al. 2011 . Reducing the size of the antennae can improve light gathering efficiency Hu et al. 2020 and biohydrogen generation. Hup-hydrogenase subunit knockout can minimize bio hydrogen utilization. Under conditions of darkness particular inhibitors can transfer electrons to reversible Hox hydrogenase or nitrogenase to boost H2 generation Burrows et al. 2011 . By not transferring 90 of light that is absorbed to Photosynthetic system PSII light harvesting complexes LHCs can lower the efficiency of production Oh et al. 2011 . This barrier can be bypassed by randomly incorporating mutant nuclear coding antenna genes or modifying antenna regulatory protein NAB1 using LHC antenna engineering. Another option is to use RNAi to knock down LHCs or chlorophyll production genes in order to opti mize H2 yield Oey et al. 2016 . 8. Bottlenecks challenges and future prospects in biofuel production from microalgae 8.1. Microalgae s challenges in commercial applications Since it is feasible to confirm the natural existence of microorganisms in a variety of conditions microalgal development generally appears to be straightforward yet the commercial transformation of biomass into biologically sustainable and ecofriendly biofuels is complicated but worth it. Microalgae are known to need light energy and sources of CO2 for self-sustaining growth organic supplies for heterotrophic develop ment and an intermediate state known as mixotrophic growth. There are a number of intermediate trophic pathways between the two ex tremes according to a publication Kandasamy et al. 2024 . Autotro phic growth nutrient inputs carbon source introduction temperature control and an appropriate pH are all required for photobioreactor based production. This study Aci en et al. 2012 states that in order to implement cultivation methods at commercial and industrial scales costs must be lowered down. Photobioreactors are a good substitute although optimal material selection and design simplicity are required. However light is required for the photosynthesis process of autotrophic algae and illumination of photo-bioreactor result in greater energy consumption as well as a larger surface area for the shallow cultivation of microalgae Carneiro et al. 2017 Singh and Olsen 2011 . Utilizing combustion gases and wastewater is an additional alter native that decreases the labor or employment and energy costs asso ciated with production. Since the aforementioned factors all entail direct financial costs careful consideration of production options is required. In order to prevent inessential costs and investor money loss Patrick Moriarty and Honnery 2024 states that these elements are critical to the planning and launch of a microalgae firm. Great volumes of nutrients and water are required for microalgal cultivation which frequently re sults in expensive production expenses and makes it challenging to introduce microalgal bio-fuels on an industrial level. The construction of an association for microalgae growing in freshwater effluent or another environment containing accessible organic compounds while under taking bioremediation however is a promising choice to overcome this problem Kang et al. 2015 . Using open-pound systems like the Algae Turf Scrubber Witarsa et al. 2020 is an additional way to reduce ex penditures and boost yield. This system is based on coral reef algal colonies. Artificial or natural light sources can be used to facilitate growth. One of this system s primary benefits is its high rate of biomass generation which outperforms other harvesting systems in terms of production yields. Numerous contaminants are taken up by the biomass of algae and can be eliminated by the system itself. The biomass can be processed into materials of economic importance including fertilizers and animal feed provided that harmful chemicals are absent Cheenakula et al. 2023 . It is anticipated that the generation and application of biofuels would increase on a global scale. However generally especially in the trans portation sector the contribution to overall energy consumption will remain modest. This is mostly because arable land usage is competing with the production of fiber and food products developing markets lack properly regulated agricultural practices market systems are geographically limited and biodiversity protection is essential Noraini et al. 2014 . Numerous research attempted to enhance the production in order to lower costs while using microalgae as the basis of bioproducts. Using a life cycle analysis a study Golberg et al. 2021 looked at the sustainability of algal bio-crude production from an economic social and environmental standpoint. A good substitute is bio-crude some times referred to as bio-oil which is made by hydrothermally liquefying semi-dry biomass and then distilling it into its constituent fractions in a refinery Golberg et al. 2021 . According to the findings producing 1-million tons of bio-crude lead to the generation of about 13 000 job opportunities and a boost to the economy of US 4 billion. Over the past ten years above figure shows how the search engine results have changed in connection to microalgae and the economy. It was confirmed by bibliometric research that the primary obstacle facing microalgae in industrial applications is their production cost. Impor tant factors that need to be taken into account in this sector were linked to this term including industrial scale commercialization economy high cost economic viability major bottleneck and others. These findings show that the outlook for microalgal based biological goods is more promising in terms of the conditions that would allow for the industrial-scale commercialization of bioproducts. Nevertheless considering the facts it is impossible to ignore the factors aimed at achieving economic viability and lowering energy costs these are the primary obstacles that need to be addressed. 8.2. Future prospects The development of new effective and appropriate growing tech nology mostly for offshore culture for all kinds of microalgae and macroalgae is essential for its effective growth as is raising the public s awareness of and acceptance of the phases that comprise algal devel opment. Cyanobacteria are potentially the most common among them in terms of producing biofuels. Transesterification is a process by which numerous kinds of microalgae transform fat into biodiesel to replace petro-based fuels fossil-fuels . In terms of density and viscosity bio diesel made from microalgal is comparable to petroleum diesel and M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 17 these types of microorganisms require the use of chemicals in contrast to higher plants which require pesticides and herbicides to produce more. The high concentration of proteins and carbohydrates in micro algae that be processed to produce methanol and alcohol fuel is another characteristic of these algae McGinn et al. 2011 . Global fuel con sumption and demand are predicted to increase quickly and the use of fossil fuels has a negative influence on the environment and poses serious problems. The world has paid close attention to the present global energy problem. The world s energy problem must be resolved with the help of renewable energy sources See Fig. 9 . One great form of renewable energy that be created without relying on fossil fuels is bio fuels which are made from biological organisms Rodionova et al. 2017 . The process s recuperation rate or energy balance is also essential for every species. It includes raising and expanding the pro duction of biomass and the potential value of biofuels while lowering operating and investment costs which include staff equipment and energy inputs . However it is claimed that under typical operating circumstances the majority of microalgal ponds possess a solar energy generation efficiency of 1 4 closed photo-bioreactor systems can attain greater efficiencies. Enhanced breeding initiatives and genetic modification are being used to try to close the large margin for improvement which is estimated to be 8 12 respectively for the ideal maximum efficiency of photosynthesis for transforming solar en ergy to oil as well as hydrogen Stephens et al. 2010 . There are now 447 algae and Spirulina spp.-producing plants in Europe. Throughout the European countries a wide range of species production techniques and industrial applications have been identified. The majority of algae production systems in Europe 68 of the mapped production units involve the harvesting of wild stocks Robak et al. 2018 . There are now 309 permits in Norway for the cultivation of macroalgae with around half of them being granted for the kelp species S. latissima L. digitata and A. esculenta . The most commercially sig nificant species at this time is S. latissima. With a market value of almost 74 000 Euro the 145 tons of kelp produced in 2017 were valued at Gegg and Wells 2017 . As the main suppliers of macroalgal biomass for biorefinery East Asian countries China Korea Japan Indonesia and the Philippines would need to work together internationally to advance and develop their agricultural technology and experience Ol ah et al. 2020 . This cooperation would be directed toward improving the mac roalgal biorefinery. These nations provided 95 of the global supply in 2010. Due to biological factors including climate the predominant species produced in each country vary. Approximately 85 and 30 of the worldwide cultivation of L. japonica and U. pinnatifida respectively was grown in China and Korea Giugni and Giugni 2010 . While other red algae were mostly farmed in Indonesia as well as the Philippines Porphyra sp. was principally grown in Japan Lam et al. 2019 . Because of their decades-long agricultural expertise East Asian nations will be crucial in increasing the quantity of macroalgae grown globally for use as feedstock in biorefineries. Future temperature pH and other pre diction sensors be more favored which prompted the development of Internet-based integrated electrical technologies and control systems for macroalgal growth systems. These days microalgal cultivation systems use this kind of technology Tamilarasan and Sahadevan 2014 . 9. Life cycle assessment It is claimed that a number of biofuels are capable of being produced from algal biomass. Therefore a range of conversion methods have been used in third and fourth generation biofuel manufacturing processes that employ microalgae to reach large-scale commercialization. i Cultiva tion ii Harvesting iii Pre-treatment iv Transesterification and v Purification comprise the traditional microalgae production method. Human activities emit CO2 into the atmosphere causing an imbalance in nature as GHGs are highly involved in global warming or climate change globally Saranya and Ramachandra 2020 . The entire life cycle assessment of biofuels has been illustrated from human activities to the production of biofuels in Fig. 10. On contrary to that open ponds as well as closed photobioreactors Weyer et al. 2010 are used in microalgae s cultivation as they consume environmental CO2 in the photosynthesis and respirational processes of algal growth and development resultantly algae s bio processing and refining comes into play to harness biofuels from algal biomass although connected biofilm cultivation has drawn attention as well recently. It is observed that Rubio Rodríguez et al. Rubio Rodríguez et al. 2011 conducted LCA research to value alternative energy routes and came to the conclusion that LCA-based indicators might be a useful tool for comparing alternative energy routes with respect to their impact on the environment and the indirect costs of natural resources for various commodities and services. Yang et al. 2011 evaluated the microalgae-based biodiesel manufacturing proc ess s life-cycle water as well as nutrient consumption. Following the growth of microalgae cells are extracted using a variety of energy-intensive cell concentration processes including centrifugation gravity sedimentation filtering flocculation and floatation Mathimani and Mallick 2018 . A variety of cell disruption methods including sonication bead pounding autoclaving microwave therapy and pulsed electric field are included in pre-treatment Ramachandra et al. 2013 . Following pre-treatment the cells undergo transesterification with the aid of supercritical CO2 acid alkali or biocatalysts to speed up the process Fukuda et al. 2001 . Purification is the last stage in the Fig. 9. Sustainable approach based on circular bio-economy for bioenergy production from microalgae aiming to reduce CO2 emissions and waste. M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 18 manufacturing of biodiesel. Technologies such as water washing or dry washing are typically used to purify crude biodiesel that contains traces of catalyst and crude glycerol Atadashi 2015 . Evaluations of the life cycle and energy balance of the microalgae-based biodiesel production process are crucial for determining the effects of the upstream micro algal culture as well as the downstream biofuel production processes. Prior studies on the life cycle assessment LCA of microalgal biofuels concentrated on comparing the effects with fossil fuels and other bio fuels as well as qualitative studies of various methodological factors such as system limitations and the allocation of co-products Collotta et al. 2016 Regarding this a previous study Carneiro et al. 2017 examined the environmental impact of biodiesel derived from micro algae versus other earth-based substrates or feedstocks bioethanol and traditional petroleum-based fuels. It found that the biodiesel obtained from microalgae was significantly more effective than the other terres trial substrates at reducing the effects of land use. In a research the amount of water and nutrients used during the synthesis of microalgal biodiesel was measured Singh and Olsen 2011 . If freshwater is utilized without recycling 3726 kg of water is needed to produce 1 kg of microalgal biodiesel. According to the findings employing wastewater or saltwater can cut the amount of freshwater used over the life cycle by up to 90 . Nevertheless regardless of whether wastewater or marine waters are employed as the medium for cultivation or how much harvested water is recycled a significant quantity of freshwater about 400 kg of biofuel needs to be needed for culture. Additionally researchers claimed that in the absence of harvest water recycling the life-cycle utilizations of nitrogen phosphorus magnesium potassium and sulfur were about 0.330 0.710 0.580 0.270 and 0.150 kg of biodiesel. On the other hand there is a reduction of about 55 in the use of these nutrients when the processed water is entirely recycled. Algal culture using saltwater or seawater can remove the requirement for potassium and sulfur as well as cut nitrogen demand by 94 . Overall as temperature and solar radiation rise the aquatic footprint of producing biodiesel from microalgae steadily shrinks from north to south Singh and Olsen 2011 . Chlorella vulgaris a microalga found in open raceway ponds was found to have a life cycle energy as well as greenhouse gas GHG analysis that was 2.5 times more energy-intensive than conventional diesel. This finding emphasizes the need for decarbonization throughout the entire production chain to fully realize the positive ecological effects of reducing GHG emissions through biomass Shirvani et al. 2011 . An increase in greenhouse gas emissions was found in the life cycle assessment of three distinct cell pre-treatment strategies on the ocean microalga Isochrysis galbana. This finding implies that different pre-treatment processes should be used in tandem to minimize envi ronmental impacts and improve energy efficiency Wang et al. 2017 . According to a comprehensive life cycle assessment LCA of C. vulgaris algae biodiesel production up to 90 of the entire method s energy was used during drying and hexane extraction Lardon et al. 2009 . According to these findings it seems unlikely that drying algae biomass and using it in place of terrestrial oilseeds in conventional solvent extraction as well as subsequent transesterification procedures will result in a net energy gain for the generation of sustainable biofuels Levine et al. 2010 . Jorquera Jorquera et al. 2010 conducted an analysis of the energy life-cycle for biomass production employing the oil-rich microalgae Nannochloropsis sp. This Singh and Olsen 2011 Fig. 10. The illustration of the green journey life cycle assessment of algae biofuel. M. Abdullah et al. Environmental Research 262 2024 119902 19 research comprised raceway ponds and tubular as well as flat-plate photobioreactors PBRs enabling algal culture. For every process the resulting net energy ratio NER was computed. The findings indicated that the predicted NERs for raceway ponds and flat-plate PBRs are 1 whereas the usage of horizontally tubular PBRs would not be financially viable NER 1 . If the biomass s lipid content were boosted to 60 dw cwd the NER for ponds and flat-plate PBRs be raised to noticeably higher values Singh and Olsen 2011 . To recapitulate it all it can be claimed that human activities emit CO2 into the atmosphere causing an imbalance in nature as GHGs are highly involved in climate change or global warming globally Saranya and Ramachandra 2020 . On contrary to that open ponds as well as closed photobioreactors Weyer et al. 2010 are used in microalgae s cultivation as they consume environmental CO2 in the photosynthesis and respirational processes of algal growth and development making the atmosphere quite ecofriendly. Resultantly algae s bioprocessing and refining comes into play to harness biofuels from algal biomass. Therefore minimizing energy inputs while increasing the efficiency of biomass and energy output is the key to producing microalgal biofuels in a way that is environmentally friendly. The purpose of this study was to assess the life cycle as well as environmental effects of a substrate-based microalgal fermenter when various nutrient sources were taken into account for the microalgae s development. This study aims to examine all aspects of the energy and environmental performance of microalgal biofuel from feedstock cultivation to bioethanol biodiesel biogas and jet-fuel synthesis in contrast to previous life cycle evaluation studies on microalgae. Representative_Docs: ['Fuel 332 2023 126199 Available online 12 October 2022 0016-2361 2022 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Microalgal biofuel production Potential challenges and prospective research Arunachalam Bose Sathya a Arunachalam Thirunavukkarasu b Rajarathinam Nithya b Abhishek Nandan c Krishnamoorthy Sakthishobana d Anand Kishore Kola e Raja Sivashankar e Hoang Anh Tuan f Balakrishnan Deepanraj g a Department of Biotechnology National Institute of Technology Warangal India b Department of Industrial Biotechnology Government College of Technology Coimbatore India c Department of Health Safety and Environment Civil Engineering University of Petroleum and Energy Studies Dehradun India d Department of Biotechnology Bannariamman Institute of Technology Sathyamangalam India e Department of Chemical Engineering National Institute of Technology Warangal India f Institute of Engineering HUTECH University Ho Chi Minh City Viet Nam g Department of Mechanical Engineering College of Engineering Prince Mohammad Bin Fahd University Al-Khobar Saudi Arabia A R T I C L E I N F O Keywords Biofuel Microalgae Sustainable approach Potential challenges Research gaps A B S T R A C T Exponential growth in industrialization can be seen as a direct outcome of the urbanization which results in the continuous depletion of natural energy reserves. The existence of carbon dioxide in the ecosystem is primarily due to the fossil fuel combustion from the variety of energy-driven vehicles. Hence to reduce its levels in the atmosphere and to prevent the depletion of non-renewable resources scientific researchers have made significant attempts to provide alternate and sustainable ways of producing energy. One such noteworthy effort is the biofuel production from the microalgae that has an excellent potential in lipid accumulation and bioconversion. Despite numerous reports are available on the effective biofuel production the process scaling-up and its commercialization remains in vain. Hence the present review is intended to critically identify the possible gaps in the current research and to provide potential challenges to be scientifically addressed in the prospective research of biofuel production. 1. Introduction The global energy crisis as well as increased amount of greenhouse gas emissions has led to the interest in alternative eco-friendly sources of renewable energy. Fuel derived from biomass has become the most promising renewable energy source when especially in comparison to solar hydro and wind energy because it can be easily preserved and trans-located and used straight in vehicles 1 2 . In the close future biofuel derived from living biomass is widely accepted as an alternative and green fuel source for sustainable energy production 3 . Biodiesel has numerous benefits over fossil diesel including the fact that it is biodegradable and nontoxic as well as produce lower greenhouse gas emissions. Biofuels developed from photosynthetic organism-based biomasses such as terrestrial crops and algal species offer tremendous potential for meeting global energy demand while still being carbon neutral and allowing CO2 carbon dioxide sequestration from the environment 4 . A promising strategy is to produce the most appropriate energy carrier from algae. Microalgae are photosynthetic microorganisms that have piqued the attention of researchers government officials and in dustrial owners 5 . Microalgae biofuels are a type of third-generation biofuel that can be used as a substitute for fossil fuels without the drawbacks of first and second-generation biofuels 6 . Due to its simple and cost effective cultivation system microalgae are one of the most suitable alternatives for a wide range of biofuels. They can easily grow with only light as a source of energy and basic nutrients such as air water and mineral salts. Furthermore on a land area basis these photosynthetic organisms are capable of fixing solar energy into biomass effectively than terrestrial plants 7 . Numerous micro algal species store a significant amount of lipids in the form of triacylglycerol TAG a preferred source of biofuel that can account for up to 70 of dry weight basis in some species 1 . Botryococcusbraunii Nannochloropsis sp. Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses R. Sivashankar B. Deepanraj . Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Fuel journal homepage Received 29 May 2022 Received in revised form 24 September 2022 Accepted 30 September 2022 Fuel 332 2023 126199 2 Dunaliella primolecta Chlorella sp. and Crypthecodinium cohnii are just a few of the microalgae that produce a lot of hydrocarbons and lipids and have a capability of producing biofuel. The approach of cultivating microalgae was brought into focus for the production of biofuels with a number of potential benefits like those of i they did not conflict with food chains of humans or animals ii they were very rich of carbon- based products protein and oil and iii they were able to grow in aquatic media such as waste water freshwater salt water and nutrients from brackish water salt water or high polished water iv grown in waste dumping sea ponds rivers waste drainage in industrial and municipal waste areas wet bare lands v develop sustainable O2 gen eration. Microalgae also have a very limited life of harvest and an incipient biomass that accelerates the expected biomass to a higher productivity. Furthermore microalgae are the only components for biofuel conversion that have a tremendous amount of carbohydrates protein and lipid 8 . Owing to all these potentials the global market for algal biofuel was estimated as 5.022 billion USD in 2020 and it is anticipated to reach 9.033 billion USD in 2027 at a Compound Annual Growth Rate CAGR of 8.75 Despite this significant market value there are many research avenues need to be technically addressed to adopt complete transition of fossil-based fuels to alternate and sustainable microalgal biofuel. Hence the pre sent review is intended to critically analyze the possible research gaps in the current microalgal research by providing comprehensive informa tion on the various production strategies and bioconversion technolo gies. For the benefit of the readers significant findings of the present review are reported here. Contrary to the microbial biomasses such as bacteria and fungi the growth and maintenance of algal cultures are not so simple for the bulk manufacturers and hence the presence of skilled labors at each stages of algal growth is inevitable. Besides the studies on the isolation of optimal strain s or consortium nutrient supply and the extent of substrate utilization are the key areas to be extensively studied. Further the analysis on the metabolic load and flux distribution are the significant research hotspots for the prospective research in the biofuel production. 2. Algae and biofuels The production of microalgae and biofuel can be carried out in two main stages that include upstream and downstream processes. Various cultivation methods are included in the upstream phase to achieve maximal biomass while the downstream phase focuses on harvest technology and sustainable biofuel production 5 . Increased biofuel production from a variety of algal strains necessitates ambient cultiva tion methods that lead to creative solutions after thorough algal research. These environmentally friendly strategies promote the use of domestic industrial and agricultural wastewater for algal cultivation in order to achieve the dual goal of wastewater remediation and biofuel production resulting in a multifaceted ecologically friendly strategy 9 10 . In general microalgae can be grown using four different methods of cultivation including phototrophic heterotrophic mixotrophic and photoheterotrophic as shown in Fig. 1. Autotrophic cultivation indicates growth by means of converting inorganic carbon to organic form with light. Heterotrophic cultivation requires organic carbon for growth in the absence of light. However in mixotrophic cultivation cells are grown by both autotrophic and heterotrophic mode depending on the food resources. Photoheterotrophic cultivation indicates growth in the presence of suitable light and organic carbon sources 11 . 2.1. Phototropic cultivation system Phototrophic microalgae can also be used as a carbon sink for the capture of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Only phototrophic cultivation is financially feasible for large-scale biomass production of microalgae 12 . Microalgae can be grown in three different cultivation systems in the phototrophic method such as open ponds closed bio reactors and hybrid two stages 13 . Whereas open systems are economical and closed systems are better for nutrient removal hybrid systems represent the culmination of open and closed systems designed Fig. 1. Algal cultivation methods. A.B. Sathya et al. Fuel 332 2023 126199 3 exclusively for increased biomass production and wastewater remedia tion resulting in effective nutrient disposal 14 . Merits and demerits of different cultivation system have been illustrated in the Table 1. 2.1.1. Open pond cultivation system This is globally the most basic and oldest systems for producing microalgae on a large scale. Since 1950s this open cultivation tech niques have been used 15 . These open pond systems are universally used due to their ability to mitigate atmospheric CO2 and are shallow in nature 7 . They are also less expensive and most frequently used open systems are raceway pond circular pond tank shallow big pond and closed ponds. The location of open pond is extremely important taking into account the amount of sunlight available and the demands of the algae to be cultivated. They are also typically fitted with a rotating arm to ensure that the culture is constantly stirred 6 . Contamination of these systems by bacteria and maybe other microalgae is a real concern and sedimentation of biomass is avoided. Poor light permeation un controlled temperature loss due to evaporation and CO2 diffusion into the atmosphere are all potential downsides 16 . To minimize the risk of toxicity in the open cultivation aerators or fountains can be used to add water movement and pond aeration pet waste a typical source of extra nutrients and germs should be collected and disposed of and install rain barrels all throughout the neighborhood to cut down on polluting runoff. 2.1.2. Closed cultivation system The closed systems have been introduced to reduce open ponds constraints by stabilizing culture conditions. The photobioreactors PBRs have been designed to maximize the ease of access of light to achieve the optimum algal biomass. Moreover the PBRs can be mixed evenly so that the light can be optimally achieved to enhance cell growth and exchange of gas 17 . It can be assembled as bags tanks or towers of plastic or glass. Photo bioreactors are available in various designs such as flat tubular or columns the most widely accepted being tubular ones 18 . The tubular reactor consists of tubes horizontally or vertically positioned in several arrays. The tube is made of rubber polyethylene glass acrylic transparent silicone or plastic. Advanced technologies for designing such PBRs have been investigated to ensure a thin layer of biomass suspension free from contamination with ideal light and reduced energy requirements 19 . The flat panel PBR reactor consists of a flat transparent glass vessel polyethylene foil plexiglass or poly carbonate 20 . In contrast with tubular bioreactors they provide a high specific surface area proportion. Extremely high oxygen content can adversely affect algal growth the oxygen generated from photosynthesis is removed using an auxiliary tank. Closed PBRs must be intended to increase the surface volume ratio for improved algal growth to ensure the availability of solar radiation across a wider photosynthetic surface area. The main downside of these controlled reactors is their expense while contamination is completely removed 21 . Additional complex ities include excessive heat oxygen accumulation scaling difficulty and bio-floating and cell damage. 2.1.3. Hybrid cultivation system The hybrid systems are particularly created such that they are a combination of both types of cultivation systems Open and Closed . They are cost-effective and are intended for large-scale algae cultiva tion. 22 . Hybrid systems achieve high nutrient removal while pro ducing high biomass. The hybrid systems are low-cost which is used for large-scale cultivation. These systems address the shortcomings of open systems as well as the relatively high expenses of closed systems. In this scenario algae will be cultivated initially in a PBR to deliver maximum inoculants before being transferred to an open system allowing for maximal biomass production 23 . When algae become prominent and effectively compete with other microorganisms in open systems the likelihood of contamination in open systems is greatly reduced. 3. Biofuels derived from microalgae Global warming and biofuel depletion have prompted the globe to investigate the generation of bioenergy from algal biomass. Currently the only alternative accessible to replace consumption and dependency on fossil fuels is the development of biofuels from algal biomass. Microalgal biomass may be used to create a variety of biofuels such as biodiesel biogas bioethanol biohydrogen etc. 3.1. Biodiesel The most used energy sources are crude oil gas and coal but they are limited so there should be an alternative that satisfies the needs. The scarcity of these sources is caused because they are not abundant so an alternative source is required. Biodiesel is one serious contender where it s available unless there is a draught for vegetable and animal oils. The animal fats like tallow fatty acid and vegetable oil like soybean oil palm oil castor oil are some of the major feedstock of biodiesel 24 . These oils are converted into biodiesel by the transesterification process. These emit fewer amounts of toxic gases like carbon monoxide partic ulate matter and they do not emit sulfur. This is due to free oxygen present in the chain and it causes complete combustion which results in less emission of gases compared to the traditional fuels. Alternative energy source helps in retaining the conventional energy sources. Ac cording to International Energy Outlook 2016 projected the utilization of energy sources go up to 48 between 2012 and 2040 25 . 3.1.1. Basics and definition The word diesel was used primarily by G. Chavanne. Rudolf Diesel invented an iron cylinder with a flywheel in its base that has its fuel 26 . The model ran on nothing but peanut oil in remembrance of this incident 10th August as international biodiesel day. Biodiesel is initially derived only from peanut and then it is found that it can be derived from vegetable and animal fats. Biodiesels were produced by the Table 1 Merits and demerits of different cultivation type for the growth of microalgae. Cultivation type Merits Demerits Reference Open Affordability Ease of operation and maintenance Lesser energy usage Scalability is simple Evaporative cooling Contamination risk is high Vast land area is required Lower biomass yields Constraints in light transmittance if thick layer is utilized 11 86 Closed Cultivation parameters are well-controlled Increased algal productivity Decreased chance of contamination Economic in nature Consistent growing environment Hydrodynamic stress is minimal Anchorage-dependent growth Difficult scaling-up Most instances necessitate cooling Hybrid Reduced contamination Decreased usage of energy Improved algal production Prone to contamination Influenced by external factors A.B. Sathya et al. Fuel 332 2023 126199 4 transesterification process. In this process glyceride reacts with alcohol in presence of a catalyst to form an ester of fatty acids and alcohol. In the past people used vegetable oil as a fuel to run diesel engines which was replaced by petrol for efficiency as the usage of petrol is causing pollution to land water and air the alternative form of renewable diesel called biodiesel came into the picture. Since this diesel is made from organic components it is called Biodiesel which consists of mono alkyl esters of long chain fatty acids and meets the requirement of American Society for Testing and Materials ASTM D 6751 27 . This type of fuel is eco- friendly efficient and can be used without modifying the engine if used up to certain blending limits Deepanraj et al. 2016 . 3.1.2. Fuel properties Generally the most cost-effective way of manufacturing the bio- diesel is through base-catalyzed transesterification as it requires low temperature and low pressure and ultimately creates a 98 yield. The reaction of triglyceride i.e. fat or oil with an alcohol to produce esters and glycerol is involved in the transesterification process. The glycerine particle with a base of three long-chain fatty acids forms the triglyceride. The properties of the fats are decided by the characteristics of the fatty acids connected with glycerine 28 . The qualities of biodiesel can be influenced by the nature of fatty acids. In the presence of a catalyst normally sodium hydroxide NaOH during the esterification process the triglyceride is made to react with alcohol 29 . The mono-alkyl ester or biodiesel and crude glycerol are produced when alcohol reacts with fatty acids. Commonly the alcohol used is methanol and ethanol Methanol produces methyl esters and ethanol produces ethyl esters and is base-catalyzed by one or the other potassium or sodium hydroxide . The reaction between oil fats and alcohol establishes a reversible re action thus the alcohol should be added in abundance to establish an entire conversion. If the ester and the glycerol layers are separated after the reaction then only the transesterification reaction is successful. The heavier co-items i.e. glycerol settles out and is sold for what it s worth for example the drug beauty care products and so forth. Table 2 ex hibits the Biodiesel yield on different types of microalgae with different feedstock. 3.1.3. Environmental and health impacts Biodiesel is commonly used all around the globe as transportation fuel due to its bio renewable fluid properties. The ecological advantages that biodiesel provides has made it more appealing. it provides more energy which can be used with respect to its counterpart fossil energy lessens ozone harming substances lessens a few significant air poisons and negligibly affects human and ecological wellbeing through N P furthermore pesticide discharge 30 . It is very less polluting when compared with petrol and diesel fuels because of which emissions of pollutant such as SO2 sulfur dioxide unburned hydrocarbons CO2 carbon dioxide air toxics CO carbon monoxide and particulates are very less 31 . 3.2. Biogas Biogas is a renewable gas produced by the breakdown of natural count such as food scraps and animal waste 32 . It s far an herbal gas that is acquired via anaerobic digestion i.e. bacterial fermentation that takes area within the absence of oxygen of natural residue from plant or animal residues. Denitrifying microorganism which converts the nitrates within the soil to unfastened nitrogen i.e. Methanogens is utilized in global gas plant. Approximately 50 70 of biogas is made from methane and the final of carbon dioxide and different as minor factor 33 . As biogas is a renewable in addition to an easy supply of energy biogas plant life notably are the greenhouse impact the plant lowers the methane emission with the aid of capturing the dangerous gas and the usage of it as fuel. 3.2.1. Basics and definition Biogas production is a biotechnology that has a very long tradition for some 2 000 3 000 years. Biogas was applied at first for sanitation purposes and further for energy production 34 . Biogas plays a salient role in transformation to an economy low in carbon. Biogas can be considered as one of the potential alternative energy sources available today. We can assume that the modern biogas production industry is just at the leap of wider implementation. Factors that affect low establish ment of biogas include but not limited to unawareness about the pos sibilities of biogas untrained labor force high capital cost and no subsidies and lack of legislative government policies. The biogas consists of methane CH4 CO2 oxygen O2 water H2O hydrogen sulphide H2S and sulphur S traces. Biogas is enhanced to biomethane 98 CH4 in a biogas treatment plant which has properties close to natural gas and can be utilized for all natural gas applications 35 . Thus refined biogas and biomethane obtained from raw biogas are renewable sources of fuels which can be reserved for future use. Gas produced released by the anaerobic organic matter digestion biomass gasification or power into gas from sources of biomass and without subsequent purification or upgrading As per source ISO 20675 2018 36 . Biogas comprises of methane carbon dioxide carbon monoxide hydrogen and heavier hydrocarbons with 2 to 6 carbon atoms As per source ISO 20675 2018 . Biomass can be divided into the following categories namely substrate of farm origin e.g livestock waste Landfill Gas municipalities waste and private household s waste and industrial by-products glycerine . Table 3 reveals the various microalgae with different feedstock used for the production of biogas. 3.2.2. Fuel properties Biogas is another effective gaseous biofuel produced from a variety of natural and waste sources. It contains CH4 and CO2 with low amounts of hydrogen H2 nitrogen N2 hydrogen sulphide H2S oxygen O2 water H2O and saturated hydrocarbons i.e ethane propane 35 . CH4 can be burned much cleaner than coal providing energy with moderate levels of CO2 emissions. Biomethane eliminates fuel-related pollution. It also reduces the risk of potentially destructive accidents 37 . 3.2.3. Environmental and health impacts Biogas is renewable and sustainable as it can enhance energy secu rity. It permits exploitation of agricultural and organic byproducts with a lesser effect on the standard of air in contrast to the use of conventional fuels. It is a good alternative than those whose emissions that leads to eutrophication and acidification. Organic material if not used becomes harmful and pathogenic. Using methane as an energy source reduces its climatic effect by forming CO2 which is comparatively less harmful as a greenhouse gas. Biogas can significantly reduce the impacts of emissions by greenhouse gas but caution must be paid towards unwanted emis sions of CH4 and nitrous oxide N2O 38 . Methane has higher impacts on the environment compared to CO2. The presence of hydrogen sul phide poses various health risks due to its toxicity and the negative pressure causes explosion of biogas. 3.3. Biosyngas Biosyngas is a semi solid cluster that is produced after digesting the organic waste and producing bio methane. This cluster usually contains plastics and heavy metals which help in the reduction of utilization. Also as it is available in surplus amount it becomes more of an expenditure which in turn causes problems to agriculture field. The main objective of this is to overcome the challenges by thermally treating this cluster and producing a variety of byproducts that will help improving the nutrients that exists in wastes. By adding the thermal treatment with existing biogas plant it increases bio methane produc tion and overall efficiency. Another advantage by adding a thermal treatment is that it broadens the sort of organic wastes that would be treated in biogas plants and thus it increases biogas production. A.B. Sathya et al. A.B. Sathya et al. Fuel 332 2023 126199 6 3.3.1. Basics and definition Biomass is present in large quantities and has a great future as a renewable energy resource. It may be used as raw material for biofuel production and chemical production further reducing the CO2 emissions and consumptions of fossil fuels. During the initial years of research efforts were made for liquid fuels production from biomass. Initially all the experimentation was aimed at production of product gas through gasification of biomass 39 . During the course of research biomass gasification developments were being made and later new insights were found related to scale and layouts of optimum biomass plants. It was found that biomass being an expensive fuel production processes should be in a way that there is maximum biomass to produce efficiency in order to ensure cost effective production. 3.3.2. Fuel properties Biosyngas can be obtained by high temperature gasification of biomass. Upon gasification of biomass for higher temperatures greater than 1200 c biomass is almost completely converted to bio syngas 40 . Components of the biosyngas produced mainly include CO CH4 and H2. It might contain traces of other elements like N2 CO2 and high-order hydrocarbons. Chemical composition of bio syngas is similar to syngas derived from fossil sources. Biosyngas is also used as feedstock for thermochemical processes like for the production of biofuels like methanol ethanol dimethylether DME and gases such as hydrogen and synthetic natural gas SNG 41 . Combustion properties of bio syngas are dependent on the composition of the gas. It is observed from experiments that increase in fraction of H2 increases the explosion pressure and decrease in explosion time. In order to reduce the explosion pressure and increase explosion time N2 CO2 is added.Treated gas is used accordingly for the purposes like storage transportation. Bioethanol Ethanol is a hydrocarbon with chemical structure C2H5OH. The hy droxide group present in the ethanol makes it a polar molecule. Bio ethanol is a biofuel that is generally produced by fermenting sugarcane and grains and other agricultural waste like wheat straw etc. Even algae grown in wastewater sewage or salt water can be used to produce bioethanol. Bioethanol can either be directly used as fuel or as an addition with gasoline. It has a greater octane number which helps in enhancing performance and efficiency in internal combustion engines. It can be used as feedstock for use in chemical industry and as fuel in thermal power plant. 3.4.1. Basics and definition Bioethanol also known as biomass-based ethanol is primarily pro duced by the fermenting sugar glucose and sucrose mainly obtained from organic sources like plants sugarcane corn maize wheat and many more using cultured microorganisms yeasts 42 . It is a transparent colorless liquid. It has many perks like biodegradability less toxicity less harm to the environment than other traditional fuels. Brazil and U.S.A were major bioethanol producers from sugarcane and corns respectively by the 1970s. Currently the production focus is mostly on lignocellulosic biomass. Bioethanol is most commonly used as automobile fuel. It is blended with petrol at certain ratios at any concentration up to pure ethanol E100 . In 2009 the Government of India adopted a nationwide policy on biofuels with a target of ethanol blending with petrol in a phased manner by 2005 2010 and 2017 5 10 and 20 respectively . But the target was not met by 2017 and the achievement date was extended to 2030. Table 5 illustrates the employment of various microalgae with different feedstock for the bioethanol production. 3.4.2. Commercial benefits Bioethanol blended fuel has a considerable advantage over conven tional fuels which are i. It is a renewable source of energy as it comes from crops that can be grown infinitely as long as all the nutritional and weather conditions are met. ii. It will limit to a level the greenhouse emission as the fuel crops will absorb the carbon dioxide emission. It will also improve the rural economy where the fuel crop is grown. iii. It is self-degradable and cleaner in nature than petroleum-based fuels. Also the carbon dioxide emission rate will be reduced if bioethanol-blend in older motor vehicle engines thus improving the air quality. iv. Since bioethanol is produced similarly to fermentation hence it can be distributed using similar transportation vehicles and methods. 3.5. Despite biochemical methods are more ecologically friendly and require less energy they aren t really appropriate for large- scale manufacturing due to their poor conversion efficiency time- consuming reaction steps and inability to be cost-effective. Gasifica tion liquefaction and torrefaction are thermochemical processes that transform biomass into biofuels such as biochar biogas syngas and hydrocarbon fuel. Different type of biofuel produced from various microalgae has been listed in Table 7. 4.1. Thermochemical conversion Biomass is converted to biofuel through a process known as ther mochemical conversion in which thermal decomposition is the primary chemical reaction. Gasification liquefaction and pyrolysis are three thermochemical processes involved in conversion of biomass. Gasifica tion occurs as a result of partial oxidation of wet biomass which gen erates a low-heating value combustion gas that can be burned directly. Catalyst is present at higher temperatures 800 1000 C for these re actions. There are several studies on the gasification characteristics of microbial biomass which include the presence of CO2 and H2 as major products and traces of CO2 N2 and methane as minor products. Using microbial biomass Spirulina Hirano et al in 1998 49 reached the maximum theoretical yield of 64.0 methanol per gram of dry biomass by partially oxidizing it at the temperature of 1000 C. Despite this one of the biggest challenges in gasification is preventing tar from forming in the gasified products because this fouls pipes filters turbines and gas engines. There have been technological advances towards minimizing tar formation including iterating the gasifier design tuning the oper ating conditions gasifying agent pressure temperature steam biomass ratio etc. and applying effective catalysts. Using Aspen Plus a new gasification model from the UK has recently been developed that pro duces syngas and CO2 with the lowest tar content but preliminary experimentation has not been performed yet to verify this model 50 . The thermochemical process of liquefaction is remarkably similar to that of gasification. The liquefaction processes occur at a considerably lower temperature one-third of the temperature required for gasifica tion but they necessitate a high partial pressure of H2 5 20 MPa . The liquefaction response frameworks and the cycle activity are normally perplexing consequently making them costly. Converting heavy hy drocarbons into light hydrocarbons is the main goal. The primary concept is to use a high water activity to transform the heavy hydro carbon chain into less complex molecules with a greater energy density. Research by Minowa et al. investigated employed wet biomass Duna liella tertiolecta as raw material in the thermos-liquefaction apparatus. At 300 C a whole liquid oil production of 42 per dry biomass was achieved with a reported higher heating value of 354.9 MJ kg. Due to the obvious growing demand for liquid fuel liquefaction method offers the potential to economically replace petroleum-based liquid oil. Fig. 2. Methods of microalgae biomass transformation into biofuel and its products. A.B. Sathya et al. Fuel 332 2023 126199 11 Moreover the pyrolysis fuel presents technical problems such as higher viscosity increased acidity dissolved compounds and higher moisture content. As a result an upstream oil upgrading system is necessary for the liquid oil purification process Demirbas A et al. 2007 . Torre faction is a thermochemical conversion process that uses biomass to create coal fuel biochar . This process produces solid coal fuel as its primary output while liquids and gases are generated as byproducts 51 . Biochar is rich carbon containing biomass that may be generated by the thermal composition of organic feedstock in absence of oxygen 52 . Pyrolysis biochar has a high surface area making it more suited for soil fertility enhancement and waste treatment but in comparison to torrefaction the colorific value is limited for pyrolysis biochar. Torre faction can thus provide higher-quality solid fuel than pyrolysis 53 . 4.2. Chemical conversion Depending on the feed composition chemical conversion of algal lipid oil is generally accomplished by esterification or trans esterification. Lipids microalgae oil are the basic material for chemical conversion. They are composed mostly of triglycerides 90 98 moisture and traces of other leftover components. To avoid saponifi cation the esterification process comes before the transesterification reaction if the lipids include a lot of free fatty acids or moisture. Transesterification of biodiesel includes the interaction of lipids of microalgae triglycerides free fatty acids through monoalcohols in the presence of a catalyst 54 . The transesterification process is classified into three kinds depending on the nature of catalyst used such as en zymes acid and base transesterification. These types were additionally partitioned into two broad classes homogeneous and heterogeneous transesterification as displayed in Fig. 3. Because of the inexpensive price of the catalyst and the quick reaction rate homogeneous trans esterification processes are favored. In contrast the separation and regeneration of the used catalyst is considerably easier in heterogeneous transesterification processes allowing it to be employed on a wider scale 55 . Due to the cheap cost of separation and the ease of catalyst pro duction heterogeneous basic transesterification is environmentally benign and can thus be simply scaled up. The homogeneous trans esterification reaction employs KOH and NaOH which are the two most often utilized bases in the commercial manufacture of biodiesel 2 57 61 . For instance homogenous methyl alcohol and sodium hy droxide achieves 85 fatty acid methyl esters FAME during process ing of waste oil into biodiesel 62 . Despite of inexpensiveness of homogeneous basic catalysts for optimal FAME production it necessi tates a larger mono-alcohol oil ratio. Most commonly employed alcohol is methanol in transesterification processes however in some cases ethanol and butanol are also used. Heterogeneous base catalysts are far more significant in industry than those aided by homogeneous catalysts during transesterification processes 2 . This may be due to the fact that solid heterogeneous base catalysts can easily be separated from liquid effluent and this doesn t form emulsion and corrosion. Acidic trans esterification reaction doesn t form soap when compared to basic transesterification since esterification and transesterification occurs simultaneously. In homogenous acid catalyzed esterification of micro bial oil H2SO4 sulphuric acid and HCl hydrochloric acid are the two almost always employed catalyst. Soriano et al. investigated the ho mogeneous transesterification of vegetable oil into biodiesel using both AlCl3 and ZnCl2 acids. 98 yield of FAME was recorded at 110 C for 18 h using AlCl3 as a catalyst. AlCl3 has a better catalytic performance than ZnCl2 as a result of its higher acidity 63 64 . Transesterification of microbial oil into biodiesel using lipases enzyme is developing as a very cost-effective and ecologically friendly technique capable of overcoming the potential issues related to basic and acidic transesterification. High-purity biodiesel production no saponification minimal operating costs simple separation and recycling are all appealing benefits of enzyme-assisted transesterification pro cesses. As a result biodiesel synthesis by enzyme-catalyzed trans esterification is the greatest long-term alternative to petro-diesel 65 . Lipases are commonly employed in both free form homogeneous transesterification and immobilised form heterogeneous trans esterification . The free form or homogeneous condition allows for better mixing and therefore increased contact duration with the catalyst resulting in higher activity especially contrasted to the immobilized arrangement. The inclusion of alcohols like methanol ethanol and butanol during enzyme transesterification is common. The presence of these alcohols has been shown to decrease enzyme activities by inacti vation or denaturation. In a study using lipase obtained from Pseudo monas cepacia for enzyme-catalyzed transesterification resulted only in 54 of FAME yield due to the inclusion of alcohol 66 . Perhaps the alcohol should be added in phases or a co-solvent such as tert-butanol or n-hexane should be employed 67 . The inclusion of such co-solvents in the generated biodiesel on the other hand enhances the separation cost which increases the biodiesel cost. In order to improve yield to 100 and to avoid enzyme denaturation long chain alcohols such as propanol and butanol could be effectively used rather than methanol and ethanol 68 . 4.3. Biochemical conversion Organic substances Sucrose cellulose bagasse and starch are converted to bioethanol through metabolic activity of microbial sources by fermentation mechanism. Depending on the requirement of oxygen fermentation can be divided in to two categories namely aerobic and anaerobic fermentation. Microalgae rich in carbohydrate content are appropriate for fermentation to generate bioethanol. On the other hand the majority of species of microalgae exhibit relatively low carbohy drates. In such cases the conditions of the microalgal cultivation like light sources and nutrient supply may be altered to change the biomass composition. Yeast converts sugars derived from carbohydrates found in algal biomass such as laminarin alginate agar sulfated polysaccharides and mannitol into ethanol. The yield of bioethanol generated from microalgae is 2 5 times that of ethanol formed from sugarcane and corn. A 65 ethanol conversion could be achieved by C. vulgaris an attractive microalgae species since it has a high starch content of about 37 . Other strains such as Spirulina Dunaliella Sce nedesmus and Chlamydomonas are also recorded as promising bio ethanol producer as they have more than 50 starch content. There are different types of algae such as red brown and green algae are all investigated for bioethanol production through fermentation processes. Brown algae are regarded as the major feedstock among microalgae varieties due to its higher carbohydrate content and simplicity of mass cultivation. Bioethanol is a marketable and widely utilized trans portation fuel. According to statistics in 2008 86 of automobiles sold in Brazil used fuel with ethanol mixing. Nevertheless bioethanol seems to have some disadvantages such being corrosive having a poor energy value and having a low vapour pressure. Bioethanol is posed for inte gration with existing transportation fuel. However in order to obtain long-term advantages and sustainability additional efforts must be made to convert bioethanol to a superior quality fuel that may be used alone or in conjunction with fossil fuels 69 . Anaerobic digestion is the technique of digesting organic materials into biogas principally methane and carbon dioxide under anaerobic condition or with the assistance of hydrogen. The biogas generated seems to have a calorific value of 20 to 40 of the feedstock s lower heating value 70 . The organic waste containing high moisture level of about 80 90 is frequently employed for anaerobic digestion pro cesses. As a result the anaerobic digestion process an environmentally friendly route becomes suitable for the conversion of wet microalgae biomass in to renewable energy for home and industrial use. Methane gas is produced during the anaerobic digestion of organic materials by removing the carbon and nitrogen components from lipids of microalgae biomass. The microalgae s carbohydrate lipid and protein composition will have a direct impact on the anaerobic digestion process. When compared to carbohydrates or protein lipids from microalgae biomass can create more biogas 51 . Microalgae Ulva lactuca can create 271 m3 of methane per tonne of organic materials 52 . The process of producing hydrogen gas from microorganisms is known as biohydrogen generation. Photosynthesis is a type of biological electrolysis wherein water molecules are divided into a proton H and an oxygen molecule O2 . When hydrogen reacts with carbon dioxide in a typical photosynthesis route carbohydrate and oxygen are produced. In some cases of micro algal species rather than converting to glucose during photosynthesis hydrogen is generated under anaerobic condi tion. Hydrogenase enzyme may be used to generate hydrogen by a va riety of microalgae species including Tetraspora Chlorella Scenedesmus Chlamydomonas and others. The generation of biohydrogen can take place in three methods namely direct biophotolysis indirect bio photolysis and fermentation. In direct biophotolysis the hydrogen is produced from the electrons and protons released by water splitting at the photosystem whereas in indirect biophotolysis the breakdown of internal carbon molecules generates electrons and protons. On the other hand end result of fermentation is H2 formation when electrons pro duced from cellular endogeneous substate oxidation that reacts with H+ 69 70 . 5. Metabolic engineering of microalgae for the biofuel production In order to produce several kinds of biofuels such as bioethanol biodiesel and biohydrogen by utilizing carbon dioxide and sunshine microalgae are regarded as potential cell factories. Despite the distinc tive benefits of these microorganisms poor economic characteristics have made it difficult to commercialize microalgal biofuels. One of the most promising approaches to deal with this problem is metabolic en gineering 71 . Metabolic engineering is the strategy of optimizing the biochemical and regulatory pathways of the microbial cell system at the A.B. Sathya et al. Fuel 332 2023 126199 13 nuclear level to up-regulate or down-regulate the product of concern. These biochemical pathways are mediated by the vast range of enzymes and regulator molecules etc. and with the effective communication of these signaling molecules the pathways are maintained in the cell 72 . One dimension of looking into the metabolic engineering is trans formation of this series of events into a numerical expression which would be termed as model expressions to predict and understand the metabolic process of the product of concern more effectively. The other view key concept of metabolic engineering is to exploit the intracellular pathways with the recombinant tools such as gene overexpression gene knock out and heterologous expression etc. Fig. 4 illustrated an over view of various computational tools for metabolic engineering. With the great use of these tools and strategies the biodiesel production can be enhanced by suitably altering the cellular pathways of microalgae. For instance up-regulating the enzymes involved in the lipid biogenesis overexpressing the gene s responsible for coding the lipid biogenic enzymes identifying the potential rate-limiting reaction in the series of pathway to alter their kinetics increasing the light permeation rate or by decreasing the cell shading and performing flux balance analysis in vestigations such as metabolic control analysis MCA and metabolic flux analysis MFA . Typically the biogenesis of lipids in microalgal system involves three primary stages viz. Carboxylation Chain elonga tion and Triacylglycerol formation. To further interrogate into the feasibility of the approaches synthetic biology might help out the ways in which the pathways of the organism can be modified without affecting their survival rates. 73 investigated the metabolic fluxes of the each cellular compartment of C. reinhardtii by adopting a stoichio metric model with the expression include S the matrix component and v the vector components of flux. S.v 0 Online resources such as Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes KEGG databases and MetaCyc databases might assist to trace the metabolic pathways of all organisms in all order of hierarchy. Also the differentially expressed genes can also be used to draw metabolic net works with the use of path Express tool 74 . Under N2 depriving conditions the differential gene expression pattern was evaluated for the pyruvate and acetyl-coA synthetic pathway with the aid of qPCR 75 . A gene knock down investigation by two micro RNAs targeting RBCS1 2 and MAA7 gene was reported in C. reinhardtii 76 . 77 has reported the fluxome studies in P. fluorescens in connection with the fructose metabolism Krebs cycle and Pentose phosphate pathway. Likewise reports can be seen in the model organism Synechocystis sp. PCC6803 in which the MFA was performed under photo-autotrophic conditions. Further the study has planned to localize the carbon distri bution in the cellular organelles using isotopically nonstationary 13 -C MFA INST-MFA with high degree of accuracy 78 79 . An over expression of CrDGTT4 type-2 diacylglycerol acyl-CoA acyltransferase gene in C. reinhardtii was accomplished to increase the accumulation of TAG under nutrient starvation conditions with the use of SQD2 sulfo quinovosyl diacylglycerol synthase 2 as promoter 80 . More recently few studies were reported with the possible use of advanced genetic tools such as multigene approaches reverse genetics clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats CRISPR technology and Tran scription activator-like effector nucleases TALEN etc. in the process improvement and optimization. Despite the use of gene knock out through RNA interference RNAi was successful in C. reinhardtii 81 D. salina 82 it is highly complex to establish a common baseline sys tem for the other species of microalgae involved in the production of biodiesel. 6. Potential challenges in the microalgal research The exponential population growth across the globe and continuous depletion of fossil reserves were the prime reasons behind the search for new alternate and sustainable way of producing fuels to meet the needs of the society. In connection with this microalgae based biofuel pro duction has received prime attention in the past decades among the energy researchers to exploit their usage in the next generations. How ever there are certain potential challenges exist in this sustainable approach which has to be scientifically addressed prior to the commercialization of the process products. 6.1. Lack of comprehensive understanding of biochemical molecular and genetic profiling Despite the fact that several strains of microalgae were employed in the biodiesel production only limited numbers of strains were able to show the excellent potential in the accumulation of lipid in terms of its quality and quantity. In accordance with this only a very few number of microalgae strains considered as a potential candidate for the energy production in contrast to the total microbiota of more than 25 000 strains 83 . Also the specified species of microalgae oleaginous microalgae has the ability to accumulate lipids of more than 20 of its own biomass would also suffer with the following limitations. a Inad equate knowledge on the elucidation of its biochemical pathways and molecular fingerprinting b inability to develop an effective and rapid tools for the screening of different strains and c absence of complete genetic profiling and comprehensive understanding of metabolic path ways of the oleaginous strains. Fig. 4. Overview of computational tools for metabolic engineering. A.B. Sathya et al. Fuel 332 2023 126199 14 6.2. Growth and operational factors of the biofuel production in large- scale cultivations The open raceway ponds and closed photobioreactor PBR systems are the ideal systems for the massive cultivation of micro algal species. Of this each of the system was suffered with potential drawback. For instance monoculture maintenance of micro algal species is highly challenging in the open raceway ponds and also the existence of non- native strains might cause the risk of micro algal spills 84 . The po tential contamination with other strains grazers and bacteria etc. might lead to the complexity in maintaining the desired population of micro algal strains. Likewise the closed PBR systems are facing the over heating and fouling issues due to the improper exchange of gases across the system. Also the capital and operational cost would be more expensive than the former open method 85 . Also the optimization of the cultivation and operational variables needs further investigations to provide the functional insights about their dependency on the inde pendent variables. Furthermore scaling up of the process seems highly complex as there are high degrees of ambiguity exist in the redundancy and the reproducibility of the functional traits of the strains. 6.3. High capital operational cost and complex downstream recovery Besides the selection of strains and its productivity dewatering of biomass is the crucial stage of operation prior to the extraction of lipids and esterification. These algal pretreatment steps may be carried out with the process of energy-intensive drying and solvent extraction which significantly influences the overall economy of the process. Secondly the requirement of basal nutrients such as water carbon dioxide 3.5 kg to 9.3 kg nitrogen and phosphorous would also contribute significantly to the overall cost of the process. Further to reduce the free fatty acid FFA content enzyme-mediated lipase based or acidic treatment should be employed which would increase the cost of the process and also complicates the downstream recovery or separation process. 7. Prospective research 7.1. Feasible ways of cost minimization The prime concern of the current microalgal research in the biodiesel production is the high capital and operational cost than the conventional diesel production. In order to alleviate this the use of nutrient-rich organic wastewater can be used to fulfill the base elements re quirements such as nitrogen and phosphorous. Also studies can be envisioned in the context of 100 absolute nutrient recycling process which would greatly reduce the process cost. However with the use of such alternative organic resources like wastewater care must be taken to completely eliminate the bacterial and other microbial communities which might influence the growth kinetics of microalgae. A systematic and comprehensive life cycle impact assessment studies need to be carried to reveal their interaction with the ecosystem and to exploit the use of by-products in sustainable way. Integrated strategies may be employed to figure out the power required to operate the cultivation ponds for instance the heat liberated from the hydrothermal system can be channelized for the generation of power which would also reduce the burden of the overall economy of the process. In contrast to first- and second-generation biofuels some species of microalgae could perhaps thrive through harsh conditions such as optimum level to high pH temperature and salinity e.g. Dunaliella Spirulina Nannochloris Chlorella species and accumulate high levels of lipids tri-acyl glycer ides TAG with high annual oil productivities 40 times more oil per acre . Following the biooil nutrient-enriched microalgal biomass car bon nitrogen etc. could be transformed to commercial goods of rele vance for the welfare of both the market and environmental profit context. Further the practice of cultivation for biomass generation the harvesting and production of biomass and oil and the addition of value to the algal biomass using the biorefinery technique all affect the eco nomic feasibility of the algal biofuel industry. 7.2. Effective utilization of microalgae A comprehensive elucidation on the biochemical molecular and genetic traits of the different microalgal species would provide greater insights into their metabolic activities and hence their pathways can be engineered in accordance with the need of the society. Also the use of algal consortium may be attempted in open pond systems rather than the monoalgal culture and their lipid accumulation properties can be compared. Exploitation of genes in the nuclear level might create mutagenic and transgenic systems which would assist the enhanced accumulation of lipid levels. Besides the study may be focused on the generation of different metabolic models with appropriate process conditions for the optimization of cellular growth maintenance and energetics. 8. Conclusion Economic development and energy demand have become more rapid in recent years and a limited resource for fossil fuels resources and the need to protect the environment there is increasing concern over the development of eco-friendly fuels for instance biofuels will support resolve the issue. Biofuels derived from microalgae have been identified as a viable feedstock for the next generation of biofuels. Microalgae cultivation system becomes significant as it depends on the degree of control required for the desired product production and its value as well. Amongst available microalgae cultivation methods such as open pond closed PBR and hybrid system the hybrid system appears to be superior over others. The promising properties of microalgae entice the notion of constructing a sustainable biorefinery to reap multifarious advantages and strengthen the goals of a resource efficient bio-economy. This re view provides an extensive application of microalgae that have advan tageous characteristics which make them suitable as a replacement feedstock for a variety of bio-refinery applications. The enzyme cata lyzed transesterification has the highest long term ability to substitute fossil fuel derived products over other traditional biomass conversion technologies. Further researchers can produce required biomolecules using microbial genetic information that can be modified via metabolic engineering and synthetic biology. The application of metabolic engi neering and synthetic biology in biofuel production derived from microalgae is still in early stages. Therefore development of powerful genetic tool increased biomass and CO2 fixation are the challenges in present scenario which is needed to be resolved.
