A critical overview of upstream cultivation and downstream processing of algae-based biofuels Opportunity technological barriers and future perspective Shamshad Ahmad a Kashifa Iqbal b Richa Kothari c Har Mohan Singh d Ahmet Sari e f V.V. Tyagi d a National Environmental Engineering Research Institute NEERI Nagpur Maharashtra 440020 India b Department of Environmental Science Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University Lucknow 226025 Uttar Pradesh India c Department of Environmental Sciences Central University of Jammu Rahya Suchani Bagla Samba Jammu Jammu and Kashmir 181143 India d School of Energy Management Shri Mata Vaishno Devi University Katra J K 182320 India e Department of Metallurgical and Material Engineering Karadeniz Technical University 61080 Trabzon Turkey f King Fahd University of Petroleum and Minerals Centers of Research Excellence Renewable Energy Research Institute Dhahran 31261 Saudi Arabia A R T I C L E I N F O Keywords Microalgae Upstream and downstream processes Value-added products Biofuel Carbon dioxide A B S T R A C T Fossil fuels are sharing a large portion of energy demand. Conventional energy sources emit a huge amount of greenhouse gas into the atmosphere which creates energy and environmental challenges for the ecosystem. To fulfill the world energy demand and to support environmental as well as economic development in a sustainable way with the utilization of technological advancement of renewable energy resources algae are presently believed as most adaptable feedstock materials for bioenergy production. Algae has a high fixation rate of at mospheric carbon dioxide which supports to fast growth rate with high productivity per unit area in the form of renewable algal biomass. The present article aims to elaborate on the three generations of biofuels sustainable microalgae biomass production cultivation systems and a wide range of growth parameters. The microalgae harvesting methods and their challenges are also discussed with a special focus on lipid extraction methods and future r recommendations. The upstream and downstream processes of microalgae could help to harness the microalgae energy in an eco-friendly manner and will help in achieving overall sustainable development. 1. Introduction Recently with fluctuating oil prices researchers academicians and the commercial sector are focusing on energy alternatives to decrease the energy crisis as a whole. According to Coyle and Simmons 2014 the total global primary energy supply in 2010 was estimated as 12 700 Million tonnes of oil equivalent Mtoe which will increase up to one hundred percent in the year 2035. Highly developed nations have a high energy utilization rate compared to other developing nations Wang et al. 2020 . The quantum of conventional energy resource utilization is consummate in advanced countries such as Australia the USA and European Union EU despite austere environmental coercions that cause global warming via greenhouse gas GHGs emission. As a result of global warming hostile conditions such as temperature elevation and ocean acidification due to GHGs make humans existence on earth challenge. The main components of the GHGs are carbon dioxide CO2 oxides of sulfur SOx and nitrous oxide N2O etc. out of which CO2 is the highest contributor at present Singh et al. 2019 . The atmospheric CO2 magnitude has amplified from 280 ppm in 1750 to 415 ppm at present William and Craig 2020 . Therefore it is necessary to mitigate this prevailing energy dilemma sensibly using the copious resources of renewable energy like wind geothermal solar and biomass energy. However developing countries like India are mitigating climate change although it is earnestly dependent on conventional energy resources. Most of the power generation in India is carried out by fossil fuel-based power plants which produce a vast amount of GHGs. The per-capita energy utilization in India is approximately 0.55 kW which is lesser than that of developed nations 1 13th of USA 1 11th of Saudi Arabia and 1 9th of Japan Kober et al. 2020 . Biomass is considered a carbon-neutral source of energy. Being the Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses R. Kothari V.V. Tyagi . Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Journal of Biotechnology journal homepage Received 15 June 2021 Received in revised form 20 January 2022 Accepted 30 March 2022 Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 75 fourth largest energy source globally after coal petroleum and natural gas it contributes to 14 energy consumption Raugei and Leccisi 2016 . A wide variety of energy necessities are abated through biomass energy like electricity generation vehicular fuel and process heat for industries. Biomass gets its distinctiveness amongst all the renewable energy forms. It commendably reserves solar energy and is the sole exclusive carbon renewable resource that could be easily transformed into a solid liquid or gaseous form of fuel by disparate transformation procedures. The biomass-based energy generated by the biochemical conversion includes biohydrogen biodiesel biogas and bioethanol which are the possible biofuels of the future generation. Among different renewable biomass energy sources algae as the third generation feed stock holds several key advantages over conventional feedstock for biofuel production biodiesel biogas biohydrogen etc. owing to its high energy content high growth rate capacity with CO2 fixation inexpensive media utilization etc. However the development of a cost-efficient microalgae cultivation system is still an issue in the large-scale commercial production of microalgae-derived biofuels. The upstream and downstream microalgae cultivation for biodiesel pro duction is important routes to manage the microalgae cultivation feasibility. Cultivation systems and growth parameters are upstream processes that are the main primary tools to produce a high amount of microalgal biomass. Harvestation methods and biomass conversion into biofuels are downstream processes that regulate biofuel lipid and value-added products production from harvested microalgal biomass. The aim of this article is focusing on upstream and downstream processes of microalgae. The first part of the article provides a wide knowledge about biofuel generations and an in-depth discussion has been provided on the potential of microalgae-based biofuels and different factors that affect the cultivation upstream and downstream processing of microalgae-based biofuels. Besides several key challenges affecting the commercial viability and applicability of algae-based bio fuels are identified and a future direction is provided to enhance biofuel production and their value-added products. 1.1. Competition between generations of biofuels Edible crops are the main source of first-generation biofuels. Various components starch sugar and edible oil of different edible crops such as corn wheat and sugarcane are used to produce biofuels. It is note worthy that as far as the generation is concerned there are no modifications in the structural configuration of the biofuels none the less change in the biofuel genesis is observed between generations. The first-generation biofuels pose both direct and indirect competition be tween crops for food and fuel. It also causes indirect competition for food crop production as it is responsible for the transfiguration of forests into agricultural land. Second-generation biofuels are said to be sustainable as they are derived from non-food biomass crops and these don t compete with arable land as shown in Fig. 1. Also zero fertilizer less water and negligible pesticide input are required for their production. Nevertheless the sustainability of these crops is being questioned because of the land-use changes that ensued for such crops growth. Commercial production of the second generation non-food crops such as jatropha is done on fertile land which gives direct competition to the land required for food production Ahmad et al. 2019a 2019b . While first and second-generation biofuels offer some advantages they suffer from the requirement of arable land water use and high-cost pre treatment. Therefore there is a need to find viable alternative energy resources to take care of economic environmental and social needs. Recently algae have emerged as an ideal third-generation biofuel feedstock that holds several advantages over first and second-generation feedstock. For instance algal biomass is possible to produce 15 300 times more biodiesel than the conventional crops on an area basis. In addition they have relatively short harvesting cycles 1 10 days for continuous mode and 10 15 days for batch mode Zabed et al. 2020 and can use wastewater as a nutrient media for their growth. Microalgal biomass could be produced in huge open ponds or through contrived closed compartments photobioreactors-PBR . The produced microalgal biomass can be subjected to drying and processing to produce bio ethanol or biodiesel. However identification of an appropriate species and operating conditions e.g. amount of sunlight water and nutrients are important as they help to accelerate growth rates Ahmad et al. 2020a 2020b 2020c . Palm produces 5950 L ha -yr of oil while Jatropha produces 1892 L ha yr but at the same time algae yields 12 000 L ha yr having 30 wt oil comparatively and volumetric productivity of algae is also high as given by some researchers in literature Adenle et al. 2013 . It is expected that 20.5 of arable land would require algae growth to meet the worldwide oil demand Nwoba et al. 2019 . This estimate could be reduced to zero if non-arable land is used for positioning the huge open ponds and closed PBR Kothari et al. 2019a 2019b . In the total global energy demand only 1.5 2.7 of the entire non-arable land would be Fig. 1. The deployment of different natural resources for the production of 1st 2nd and 3rd generation biofuels. S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 76 required by algae Trentacoste et al. 2015 . 2. Algae sustainable alternative biomass Algae are an assemblage of eukaryotic microorganisms whose ad herents have a unique attribute of oxygenic photosynthesis. Algal spe cies come in various sizes they could be micron µ sized single cell multicellular colonies or paradoxical of intricate spiny leafy structures. Surprisingly they could have a length of less than 2 mm picoplankton or 50 60 m giant kelp . Algae can be characterized either based on farm and texture Fritsch 1935 . Among different algae microalgae are the ones that have attracted the most attention for the biofuel industry. About 50 000 different microalgae species have been described and these can be divided as per the pigments resulting from their metabolism and their cell wall constituents. The most common classification is based on the cellular structure that classifies microalgae into six divisions or sections viz. 1 Pyrrophyta 2 Chlorophyta 3 Chrysophyte 4 Euglenophyta 5 Chlorophyta and 6 Rhodophyta. A detailed classi fication of microalgae is provided in Fig. 2. Microalgae species have varying chemical composition with no special organelles although this exceptional feature makes cultivation easier and controllable . The photosynthetic mechanism of microlgae is similar as to land plant but because of their simple cellular structure they have ample contact with water CO2 and other nutrients. Hence solar energy is more proficiently converted into biomass by the micro algae as opposed to the plants. Moreover compared to land-based plants microalgae produce more oil per acre to produce the same bio diesel quantity Fig. 3 . They don t require potable water and can grow in wastewater taking nutrients from it. 2.1. Microalgal cultivation system The commercial microalgae cultivation uses a special kind of bioreactor which provides optimum growth conditions for high pro ductivity. Open raceway ponds and closed photobioreactors are currently being used for microalgae cultivation Fig. 4 and their se lection depends on the specific needs. Open raceway ponds are commonly utilized for wastewater treatment whereas closed photo bioreactors are employed for pharmaceutical and value-added products. The closed photobioreactors show superiority over the open pond re actors. It requires nutrients like phosphorus iron nitrogen and occa sionally silicon for its growth So the growth medium should have an abundant amount of these inorganic elements. Many microalgae pre dominantly produce neutral lipids exclusively triacylglycerol and hy drocarbons the raw matter for biofuels under impelled environmental conditions. A variety of applications of microalgae prevail such as bio fuel production biodiesel biomethane biohydrogen CO2 mitigation manufacturing of nutrient supplements and nutraceuticals and waste water treatment Callegari et al. 2020 . Compared to terrestrial plants microalgae are more proficient in photosynthesizing and fixing CO2. For screening purposes an algal strain is firstly isolated then purified and subsequently grown under sterilized environments in the laboratory. An ideal strain should exhibit certain remarkable characteristics like high lipid content higher productivity a hasty growth rate and excess tri acylglycerols TAG fatty acid profile. It should also endure a broad range of temperature pH and salinity besides efficiently extract CO2 from effluent sources and contrive sustainable byproducts de Alva et al. 2018 . 2.1.1. Raceway pond The raceway pond has been the most frequently utilized open pond reactor system for large-scale microalgae cultivation and commercial output for the past 40 years. The most common algae species that can be cultivated in a raceway pond are Chlorella Spirulina Dunaliella and Haematococcus and the culture mode can be pure culture or wastewater with CO2 capture technology being utilized in some power plants Shekh et al. 2021 . A raceway pond can be built out of concrete or plastic and placed on the ground or dug into the earth and enclosed by a wall to keep fluids out of the soil. A raceway pond can be made with a single channel or multi-channels and depth of culture medium is generally between 15 and 50 cm with paddlewheel baffle which control liquid flow and keep the algal cells floating in the culture medium and avoid sedimentation. Baffles guide the movement of cells and keep them from settling in a dead zone. Algae cells are adequately mixed and maintained in a continuous flow in order to receive sunlight and CO2 from the environment. In a raceway pond biomass productivities reached 60 100 mg L-1 d-1 Kassim 2015 . Although the open pond reactor sys tem has shown to be the most cost-effective and long-term option for large-scale commercial microalgae production it still has faults that make it unsuitable for generating high-value-added microalgae products like fine compounds and natural pigments because contamination-free cultivation is still a great challenge with open pond reactor. Bacteria fungi and other algae species are the main contaminating agents that are identified by Assunç ao and Malcata 2020 . However open pond Fig. 2. Classifications of algae. S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 77 reactors continue to be the most popular kind of bioreactor for large-scale microalgae production especially outside the laboratory because of their low cost easy to operate and expandability. The world s biggest raceway pond which covers a massive 4 44 000 m2 is located in Calipatria USA and was designed and specialized for the mass production of spirulina-based goods. A number of wastewater sources can be utilized for algal cultivation depending on the nutrients required by algae species S. Ahmad et al. 2021 I. Ahmad et al. 2021 . The maintenance of light and temperature at the optimum range is a tedious task in open race pond reactors. With the exception of tropical areas the growing season varies considerably by region and is limited to the warmer months. Bad weather usually slows the growth of algae. Open ponds have several disadvantages including uneven light intensity evaporative losses CO2 penetration from the atmosphere and the requirement for large areas of land. Commercial algae production in open pond reactors has also been confined to species that can tolerate extreme conditions of contamination. Mass transfer rates are also poor in open culture techniques due to inadequate stirring mechanisms resulting in low biomass output shown in Table 1. Fig. 3. Biodiesel productivity of different crop plants and algae. Fig. 4. Cultivation of microalgae in open pond and photobioreactors. S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 78 2.1.2. Flat panel photobioreactor Flat panel photobioreactor FPBR is a rectangular box-shaped variation of traditional PBR that utilized for algae cultivation. It may be used indoors or outdoors depending on whether artificial light sources are employed. Glass plexiglass poly-carbonate and plastic bags are utilized to make FPBR which are transparent or semi-transparent. FPBR has sparked a lot of interest for producing photosynthetic micro organisms due to their large illumination surface area Suparmaniam et al. 2019 . Transparent materials are frequently used in FPBRs to maximize the use of solar light energy. As a result a light path that is sufficiently short generates a high light surface S V as well as effective light distribution penetration and utilization. In comparison to hori zontal tubular photobioreactors FPBRs accumulate dissolved oxygen concentrations more slowly Behera et al. 2019 . In contrast a flat form poses a high risk of photoinhibition especially in outdoor cultures or during the early stages of development diluted cultures . Light over saturation inhibits cells at high levels of irradiation causing significant damage to photosynthetic systems and cellular metabolism eventually leading to culture failure. It has been suggested that FPBRs can achieve high photosynthetic efficiency. FPBRs are suitable for large-scale algae cultivation. However as indicated in Table 1 they have some limits. FPBRs are often used to treat wastewater with low organic load low solid content and increased light transparency such as urban waste water residential wastewater and fish processing wastewater Sarker 2021 . There is also an example that is used to treat starch industrial wastewater. Hydraulic retention time HRT is a critical design param eter since high condensed growth microalgae have a self-shading effect that decreases biomass yield and nutrient uptake. However evaluating the bioreactor s photosynthetic impact using different microalgae strains is equally important. 2.1.3. Tubular photobioreactor Tubular photobioreactors TPBRs have the highest surface-to- volume ratio which benefits microalgae light exposure. TPBRs are built of transparent tubing glass or polyethylene with the most typical shape being a serpentine loop arranged in a single plan Hijazi et al. 2020 . The most frequent alternative for outdoor mass growing is the horizontally displayed patterns. Another distinguishing characteristic of tube reactors is their radial mixing efficiency. A traditional tubular PBR is shown in Fig. 1. Beyond the tubes a gas exchange system aids in the intake of fresh growth media the cycling of cooling water and the supply of CO2. TPBRs are distinguished from the other PBRs by their tube length and diameter flow velocity recirculation type and geo metric design of the light receiver Solimeno et al. 2017 . The tubes utilized are generally between 0.1 and 0.6 cm in diameter with lengths varying from a few hundred meters to thousands of meters photosyn thetic activity will largely limit tube length between liquid degassing locations. With dimensions of 0.1 cm or smaller productivity has been found to improve. TPBRs are referred to be solar collectors because microalgae migrate across a wide sun-light surface. The lens effect also known as the focusing effect ensures that incident light is equally dispersed since it is diffused around the perimeter and travels in a radial path concentrating on the tube s axis Assunç ao and Malcata 2020 . Mutual shadowing is decreased as a result of this process and radiation intensity can be raised. The high S V ratio of TPBR is particularly ad vantageous for effective light harvesting with minimal photo-inhibition. Due to the high land requirements and additional expenses involved with solar collector equipment like as degasser units medium pumps nutrient mixing reservoirs and CO2 delivery systems TPBRs cannot be extended forever such as carbonation towers . In TPBRs air-pump or airlift devices are often employed to aerate and mix the cultures. The advantages and disadvantages of TPBRs are shown in Table 1. Because of their wide lighting surface area TPBRs are ideal for outdoor bulk algal Table 1 Comparison of various types of reactors used to culture microalgae on a large scale. On the other hand these PBRs have many faults one of which is inadequate mass transfer. Several studies have shown for example that in TPBRs extraordinarily large amounts of dissolved oxygen DO may be easily produced. In outdoor TPBRs photoinhibition is also fairly frequent. While the tube diameter can be increased and the tube length is needed to be maintained as low as feasible. Unless a suitable mixing mechanism is in place the cells in the lower section of the tube will not receive enough light for cell development due to the light shadowing effect . In any event by enhancing the mixing system in the tubes effective light distribution to the cells may be obtained Huang et al. 2017 . Furthermore most of the TPBR make it difficult to manage cul ture temperatures. Even if they have a thermostat maintaining the proper culture temperature can be expensive and time-consuming. Cell adhesion to the tube walls is common in tubular photobioreactors which should be noted. In long tubular photobioreactors oxygen and CO2 transfer gradients run the length of the tubes. 2.1.4. Vertical photobioreactor The construction of different varieties of vertical column PBRs is shown in Fig. 1. The top of the VPBR has a freeboard regime for gas liquid separation. Air bubbles rise higher in the air causing turbulence which aids in mixing Qin et al. 2019 . Perforate plates may be used inside the column depending on the design to break up bubbles and generate turbulence in a transparent column. An air sparger is used to supply air or CO2 at the bottom of internal column and degassing occurs at top of the internal column in the free board regime. Because the gas holdup within the internal column is much higher than the gas holdup in the degassed liquid outside of it the liquid gas combination flows up ward inside the internal column while the degassed liquid flows downward outside. The most evident advantage of VPBRs is better mixing which allows for adequate cell exposure to light radiation even when column width and cell density are large. It also has the advantage of being basic and easy to clean. A flat plate splits the column s diameter and divides the column into two parts the riser and the down comer regions in split column VPBRs. The liquid is carried upward by air pushed from the bottom of the riser zone Catrawedarma et al. 2021 . The heavy degassed liquid descends after the liquid gas separation happens at the top of the column. Aeration and liquid circulation are used to achieve mixing. Degassing takes place at the top of the column in a gas liquid separation zone and in an external loop VPBRs the degassing liquid is cycled via an external circulation. The airlift PBR had a greater dry biomass weight and chlorophyll-a concentration than the bubble column PBR shown in Table 1. 2.1.5. Open v s closed system The characteristics of microalgal growth and composition are de pends on the environmental factors and mode of cultivation photo trophic heterotrophic mixotrophic and photoheterotrophic . Phototrophic cultivation occurs in light where solar energy atmo spheric CO2 and water combine to produce chemical energy through photosynthesis. Most of the research is grasped through the photoau totrophic and heterotrophic modes of cultivation so that algae can grow under mixotrophic and photoheteropic modes Vargas et al. 2018 Su et al. 2020 . Based on mode two processes open system and closed system are used for biofuel production and other value-added products. Table 1 is listed the advantages and disadvantages of the various culturing systems. Open pond systems called raceway ponds are the highly energy-efficient and microalgae species Chlorella pyrenoidosa Spirulina sp. etc. can achieve the high yield at reasonable energy costs. Big open systems can be used for microalgae cultivation to produce proteins β-carotene and value-added products. The advantage of an open pond system is that construction and operation are easier. However it requires a highly selective environ ment because the environmental parameters are not controllable due to contamination from other algae and protozoans. This makes mono culture cultivation difficult because it needs a highly sophisticated environment to maintain the pure culture condition. However a small group of algal trains such as Chlorella nutrient-rich medium Dunaliella salina need very saline medium and Spirulina adaptable to high alkalinity can flourish under such extreme condition. As compare to closed photobioreators systems in term of biomass productivity the open pond systems are less efficient. It can be attributed to several deter mining factors including evaporation temperature and radiation fluc tuation CO2 deficiencies and inefficient mixing. Although evaporative losses contributes cooling and it may also results in significant changes to the ionic composition of growth medium with detrimental effects on the algae growth Anandraj et al. 2019 Barten et al. 2021 . Seasonal and diurnal fluctuations of temperature are very difficult to control in open ponds Ahmad et al. 2017 . Potential CO2 deficiencies due to diffusion into the atmosphere may reduce biomass production due to inefficient utilization of CO2. Also poor mixing may result in poor mass CO2 transfer rates causing low biomass productivity. Light limitation due to top layer thickness may also reduce biomass productivity. The algal cultivation systems are varies and it depends on the desire product and strains. Various biomass-based products used in energy recovery include biodiesel bioethanol biobutanol biohydrogen and biogas. For the traditional heterotrophic cultivations for microalgal biotechnology large scale production are needed to reduce the size of cultivation area that consequently reduces production and downstream processing cost. Although light is a limiting factor microalgae have high light utilization efficiency and high biomass concentrations. The main idea of using sunlight to produce value added compounds has many limitations and it depends on the light regime inside the cultivation system which is the main component of design and scaling of PBR. Photobioreactors have a higher diversity of shapes and configurations the most common being tubular bubble column air-lift and flat-panel. Currently close photobioreactor have received significant research attention. Furthermore commercial-scale production of cultured biomass is needed to increase the accessibility of algal biomass which is directly or indirectly influenced by the type of closed photobioreactors CPBRs used. Hence to achieve the maximum viability of CPBRs at the commercial scale several researchers investigated CPBRs especially the construction materials used additionally other influencing parameters of CPBRs are assessed to evaluate the commercial feasibility of CPBRs for algal biomass production. Tubular PBR are considered the best culture system in cooler climatic settings with no overheating worries. In a tropical environment raceways or open ponds may be more suitable so that a large amount of the water requirement is met. A hybrid reactor is made by combining a PBR and a raceway Kothari et al. 2019a 2019b . In the morning hours culturing algae could be done in the PBR and by afternoon they could be moved to the raceway. Yet again the culture could come back to the PBR in the evening hours. For diverse segments of the life cycle a PBR and an open pond could be used simultaneously Ahmad et al. 2017 . Various types of bioreactors are available for culturing algal biomass. According to literature and working conditions open and closed-type bioreactors are used for most experimental studies. Table 1 recapitulates the benefits and shortcomings besides a few good features of all PBRs varieties. 2.2. Growth parameters The most important influencing parameters for regulation of algal growth are nutrients quality and quantity pH light intensity temper ature. The optimal parameter ranges are species-specific and they all are interdependent. The growth parameters decide the output prod ucts of microalgae cultivation. Fig. 5 illustrates the various growth parameters required for algae growth which can improve the economic feasibility of microalgae cultivation for desired needs. A detailed description of individual parameters is provided in the following sections. S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 80 2.2.1. Nutrients Biodiesel production from microalgae is lucid as well as intricate. The essential requirement for survival is only water H2O CO2 and sunlight. However to produce biodiesel a considerable amount of microalgae is needed requiring sufficient nutrients. Thus large-scale algal production is not possible without proper nutritional support. The macronutrients like nitrogen N and phosphorus P are the pre requisites for algae growth. N plays an important role in efficient pro tein carbohydrate and lipid metabolism and their shortage. P is an important micronutrient for the structure and metabolic needs of algae. It is part of algal nucleic acid long-chain polyphosphate and phos phoproteins. It plays an important role in cell division and nutrient starvation leads to the accumulation of triacylglycerol TGA Solo vchenko et al. 2014 . Besides macronutrients micronutrients such as magnesium Mg potassium K calcium Ca manganese Mn Zinc Zn and Sulfur S are also required. Cells lose chlorophyll in the Mg deficit whereas sulfur deficiency suppresses cell division Fozer et al. 2017 . Iron Fe is an obligatory element for pertinent photosynthesis. For media preparation of marine algae sodium chloride NaCl is also an imperative aspect. Specific prevalent media compositions are enlisted Fig. 5. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 81 in Table 2. The environmental circumstances and algal nutrient composition could chiefly affect the N content in the algae. For optimum algal growth the elements silicon for diatoms should be provided. The nutrient medium should be appended with some salts like K in saline groundwater usage to grow algae. Various types of wastewater have also been tested for culturing algae. The microalgal cells consume N and P for their growth and this is how the N and P are removed Wang et al. 2014 . The degradation of nutrients is also performed by the microor ganisms on the condition that they are present in the microalgal culture. Through the process of nitrification and denitrification the degradation of ammonia nitrate and nitrite could result with the aid of few distinct bacteria. Algal cells could enthrall the inorganic nitrogen after it has been converted to NO3 - form through the nitrification process or it could be degraded into gas nitrogen continually. Besides the physical re actions chemical reactions like absorption ion exchange sedimentation as well as precipitation perform an essential part in reducing P Shah et al. 2018 . Through microbial actions too phosphate could be despoiled to a great extent. Moreover P could be removed through precipitation once the pH of the microalgal culture upsurges. The concentration of lipids increases as a result of nitrogen deficit. But at the same time biomass production is hampered as a result of lipid accumulation. In N defi ciency sunlight a limiting factor is augmented so that the biomass could be retained. Algal cells develop a protein deficiency but a boost of carbohydrate is seen as nitrogen is required for protein rather than carbohydrates. In the case of micronutrient deficiency photosynthesis occurs at a slower rate. Commercial grade fertilizers envisioned for traditional crops and they could be used as a nutrient source instead of expensive media. The discarded biomass can also be used as fertilizers after oil extraction Milledge and Heaven 2013 . Nutrients are crucial elements which regulate the algal metabolism for production of various valuable chemicals and biofuels. Thus optimizing the dose of various nutrients is essential to improve algae cultivation s economic viability. 2.2.2. Water Water is mandatory for algal growth and their conversion into bio fuel. Notwithstanding climatic conditions algal species grown in race way ponds and CPBRs have enormous water availability. Subsequently freshwater sources are restricted in regions where algae s productivity is maximum i.e. expanses of intense solar radiation throughout the year . Saline water is also necessary for the growth of algal culture. Moreover the freshwater source culture is impossible in almost all situations as the supply of freshwater is limited. Algal growth would be affected tempo rally when the fatalities through evaporation would be substituted by the open pond salinity. A fractional blow-down or complete emanci pation of the open pond water should be done when the algae s endurance range is narrow similar to many marine algal forms . Fortunately algae have the potential to grow both in fresh water and in wastewater including seawater. Similarly water and nutrients are the most critical variables for algal biomass production. Various researchers are exploiting this ability and efforts are in place to develop sustainable synergistic and integrated approaches for algal production by treating nutrient-rich wastewater Pathak et al. 2015 . 2.2.3. Wastewater Microalgae are oxygen-producing photosynthetic microorganisms similar to terrestrial plants. They are common in several environments like fresh and marine water and different wastewater such as municipal wastewater agricultural runoff industrial etc. . However wastewaters have different physicochemical properties compared to the marine and fresh waters or standard culture media. Thus algae have a peculiar ability to utilize various wastewaters as wastewater contains macronu trients such as N and P which are necessary for algal growth and presence of organic matter in the wastewater acts as a carbon source to synthesize carbohydrates proteins and lipids. Based on the molecular formula C106H263O110N16P of algae dos Santos et al. 2017 biomass produced from the utilization of wastewater it takes 0.063 g N and 0.009 g P while C and N contribute more than 50 and 7.3 to the mass weight Li et al. 2019 . The ratio of N P and C N varies signifi cantly with wastewaters while microalgae coordinate with nutrient and balance N P ratio in biomass. Several researchers found increasing the N P ratio in microalgae inversely affects productivity Nguyen et al. 2020 . The ratio of N P could vary between 4 and 40 however a range of 6.8 10 is considered optimal for microalgal growth and efficient removal of pollutants Huo et al. 2020 . During the strain screening process of microalgae for wastewater treatment multiple criteria are established such as fast growth rate high nutrient removal rate robust adaptability and high biomass pro ductivity. The high growth rate depends on adaptability which is positively correlated with a high nutrient removal rate. There are several genera belonging to microalgae that have been reported for wastewater treatment. The commonly reported genus belong to Chlorella which includes species such as C. kessleri C. emersonii C. pyrenoidosa C. sor okiniana C. vulgaris and C. reinhardtii and so on. Other species such as Anabaena doliolum Anabaena osaquae Arthrospira platensis Auxeno chlorella protothecoides Botryococcus braunii Chlamydomonas reinhardtii Desmodesmussp Dunaliella salina Haematococcus pluvialis Hindakiasp Isochrysis galbana Nannochloropsissp Neochlorisoleo abundans Micro cystic aeruginosa Oscillatoriasp Phaeodactylum tricornutum Phormidium bohneri Scenedesmus sp. Synechococcus elongates Trentepohlia aurea have also been reported. Table 3 summarizes algae species along with composition commonly used in wastewater treatment. 2.2.4. Light Light is the source of energy like other plants for algal photosyn thesis. Light intensity spectral quality and photoperiod are the crucial variables for algal growth. Light intensity high low requirements are highly specific to the type of culture strain used. This holds virtuous as the light energy could be made easily accessible through sunlight. However it becomes rather challenging to exploit the energy from biomass fabrication as there is an exertion of exposing the algal culture to a sufficient amount of light energy as depicted in Fig. 6. The microalgae could harness the wavelength range of 400 700 nm from an expansive realm of solar radiation. This particular solar radiation is termed active photosynthetic radiation PAR and 43 of the incoming solar radiation lies in the PAR expanse based on energy Ahmad et al. 2019a 2019b . The photosystem receives a good amount of the capti vated light energy by pigment-protein antenna complexes. There is a separation of charge by the red photon s energy and consequently quinones become the receiver of the liberated electrons in Photosystem II PS-II . Like all terrestrial plants algae photosynthesize and transform gaseous CO2 into organic substances specifically carbohydrates by procuring energy from sunlight. Because of the primary pigments chlorophyll a and b algal growth is enhanced in blue and red lights as these pigments are subtle to such wavelengths and used for light har vesting Hong et al. 2017 . The cells of Chlorella vulgaris absorbs light in the range of 400-500 nm blue besides 625-675 nm red however the remaining solar light was dissipated in between the algal cells Wang et al. 2014 . Similarly it was found that the volume of Scenedesmus obliquus cells enlarged and the nuclear splitting eventuated expedi tiously in red light 625-675 nm . In the photosynthetic process the autotrophic microalgae transform the CO2 into organic compounds by harnessing the visible light. Artificial light in photoautotrophic and mixotrophic microalgae is also explained. The yield and superiority of the biomass are the two regulatory features when the achievement of any industrial or agricultural merchandise is to be determined. The photosynthetic photon flux density PPFD photoperiod and light spectral regulation could be synchronized for microalgal production using artificial light. This would help in achieving the aforementioned features. A restricted proportion of sunlight is available during the S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 82 daytime and the sunlight aggregate is quite capricious cloud cover . Moreover in the winter months certain world regions receive scanty sunlight thereby necessitating an alternative source of light which could be manipulated for uninterrupted algal production. Table 4 summarized the various light sources natural and artificial according to availability and their specificity in terms of algal growth. 2.2.5. Temperature For algal growth temperature proves to be a strong influencing parameter. Temperature alone determines N uptake CO2 fixation and organization of the cells thereby persuading every algal species growth rate. An increase in temperature leads to an increased growth rate until it reaches the optimum. After reaching the optima the growth rate gradually declined due to increasing temperature Table 5 . A positive correlation is seen between temperature augmentation and photosyn thesis and cell division beneath optimum growth temperatures. The tendency is elucidated by the augmentation of enzymatic accomplishments associated with the Calvin cycle Mourelle et al. 2017 . A comprehensive study and modeling have been reported to study the interconnection between growth rate and below optimum temperature. Using the Arrhenius function temperature coefficient Q10 growth rate escalation by 10 C upsurge in the temperature rate of growth escalates is frequently used as a factor and is anticipated to give a value nearby 2. An increase in temperature will become hostile for algal growth photosynthetic activity and division of cells while growth duple with every 10 C rise in temperature. Microalgal growth rate shows an abrupt fall when the temperature required for growth sur passes the optimal temperature. This abrupt decline in microalgal growth is due to the heat stress that distresses the enzymatic functions inactivation denaturation and denatures the proteins entailed in photosynthesis Rizwan et al. 2017 . When a graph is plotted for the growth of microalgae alongside temperature a bell-shaped curve is obtained. The optimal growth temperature for microalgal cultivation generally ranges between 20 24 C and sometimes it vary with the composition of the culture medium. The effect of temperature on the phosphorous concentration in wastewater was also studied using algae. It was found that at elevated temperatures 25 C the phosphorous amount was comparatively higher than at lower temperatures Pasaribu et al. 2016 . Besides phosphorus the elevated temperature was also found to increases the update of various metals such as that arsenic tungsten zinc and cadmium. 2.2.6. pH For the growth of microalgae and biofuel production pH is consid ered an imperative environmental factor. For the growth of microalgae and cyanobacteria the optimum pH ranges are prominently dependent on species type. The optimal pH for most microalgae species lies be tween 7 and 9 Rai et al. 2015 . The features of microalgal biochemical reactions often determine the pH of the cultivated medium. The whole algal culture may subside if the optimum pH is not maintained because all cellular processes may get disturbed at higher pH. According to Gao et al. 2012 the most favorable pH for C. marina was between 7.5 and 8.5 beyond which the microalgal growth was substantially decremented. 2.2.7. Downstream processing There are multiple steps required for the production of biofuels and valuable chemicals from microalgae biomass. The harvesting of micro algae biomass from liquid medium and extraction of the desired prod ucts are a complex and expensive processes. These processes are the key factors that determine the economic viability and quality of microalgal products. 3.1. Harvesting The efficient collection of algal biomasses is a challenge for the algal- based biofuel production process. Harvesting is one of the initial step of downstream processing to achieve solid content from 1.0 to up to 20 . The process costs about 20 30 of biofuel production s overall expense. Harvesting and dewatering together constitute 90 equipment cost to manufacture algal biomass Milledge and Heaven 2013 . The dilute suspension requires constant harvesting which makes it more expensive than the harvesting of terrestrial flora. The energy needed for harvesting through settlement and centrifugation on dry biomass basis is 1 MJ kg for microalgae while that of wood is 0.7 0.9 MJ kg Al-Ho thaly et al. 2015 . Instead of concentrating on recovery micro-algal biodiesel production works had pivoted on the yield and configura tion. For harvesting the microalgae various methods such as sedimen tation flocculation flotation centrifugation filtration or an amalgamation of all these have been employed. These processes have been discussed in the followings section. 3.1.1. Physical methods Centrifugation is the major physical method used for extracting the secondary metabolites and producing value-added products. The effi ciency of algal biomass harvesting differs in the one-step or two-step centrifugation methods. However the cell structure can be damaged by the gravitational force and shear stress. Moreover this technique requires huge capital and energy consumption therefore it seems economically incompatible. For the harvesting of 1 kg of algal biomass via centrifugation 1 MJ of energy is required. In general it results in high energy consumption 700 MJ dry tone of algae high GHG emis sion 50 kg CO2 eq dry tone of algae and high equipment cost as compared to other methods Pacheco et al. 2015 . The solids are separated from the liquids and gases by filtration from a membrane through which only fluid could pass. The algal slurry is retained by a porous membrane and the remaining water moves through a filter. For accelerating the filtration via a porous membrane pressure tempera ture and concentration is needed. For harvesting the microalgae various filtration processes such as vacuum macro micro ultra pres sure filtration and tangential flow filtration TFF have been exploited Milledge and Heaven 2013 . The advantages and disadvantages of various filtration processes are described in detail in Table 7. Though filtration seems to be a better technique for the microalgae of consid erably large size it isn t applicable for small size algal species like Dunaliella Chlorella and Scenedesmus. To harvest fragile cells ultra-filtration and membrane micro-filtration is more favored due to their nominal cost low chemical consumption and low energy requirement. Before the water treatment algae are separated from their culture medium through micro strainers. The mesh size of the micro strainers is generally in the range of 15 64 mm allowing the passage of the finest algae through it. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 85 microalgal cell sizes and is often used for flocs filtration Mathimani and Mallick 2018 . Though ultra-filtration could be well applied for recovering the fragile microalgal cells it is not generally used for dew atering the microalgal because it suffers from the costly operation high maintenance cost high electricity consumption and requirement of the special membrane. For instance for the production of 6 dry slurry of microalgae 0.4 kW h m3 energy is needed. TFF can recover 70 89 of algae from freshwater Pragya et al. 2013 and is considered an energy-efficient method for harvesting microalgae. TFF has a certain advantage over the centrifugation technique as the former is capable of retaining the complete structure and associated properties of the microalgal cells in the slurry after harvesting while the latter damages the intact cell structure of the microalgal cells after harvesting. Dead-end filtration is an appropriate technique for microalgal cells of 70 mm cell diameter. Though it is an extensively applied technique for harvesting microalgae its operation cost is enhanced due to clog ging. The gravity sedimentation technique involves solid-liquid sepa ration in which the slurry is precipitated due to gravity and a clear liquid is left as supernatant. The reliability in gravity sedimentation is quite low because microalgal cells density keeps changing though it gives the solid concentrations of 1.5 . Sedimentation time and velocity determine the efficacy of gravity sedimentation which is directly linked to the cytoplasmic density. Generally the cytoplasm density of the cyanobacteria marine diatoms and microalgae range from 1.082 to 1.104 g cc3 1.03 to 1.23 g cc3 and 1.03 to 1.1 g cc3 respectively. Whereas the mean sedimentation velocity of cyanobacteria diatoms and microalgae is 0.1 m d Liu et al. 2019 . The gravity sedimentation GS process involves low energy and is therefore cost-effective. How ever the consistency is ambiguous because of variable thickening in addition to low slurry output. In some of the research studies it has been reported that the gravity sedimentation process is not efficient in har vesting the low mass microalgae and a significant amount of biomass wanes at the time of settling. In flotation bubbles are formed on which the solid suspended particles get trapped and lifted to the surface of a liquid because of low density. This results in the separation of solids from liquid Barros et al. 2015 . Floatation has certain advantages as it doesn t require much space has good flexibility and also the operating time is comparatively lesser. Hence it has proven to be a good method to harvest freshwater microalgae species Table 7 . Though dispersed air flotation DAF requires quite expensive in struments it is energy efficient whereas electrolytic flotation requires a comparatively huge amount of energy consumption. DAF is a technique generally used for wastewater treatment. The variability of the sus pended particles is the determining factor of the harvesting proficiency through flotation. When the instability is low the contact of airborne particles will be more. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 86 in which the ozone gas is passed through the suspension and charged bubbles are produced thereby allowing the cells to float on the surface Mathimani and Mallick 2018 . Yet it is quite expensive and the contamination issues do not make it a suitable method for large-scale application and implementation. 3.1.2. Chemical methods The chemical methods of harvesting are generally called the floc culation process. In this process different coagulants are added to the microalgae slurry that causes microalgal cells to come close to each other and form a gigantic ball. This results in the easy settling of larger algae particles due to gravity. Generally the flocculation process occurs by neutralization patching sweeping and bridging Chen et al. 2015 . As shown in Fig. 7 chemical flocculation is mediated by inorganic and organic polymeric flocculants. During harvesting the microalgal cells are negatively charged which interact with the positively charged chemical flocculants resulting in the successful harvesting of micro algae. The major inorganic flocculants are Fe2 SO4 3 FeCl3 Al2 SO4 3 MgCl2 NH4 2SO4 AlCL3 ZnSO4 ZnCl2 CaCl2 and NH4Cl Mathimani and Mallick 2018 . Mubarak et al. 2019 studied twelve inorganic salts and found that six salts Fe2 SO4 3 FeCl3 Al2 SO4 3 AlCL3 ZnSO4 and ZnCl2 flocculated C. minutissima within 24 h while the rest were inef fective. However inorganic flocculants containing aluminum salts can affect methanogenic and acetogenic bacteria According to Barros et al. 2015 inorganic polymers such as polyaluminum chloride PAC can hinder the enzymatic activity that ceases transesterification. Conse quently the main disadvantage with inorganic flocculants is that they can affect the downstream processes show in Table 8. On the other hand organic flocculants are natural chemically syn thesize or polyelectrolyte. The common organic polymeric flocculants are polyacrylamides cellulose chitosan surfactants certain synthetic fibers etc. Organic flocculants are biodegradable so they don t cause downstream pollution. However they are too expensive compared to inorganic flocculants which makes them unsuitable for large-scale harvesting. The pH is an important factor that regulates the applica bility of organic flocculants for the harvesting of microalgae. Schlesinger et al. 2012 investigated that the harvesting efficiency of Nanno chloropsis sp. culture reached 95 when the culture medium pH was managed to 10. 3.1.3. Biological methods Biological methods represent the flocculation of microalgae harvest from the liquid medium using biological things substances or micro organisms . Different biological agents such as fungi bacteria microalgae and plant-based substances are utilized to harvest micro algae. Although biological methods are low cost and eco-friendly the contamination of microalgae biomass still is a challenge for sophisti cated applications. 3.1.4. Bioflocculation and auto-flocculation These flocculation processes do not require the addition of chemical substances as flocculants instead biopolymers are used to harvest microalgae. Substances like extracellular polymeric substances EPS γ glutamic acids are used as bioflocculants Barros et al. 2015 Chen et al. 2019 . To harvest the biomass from algae the bioflocculation has been categorically divided into bacterial fungal and plant-based floc culation. Several pieces of research suggest that bacteria are great drivers of bio-flocculation. The benefits and drawback of bioflocculation are described in Table 9. A comparatively high EPS concentration pro duced by the bacteria and the capability of the microalgae for flocs formation by getting attached on their surface determines the bio flocculation. The efficiency of flocculation and nutrient removal of 92.0 6.0 and 88.0 2.2 respectively was achieved during bio flocculation by Chlorella vulgaris when it was cultivated in untreated seafood wastewater Nguyen et al. 2020 . The results established the fact that the bioflocculation process was encouraged by bacterial exis tence. An enhancement in the yield of the fatty acids and lipid is noticed when the microorganisms are added. Microbiological contamination arising out of culturing the microalgae with the bacteria fungi and various other microorganisms affects the downstream microalgal pro cessing. Bioflocculation of microalgae is generally done by bacteria nowadays while other sorts of microorganisms like fungi and actino mycetes are yet not considered so far. A gel-like layer that is developed by the EPS on the membrane causes flow resistance leading to mem brane replacement repeatedly. In the case of autoflocculation microalgal cells can adhere to each other and form floc. Generally autoflocculation can occur naturally due to stress of the environment such as a change in pH nutrients tem perature quantities of calcium and magnesium ions in the culture me dium. Microalgae cells form flocs because of negatively charge on surface of cells by easier The electrostatic interactions are hampered due to variation in the Mg2+ and H+ OH- ratio among anionic algae Wan et al. 2015 . When the pH of the culture medium was accustomed to pH 10 the harvesting efficiency of Nannochloropsis sp. increased up to 95 Schlesinger et al. 2012 . The hydroxide OH- ion of K Mg and Ca was added to Chlorella vulgaris for flocculating that yielded the biomass above 98 . NaOH is added for carrying out the process of auto flocculation. The efficiency of biomass recovery of around 90 was achieved for Dunaliella tertiolecta after adding NaOH in the pH range from 8.6 to 10.5 and settling time of few minutes. Some studies inform that polysaccharides show involvement in autoflocculation like poly saccharides synthesized by Scenedesmus obliquus AS-6-1 and Chlorella vulgaris JSC-7 Alam et al. 2016 . Various species of microalgae exhibit autoflocculation characteristics among which Ettliatexensis SAG79.80 Scenedesmus obliquus AS-6-1 Chlorella vulgaris JSC-7 and Ankistrodesmus falcatus are prominent Salim et al. 2012 . The bioflocculation and autoflocculation methods for microalgal harvesting are simple cost-effective and demand less energy. A comprehensive life cycle assessment of microalgal bioflocculation is indispensable to understand the overall energy consumption and processing charge for laboratory and large-scale industrial applications. In the downstream processing and production of various products secondary pollution is not caused. During bioflocculation the EPS given by the microalgae during floccu lation follows the dual mechanism of patching and bridging Fig. 8 . When the microalgal cells are closely associated with one another the patching mechanism works whereas as a large network of new cells formed throughout the culture medium which is due to bridging mechanism. However the different microbial mechanisms involved in bioflocculation and autoflocculation remain unexplored. Fig. 7. Processes of harvesting of microalgae. S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 87 3.2. Extraction of lipid and its conversion to fuel The lipid extraction method from algal cells comes after cell har vesting. Biodiesel productions through microalgae are two techniques like bio-prospecting of high-lipid-containing strains and stimulation of lipid production through strain enhancement approaches both physio logically applicable. Lipid extraction is technically and economically feasible and algal strains with low lipid content 10 can also be uti lized for biodiesel production. The limitations and advantages of these processes have been sum marized in Table 10. After lipid extraction it is converted into fatty acid through transesterification. Transesterification refers to the chemical way that converts the fatty acid into the fatty acid methyl esters FAME termed as biodiesel Ahmad et al. 2019a 2019b . In this process viscosity of FAME is reduces. Initially the transesterification process was carried out using the base or acid catalysis but now alternative methods such as enzymatic transesterification methanolysis and mi crowave assisted transesterification have also been studied. After extraction of lipid from algae the lipid extracted algae LEA is leftover that provides comparable high yields of protein and low sugars to those from whole-cell algae. LEA is an important by-product that needs to be measured after extracting the bio-crude of algae. It is utilized for cattle feed and coal power plant fuel. LEA is also used as heavy metal biosorbents. LEA has high ammonia and nitrogen content and the concentration might be greater than that seen in whole-cell algal digestate. The efficiency of energy production and nutrient recycling by an aerobically digested LEA usually produced more methane than whole-cell algae but many inhibitory factors such as toxicity of ammonia algal cell resistance and nutrient consumption by bacteria could reduce the effectiveness of LEA. In the transesterification process alcohol and triglycerols are mixed in a proportion of 3 1 M for generating biodiesel. The distinct properties of the glycerol and FAME are demarcated as the former gets down in the base due to substantial density whereas the latter stays at the apex Chew et al. 2017 . Approximately 80 of the extricated algal oil vol ume could yield biodiesel Ahmad et al. 2019a 2019b . During trans esterification usually chemical catalysts acids bases or biological catalysts enzymes are applied. Numerous chemical catalysts like NaOH KOH Al2O3 BaO SrO Cao Zeolites HCO3 Na and K alkoxides like sodium methoxide Na-OCH3 sodium ethoxide Na-OC2H5 so dium propoxide Na-OC3H7 and sodium butoxide Na-OC4H9 have been employed for biodiesel production Ogunkunle et al. 2017 . Some chemical catalysts mainly acids like sulfonic acid sulfuric acid and hydrochloric acid are used for biodiesel generation. For the action of enzymatic biocatalysts lipases are deployed. Transesterification cata lyzed by alkali catalyst is expeditious 4000 times than the acid-catalyzed. Though alkali catalyzed reaction is hasty however it could result in saponification because of the amount of free fatty acids FFA 2 Mandal et al. 2013 . The water formed during the alkaline transesterification could usher the saponification reaction therefore triglycerides and alcohol used in the process should be extensively anhydrous. When an exorbitant amount of FFA 2 is to be transformed into esters acid-catalyzed transesterification proves to be a pragmatic approach. Energy intensiveness saponification menace segregation problem of catalyst and products the obstacle in glycerol retrieval are some of the challenges while using chemical catalysis. For trans esterification the enzymes could be very well employed as they demonstrate notable endurance to lipid s FFA content. At a temperature range of 35 45 C lipase transesterification is performed guaranteeing no catalytic activity of saponification Razzak et al. 2013 . The en zymes actions are curtailed in the transesterification reaction as the restrained surface of the lipase coheres with glycerol. The reason behind why this method is not being used commercially is because the lipase enzyme is quite expensive and there arises a difficulty in salvaging the glycerol from a restrained lipase surface. The enzymatic trans esterification would be a preferred method only if the restriction of the enzyme and multiple enzymes are performed oppositely. In Table11 various processes of transesterification are compared based on the catalyst used in the process. After extracting lipid from the algal cell a significant amount of residual biomass 70 remains unutilized because lipid constitutes only 25 32 of total algae biomass. This re sidual biomass is another important source of valuable products which comprises vitamins proteins and different chemicals. It results in zero waste and the end product of algae biomass can be utilized as fertilizer for the agriculture field. 3.3. Value-added products The potential use of algal biomass is not restricted only to biodiesel and biohydrogen production but also in applications such as biogas bioethanol bio-methanol bio-plastics medicinal value bio-ferilizer and animal food production Kothari et al. 2017 . Microalgal cultiva tion is significant to achieve high algal biomass having a wide range of applications in a different field polysaccharides lipids pigments pro teins vitamins bioactive compounds and antioxidants etc. . However more in-depth studies need to be conducted on the increase of micro algae cultivation and advanced processing techniques to set-up the po tential of algal culture for biofuel production Fig. 9 . The substitute of microalgae biofuels which have high productivity possibilities and no competition with conventional food crops is becoming popular gradu ally. Microalgae synthesize various bioactive chemicals such as lipids carbohydrates protein and pigment which show medicinal qualities. The difference between nutraceuticals and medicines is not possible food and dietary supplement depending on the country to country. Nutraceuticals products from algae have ability to improve the health prevent chronic diseases increase life expectancy and provide structural functional support to the body. An efficient food can provide supplementary or improved benefits over and above its basic dietetic value. Due to high protein content microalgae have been a good source of the different classes of lipids polyunsaturated fatty acids PUFA pigments vitamins Aratboni et al. 2019 Katayama et al. 2020 and bioactive compounds Table 12 . These bioactive compounds are syn thesized within the microalgal cells are exposed to different stresses such as nutrient starvation temperatures and UV irradiation pH etc. . Red microalgae eg. Cyanidios chyzonmerolae produce a broad spectrum of carotenes which are natural colorants used in different pharmaceu tical and cosmetic products. Spirulina is a good source of Phycocyanin which grows in an open pond for commercial production Kannaujiya et al. 2019 . Several novel bioactive chemical compounds like carra geenans fucoidans ulvans etc. are extracted from the marine brown microalgae such as Clasdosiphon okamranus Chordaricles neacystus Chordaricles Nenacystus Hydrilla sp. and F. ocussp. The anticancer and antioxidants effects of these novel compounds are in the clinical trial. Carotenoids pigments are used as a coloring agent for fruits and vegetables and other food ingredients. Borowitzka 2013 founds that Dunaliella salina produces the highest content of beta-carotene and Astaxanthin respectively of any organism. This can reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases and certain categories of cancer like lung and breast cancer. Microalgal culture systems are used to produce long-chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids which are important human growth supplements. Besides microalgal lipids are also utilized for the production of biodiesel. After extensive literature survey on biomass-based value-added products VAPs including con version route of biomass to biofuel influencing parameters and further uses of residual biomass for secondary bioenergy options providing a new insight for bio-economy. The bio-economy concept is significant for further challenges like energy crisis environmental imbalances and unsustainability on planet earth. Fig. 8. Biological harvesting mechanism. S. The key challenges and prospects Although microalgae biomass has shown vibrant applications with developing technology several concerns need to be resolved to utilize microalgae biomass better. These concerns lie with both biofuel pro ductions and value-added products. Though significant research has been conducted to reduce the operational cost of microalgae production and processing as well as of various refining technologies involved in biodiesel production the commercial application is still a challenge. To promote microalgal biodiesel production the main hurdles that limit its large-scale application should be keenly identified and researched i inefficient growth of pure culture-specific microalgae species in large quantities for large scale application is a major obstacle Fig. 10 . Thus efforts are required to identify and grow efficient cultures that can survive poten tial contaminates and yield higher. ii The cultivation cost of micro algae in the PBRs demanded 47.4 cost and a major portion of cost involve in power consumption materials design and operation. The cost of energy consumption and construction significantly decreases when the microalgae are cultivated under optimized conditions. For improving and optimizing the design of the photo-bioreactors and making it economically feasible there is a huge difference amid the design of an inexpensive and high-end reactor. iii The species of the microalgae and various growth environments determine the lipid yield. So the importance of the selection of suitable microalgae species and environmental conditions are directly affect the lipid production. The lipid productivity is hampered in certain cases because there exists an opposing association amid the cell growth and lipid accumulation thereby necessitating to prioritize the optimization of microalgae growth conditions. Thus there is a need to establish optimized micro algae growth conditions that can ensure high lipid productivity. iv Difficulty in separating the additives from the biomass of algae is the major hindrance in harvesting. Exhaustive research should be carried out to answer certain existing problems of rate and recovery of the harvest enhancement without hampering the downstream processes of biodiesel production like quality and production. For large scale bio diesel production the main focus should be on the identification of an operatively feasible and cost-effective cultivation system of microalgae optimization of the microalgae culture environment for the enhanced rate of growth and lipid productivity including the cutting-edge tech nologies for separation and harvesting the biomass of microalgae. Algae and its value-added products. S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 92 4.1. Microalgae cultivation perspective Light and temperature are the main component of photobioreactors that enhanced the energy and cost input of microalgae cultivation. However utilization of LED lightning systems somehow reduced the light energy input but consistent and constant maintenance of temper ature is still a great challenge in way of energy reduction. Apart from cost various technical factors are also affect the cultivation of microalgae in photobioreactors such as mixing mass transfer abiotic conditions and growth kinetics of microalgae. Natural solar light is the freely available source that can easily reduce the light energy of cultivation but photoinhibition is the main drawback of it. Temperature can also pro vide by nature light because microalgae need a temperature range of 15 35 C but in photobioreactors in natural light it rises more than 40 C that reduces the growth as well as biochemical productivity of microalgae Osama et al. 2021 . Therefore design consideration of cultivation systems open pond and closed photobioreactors need to maintain light and temperature control so that energy input of cultiva tion systems must be reduced. The average total cost of lipid production is estimated at 12.73 gal for photobioreactor while 31.61 gal for open pond. This indicated that the cost of biofuel production is higher in the open pond as compared to the photobioreactor. Zhu et al. 2018 used bag type photobioreactor plant for microalgae cultivation and they estimated a total cost of about 22.7 million USD yr in which nutrients bag photobioreactors replacement and CO2 are shared 60 cost of total production.
