Way forward for sustainable microalgae production. S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 93 open and photobioreactors can able to reduce the cultivation cost. However wastewater and CO2 from thermal power plants can partici pate as import variable for cost reduction because of wastewater and CO2 available at almost zero cost. Microalgae cultivation and harvesting should not be aimed only for commercial biodiesel and bio-refinery production it should also engulf various other value-added products like biochar proteins vitamins pigments and nutraceuticals which will lower the overall production cost of biodiesel production. Microalgae-based third-generation bio- refinery is still in the developing phase and it conceptualized by inte grating various routes at zero waste and low emission. The main chal lenge with microalgae-bio-refinery is cost and technology because extraction of valuable chemicals from microalgae needs sophisticated techniques that enhance the cost. More rigorous research and develop ment need to ensure the sustainability and profitability of microalgae bio-refinery. 4.2. Genetic engineering perspective Chlorella Dunaliella Haematococcus Spirulina Nannochloropsis are well accepted industrial microalgae species which are widely adopted worldwide and they produced numerous products which are utilized for feed food and medicine sectors. Modern engineering science such as biotechnology metabolic and genetic engineering are able to change the metabolic pathway of microalgae that induced biosynthesis of bio chemicals in the cell. Consequently desired produces can be successfully achieved. Misra et al. 2012 analyzed genome-wide identification and characterization of 398 putative genes in lipid biosynthesis in a group of microalgae Chlamydomonas reinhardti Ostreococcus lucimarinus Ostreo coccus tauri and Cyanidioschyzon morelae Volvox carteri. They suggested that orthologous proteins involve in the core lipid metabolic pathway in microalgae. The manipulations of phytohormones and nutrients stress are enhanced biomass and biochemical production including lipid pro duction. Auxins Indole-3-acetic acid IAA diethyl aminoethyl hex anoate DAH can easily regulate biomass and lipid production in microalgae cells. S. obliquus increased their biomass content by 1.9-2.5 fold through IAA used. Similary 2 4-D improved 40 biomass produc tivity in Dunaliella tertiolecta. Scenedesmus quadricauda Chlorella sor okiniana Nannochloropsis oceanica are significantly performed in the nitrogen stress conditions and increased 2.1 fold biomass and lipid accumulation Sun et al. 2018 . There are various pathways of biosynthesis of valuable chemicals are identified in the microalgae cell. The carotenoid biosynthesis pathway has been widely studied and phytoene synthase phytoene desaturase enzymes are widely applied enzymes that improve the production of carotenoids in microalgae. However other enzymes are also involved in the regulation of biosyn thesis of carotenoids. Similarly squalene is produced by down regula tion of squalene epoxidase through RNAi in Chlamydomonas and most of the efforts for chloroplast transformation are also made with Chlamy domonas Kumar et al. 2020 . Various recombinant proteins and anti bodies are potentially produced by genetic engineered microalgae cells. Thus genetic engineering and metabolic engineering can enhance lipid production with various other biochemicals. 4.3. Microalgae harvesting perspective Microalgae harvested by biological methods chemical methods and physical methods. Among these harvesting methods physical methods provide a high quality of biomass whereas chemical and biological methods still are suffering contamination problems. However physical methods are being energy and cost-intensive. Therefore a cost- competitive recyclable and eco-friendly harvesting technique with high purity of biomass is still required. The biological methods are more attractive in future because low-cost and biodegradable nature. Opti mization techniques of flocculation with chemical and biological methods are consistently improving the quality of the harvesting process. However optimization of flocculant dose for microalgae is still mattered of concern because each flocculant has unique characteristics that cannot be applied uniformly for all kind of microalgae. For getting a deeper insight into the mechanisms involved in surface binding of bio flocculant with microalgae cells thermodynamic kinetic isotherm and response surface methodology RSM principles could be used. There are several types of research that have confirmed that genetically modified microalgae can be used for flocculation. Also by altering the algae to prompt a receptor molecule and legend and then adding it to a different culture the antigen so produced could be used for inducing flocculation. The selection of chemical flocculant for the specific use of microalgae can also reduce the cost and environmental burdens such as calcium- based chemical flocculant can be work as a catalyst in the trans esterification process during the conversion of lipid into biodiesel Ahmad et al. 2020a 2020b 2020c . Similarly starch based chemical flocculants can be used for feed application that are not in toxic nature. 4.4. Economy and environmental protection perspective The cultivation cost of the microalgae would be greatly curtailed if it is done in rural areas since the land is available at a reduced rate. Some researchers suggest that collaborating fish and shrimp culture along with microalgae cultivation can boost animal productivity as well as water quality. The techno-economic analysis of the sustainability of biofuels and co-products from algae are analyzed by Cruce and Quinn 2019 . They suggested that hydrothermal liquefaction protein extrac tion with novel pathways and fractionation outcomes compared with other biofuels source at 5.37 USD 4.44 USD 11.13 USD and 4.31 USD respectively. However certain factors should be considered while selecting the land as the geographical environment temperature energy supply and the transportation of the equipment and materials can play important role in cultivation. The raw material cost could be signifi cantly reduced if the wastewater treatment is combined with a high CO2 e.g. 15 concentration which can be used as a nutrient and carbon source. The cost of CO2 reduction and wastewater treatment can posi tively reduce the net cost of microalgae cultivation. However treatment of 1 m3 of wastewater was needed 1.59 kg-CO2 eq m3ww and produced 113 g of algal biocrudes and 2.76 kg-CO2 eq m3ww by conventional process Ishizaki et al. 2020 . It shows that valuable biomass production takes place during wastewater treatment with low CO2 as compared to conventional wastewater treatment. The New strategies are anticipated considering the proficiency and expediency of the microalgal waste water treatment process i Micro-pollutants could be removed by the process ii The clean fresh water along in addition to the fertilizers could be saved which are required for microalgae production iii Recycling the resources and nutrients and recapture the lost energy should be considered and taken care of it. An extensive study is required for evaluating the viability of the method for practical applications. For removing the contaminants thoroughly at a high rate the design oper ation as well as the optimization of operating parameters should be dealt with sternly for making it feasible for large-scale industrial applications. 1 kg microalgae biomass production requires 3494 kg freshwater for biodiesel production and utilization of wastewater 50 concentration is reduced the 39 freshwater while the pure concentration of waste water utilization is reduced 93 freshwater that reached the 219 kg- water kg microalgae biodiesel Feng et al. 2016 . Correa et al. 2019 analyzed that the utilization of seawater for microalgae cultivation could achieve 4.17 1011 L year based on suitable land that is be tween 10 and 20 of total transport energy demand in 2030 and most important is that it could not directly compete with food and biodiver sity. Thus economic and environmental aspects are co-related to each other. Gerbens-Leenes et al. 2014 observed the land use of microalgae-based biofuels ranges from 2 to 200 m2 GJ net energy and water footprint was lies between 8 and 193 m3 GJ net energy. These values of energy provide 3.5 transport fuels in European Union in S. Ahmad et al. Journal of Biotechnology 351 2022 74 98 94 2030 and the highest land productivity needs 17 000 km2 to produce 850 PJ yr. In this way microalgae-based biofuels production can be sustainable by reducing the load on freshwater land energy and emission. 5. Future recommendations The importance of microalgae has been increased because of their economic applications in medicine fuel food and feed. Therefore knowledge about upstream and downstream process is need of current era. In this review various aspects of upstream and downstream are rigorously discussed with their key challenges. The future recommen dations are concluded here for the sustainable microalgae production Cultivation of microalgae with the treatment of wastewater is low cost and low emission process. Thus nutrient recovery from waste water is a cutting edge technology that reduced cost and emission load. Combination of microalgae cultivation with wastewater and CO2 source can be a potential way forward for clean water and air. The water footprint of microalgae cultivation for biofuels production can be reduced by utilization of wastewater as a medium and nu trients concentration of wastewater can also be enhanced the sus tainability by reducing freshwater and replacing chemicals of the medium. Most of the economic analysis of microalgae cultivation is based on lab studies that cannot be completely reliable at the commercial level. So more applied research data is needed from the commercial utilization of microalgae. Although initial results of metabolic engineering and genetic engi neering are showing desired outcomes in the direction of biomass and biochemical production and these are lab-scale results so their implementation at the industrial level is yet to be part of more rigorous research and development. Low cost recyclable and biodegradable flocculants are needed for the harvesting of microalgae that have high harvesting efficiency and they can be effective for various kinds of microalgae. 6. Conclusion Microalgae are acted as the miniature factory for sustainable and cost-effective production of biofuels value-added products and food ingredients. The technical and scientific feasibility of the upstream and downstream processes of microalgae are important for biofuels pro duction and the focus on process parameters that play an important role in the growth and accumulation of value-added chemicals in microalgae cell. It can be seen that the upstream process needed a huge amount of water nutrients and energy that enhances the initial capital cost. Moreover microalgae are prone to contamination and thus require unique cultivation conditions which can be provided in photo bioreactors. The hybrid cultivation systems seem a preferred choice in controlling the environmental conditions i.e. lower the production cost prevent culture contamination . In the case of downstream processes there is no single technique that is appropriate for microalgae harvest ing. The harvesting technique consumes the highest proportion of en ergy and time and thus the adaptation of new technologies for the harvesting and extraction of value-added chemicals may provide possible solutions. Therefore innovative upstream processing and downstream processing should be identified before the process can be applied on a large scale. Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology journal homepage Microalgae A promising source for biofuel production Sakshi Tomar a Shruti Agarwal a Harshita Singh a Reetesh Kumar b Kamal A. Qureshi c Mariusz Jaremko d Abdul-Hamid Emwas e Pankaj Kumar Rai a a Department of Biotechnology Faculty of Bioscience Invertis University Bareilly 243123 India b Institute of Applied Sciences Humanities Faculty of Agricultural Sciences G.L.A. Mathura India c Department of Pharmaceutics Unaizah College of Pharmacy Qassim University Unaizah 51911 Saudi Arabia d Biological and Environmental Science and Engineering Divison BESE King Abdullah University of Science and Technology KAUST Thuwal 23955- 6900 Saudi Arabia e Core Lab King Abdullah University of Science and Technology Thuwal 23955 Jeddah Saudi Arabia A R T I C L E I N F O Handling Editor Dr. Ching Hou Keywords Biofuel Biohydrogen Biodiesel Cultivation Harvesting Sustainable Energy A B S T R A C T Biofuels are emerged as an alternative to fossil fuels due to their sustainable and renewable na- ture. Among various biofuel sources algae have gained significant attention due to their high growth rates photosynthetic efficiency and ability to produce lipids and carbohydrates required for Biofuels production. Algae cultivation has no special requirements only water simple salts minerals and sunlight are required. Also biofuel production from algae cultivated in wastewater has an added advantage of wastewater treatment and CO2 sequestration from the environment. Although commercial feasibility of algae based biofuel is still uncertain and so far not clear if it could compete equally with other available fuels in the market. The experts are in favour of pro- motion of algae based biofuels considering the added advantage of carbon sequestration and wastewater treatment approach involved in algae based biofuels. The concept of a circular econ- omy and carbon neutrality in algae cultivation and harvesting are two intertwined approaches that hold great promise for sustainable and environmental friendly algae based biofuel produc- tion. This article provides a comprehensive overview of recent advancements in algae-based bio- fuel production focusing on cultivation and harvesting techniques factors affecting algae growth algae-based biofuel production technologies and the commercial feasibility of algae for biofuel production. Further research related to cultivation and harvesting developing new species and optimizing the biofuel production process should be carried out to make the prices of algae based biofuels competitive. 1. Introduction Biofuels biomass-derived fuels are nowadays a prominent substitute for fossil fuels since they are an environmentally friendly source of energy. Biofuels have the potential to improve the global energy system reduce dependence on fossil fuels decrease emis- sions of pollutants and supply energy in the form of solid liquid or gas Abd El-Malek et al. 2022 Akter et al. 2020 Raj et al. 2022 . The primary cause of carbon dioxide s presence in the ecosystem is the combustion of fossil fuels by the various energy-driven vehicles. Thus scientific experts have worked hard to develop alternative and sustainable forms of energy production in order to Corresponding author. E-mail addresses S. Tomar S. Agarwal H. Singh R. Kumar K.A. Qureshi M. Jaremko A. H. Emwas P.K. Rai . Received 8 August 2023 Received in revised form 18 September 2023 Accepted 1 October 2023 Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 2 S. Tomar et al. lower its levels in the atmosphere and stop the depletion of non-renewable resources. Producing biofuel from microalgae having enormous potential for lipid accumulation and bioconversion is one such remarkable effort Sathya et al. 2023 . Biofuels are catego- rized into four generations depending on the type of feedstock used for their production Alalwan et al. 2019 . The first-generation biofuels are made from edible feedstocks like corn or sugarcane which may cause food insecurity in the future. The second- generation biofuels are made from cheap and abundant non-food biomass sources such as agricultural remains. The third-generation biofuel are produced from feedstocks like algae specifically microalgae and macroalgae are attracting more attention. The fourth- generation biofuels are those that are produced from genetically modified microbes Sarwer et al. 2022a b . Production of biofuels like biodiesel and biohydrogen from algal biomass is mostly considered as a sustainable alternative to petroleum fuels especially in the transportation sector Rai et al. 2018 Najjar and Abu-Shamleh 2020 . Algae as the third-generation feedstock have the potential to address the energy crisis. However the high production and harvesting cost is the main restriction to its commercialization Chu et al. 2021 . Although the high energy consumption combined with the harvesting phase poses a significant impediment to the sub- stantial commercialization of algal biodiesel Najjar and Abu-Shamleh 2020 . Algae have been gaining significant consideration be- cause of their potential to serve as a feedstock for either biofuel or nutraceutical production. Moreover microalgae have 10 to 50 times more carbon sequestering potential than terrestrial plants Bhola et al. 2014 . Algae are also reported to be used as dietary sup- plements. It is challenging to add algae directly to the food due to their strong flavor and color. Furthermore the addition of algae into food may also affect the bioavailability and bioaccessibility of bioactive substances in microalgae. Therefore a thorough evalua- tion of the health advantages of food derived from algae is necessary. This will make it easier to promote food based on algae Chen et al. 2022 . When environmental conditions pH temperature light carbon dioxide salinity and nutrients changes they may pro- duce and store beneficial substances in the form of cell metabolites Gatamaneni et al. 2018 . Algae are widely distributed short- lived organisms that significantly reduce the pressure from industrial carbon emissions. Additionally algae are a preferred source for recombinant proteins due to their remarkable advantages of being photoautotrophic and containing both prokaryotic and eukaryotic expression systems Ma et al. 2022 . Microalgae cultivation using wastewater has re- ceived attention around the globe as a platform to remove inorganic nutrients from the wastewater and produce microalgae biomass for biodiesel production. This can be accomplished by turning readily available nutrients from wastewater particularly nitrogen and phosphorus into microalgae biomass which will also absorb carbon dioxide CO2 through photosynthesis. Because it is derived from renewable resources microalgae biodiesel could help to reduce greenhouse gas GHG emissions to the atmosphere by replacing fossil fuels. Despite the many advantages of producing microalgae biodiesel many technological challenges must be overcome before com- mercializing the product. These challenges include complicated procedures the need for significant energy input during growing and dewatering harvesting operations . In addition a further pre-treatment step is required to damage the microalgae cell wall to in- crease lipid extraction efficiency Kadir et al. 2018 . There are various approaches to increase the lipid carohydrate content of the al- gae. Shi et al. 2022 proposed a novel regulation method to promote the growth and high amylose starch accumulation by a newly isolated Platymonas helgolandica. They reported that adding glucose and controlling the appropriate circadian light and dark time will increase growth rate and amylose concentration Shi et al. 2022 . The attribution of biodiesel production is adequate on a macroscale considering the global energy market. The process of biodiesel production will be of great importance to developing countries in par- ticular due to its cost-effectiveness eco-friendly nature easy operation and potential to replace conventional fuel resources. The first generation bioethanol made with edible feedstocks due to some conflicts this source is currently not thought to be sustainable. De- spite being produced from non-edible sources second-generation bioethanol is not economically viable due to its high production costs. Third-generation bioethanol made from microalgae and macroalgae has been viewed as a possible alternative to decrease pe- troleum fuels because it does not have the problems of its precursor Veza et al. 2022 . The concept of a circular economy and the pursuit of carbon neutrality in algae cultivation and harvest are two intertwined approaches that hold great promise for sustainable and environmental friendly algae based biofuel production Hoang et al. 2022 . In a circular economy resources are maximally uti- lized and waste is minimized. In algae cultivation closed-loop nutrient cycling could be established where nutrients required for growth e.g. nitrogen and phosphorus are sourced from waste streams like wastewater or agricultural runoff Calicioglu and Demirer 2022 . Algae absorb these nutrients cleaning the water and converting them into biomass. Carbon neutrality could be pro- moted by sourcing nutrients from waste streams and utilizing carbon dioxide from industrial processes or the atmosphere Osorio- Reyes et al. 2023 . Algae absorb carbon dioxide during photosynthesis offsetting emissions from other sources making algae cultiva- tion carbon-neutral Daneshvar et al. 2022 . Another approach that could be used is after lipid extraction for biofuel production residual biomass could be utilized in other applications such as animal feed fertilizers or bioplastics Beckstrom et al. 2020 . Again utilizing residual biomass reduces waste and maximizes the carbon capture potential of the microalgae Wicker et al. 2023 . Sustain- able harvesting methods and continuous cultivation systems could ensure a constant supply of algae without disrupting the ecosys- tem making the process more cost-effective A. A. Khan et al. 2022 . Also using energy-efficient harvesting techniques such as grav- ity settling or electrocoagulation minimizes the energy footprint and supports carbon neutrality Ogbonna and Nwoba 2021 Hoang et al. 2022 analyzed the role of microalgae in the circular economy and suggested that the potential of scaling up current microalgae- based production could benefit from the waste-to-energy strategy with microalgae as a key intermediate. In summary the integration of circular economy principles and carbon neutrality objectives into algae cultivation and harvesting could create a more sustainable and environmental friendly approach to algae based biofuel production Choudhary et al. 2022 . This approach aligns with the broader goal of mitigating climate change and achieving a more sustainable and circular bioeconomy Sani et al. 2023 . This article attempts to discuss the most recent research and development in the production of algae-based biofuels. In addition this article dis- cusses algae cultivation techniques factors influencing algae growth harvesting and algae-based biofuel production processes. Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 3 S. Tomar et al. 2. Algae Algae are a diverse category of heterotrophic and photosynthetic entities from various phylogenetic groups classified as macroal- gae Syrpas and Venskutonis 2020 Chen et al. 2022 . They are superior in terms of productivity and photosynthetic efficiencies and not require as much land as compared to higher land-based plants Shobana et al. 2017 . In addition algae can transform atmos- pheric CO2 into compounds such as lipids carbohydrates proteins etc Kavitha et al. 2017 . Due to shorter doubling time 2 5 days and simple growth requirements in comparison to other feedstock sources algae are preferred to be used as the substrate for the pro- duction of biofuel biohydrogen and biodiesel Suganya et al. 2016 . 2.1. Microalgae Microalgae are unicellular photosynthetic microorganisms inability freshwater or saline environment Shetty et al. 2019 . In the exponential phase microalgae can double in number in as few as 3.5 h and typically do so within 24 h Vassilev and Vassileva 2016 . Microalgae are mainly composed of lipids 5 60 carbohydrates 8 30 and protein 40 60 Kumar et al. 2022 . Further- more some additional compounds such as fatty acids pigments antioxidants and vitamins Suganya et al. 2016 . In addition they produce other high-value chemicals such as fatty acids phycobilin pigments docosahexaenoic acid astaxanthin and ꞵ-carotene Shi et al. 2022 . 2.2. Cyanobacteria Cyanobacteria are common members of freshwater brackish and marine plankton worldwide. Cyanobacteria are commonly found on rocks and soil and in a symbiotic relationship with fungi and plants. At the subcellular level cyanobacteria have a simple structure that doesn t have a nucleus Kaviya et al. 2019 . Cyanobacteria contain photosynthetic apparatus which helps them to per- form photosynthesis in higher plants and algae. Still in cyanobacteria the chloroplast is absent due to which these reactions occur in latter organisms Singh 2018 . Unicellular and filamentous forms are primarily found in cyanobacteria. Both morphotypes can pro- duce structures visible to the naked eye such as spherical irregular colonies e.g. microcystins larger or pinheads and bundles of filaments like sawdust in size and shape. Commonly cyanobacteria are classified as algae known as blue-green algae a distinct group of bacteria that can perform photosynthesis. The nutrients and sunlight are changed by cyanobacteria into energy for reproduction and growth Chittora et al. 2020 . 2.3. Macroalgae Macroalgae called seaweed are multicellular macroscopic marine algae living near the seabed Pereira 2021 . Seaweed may be- long to the group of multicellular algae-brown algae green algae and red algae. These three groups of algae are not thought to have a common ancestor. Macroalgae contains an algal body known as the thallus stem-like structure stipe basal-type structure holofast finger-like extension of holofast known as haptera Suganya et al. 2016 . The biochemical composition of the macroalgae in terms of lipids and carbohydrates content is depicted in Table 1 Becker 1994 Kaliaperumal et al. 2002 . 3. Algae as a biofuel precursor Algae is being used to produce numerous biofuels such as biohydrogen biodiesel bioethanol biomethane and biobutanol Abomohra and Elshobary 2019 . Various thermochemical processes have also been devised to produce biofuels using various bio- mass conversion technologies. Among them the process of pyrolysis is simple practical and inexpensive and it may be used with a wide range of feedstocks Escalante et al. 2022 . Biofuels obtained from algae have the efficiency to replace fossil fuels as they are carbon neutral and thus have the potential to avoid energy security concerns and climate change. Many countries have launched programs policies pertaining to promotion of Biofuel production and utilization Ref. Table 2 . 3.1. Biodiesel Production of biodiesel from algae promises sustainable energy due to their fast growth rate and capability to be cultivated in freshwater seawater and wastewater shown in Fig. 1. The entire cycle of algae is completed via photosynthetic reactions that change light energy into renewable energy Peter et al. 2022 . Biodiesel is a renewable non-toxic biodegradable diesel and a long-chain fatty acid alkyl ester mixture. Biodiesel could be used alone or in blended form with petroleum diesel. Utilizing biodiesel as a fuel sub- stitute can help reduce reliance on petroleum-based fuels and enhance environmental quality in broad Noor et al. 2018 . Primary four techniques have been reported for biodiesel production direct use by blending raw oils thermal cracking micro-emulsions and transesterification Chew et al. 2018 . Biodiesel and biogas production from microalgae cultivated on waste water in closed Photo-Bioreactor. biodiesel. An enzymatic catalyst either acidic or basic is used in the in-situ transesterification process. The acid reaction effectively changes free fatty acids and triglycerides into fatty acid methyl esters FAME . Acid catalyst gives a high yield in FAME up to 99 of conversion Dehiba et al. 2017 . Biodiesel production from microalgae has been suggested to be much more sustainable and feasible Dickinson et al. 2017 . The process of biodiesel production will be of great importance to developing countries in particular due to its eco-friendly easy operation cost-effectiveness and potential to replace conventional fuel resources. Also algal biomass doesn t re- quire land for cultivation and is free from lignin Tomar et al. 2021 . The sufficient lipid content in microalgae proved it more suit- able for biodiesel production. Other products produced simultaneously during large-scale microalgae cultivation have various phar- maceutical and food industry applications besides lipid production. The simultaneous production of other economic products makes the process more cost-effective. Ağbulut et al. 2023 analyzed the microalgae bio-oil production using pyrolysis and hydrothermal liquefaction and suggested that microalgae bio-oil could become a promising alternative fuel for transportation and power genera- tion. Ahmad et al. 2022 reviewed the recent biomolecular and biotechnological approaches to increase lipid and carotenoid produc- tion from microalgae Ahmad et al. 2022 . The lipid production from microalgae is affected by various factors like nutrient availabil- ity light intensity temperature retention time and algal strain type Kothari et al. 2023 . Maintaining these factors at their optimum levels increases the cultivation cost thus making the process of biofuel production from microalgae economically non-viable. The au- thors suggested an integrated approach including wastewater treatment by algal biomass harvesting and producing bioactive com- Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 6 S. Tomar et al. pounds and biofuels from algal waste for feasible economic and sustainable biofuel production and other future applications Kothari et al. 2023 . Even though genetically modified microalgae strains have shown considerable potential for enhanced lipid and other value added product production it is dangerous to commercialise them for industrial uses. Beacham et al. 2017 advocate that pru- dence and common sense should be applied while cultivating large-scale genetically modified algal strains. The cultivation facility should be contained to restrict the release of strains into the environment. 3.2. Biohydrogen Biohydrogen is a promising and attractive alternative energy source as it can be easily generated. It is considered a zero-emission fuel much cleaner than all other fuels Singh et al. 2022 . Biohydrogen carries energy that can be used to replace gasoline in vehi- cles. Biohydrogen advantages include its high energy content and water vapour as the only by-product of combustion. It could gener- ate electricity in fuel cells by utilizing algal biomass and organic waste as feedstock Lee 2016 . Hydrogen production s conventional physical and chemical processes are energy intensive and unsustainable whereas biological production methods are sustainable clean and less energy-intensive Boboescu et al. 2016 . Furthermore Biological hydrogen processes may utilize variety of the sub- strates and have high conversion efficiency Rai et al. 2011 Goria et al. 2023 did the SWOT analysis of biohydrogen production from algal biomass. Excellent waste valorization and carbon capture are the strengths. Low biohydrogen yield and expensive startup costs are weaknesses. Algal biohydrogen can be improved by adopting environmental metabolic or genetic changes. The risk is that the technology still lacks credibility even with the suggested modifications Goria et al. 2023 . 3.3. Bioethanol Ethanol is the most common biofuel that can be produced from algal biomass da Maia et al. 2020 . Algae contains proteins car- bohydrates lipids and other valuable compounds. The carbohydrates such as cellulose and starch can be converted into bioethanol by fermentation. Microalgae utilization as a starch source for bioethanol production overcomes various limitations associated with the conventional starch source Özçimen et al. 2020 . Ethanol from algal biomass has several advantages -arable land is not used in this and thus CO2 emission to the environment is low da Maia et al. 2020 . Moreover high octane numbers prevent the engine from knocking Maity and Mallick 2022 . 3.4. Biobutanol Biobutanol is preferred as one of the most promising biofuels because of its energy density. The fermentation process can produce biobutanol but it has less efficiency in products because of the inhibitory effects of some compounds Onay 2022 . Plants and their waste can also produce it. However these feedstocks have limitations because of their low growth rate and efficiency of products for production. Because of these advantages researchers focus on algae for biobutanol production Onay 2022 . The use of algae can re- duce agricultural land usage and no fuel and food conflict exit. Moreover for growth algae can utilize inorganic carbon from the at- mosphere and could produce clean energy Shanmugam et al. 2021 . Biobutanol has several advantages over ethanol including low water solubility and conventional in engines without any modifications Onay 2022 . Biobutanol is safe and more convenient for pipeline transportation because it possesses low hygroscopicity is less corrosive and has low volatility than ethanol thus it is consid- ered an ideal biofuel Lee et al. 2020 Ashani et al. 2020 . 4. Algae cultivation techniques Algal biomass can generate biofuels such as biodiesel biohydrogen and biogas because it grows faster doesn t compete with agri- cultural land for its growth and converts sunlight into chemical energy by consuming CO2 Ramaraj et al. 2016 . The consumption of wastewater as a medium for algae cultivation has several benefits including nutrient removal 80 100 heavy metal removal 80 100 carbon sequestration from the atmosphere 1.83 kg CO2 kg 1 biomass and high biomass generation for biofuel produc- tion 40 50 higher than crops feedstock Shahid et al. 2020 . In general algae are cultivated in either the open pond system or in a closed Photo-bioreactor PBR and in facilities that process wastewater for the purpose of producing biofuel. Due to superior control over the environment and other factors influencing the growth of algae PBRs are thought to be more effective in the cultivation of biomass and the treatment of wastewater Yaqoubnejad et al. 2021 . 4.1. Open pond system The open pond system cultivation is the most commercially explored due to its low operational cost. Closed photo-bioreactors may have higher photosynthetic efficiency and biomass yield than open ponds Pires et al. 2017 . The aspects imperative to consider while selecting the open pond system are energy cost of land water nutrients the biology of the algae and local climatic conditions and final product. The open pond system is the primary system used to produce microalgae on the commercial level and in waste- water systems. Open pond culture systems can be elaborate as an inclined system mixed ponds shallow lagoons ponds raceway ponds and circular central-pivot ponds. Since the open pond cultivation system utilizes sunlight as a primary source and mixing the cultivation medium is less energy intensive and has a high surface area for gaseous exchange the operation of the open pond system is comparatively low Jerney and Spilling 2020 . 4.2. Shallow lagoons and ponds For thousands of years ponds lagoons and ditches have been utilized as primitive systems for wastewater treatment. Simple ponds of various shapes and sizes commonly enriched with manure produce algal biomass Borowitzka and Moheimani 2012 . Al- Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 7 S. Tomar et al. gal biomass for humans has been produced using some natural algae growing methods. Spirulina Arthrospira was once extracted from natural lakes by the Aztecs García et al. 2017 . The two Dunaliella salina β-cartone plants at Whyalla South Australia and Hutt Lagoon Western Australia are currently operated by BASF Baden Aniline and Soda Factory . They are the world s largest commer- cial microalgae production plants. Each of these plants has a total pond area of around 700 ha. The advantage of shallow lagoon ponds is that the unialgal culture can be maintained because the algae are grown in very high salt concentrations Borowitzka and Moheimani 2012 . Based on the pond area productivity is low and due to its utilization efficiency and cheap harvesting process this is the world s cheapest algae production system Suparmaniam et al. 2019 . 4.3. Inclined cascade system In cascade system ponds algae culture flows down in cascade surface and is collected then pushed back up to the top of the in- cline. Setlík and co-workers 1960s developed the patented inclined system at Trebon in the Czech Republic Setllk 1970 . In this set-up during the day culture is circulated from the bottom of the slope to the top and at night it is stored in a huge tank. This process reduces the culture s total pumping cost and overnight cooling. In Bulgaria 3000 m2 plants with sloping ponds have been constructed Becker 1994 . The ponds are constructed of concrete and covered with iron grids producing turbulence. This technique has the advantage of removing moisture and thermal instability while also achieving high algal biomass and making harvesting easier Xu et al. 2020 . 4.4. Circular central-pivot ponds Circular ponds are the oldest used for cultivating algae commercially in Indonesia Japan and Taiwan Tan et al. 2020 . These ponds are constructed from concrete and mixed by a rotating arm placed in the pond s core with up to 0.5ha in capacity and 50m in diameter. In circular ponds the arm travels a much larger distance so the mixing at the periphery of ponds is much more significant Borowitzka and Moheimani 2012 . 4.5. Mixed ponds Mixed ponds are most widely used for algae production for aquaculture feed Zhu et al. 2022 . These ponds are approximately 50 80 cm deep with an aeration facility. Productivities are low due to the uneven mixing depth of the ponds Koley et al. 2019 . There is an alternative mixing method for regular ponds i.e. drag boards. The drag boards connected with electric motors are pulled from one end of the pond to the other forcing the water to flow and create a turbulent back-whirl. In this system less power is used but productivity is low because of irregular mixing and depth of the ponds Borowitzka and Moheimani 2012 . 4.6. Raceways ponds Raceway ponds are mainly used to cultivate microalgae at a commercial level and treat wastewater. Although polyvinyl chloride PVC liners have also been utilized geotextile liners High Density Polyethylene HDPE and other types of plastic are typically used to line raceway ponds used for commercial algae production. These liners have a life of at least 20 years only when carefully and cor- rectly laid and the choice of liner material is correct. Raceway ponds can be built into the ground with sloping side walls and lined or they can be built on top of the ground with pond walls made of concrete blocks or pre-formed concrete set-up. The cost of pond liners is very high and cheaper alternatives must be explored to lower the construction cost. Rubber asphalt and other elastomeric materi- als have been employed in cold-applied two-component and hot-applied systems both with and without reinforcing fabrics Dodd 2017 . This still hasn t shown to be as reliable and efficient as membrane pond liners. The pond culture must be circulated at around 20 30 cm S 1 to maintain the algae afloat give easily uniform illumination and minimise thermal stratification. Various systems have been tested in the raceway pond for rotating and mixing the algal culture. Propellers Archimedes screws Airlifts Pumps im- pellers Paddlewheel and water jets are a few examples Borowitzka and Moheimani 2012 . 4.7. Closed systems Algae are grown in a closed environment with this method and any required controls can be applied to the physical conditions. This system comprises a Photobioreactor PBRs i.e. Horizontal tube photo-bioreactor Flat panel photo-bioreactor Stirred tank photo-bioreactor and Vertical tube photo-bioreactor. 4.7.1. Vertical tube PBRs In vertical tubular PBRs microalgae productivity depends on the location species grown biomass concentration tube diameter the distance between the tube and the number of horizontal tubes per stack vertically stacked system Sirohi et al. 2022 . Dynamic sunlight patterns across the year and growth characteristics of algae and reactor dimensions are used as the model in this type of photo-bioreactors. In this system the performance can be improved by using light-reflecting materials on the ground surface. The air- lift column and bubble column are the vertical tube PBRs with an air sparger at the bottom of the reactor that improves mass transfer by creating air bubbles for proper mixing Alhaboubi 2021 . The bubble column reactor has no internal structure and the fluid pat- tern is mainly managed by the bubble of air produced. The height of this PBRs is twice its diameter and light is externally supplied. The photosynthetic efficiency and mixing of algal cells by the light flash effect enhances the mobility of algal cells. With this config- uration the gas flow rate is critical to control as it affects the dark and light cycle Ting et al. 2017 . The Airlift reactor is the modified bubble column design considered cost-effective for various types of microalgae cultivation. The advantage of this photo-bioreactor is efficient mass transfer ideal for algae immobilization and suitable for mixing with low shear stress Ting et al. 2017 . Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 8 S. Tomar et al. 4.7.2. Horizontal tube PBRs This type of PBRs was the first closed reactor for microalgae cultivation and is also known as the tubular reactor. The reactor can be fitted into place in a variety of ways to create walls helices and panels to prevent light from a light source from diffusing into the culture medium tube diameter. In this design the tube diameter can be reduced due to the complication of a light source in the cul- ture medium. Within the tubes the culture medium is circulated with exposure to the light source and a compressor pump recovers. Maintaining the high turbulent flow regime in the reactor is essential to avoid microalgae flocculation Huang et al. 2016 . 4.7.3. Stirred tank PBRs Stirred tank photo-bioreactor used for producing microalgae is based on the fermentation tank design except that microalgae cul- tivation requires an additional external light source. Agitator s mechanical movement promotes the mixing of the culture media while ensuring mass transfer and optimal heat Klinthong et al. 2015 . Stirred tanks perform well in indoor cultivation because they enable efficient mixing and transfer with the addition of aeration potentially increasing the solubility of gas Chew et al. 2018 . Due to problems with illumination stirred tank photo-bioreactors can only be used at small laboratory scales. The main objective of develop- ing a Continuous stirred tank reactor was to enhance algal biomass productivity. 4.7.4. Flat panel photo-bioreactor FPPBR The flat panel photo-bioreactor consists of two transparent or semi-transparent glass sheets assembled in a rectangular box and connected in a cascade towards the light source. They can be placed vertically or at an angle to obtain high light from the sun or other light sources Chew et al. 2018 . The FPPBR have a short light path facilitating efficient light penetration to the microalgae thus be- ing suitable for outdoor and indoor cultivation. The fitted air sparger produces air bubbles. Enhancing the mixing rate and providing sufficient amounts of CO2while releasing the oxygen as exhaust gas to enhance the flashing light effect could potentially enhance mi- croalgae biomass productivity Chew et al. 2018 . However this design has a few limitations such as aeration which generates hy- drodynamic stress and biofouling near the surface Ting et al. 2017 . Potential risks include aeration-caused high-stress damage and biomass adhesion to the bioreactor s walls. Another difficulty is controlling the temperature inside the flat panel photo-bioreactor however sprinklers or heat exchangers can do this. 4.8. Economic cultivation of algae in wastewater Biofuel based on algal biomass is a promising alternative to fossil fuels. The major obstacles to algae based biofuel are biomass harvesting and cultivation of water and carbon sources from the liquid medium Ummalyma et al. 2021 . Cultivating algae on waste- water in the presence of sunlight by capturing atmospheric CO2 from the atmosphere for biofuel production is a novel and cost- effective method for generating alternative energy Rai et al. 2020 . For biofuel production algae gain an interest in nutrient recov- ery wastewater treatment and renewable energy generation Li et al. 2022 . The algae s ability to fix CO2 and produce high-value- added products makes algal wastewater treatment economically feasible Bashir et al. 2022 . Wastewater is the end product of mu- nicipal agricultural industrial and domestic sources Chakraborty et al. 2023 . Generally inorganic content like calcium sodium magnesium potassium phosphate bicarbonate sulfur heavy metals and ammonium salts and organic mass like proteins volatile acids carbohydrates and lipids are present in wastewater P. Singh et al. 2016 . Wastewater composition is a reflection of the tech- nology used and the way of life in the producing society Abily et al. 2023 . Wastewater composition is variable-phosphorus and ni- trogen concentration vary from one water source to another and even seasonally and daily for a single source. Wastewater from mu- nicipal has a lower concentration of total phosphorus TP 5 20 mg L 1 and total nitrogen TN 15 90 mg L 1 than wastewater pro- duced from animals Chawla et al. 2020 . The concentrations of the nutrients in agricultural wastewater also vary by source. The TP varies from 30 mg L 1 dairy to 987 mg L 1 swine and TN varies from 185 mg L 1 in dairy to 3213 mg L 1 in swine . In the in- dustrial wastewater the lowest concentration 1.1 mg L 1 for TN and 0.6 mg L 1 for TP was observed in the paper mill Chawla et al. 2022 . Macronutrients such as phosphorus nitrogen and carbon are required to grow algae Khan et al. 2018 . The ratio of C N P is the primary factor that determines the availability of nutrients in wastewater and directly affects the survivability chemical com- position biomass productivity and nutrient removal of the algal cultures AlMomani and Örmeci 2016 Orefice et al. 2019 Znad et al. 2018 . In wastewater carbon and ammonium are essential to promote algae growth and phosphorus plays a crucial role in the en- ergy metabolism of the algae. For simultaneous utilization of phosphorus and nitrogen the ratio of N P must be in the proper range Chawla et al. 2020 . Algae utilizes micronutrients like silicon and iron and some micronutrients are toxic to the algal species if the concentration of these is too high. Although there are several strains of algal species which can tolerate heavy metals and helps to ab- sorb these metals from the environment Chawla et al. 2022 . Some species of algae remove pollutants such as mercury cadmium and organic chemicals from industrial wastewater thus enhancing the algal growth rate S. Khan et al. 2022 . The treatment of wastewater involves the removal of phosphorus organic carbon nitrogen heavy metals and other contaminants using chemical physical and biological processes Liu et al. 2020 . Treatment of wastewater by conventional processes requires a large amount of aeration in bacterial oxidation of organic carbon and biological nitrogen removal in the nitrification stage. During nitrification vast amounts of greenhouse gases N2O are released Campos et al. 2016 . In contrast wastewater treatment with algae has been consid- ered an environmentally friendly approach Priyadharshini et al. 2021 . Treating wastewater using algae is a feasible and cost- effective method for CO2 bio-fixation Almomani et al. 2019 . The main advantage of using algae in wastewater treatment is the O2 generation by photosynthesis. Microalgae can utilize both inorganic nitrogen Ammonium Ammonia and organic nitrogen urea as well as nitrates and nitrites Ross et al. 2018 . NO2 emission in the wastewater treatment process is a consequence of the environmen- tal conditions under which nitrogen removal occurs Arun et al. 2020 . Microalgae directly assimilate PO4 and NH3 and helps in the metabolic function and growth of the cell Borowitzka et al. 2016 . Autotrophic growth of microalgae utilizes inorganic carbon in the Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 9 S. Tomar et al. form of dissolved CO2 in the bicarbonate-carbonate buffer system Arana and Gude 2018 . The efficiency of CO2 fixation when in- jected continuously in the culture of microalgae was in a range of 16 64 at an input CO2 concentration of 1 15 for Chlorella sp. Hajinajaf et al. 2022 and 4 66 at an input CO2 concentration of 6 15 for Scenedesmus sp. Nayak et al. 2016 . Table 3 shows the wastewater generation volume and wastewater nutrients available in different countries that could be used to cultivate algae for bio- fuel production. 5. Factor affecting algae growth 5.1. Temperature The metabolic process within the cell and the supply of physicochemical carbon dioxide to the cell are both affected by tempera- ture Ördög et al. 2016 . Temperature plays a vital role in algae growth thus crucial to keep the temperature under control Paliwal et al. 2017 . Microalgae s gross photosynthetic activity is affected by temperature because they undergo cellular division which in- fluences their biomass productivity. Cell division takes place because of enzymatic activity related to the Calvin cycle. The Arrhenius equation is the most often used expression for connecting growth rate to temperature. According to the Arrhenius equation growth doubles as the temperature increases until an optimum temperature is achieved Ahmad et al. 2020 . Heat stress causes the inactiva- tion of enzymes and denaturation of a protein involved in photosynthesis causing a slowdown of algae growth Dalby et al. 2021 . Three Dunaliella salina strains are isolated from 60 saline soil samples and were reported to grow rapidly at 22 °C Wu et al. 2016 . It was found that Dunaliella has the ability to grow in the temperature range between 0 °C and 45 °C. Still the optimal growth tempera- ture for Dunaliella sp. was reported to be 32 °C with a temperature range of 25 °C 35 °C Wu et al. 2016 . 5.2. pH In algae growth one of the basic parameters is pH which affects cell metabolism and biomass production. The majority of algal species are known to survive at neutral pH. However all algal strains are believed to have a limited pH and optimum range for their growth Gatamaneni et al. 2018 . Algae sequester CO2 during photosynthesis and at ideal pH the bicarbonate in the medium is changed to CO2 by the activity of the algae enzyme carbonic anhydrase which results in the removal of hydroxyl ions which raises the pH Beigbeder et al. 2021 . Since the thylakoid and chloroplast have a vital role in photosynthesis their function is limited to a specific ray of pH. Therefore the culture medium should have a particular pH range. The availability of nutrients such as organic acids and iron is also affected by pH Robles-Aguilar et al. 2019 . Because carbonate equilibrium controls pH it is regarded as a cru- cial environmental component in both seas and inland water. It was found that at acidic pH 3.0-6.2 and alkaline pH 8.3-9.0 pH the microalgae Chlorella vulgaris grow slower. When the pH was between 7.5 and 8.0 optimum growth was achieved Gerardi 2015 . The optimal pH for the growth of Spirulina platensis was reported in a range pH 7.0 and 9.0. The microalgae s highest growth rate was reported at pH 8.0 indicating that moderate alkalinity was required for optimal growth Gatamaneni et al. 2018 . At a pH 7.0 the microalgae seemed to have the highest biomass productivity Fagiri et al. 2013 Ren 2014 . Tomar et al. was reported at pH 9.18 Abu-Rezq et al. 2010 . The D. baradawil and C. ellipsoides are said to have optimal growth in the pH 7.5 and 10.0 respectively. At pH 10.0 the growth of Chlorella ellipsoidea and Dunaliella bardawil was inhibited because carbonate ions are absent that are an essential source of inorganic carbon Chen et al. 2020 . 5.3. Nutrients The growth of algae is directly proportional to the rate of consumption of nutrients where the most limiting nutrients are ab- sorbed as described by the equation given by Michaelis Menten μ μmax S S + K Where μ is the growth rate μ max is the maximum growth rate S is the concentration of limiting nutrients and the concentration lead- ing to a half-maximal growth rate is described by K also known as the half-saturation constant Yang et al. 2016 . Elements phospho- rus is a component of phospholipids while nitrogen is the building block of nucleic acids and proteins. When these macronutrients are insufficient metabolic pathways usually change Romero-Rodríguez et al. 2018 . Phosphorus is considered the limiting compo- nent when the N P ratio of N P exceeds 16 Juneja et al. 2013 and the nitrogen concentration must be regulated to maximize mi- croalgae growth. Therefore phosphorus in optimal quantity is considered beneficial for microalgae growth. Microalgae cannot sur- vive in phosphorus concentrations below 0.045 mg L 1 or above 1.65 mg L 1. When the content of phosphorus is equal to 0.02 mg L 1 growth is promoted Juneja et al. 2013 . The study on Chlorella vulgaris and Nannochloropsis oculata suggested that lipid synthesis increased when nitrogen availability was reduced but there was no influence on microalgae growth patterns Church et al. 2017 . In the Calvin cycle the microbial cell converts inorganic carbon into glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate Paes et al. 2016 . The car- bon and nitrogen internal ratio regulates when metabolism shifts towards functioning molecules because of the high photosynthetic rate the inner carbon exceeds the C N ratio in the initial stages of growth resulting in protein synthesis. However as the organism grows the N2 present in the liquid medium start depleting and the production shifts from proteins to lipids Gao et al. 2022 . Cop- per Manganese zinc cobalt iron and nickel are critical metals that are required by algae for their metabolic processes. Algal growth may be restricted if they are not present Concas et al. 2016 . Adding trace elements such as Fe3+ Zn2+ Mn2+ Cu2+ Co2+ and EDTA increase the growth of Nannochloropsis oculata. Increased concentrations of the trace elements increase the photosynthetic ac- tivity of the algae by rising CO2 levels. This shows that trace elements have a strong influence on fatty acid composition and also on lipid productivity Sun and Huang 2017 . 5.4. Type of reactors used for algae cultivation The most challenging aspects of commercial microalgae production for designing is an efficient reactor cultivation processes and finding algal strains capable of capturing a significant amount of solar carbon dioxide and solar energy. No the best reactor system which can be identified as one that can give a maximum output with low input exists despite several attempts. The situation will de- cide the optimum culture method because the types of algae that are available and the end aim are important factors. The essential el- ements that can influence the flow rate of the liquid-liquid phase in microreactors are channel size mixer type reaction temperature and internal configuration reaction time. The improved reactor technology for large-scale production has limitations by microreac- tors and has practical implications Dou et al. 2013 . The reactor s design includes flat plate reactors fermenter-type reactors tubular reactors and processing parameters covering gaseous transfer light requirements and medium mixing Gopi et al. 2022 . Light pene- tration is the main factor influencing the reactor s design which requires a high surface-to-volume ratio. This penetration is essential if one desires to improve the efficiency of photosynthesis which is required for increased product and biomass productivity. Several shapes have been developed and examined to attain the desired high surface-to-volume ratio. Fermenter-type flat plate and tubular shapes are three fundamental varieties the tubular and flat plate is specifically designed for efficient sunlight harvesting whereas the fermenter type requires artificial illumination. Flat plate and tubular reactors are the most popular choices Skjånes et al. 2016 . Table 4 describes the limitations and advantages of Photo-bioreactors for algae cultivation. 6. Strategies to enhance lipid carbohydrate content 6.1. Stress Microalgae lipid production requires appropriate pH temperature nutrients and light. Furthermore the mentioned environmen- tal factors are often unsuitable for optimal growth conditions for algal growth. However increasing their content can enhance bio- chemical compositions like carbohydrates and lipids under temperature light salinity and nutrition stress conditions Jaiswal et al. 2020 . During stress conditions microalgae can overproduce lipids or carotenoids Suganya et al. 2016 Jaiswal et al. 2020 . Under high salinity stress lipid accumulation increased to 70 in Dunaliella sp. and 21.1 in Chlorella vulgaris sp. Zhu et al. 2016 . 6.1.1. Salinity stress Salinity plays a significant role in biochemical and physiological processes for microalgal development fatty acid metabolism and reproduction. Hence salinity stress is one of the most effective lipid enrichment techniques Alishah Aratboni et al. 2019 . The os- motic pressure within microalgal cells is known to change due to this form of anxiety triggering a stress response that enables mi- croalgae metabolism to adjust to the new environment Alishah Aratboni et al. 2019 . Salinity has a significant effect on several bio- fuel products. A high salinity environment has increased bioethanol production from Spirulina maxima. Several species of microalgae synthesize low molecular weight carbohydrates under salt stress. The salinity stress also affects the accumulation of lipids in microal- gae cells Table 5 . In Dunaliella tertiolecta the lipid composition is improved by 60 70 with increased salinity Jaiswal et al. 2020 . Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 11 S. Tomar et al. R. Kumar et al. 2019 . 6.1.2. Heavy metal stress Heavy metal supplementation in microalgae cells may increase carbohydrate and lipid accumulation Jaiswal et al. 2020 . Heavy metals such as zinc Manganese copper nickel and iron are essential micronutrients for the biological process as they contribute vita- min precursors catalytic co-factors of several metalloenzymes and structural cell membrane proteins Alishah Aratboni et al. 2019 . For example in Agmenellum quadruplicatum glucose concentration increased from 5 to 45 during the Fe2+stress environment while in Chlorella vulgaris the lipid composition increased by 7-fold during the Fe2+stress environment Jaiswal et al. 2020 . In many di- atom species e.g. Cyclotellacryptica Naviculaseprophila and Chaetocerosmuelleri the stress of the silicon have the ability to increase the lipid content Griffiths and Harrison 2009 . Furthermore nutritional trace metals e.g. Mo Mg Zn Ni and Fe are required to produce nitrogen-catalyzed biohydrogen Zhu et al. 2016 . 6.2. Genetic engineering A genetic engineering approach is one of the best methods to genetically modify microalgae to increase the productivity of lipids shown in Fig. 2. Genetic engineering techniques are attracting more attention from researchers since they are thought to be unique and almost untunable tools V. Singh et al. 2016 Lenka et al. 2016 . Genetic engineering can inhibit express or decrease one or more genes involved in producing the desired metabolite. The genes concerned with photosynthesis growth rate and enhanced resis- tivity to harsh environments such as temperature salinity and pH in microalgae as well as genes involved in lipid metabolism Song et al. 2015 . By analysing the molecular tools available for the genetic engineering of microalgae it may be possible to increase prod- uct yields and produce new microalgal bioproducts rapidly for commercial use Dickinson et al. 2017 . Various methods of bioengi- neering can be applied for the genetic modification CRISPR Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeat associated with protein 9 random mutagenesis ZFN Zinc finger repeat mainly used for alteration of the gene sequence Dickinson et al. 2017 Sproles et al. 2021 . For the repression and activation of gene expression miRNA micro RNA and siRNA short interfering RNA are used Yao et al. 2016 . Working with genetically modified algae has a number of drawbacks including environmental consequences and ethical concerns about its release into the environment. It is important to note that the release of genetically modified algae into the natural habitat must be investigated appropriately and approved by various international expert committees because in the event of an error or consensual release of GM genetically modified microalgae these types of microalgae can not only survive but also re- produce and spread further in the natural habitat Huang et al. 2016 . Table 6 describes the target of genetic manipulation and its impact on lipid production. Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 12 S. Tomar et al. Fig. 2.
