Cyanophycinsynthetase gene fatty acids release into growth medium Radakovits et al. 2011 Synechocystissp. Phosphotransacetylase gene Fatty acids production enhanced Bode et al. 2014 6.3. Co-metabolism Co-metabolism has been intensively studied to find the limitations in substrate utilization by individual strains to produce addi- tional byproducts Magdouli et al. 2016 . More research is currently being carried out on the interactions between different varieties of algae whether they are beneficial or antagonistic mutualistic or symbiotic. Furthermore microbial consortia could accomplish more complex tasks than monocultures and perform impossible functions for individual strains or species to perform Bhatt et al. 2021 . The co-metabolism method provides a competent and safer alternative for reducing the cost of raw materials for biodiesel pro- duction. Monoraphidium sp. FXY-10 and Chlorella sp. U4341 two potential biodiesel feedstocks were recently identified Bogen et al. 2013 . As mentioned earlier it is reported to enhance lipid productivity 20-fold in co-metabolism. The goal was to release lipids with minimal energy consumption while remaining feasible for the regrowth of high-value products during lipid extraction Menegazzo and Fonseca 2019 . Up to 50 of the total cost of producing biodiesel falls into harvesting Wrede et al. 2014 . Bacterial bio- flocculants isolated from bacterial species could be used as flocculating agents for algae such as Scenedesmus spp. and Solibacillus sil- vestris Powell and Hill 2013 Wan et al. 2013 . Filamentous fungi are also known to be an attractive bio-flocculating agents Magdouli et al. 2016 . Moreover the increasing cost of organic CO2 and the requirement for process control significantly affect oil formation in algae species. As a result the co-metabolism method has been solely tested to reduce operating costs. In a study for lipid Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 13 S. Tomar et al. production various culture methods were investigated. The co-metabolism of Chlorella sp. U4341 and Monoraphidium sp. FXY-10 pro- duced 93.4 - 223.42 and 21.23 gm 3d 1 of lipid productivity under heterotrophic and mixotrophic conditions. However the lipid pro- ductivity was around 29.52gm-3 d 1 in photoautotrophic states Zhao et al. 2014 . 7. Technique for algal biomass harvesting Harvesting algae is a two-step process that includes bulk harvesting and thickening. The first step bulk harvesting is intended to separate the biomass from the suspension in the bulk and the technologies employed are flocculation flotation or gravity sedimenta- tion. The second step thickening concentrates the slurry employing methods like centrifugation filtration and ultrasonic aggrega- tion. However algae biofuel production s most challenging part is harvesting using cost-effective methods Yin et al. 2020 . Algae are harvested using centrifugation gravity sedimentation micro straining flocculation floatation filtering and occasionally a combina- tion of one or two methods. Flocculation is good efficient and economical for harvesting a large number of algal species Chutia et al. 2017 Rakesh et al. 2020 . 7.1. Centrifugation The ideal process for microalgae harvesting is centrifugation because it can remove particles from algal suspension without using any additive agents Rakesh et al. 2020 . Immense shear pressures are applied during centrifugation causing the algal cells to lyse and release algal oil into the media. After that the oil recovery was done. Pahl et al. 2013 investigated several centrifuges including hydro cyclones perforated and imperforated basket centrifuges decanters and disc stack centrifuges for biomass separation. Disc stack centrifuge is used to recover high-value industrial algal products however they have a low energy return since more energy is lost than is recovered Najjar and Abu-Shamleh 2020 . Decanter centrifuges are very efficient but consume a lot of energy. In con- trast hydro cyclone centrifuges require less maintenance but are unsuitable for large-scale applications because of their high produc- tion cost and energy Rakesh et al. 2020 . While considering centrifugation as harvesting technique one should consider factors such as the specific microalgal species the scale of cultivation the required biomass concentration and the available resources. Centrifu- gation is particularly well-suited for applications where efficiency speed and high biomass recovery are crucial such as large-scale industrial production or research requiring concentrated microalgal biomass. However it may not be the most cost-effective or en- ergy-efficient option for all situations and alternative harvesting techniques should be evaluated based on the specific needs of the project or process. 7.2. Sedimentation Despite its rudimentary character sedimentation is effective for a different types of microalgae and is quite energy efficient Mathimani and Mallick 2018 . Therefore gravity sedimentation should be used to harvest microalgae for low-value end products like biofuels Muylaert et al. 2017 . However this method s reliability could be higher because microalgal density is essential for process efficiency. The sedimentation rate of microalgae is 0.1 2.6cm h 1 which is a prolonged process due to this biomass deterio- rates restricting its routine biomass Iasimone 2018 . To increase microalgal settling a coagulation flocculation step is often used before gravity sedimentation. Because of microalgal auto-flocculation the best results for harvesting microalgae utilizing gravity sed- imentation were obtained using lamella-type separators total suspended solid recovery is 1.6 Kumar et al. 2023 . Although sedi- mentation tanks are a simple and low-cost method the concentration achieved without prior coagulation flocculation coagulation is relatively low Ortiz et al. 2021 . Similarly in lamella-type separators microalgal concentration is unreliable andlow which requires further thickening Barros and Berk 2018 . In practice the choice of microalgae harvesting method including sedimentation de- pends on various factors such as the specific microalgal species the scale of cultivation the required biomass concentration and the overall goals of the cultivation process. Sedimentation remains a valuable and reliable method for harvesting microalgae in many ap- plications particularly in large-scale low-energy and cost-conscious operations. However it should be considered alongside other harvesting techniques to determine the most suitable approach for a particular situation. 7.3. Bioflocculation Harvesting techniques like flotation flocculation and flocculation can be used to harvest microalgae. The flotation technique is the separation process in which air or gas bubbles lift suspended particles at the top of the liquid surface where they are collected by skimming Sarwer et al. 2022a b . The process of flotation can harvest marine and freshwater microalgae. Low volume requirements short operating cost large-scale harvesting and adaptability rate at low starting cost are the advantages of using floatation. The flota- tion process requires flocculants and is followed by flocculation and coagulation Singh and Patidar 2018 . The flocculation tech- nique involves aggregating small and unstable particles by electrostatic patching bridging or surface charge neutralization after adding flocculants Matter et al. 2019 . The formation of flocs allows for recovery or separation by conventional or simple gravity- induced settling methods. Flocculation is the superior method for microalgae harvesting because of its economic feasibility and effi- ciency Muhammad et al. 2021 . Biogenic or non-biogenic flocculants are used during algal harvesting. Chemical flocculants are widely utilized for effective harvesting but the high cost is a significant drawback Singh et al. 2023 . To overcome this bio- flocculation-based microalgae harvesting technology is a promising strategy at a low cost for algal biomass production Ummalyma et al. 2017 . Microalgal flocculation made by extracellular polymeric substances EPS and various types of microbes is termed floccula- tion Alam et al. 2016 . Recently researchers have been focusing on fungus-induced flocculation associated with bacteria algae- algae flocculation and flocculation based on plants Muhammad et al. 2021 . Bioflocculation could be a valuable and sustainable Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 14 S. Tomar et al. option for microalgae harvesting particularly in scenarios where energy efficiency high biomass recovery and reduced chemical us- age are priorities. 7.4. Flotation In the flotation process gas or air is transformed into bubbles by the liquid solid suspension due to which solid particles will at- tach to gaseous molecules and are carried out and accumulated on the surface Rakesh et al. 2020 . It has been reported that the flotation process is quicker for various microalgae species than sedimentation. Arenas et al. 2017 . Flotation mainly includes dis- persed air flotation DiAF dissolved air flotation DAF and electro-flotation EF Xu et al. 2021 . Dissolved air flotation technique uses small bubble sizes ranging from 10 to 100 mm generated when air gets dissolved in water under high pressure Chen et al. 2011 . The bubbles force suspended algae cells to float on the surface which could further be skimmed off. In dispersed air flotation 700-1500 mm bubbles are produced by continuously passing the air through a high-speed mechanical agitator or by porous material like spargers or diffusers. This flotation technique requires less energy but equipment cost is high and the pressure drop during air bubbles generation is high Hassanzadeh et al. 2022 . In electro-flotation microalgae cells float on the water surface with fine hydro- gen bubbles formed by electrolysis. Microalgal biomass could be separated from the growth medium by hydrogen evaluated at the cathode. Bubbles of hydrogen stick to the algal flocs and then force them to float on the surface Singh and Patidar 2018 . No require- ment of chemicals is the benefit of using this technique while high power requirement and cathode fouling are the major drawbacks of this type of flotation technique Hassanzadeh et al. 2022 . The harvesting method flotation should consider factors such as the specific microalgal strain the scale of cultivation the desired biomass concentration and the available resources. Flotation can be a valuable and sustainable option for microalgae harvesting particularly in scenarios where energy efficiency high biomass recovery and reduced chemical usage are priorities. However successful implementation may require careful process optimization and consid- erations of microalgal strain compatibility. 8. Technologies for biofuel production from algae 8.1. Biodiesel production The very first pre-requirement for the production of biodiesel from microalgae is lipid extraction. The process of lipid extraction contributes 30 40 of the total cost in the production of biodiesel V. Kumar et al. 2019 . Since microalgae have thick cell walls and membranes lipid extraction is challenging. The most important aspect for producing biodiesel at an affordable cost is believed to be the effectiveness of lipid extraction from microalgae Karim et al. 2020 . The inner membrane of microalgae is formed by a microfib- ril matrix of hemicellulose and cellulose and the cell wall is enriched with a polysaccharide matrix. Plant oil mechanical extraction methods are ineffective due to the extremely small size of microalgae cells 3 10 μm . As a result greener solvent systems such as ionic liquids ILs pyrolysis CO2 SC CO2 and switchable solvents have been investigated for the extraction of lipids Sequeira et al. 2021 . 8.1.1. Soxhlet method The Soxhlet extraction method could extract a range of volatile compounds from solid samples into the oil. After removal the sol- vent containing the extracted biocompound is returned to the flask and the process is replicated until all the analytes have been re- moved. The extraction solvent must be explicitly selected since different removal solvents will produce other natural compounds from the same substance. The extract composition will differ from one solvent to another Liu et al. 2018 . When extracting chloroform us- ing the Soxhlet method the optimum solvent is methanol 2 1 Kumar et al. 2018 obtained 18.6 lipid from the freshwater macroalga. Generally Soxhlet extraction is a simple procedure that involves less effort and the isolated lipid can be used for conver- sion immediately. On the other hand this process is time-consuming tedious and requires a lot of energy. 8.1.2. Folch method Folch et al. 1957 studied the effects of a 1 2 v v methanol and chloroform on lipid extraction from animal tissue to obtain higher lipid yield Folch et al. 1957 . After filtration the homogenate and five folds of saline water were added to the lipid- containing solution. Once well combined the mixture is separated by gravity into two layers in which one layer contains lipids. Soares et al. 2014 investigated fatty acid methyl ester extraction efficiency in 3 different microalgae Nannochloropsis oculata Chaetocerosmuelleri and Chlorella sp using different methods Folch method-chloroform methanol 2 1 v v hexane ethanol 4 1 pure hexane Bligh and Dyer method-methanol for protein removal ammonia and ethanol mixture is used followed by addition of and petroleum and diethyl ether extraction of lipid . In all three microalgae the Folch method and methanol dichloromethane gave maximum lipid recovery Soares et al. 2014 . The Folch approach is undoubtedly a fast simple and effective lipid extraction method for huge volumes of materials. However this method has the disadvantage of using hazardous chemicals that increase opera- tional costs Kumar et al. 2019 . 8.1.3. Bligh and Dyer method Bligh and Dyer 1959 introduced a method that used a monophasic mixture of methanol and chloroform and water for extrac- tion Bligh and Dyer 1959 . This is the standard method to determine total lipid content. In this method chloroform methanol and water are used in two-step extraction and when the phases separate lipid content is evaluated in the chloroform phase. When a suitable amount of chloroform or water is added a two-phase system is created with lipids settling in the bottom chloroform layer. In contrast the non-lipid portion rises to the top layer of water and methanol. The strong bond between lipid and chloroform mole- cules leads to their separation. This method is usually implemented for lipid extraction from microalgae Vasistha et al. 2021 . The Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 15 S. Tomar et al. mixture of Chloroform methanol 1 1 gave the highest lipid content while optimizing the extraction of total and non-polar lipids. The authors also suggested that while using this mixture there is no need for pre-treatment or addition of antioxidants Wu et al. 2017 . Furthermore it was reported that sequence of solvent addition affects the efficiency of the lipid extraction from microalgae. Lipid extraction from dried Nanochloropsis cells showed that when the solvents were added in order of increasing polarity the ex- traction yield was increased from 185 mg 18.5 to 210 mg 21.0 confirming that the order of solvent addition is an important aspect to increase the extraction efficiency Cooney et al. 2009 . 8.2. Biohydrogen production The biohydrogen production methods are sustainable for producing hydrogen at ambient operating temperature and pressure. In biological route of hydrogen production renewable sources like biomass and solar energy is utilized to produce hydrogen through dark-fermentation photo-fermentation direct or indirect photolysis Akhlaghi and Najafpour-Darzi 2020 . Waste materials like rice winery wastewater molasses sugary wastewater municipal solid waste starch wastewater food wastes from rice straw sugarcane coir and sweet sorghum bagasse have been used as a substrate for biohydrogen production Rai et al. 2011 . Biohydrogen could also be produced using Microbial electrolysis cells MECs . MECs are unique biotechnological technologies that can produce H2 from or- ganic material present in wastewater or biomass. However this technology is still nascent with current issues of scaling up while at- taining a desired H2 yield Kadier et al. 2019 . To the best of our knowledge there is no report of H2 production by MECs using algal biomass as substrate. 8.2.1. Bio-photolysis Bio photolysis involves algal photosynthesis to dissociate water. Bio-photolysis is a biological method where sunlight dissociates water molecules with the help of photosynthetic membranes and catalysts. Two types of bio photolysis are widely studied indirect and direct. 8.2.1.1. Direct photolysis. In direct photolysis photosystems PS I and PS II in cyanobacteria and green algae cells absorb light en- ergy to split water molecules into H+ ions and O2 molecules Rai et al. 2020 . Cyanobacteria as well as microalgae can carry it out. On absorbing energy the electron in PS II gets excited and transfers to Ferredoxin via PS I Dincer and Acar 2015 . This e-is further transferred by ferredoxin to enzymehydrogenase which is present in algal cells that reduces H+ to H2 da Silva Veras et al. 2017 . Direct photolysis faces challenges related to low hydrogen production rates oxygen inhibition microalgae sensitivity to environmen- tal conditions and the cost of cultivation and processing. 8.2.1.2. Indirect photolysis. It takes place in two steps. In step 1 the water molecule splits to give oxygen in the presence of light and H+. In step 2 CO2 fixation and carbohydrate release occur producing hydrogen in the presence of enzyme hydrogenase. Among hydrogenase and nitrogenase the hydrogen production rate from green algae is high for the hydrogenase enzyme. Indirect photolysis faces challenges related to process complexity energy input oxygen sensitivity cost of cultivation and scale-up com- plexity. 12H2O + 6CO2 +light C6H12O6 + 6O2 C6H12O6 + 12H2O + light 12H12 + 6CO2 8.2.2. Dark-fermentation In the dark-fermentative biohydrogen production organic substrates such as sugars wastewater amino acids etc. produce hydro- gen by employing anaerobic organisms without light Christopher et al. 2021 . Its low production cost makes it a favourable alterna- tive to conventional methods Dahiya et al. 2021 . There are three types of hydrogen-producing bacteria-non sporulating anaerobes facultative bacteria and spore-forming obligate anaerobic bacteria. The spore-forming anaerobic microorganism such as Clostridium sp. is more efficient in producing hydrogen Castelló et al. 2020 . The various factors that affect hydrogen yield are pressure temper- ature hydraulic retention time pH etc. Garcia-Depraect et al. 2021 . It is imperative to pre-treat the algal biomass before its use as substrate in biohydrogen production Singh et al. 2022 . Although dark-fermentation offers advantages in terms of hydrogen yield substrate flexibility and high hydrogen purity. However it also faces challenges related to lower conversion efficiency pre-treatment cost byproduct formation pH control and sensitivity to inhibitors. Researchers have to explore the ways to optimize dark- fermentation for microalgae based biohydrogen production for sustainable hydrogen production. 8.2.3. Photo-fermentation In Photo-fermentation the photosynthetic bacteria convert organic substrates into hydrogen through hydrogenase and nitroge- nase under suitable operating conditions Rai et al. 2020 . The organic compounds give hydrogen in nitrogeniscatalyzed reactions inthe presence of light using bacteria which perform photosynthesis or anaerobic bacteria like Rhodopseudonomas Rhodospirillumand Rhodobacter Hitam and Jalil 2020 . Using Fe and Mo further improves the hydrogen yield. Light availability and specific substrate requirements such as small fatty acids having acetate and propionate are the major hurdles to the industrialization of this method Baeyens et al. 2020 . The photo-fermentation step is carried out on the spent medium obtained after dark-fermentation of microal- gae biomass for biohydrogen production. Although Photo-fermentation for biohydrogen production from microalgae holds promise as a renewable energy source with reduced environmental impacts. However it faces challenges related to process complexity en- ergy balance low yield reactor design contamination and economic viability. Ongoing research and development efforts are focused Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 16 S. Tomar et al. on optimizing the process to overcome these limitations and make photo-fermentation a more practical and sustainable option for hy- drogen production. 9. Bioethanol Bioethanol production from algae biomass involves converting the carbohydrates in algae into ethanol which can be used as a re- newable fuel Sirajunnisa and Surendhiran 2016 . Algae are considered a promising feedstock for bioethanol production due to their high growth rates and ability to accumulate significant amounts of carbohydrates Khan et al. 2018 . For bioethanol production from microalgae the first step is the cultivation of algae in open ponds closed Photo-bioreactors or other suitable cultivation systems Yen et al. 2019 . The growth conditions such as nutrient availability light and temperature need to be optimized to maximize biomass production Khan et al. 2018 . Once the algae reach a desirable biomass concentration harvesting of the biomass has to be done. Harvesting methods include filtration centrifugation flocculation or a combination of these techniques Tan et al. 2020 . The har- vested algae biomass is typically pre-treated to break down the rigid cell walls and improve the accessibility of carbohydrates Weber et al. 2022 . Standard pre-treatment methods include mechanical disruption thermal treatment or chemical treatment. The physical pre-treatment reduces the size of lignocellulosic biomass and crystallinity by extrusion irradiation grinding and milling methods Edeh 2021 . Chemical pre-treatment involves oxidative delignification alkali acid and organic acid methods. These methods are unique for a specific type of feedstocks and help remove lignin hemicellulose from the polymer matrix Edeh 2021 . The pre- treatment methods using chemicals are helpful but require severe operating conditions which may result in adverse effects during the downstream process Kumar et al. 2020 . The pre-treated biomass is then subjected to enzymatic hydrolysis where enzymes such as cellulases and hemicellulases break down the complex carbohydrates into simpler sugars like glucose and xylose Nordin et al. 2022 . These sugars are the primary feedstock for ethanol production. For further processes i.e. fermentation to occur this hydroly- sis stage requires enzymes that can only digest monomer sugars. Enzymes or acids are required to catalyze the process. Hydrolysis by acid catalysis is the most widely used involving diluted or concentrated acid H2SO4 and HCl Edeh 2021 . C6H10O5 n + H3O+ H2O + nC6H12O6 β-glucosidases cellobiohydrolases and endo-1 4-β-glucanases are the cellulase enzymes used during hydrolysis but are expensive be- cause of their high demand in industries Sharma et al. 2020 . The hydrolyzed sugars are fermented by adding specific yeast or bacte- ria strains that can convert sugars into ethanol through anaerobic fermentation Walker and Stewart 2016 . The fermentation process converts the sugars into ethanol and produces carbon dioxide. C6H12O6 + yeast 2C2H5OH + 2CO2 Sharma et al. 2020 Senatore et al. 2020 Saccharomyces cerevisiae is the most common microbe used during fermentation because of its high productivity rate and high tol- erance limits Surendhiran and Sirajunnisa 2019 . Saccharomyces cerevisiae converts mannose fructose and glucose to ethanol while xylan can be converted to xylose. After fermentation the resulting mixture contains a low ethanol concentration water and other impurities. The ethanol is then concentrated through distillation followed by further purification steps like dehydration to remove water and obtain a higher ethanol concentration Khalid et al. 2019 . The pure ethanol is recovered from the distillation process and any remaining impurities are removed to meet the required quality standards Suthar et al. 2019 . The recovered ethanol can be used as a biofuel or further processed for various applications. Azeotropic adsorption extractive membrane and diffusion distillation are the techniques used for ethanol recovery. For large-scale operations the extractive distillation process is most commonly used Edeh 2021 . It is worth noting that bioethanol production from algae biomass is still in the research and development stage. Various challenges must be addressed such as optimizing the cultivation process improving biomass conver- sion efficiency reducing the energy inputs required and scaling up production to a commercially viable level Usmani et al. 2021 . However ongoing advancements in biotechnology and process engineering hold promise for the future of algae-based bioethanol production Kostas et al. 2021 . Table 6 shows the carbohydrate content of algal species with bioethanol yield. Bioethanol production from algae faces challenges related to operation cost ethanol tolerance cultivation pre-treatment cost and efficiency and competition with other land uses. For commercialization of bioethanol production technology from microalgae the circular economy and carbon neutrality concept has to be follow. 10. Biobutanol Biobutanol is the butanol produced from organic natural renewable or biodegradable biomass. Biobutanol could be produced from eco-friendly biomass by alcoholic fermentation Pugazhendhi et al. 2019 . Biobutanol is gaining more attention as a potential alternative to ethanol and demand for fermentative biobutanol production has gained interest Wang et al. 2017 . The availability of feedstock is the major challenge faced during biobutanol production. The use of agricultural biomass as feedstock is less efficient and controversial. In contrast the third-generation feedstock microalgae has been considered as promising for biobutanol production because of its high carbohydrate content and growth rate Wang et al. 2017 . Biological acetone-biobutanol-ethanol ABE fermenta- tion has the potential to replace chemical synthesis for the production of butanol Xue et al. 2017 . Over the past few decades at the commercial level renewable biobutanol could be produced from cellulosic and non-cellulosic feedstock. ABE fermentation denotes the anaerobic fermentation of sugars in the medium of ethanol acetone and butanol in the ratio of 1 3 6. The strains of Clostidia used for industrial butanol production are C. saccharoperbutylacetonicum C. beijerincki C. saccharobutylicum and C. acetobutylicum Wang et al. 2017 . While employing microalgal biomass as a feedstock the pre-treatment of the biomass is essential to disrupt the microal- Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 17 S. Tomar et al. gae cells to release the constituent sugars Wang et al. 2017 . Glucose and mannose are the most common hexose sugars released with others including Rhamnose Fructose Galactose and Fructose. Currently the four technologies most commonly used for pre- treatment microalgal biomass are mechanical thermal biological enzymatic and chemical Obata et al. 2016 . Among these me- chanical and thermal pre-treatments are efficient for cell disruption in microalgae. In continuous reactors thermal pre-treatments are the most employed method Mehariya et al. 2021 . Pre-treatment with chemicals is usually conducted at high temperatures. For the production of butanol microalgal biomass and acid hydrolysis wastewater microalgae pre-treatment was conducted using 1.01 M sulphuric acid at 80 90 °C for 120 min Song et al. 2021 . Mechanical pre-treatment is independent of the microalgae species and the associated differences in the cell wall structure Onumaegbu et al. 2018 . The pre-treatment with chemicals works better if combined with any other method and the combination of chemical and thermal methods is successful Ramos et al. 2022 . Thermal microalgal biomass decomposes at 108 °C for ABE fermentation Elkatory et al. 2022 . Mechanical and thermal pre-treatments lead to cell dis- ruption but they cannot obtain a high yield of monosaccharides. Chemical pre-treatment can break the cell walls and hydrolyze mi- croalgae carbohydrate into fermentable sugars. However some inhibitory compounds are produced during the process of chemical pre-treatment and affect butanol production and cell growth during fermentation Wang et al. 2017 . Enzymatic pre-treatment can be used to increase soluble sugar recovery from the carbohydrate content of microalgae biomass without producing any inhibitors during fermentation Lakatos et al. 2019 . Biobutanol production from microalgae offers the potential for a renewable and more ver- satile biofuel compared to ethanol. However it faces challenges related to production cost low butanol yield butanol toxicity pre- treatment cost and competitive market. Ongoing research and development efforts aim to overcome these challenges and make biobutanol from microalgae a more economically viable option. 11. Biomethane Biomethane is a promising biofuel that can be produced from various biomass using anaerobic digestion AD Zabed et al. 2019 . The biomass sources include agricultural residues food wastes forestry residues microalgae industrial organic waste energy crops and organic-rich wastewater Cucchiella and D Adamo 2016 Jankowska et al. 2017 . Among all these sources microalgae are con- sidered the most attractive feedstock because of their high biomass yield five to ten times higher growth rate and suitability to culti- vate in nutrient-rich wastewaters and nonarable lands in addition microalgae have the potential to consume CO2 thus reduce its ac- cumulation in the atmosphere Stephens et al. 2013 Kröger and Müller-Langer 2012 Ward et al. 2014 . The pre-treatment tech- niques for producing biomethane include physical chemical and biological methods Uggetti et al. 2017 . In recent studies it has been shown that pre-treatment of microalgae is beneficial in improving AD performance. Some pre-treatment like microwave ther- mal and enzymatic have already been tested in continuous reactors while thermochemical ultrasound and hydrolysis have been tested in biochemical methane potential BMP tests Uggetti et al. 2017 . The thermal pre-treatment at low temperatures 100 °C for example after thermal pre-treatment at 100 120 °C the yield of methane byNannochloropsis salina has been increased by 108 while the yield of methane increased 3-fold by Scenedesmus sp. Ometto et al. 2014 . The pre-treatment by ultrasound method increases the final methane yield by 33 Alagöz et al. 2018 . In summary methane production from microalgae offers the potential to generate renew- able energy while mitigating greenhouse gas emissions and treating wastewater. However it comes with challenges related to cost long start up periods cultivation and the need for infrastructure. As technology advances and research continues addressing these challenges may lead to more efficient and economically viable methane production from microalgae. 12. Commercial feasibility of microalgae cultivation for biofuel production The production of biofuels from microalgal biomass is gaining interest due to a number of significant characteristics of microal- gae. However still the technologies for biofuel production from microalgae are costly and not efficient. Tables 7 and 8 list the various technologies and steps utilized for algae conversion into biofuel with their process efficiency and cost. A study analyzed the econom- ics of a sugar industry s waste effluent and byproducts as low-cost carbon dioxide and nutrient sources for microalgal biofuel produc- tion that was theoretically related to the factory Zewdie and Ali 2022 . In this regard promising sources of future biofuel have been found in microalgae. In situ conversion biochemical conversion thermochemical conversion and conversion after extraction are al- ternate methods for producing biofuel from microalgae Karpagam et al. 2021 . According to some research it is resource- and en- ergy-efficient to simultaneously produce biodiesel from the transesterification of extracted oil and biogas from anaerobic digestion Broberg et al. 2011 . The cost of producing microalgal biomass is substantially higher than other energy crops Kitchen et al. 2019 . Microalgal-based carbon capture could be more economical if the algal biomass 2 g L is converted to biofuels pharmaceuticals and nutraceuticals through biorefinery approach yield range 60 99.5 Tarafdar et al. 2023 . Despite the recent developments only limited investigations are available on its economic aspects that indicate a production cost of 0.5 15 kg microalgal biomass. Microalgae multiplies rapidly and has a great potential to sequester carbon from the atmosphere and recycle it into bioenergy Ummalyma et al. 2022 . The advanced focused areas for the viability of microalgal biofuel production are genetic engineering for strain improvement the bio-refinery technique for effective material and energy utilization and economical nutrient and CO2 sources Kitchen et al. 2019 . To enhance biofuel yield some authors suggested to employe nanomaterial-bound microbial enzymes and nanocatalysts AQUASTAT 2016 . Combining wastewater treatment with microalgal cultivation is essential to lower the production cost. This will reduce environmental pollution and nutrient costs. One of these plants with an attached distillery is the Metahara sugar factory in the nation s southeast. It has an annual capacity of around 130 000 t of sugar and 12 000 t of ethanol Broberg et al. 2011 Jeyakumar et Biocatalysis and Agricultural Biotechnology 53 2023 102877 18 S. Tomar et al. Tomar et al. al. 2022 explored the biofuel production from Padina tetrastromatica and Sargassum swartzii macro-algae biomass by fermentation with Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Zymomonas Mobilis. The results obtained Bioethanol yield 80 indicated that both the species are suitable for Bioethanol production. Further the utilized biomass after bioethanol production was used for the lipid extraction for biodiesel production. The biodiesel yield was improved after the addition of Nano-catalyst MgO.La2O3. This integrated approach paves the new pathway for bioethanol and biodiesel production from the same algal biomass making the process more economically viable. The design of PBRs for the cultivation of microalgae is an important aspect for its optimum operation and cost effectiveness. The high capital input in research and development and operating cost the designing and scaling-up of PBRs remain a challenge. It is imperative to develop hybrid PBRs to improve the process efficiency and overall input cost Sirohi et al. 2022 . To follow the princi- ples of circular economy and carbon neutrality it is imperative to develop specialized PBRs capable of simultaneous biofuels produc- tion wastewater treatment and CO2 fixation. Computational Fluid Dynamics CFD could be used as a tool for the design and scale-up of a such type of PBRs. The CFD modelling of PBRs involving fluid dynamics light transport and algal growth kinetics will result into the development of more efficient and less operating cost required PBRs. Ranganathan et al. 2022 suggested multi-scale modelling approach and development of low-cost efficient computational framework for the development of PBRs in future. Furthermore the group recommends the utilization of process intensification techniques for improving the PBRs in terms of hydrodynamics mixing and mass transfer performances and algal growth productivity. 13. Challenges and future directions Microalgae-based biofuel generation has drawn much attention as a potential replacement for fossil fuels. However there are still many issues that must be resolved before microalgae-based biofuels may be widely commercialized. Some critical challenges and po- tential directions for this area are Cost-effectiveness Maintaining ideal growth conditions and separating the microalgae from the culture media requires much energy ultimately adding to the biofuel production cost. In order to reduce energy and cost inputs fu- ture research should concentrate on developing cost-effective cultivation systems and harvesting methods Strain selection and ge- netic engineering Improving biofuel productivity requires finding new microalgal strains with high lipid or carbohydrate content and rapid growth rates. Exploration of genetic engineering and synthetic biology techniques should continue in the future in order to cre- ate superior strains that are more effective in producing biofuel Nutrient availability and wastewater utilization The cost and envi- ronmental impact of growing microalgae for biofuels can be decreased by creating sustainable nutrient sources such as using waste- water or industrial wastes. Future research should concentrate on improving nutrient recycling systems and investigating new nutri- ent sources Scale-up and commercialization Most research on microalgae-based biofuels has been done in laboratories or on a small scale. Maintaining consistent productivity improving large-scale cultivation systems and devising effective downstream processing strategies are just a few of the difficulties associated with scaling up production to commercial levels. Future studies should concen- trate on proving that large-scale production is feasible and addressing the commercialization-related technical and financial difficul- ties Life cycle assessment LCA and sustainability The evaluation of the environmental impact of microalgae cultivation and biofuel production using life cycle assessments can assist in pinpointing areas for research and ensure sustainability. Future studies should keep evaluating the environmental and social consequences of producing biofuel from microalgae and come up with plans for mini- mizing those effects Co-product utilization Microalgae during cultivation produce valuable co-products such as high-value chemi- cals animal feed or fertilizer. Using these co-products may improve the commercial viability of producing microalgae-based biofuels. Future efforts should concentrate on developing effective co-product extraction and processing methods and investigating market and application opportunities. In broad terms overcoming these obstacles and expanding research in these directions will be essential to maximizing the poten- tial of microalgae-based biofuel production as a sustainable and practical replacement for fossil fuels. 14. Conclusion The utilization of algae as a feedstock for biofuel production has garnered significant attention due to its numerous advantages such as high growth rates minimal land requirements and potential for carbon dioxide sequestration. The conversion of algal bio- mass into biofuels involves numerous processes and each has its own set of challenges and opportunities and ongoing research efforts are focused on improving conversion efficiencies and reducing costs. The interdisciplinary collaboration among scientists engineers policymakers and industry stakeholders is very much required to realizing the full potential of this renewable and environmentally friendly energy source. Till date no known process ranging from algae cultivation harvesting conversion to biofuel is 100 efficient. The concepts of circular economy and carbon neutrality cost benefit analysis life cycle assessment should be followed and analyzed while promoting a technology for commercialization related to algae based biofuel production. The efficient reactor design and oper- ation could also enhance the success rate of this carbon neutral technology. No known reactor design or operation is available having 100 light conversion efficiency. The literature available clearly indicate that no single technology has the potential of commercial- ization of the algae based biofuels. The only solution to this hurdle is to integrate the process of wastewater treatment carbon seques- tration Biofuel production and value added compounds production. Overall algal biomass holds great potential as a renewable and sustainable energy source. Although several technical and economic challenges need to be addressed ongoing research and develop- ment efforts are steadily pushing the field forward. Name: 4_the_of_and_biodiesel
Representative_Docs: ['Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 Available online 4 January 2024 0959-6526 2024 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Review A review of the strategy to promote microalgae value in CO2 conversion-lipid enrichment-biodiesel production Huan Liu a Tian-Ji Liu a Hua-Wei Guo a Ya-Jun Wang a Rui Ji a Le-Le Kang a Yi-Tong Wang a Xuan Guo a Jun-Guo Li a Li-Qun Jiang c Zhen Fang b a College of Metallurgy and Energy North China University of Science and Technology 21 Bohai Street Tangshan 063210 China b Biomass Group College of Engineering Nanjing Agricultural University 40 Dianjiangtai Road Nanjing 210031 China c Guangdong Engineering Laboratory of Biomass High-value Utilization Guangdong Plant Fiber Comprehensive Utilization Engineering Technology Research and Development Center Guangzhou Key Laboratory of Biomass Comprehensive Utilization Institute of Biological and Medical Engineering Guangdong Academy of Sciences Guangzhou 510316 China A R T I C L E I N F O Handling Editor Panos Seferlis Keywords Microalgae biodiesel Lipid productivity Stress conditions Catalyst Economic environment analysis A B S T R A C T Fossil fuels including coal oil and natural gas remain the main source of global energy supply. Not only the storage capacity is limited but also the use of the ecological environment causes great damage a serious threat to human life safety. Microalgae biodiesel receives extensive attention due to its biodegradable and carbon-neutral green energy characteristics which is used to reduce or replace the use of these fossil fuels. Because of the slow growth of microalgae low lipid content and low biodiesel production people begin to study ways to improve the growth and lipid production of microalgae and catalytic conversion of biodiesel. In this paper the research progress of the whole process from microalgae culture to microalgae oil production to microalgae catalytic conversion of biodiesel in recent years is reviewed. The efficient growth and oil production of microalgae the catalytic conversion methods of microalgae biodiesel and the application prospects of microalgae biodiesel are discussed and summarized. Specifically this review critically discusses i The current development status of microalgae culture and microalgae biodiesel ii Cultivation methods for efficient growth and oil production of microalgae under different stress conditions iii The effects of different types of catalysts and catalytic methods on the yield of biodiesel iv Environmental problems and economic value of the whole process of microalgae biodiesel production v Current limitations and future research directions in the field of microalgae biodiesel. Studies show that regulating light temperature pH nutrients etc. can improve the growth and oil production of microalgae in which the addition of anions and cations can change the physiological biochemical and metabolic mechanisms of microalgae. At present a large number of genetic modification and metabolic regulation engi neering technologies are applied to microalgae oil production. They have precise control of the targeting mechanism in cells to induce increased lipid accumulation. The two-stage culture model can simultaneously increase biomass and lipid content. The addition of homogeneous heterogeneous biological enzymes and nano- catalysts accelerates the conversion efficiency and improves the yield of biodiesel. The catalytic yield of several magnetic nano-catalysts studied is as high as 98 . The supercritical method and ionic liquid method are favored by everyone because they do not use catalysts to reduce environmental pollution. In situ trans esterification replaces the traditional two-step transesterification method to reduce energy consumption and cumbersome steps. Hydrothermal liquefaction method can directly convert wet algae biomass into biofuels without drying at high temperatures and pressure and in the presence of water. However the current high-cost economic problems in the production of microalgae biodiesel and the environmental problems caused by the addition of catalysts need to further study the efficient and low-cost microalgae culture methods and new environmentally friendly catalysts and catalytic methods to improve the yield of microalgae biodiesel to realize the commercial production of microalgae biodiesel as soon as possible. Corresponding authors. Corresponding author. Corresponding authors. Corresponding author. E-mail addresses Y.-T. Wang X. Guo J.-G. Li Z. Fang . Contents lists available at ScienceDirect Journal of Cleaner Production journal homepage Received 26 September 2023 Received in revised form 13 December 2023 Accepted 30 December 2023 Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 2 1. Introduction Fossil fuels including coal petroleum and natural gas remain the main source of global energy supply. In the past few decades energy consumption and CO2 emissions have increased rapidly due to increasing population and energy demand exacerbating global climate change Mikhaylov et al. 2020 Jeffry et al. 2021 . Excessive emission of CO2 is the main cause of the greenhouse effect. Excessive CO2 seri ously destroys the ecological balance and hurts humans animals and plants. A report submitted by the United Nations Environment Pro gramme points out that about 37 billion metric tons of CO2 is emitted into the atmosphere every year accounting for 74 of the total greenhouse gas emissions. It is expected that the global average tem perature will rise by 2 C by 2050 Johnson 2019 . Environmental and energy issues have intensified people s interest in renewable fuels and the development of biofuels has become necessary such as bioethanol biodiesel biohydrogen and biogas to reduce or replace the use of these fossil fuels. Biodiesel has attracted wide attention for its biodegrad ability and carbon neutrality Kim et al. 2022 . It is a promising renewable energy source. Compared with other renewable energy sources such as solar energy and wind energy biodiesel is the most attractive alternative to petrochemical diesel. After mixing with gasoline at a rate of 85 they can be used directly without any modification of the engine Fulton et al. 2015 . Scientists around the world are trying to turn their attention to the study of high-quality biodiesel. Microalgae cells have a simple structure and can grow only by light CO2 water and nutrients. Microalgae has high photosynthetic efficiency and rapid growth. Under appropriate conditions they can undergo one or two cell divisions per day. Generally the biomass can be doubled in one day. Some algal strains such as Chlamydomonas reinhardtii and Chlorella can even be doubled in a few hours especially in polyculture autotrophic and heterotrophic combination Yang et al. 2022a . Microalgae can grow throughout the year and the CO2 fixed by microalgae photosynthesis accounts for more than 40 of the global CO2 fixed amount each year. It does not compete for food production resources and is not limited by seasons which can ensure a stable supply of raw materials for production Siddiki et al. 2022 . Microalgae are highly versatile and adaptable and they can thrive in wastewater and saline water Ali et al. 2021 . Wastewater contains a large amount of inorganic salts which are mainly in the form of ions such as carbonate ions phosphate ions copper ions iron ions and calcium ions etc. Excessive discharge of wastewater e.g. brine will reduce water qual ity. At present the world is facing a serious shortage of water resources. It can be solved by using the seawater desalination brine salty waste water process. Among them high-pressure reverse osmosis HPRO and hot steam compression multi-effect distillation MED-TVC are commonly used methods for treating seawater desalination brine Panagopoulos 2022 Panagopoulos 2020a Panagopoulos 2020b . In addition microalgae can efficiently absorb nutrient salts in wastewater use them for growth and metabolism and produce high-value com pounds reduce water body eutrophication with strong environmental restoration ability and economic value Chew et al. 2018 . Compared with the previous two generations of biodiesel feedstocks animal and vegetable oils and waste gutter oils Ianda et al. 2022 microalgae is more suitable as a potential biodiesel feedstock because it not only has high biomass and lipid content but also is environmentally and economically friendly and feasible. Lipid is one of the most important metabolites in the growth and reproduction of microalgae and is an important source of biodiesel and high-value-added products. Triacylglycerol TAG is the main form of lipid accumulation in microalgae and serves as the energy for the sur vival and maintenance of microalgae Ananthi et al. 2021a . According to the different microalgae species and microalgae culture conditions the lipid content of microalgae accounts for 20 60 of its stem cell weight Bibi et al. 2022a . The lipid content and biodiesel yield of microalgae are 15 300 times that of oil-bearing crops such as corn soybean sunflower and castor Shah et al. 2018 . The high lipid content of microalgae makes it a suitable raw material for biodiesel production. Microalgae can usually produce a large amount of biomass but the lipid content is relatively low. Under ideal culture conditions microalgae produce polar lipids by synthesizing fatty acids. When the growth con ditions are unfavorable or stressed microalgae will change their biosynthetic pathways synthesize neutral lipids mainly TAG and maintain their survival through the formation and accumulation of neutral lipids Chin et al. 2023 . Microalgae can effectively change the lipid metabolism pathway by changing the culture environment so they can adapt to a wide range of environmental conditions. The lipid content of microalgae can be increased by external environmental stress Bibi et al. 2022b such as nutrient limitation light intensity temperature pH and CO2 but the growth rate of microalgae will slow down because the interference of cell biological processes leads to a decrease in cell division rate and slows down cell proliferation. Environmental stress may be counterproductive to some extent. However the new two-stage culture model can solve this problem Aziz et al. 2020 . Two-stage culture first increases biomass in a well-nourished environment and then increases lipid content by utilizing stress to achieve high biomass and high lipid content. In recent years co-culture of microalgae and other microorganisms such as bacteria co-culture is a biological system in which two or more different organisms grow together in natural or synthetic media has been shown to increase microalgae biomass lipid content and yield of high-value products Zheng et al. 2023 . In addi tion to environmental stress there are a large number of studies such as genetic modification and metabolic engineering techniques that have been applied to this field to induce increased lipid accumulation by precisely controlling the targeting mechanisms in cells Ranjbar and Malcata 2022 . Traditionally the synthesis of biodiesel from microalgae biomass includes two steps. One is to extract lipid from microalgae biomass and the other is to catalyze the transesterification of microalgae lipid to biodiesel. In this reaction fatty acids are hydrolyzed and methylated into fatty acid methyl ester biodiesel Hu et al. 2008 . The traditional two-step method does not have good economic value as the need to consume more energy and the one-step method can solve this prob lem. The one-step method is also known as the in-situ trans esterification method that is lipid extraction and catalytic transesterification are carried out simultaneously Thanh et al. 2022 . The addition of catalysts is the key to making significant progress in the biodiesel industry which greatly improves the reaction rate Zul et al. 2021 . Most biodiesel catalysts are homogeneous catalysts which are attractive because they can produce high biodiesel yield at low cost in a short time. However this type of catalyst is often mixed with the product and is difficult to separate resulting in equipment corrosion and water pollution Gupta and Singh 2023 . Heterogeneous catalysts are a good substitute for homogeneous catalysts owing to their high efficiency and environmental friendliness and heterogeneous catalysts are suitable for raw materials containing high concentrations of free fatty acids FFA Galadima and Muraza 2014 . Since its high specific surface area high catalytic activity high saponification resistance and good rigidity the new nano-catalyst can easily solve the problems of mass transfer resis tance low efficiency time-consuming and the use of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts Mittal and Ghosh 2023 . Bio-enzyme cata lyzed transesterification especially lipase-based transesterification is an environmentally friendly method that can solve the unfriendly environmental problems of the chemical catalysis acid and alkali cat alysts transesterification process. However the transesterification of enzymes has a high cost and slow reaction rate and the utilization and regeneration of catalysts are limited Christopher et al. 2014 . The addition of the catalyst not only increases the separation and recovery steps but also the disposal of the catalyst is harmful to the environment. Transesterification reaction can also be carried out without a catalyst Kusdiana and Saka 2001 introduced a new supercritical fluid trans esterification process for the synthesis of biodiesel. Supercritical fluids H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 3 are fluids whose temperature and pressure are higher than their critical points. These fluids have high diffusivity and solubility. Supercritical transesterification does not require the addition of catalysts raw ma terial pretreatment and extraction of lipid from microalgae biomass. The extraction and reaction can be completed simultaneously in one step and biodiesel can be obtained in only a few minutes Rathnam and Madras 2019 . Another new method for biodiesel production is the ILs method. ILs are composed of cations and anions and are a liquid organic salt at room temperature. It is considered to be a new environmentally friendly production route because it can be used as a solvent and catalyst for microalgae biodiesel production. The catalytic reaction of ILs has been proven to have the advantages of high reactivity and simple sep aration steps under mild conditions Ong et al. 2021 . The use of microalgae to produce biodiesel has been well studied but the economic and environmental issues of the entire biorefinery process are still a challenge for its commercialization such as the chemical costs and pollution issues involved in upstream processing the extraction of high value-added products from microalgae and the catalytic conver sion of downstream processed products into biodiesel yield and quality issues. Microalgae is regarded as the most promising feedstock for the third generation of biodiesel production. Despite some challenges microalgae biodiesel is still attractive and has broad prospects for commercial application. At present there is no research on the whole process method of microalgae biodiesel production in the published review articles. This review summarizes and discusses the whole process method of microalgae biodiesel production in recent years including microalgae growth microalgae oil production and microalgae catalytic conversion of biodiesel. The effects of anions and cations on the physi ology and biochemistry of microalgae and the effects of genetic meta bolic regulation on the lipid accumulation of microalgae are emphatically introduced. The advantages and disadvantages of different catalysts and catalytic methods in the production of microalgae bio diesel are compared. The economic value and environmental safety analysis of the whole process of microalgae biodiesel production are carried out and the limitations of the current research on microalgae biodiesel and the future development direction are explained. Compared with other related review articles this paper comprehensively reviews the research progress of the whole process of microalgae biodiesel production which gives readers a clearer and more comprehensive understanding and provides a useful theoretical perspective for the early commercialization of microalgae biodiesel. 2. Efficient growth of microalgae Microalgae is the primary producers of aquatic ecosystems. They have the characteristics of fast growth and a simple culture. They can grow in various habitats and preferentially in aquatic environments but they can also grow in other spaces including deserts and permafrost Levasseur et al. 2020 . According to the way microalgae use carbon sources microalgae culture types can be divided into three types photoautotrophic heterotrophic and mixed culture Bo et al. 2023 . Photoautotrophy is the most commonly used culture method because of its energy-saving and environmental protection. Photoautotrophy can be carried out in open-air runway pools and photobioreactors mainly relying on sunlight or other light sources and using CO2 as an inorganic carbon source. However the light culture mode needs to consider maintaining a sterile environment and good light penetration. Compared with the photoautotrophic mode the main advantage of the heterotrophic mode is that it does not depend on the light source. The growth of microalgae mainly depends on the organic carbon source in the medium but the heterotrophic mode is susceptible to bacterial contamination. The mixed culture mode is a combination of autotrophic and heterotrophic. Microalgae consume both organic and inorganic carbon sources under this culture condition which improves the biomass productivity of microalgae Arun et al. 2021 2022 . Micro algae similar to terrestrial plants also have photosynthetic characteristics that is capturing sunlight radiation and absorbing CO2 in the atmosphere so that they can grow and reproduce. It takes about 1.8 kg of CO2 to produce 1 kg of dry microalgae most microalgae can adapt and grow under various CO2 concentrations which is mediated by a series of changes at different cellular levels including changes in gene expression involved in the CO2 concentration mechanism operation CCM . The CO2 concentration mechanism is a mechanism for algal cells to effectively conduct photosynthesis at low CO2 concentrations. This mechanism involves a variety of proteins such as inorganic carbon transport carriers ATPases provide active transport of HCO3 to energy and one or several carbonic anhydrases Priyadharsini et al. 2022 . Microalgae can also convert nutrients in wastewater into high-value compounds to meet their growth Abdelfattah et al. 2023 Such po tential has attracted people s attention. The growth of microalgae was affected by adjusting light intensity temperature pH and anion and cation conditions. This chapter will review the main factors affecting the growth of microalgae focusing on the effects of anions and cations on the growth of microalgae and the mechanism of physiological metabolism. 2.1. Effects of environmental factors on the growth of microalgae 2.1.1. Light conditions Light conditions including light intensity light wavelength and light-dark cycle are the key factors for the growth of microalgae. It is found that the biomass increases with the increase of light intensity below the light saturation limit. Although insufficient light supply will inhibit the growth of microalgae photoinhibition may occur when microalgae cells are exposed to strong light Xu et al. 2020 . An appropriate light cycle can improve the light efficiency and biomass of microalgae and protect microalgae cells from photoinhibition Yuan et al. 2020 . In the photosynthesis system fixing a CO2 molecule re quires 8 photons about 48 of the incident sunlight . However high photon flux density can cause light damage to microalgae and reduce photosynthetic efficiency. In this case the selected light-dark cycle will have an important impact on microalgae because microalgae cells can repair light-induced damage during the dark period. The growth of microalgae under different light intensities and different light cycles shows that light conditions have a great influence on microalgae Gonçalves et al. 2014 . EswaryDevi et al. 2022 studied the cultiva tion of two marine algae strains Chlorella salina and Spirulina subsalsa using an urban sewage mixed medium. The maximum biomass yield of Chlorella salina was 2.6 g L when the light intensity was 150 μmol m2 s the photoperiod was 16 8 h and the aeration rate was 0.2 vvm. The maximum biomass of Spirulina subsalsa was 2.9 g L when the light in tensity was adjusted to 100 μmol m2 s. Further acclimation of the two microalgae in municipal wastewater can also increase biomass produc tion which was 3.0 and 2.8 g L respectively indicating that it is feasible to use 40 60 of the wastewater mixed medium as a nutrient source. Another study by EswaryDevi and Parthiban 2020 also opti mized the microalgae culture conditions and the ratio of wastewater to medium. Under the optimized growth conditions such as 80 urban sewage mixed with 20 Fog s medium and the acclimation of waste water the biomass of Nostoc ellipsosporum increased from 1.4 g L to 2.9 g L and the removal rate of nitrogen and phosphate in wastewater was as high as nearly 90 . At 300 C the yield of bio-oil produced by hy drothermal liquefaction of biomass was 24.6 . 2.1.2. Temperature Temperature is one of the main factors determining the distribution and abundance of species and it is a key sensitive parameter affecting the enzyme activity and metabolic process in microalgae cells. Under normal circumstances the optimal culture temperature of most micro algae is between 20 and 30 C Barten et al. 2021 . Thermophilic algae which grow on the wooden structure of the cooling tower of a thermal power plant in central Mexico have heat-resistant molecules that make H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 4 up their cells. They can survive at temperatures up to 40 C Covarrubias et al. 2016 . This example is only a special case. When the temperature is lower than the optimal temperature the increase in temperature is beneficial to the growth of microalgae. When the temperature exceeds the optimal temperature the denaturation and inactivation of the enzyme will have a serious inhibitory effect Zhang et al. 2021 . The effect of temperature on photosynthesis is mainly caused by the complex dynamics of ribulose-1 5-bisphosphate. This catalytic enzyme of photosynthesis is involved in two competitive physiological pathways photosynthesis and photorespiration with dicarboxylase and oxygenase activity respectively affecting the growth and metabolism of micro algae Ras et al. 2013 . High and low temperatures have an unequal effect on microalgae culture. Most microalgae can tolerate temperatures around 15 C lower than the optimal temperature but only 2 4 C above the optimal temperature is not conducive to the growth of microalgae Gonzalez-Camejo et al. 2019 . 2.1.3. pH The pH is one of the key factors in controlling photosynthesis inorganic carbon distribution and metabolic characteristics of micro algae. It is very important to provide the optimal pH for the growth of microalgae. For example Chlorella is not conducive to growth under alkaline conditions. When the pH of 7 the biomass productivity of Chlorella is the highest and it is also easy to increase the biomass under acidic conditions. However when the pH of lower than 3 the growth of microalgae will be inhibited or even lethal Hao et al. 2022 Song et al. 2020 . The change in pH will affect the concentration of H+ and OH in the liquid medium of the medium as well as the protonation and deprotonation of the chemical groups on the cells and substrates thus changing the ζ potential of the cells and substrates. The ζ potential decreased with the increase of pH. The medium solution of microalgae had positive potential under acidic conditions and negative potential under alkaline conditions. The dissociation rate of carboxyl groups in microalgae cell membranes composed of polysaccharides proteins and lipids is inhibited at low pH and the dissociation rate of amino groups is increased. When the pH increases microalgae cells will release extra cellular substances to protect them from the surrounding environment Ahmad et al. 2021 Yuan et al. 2019 . 2.2. Effects of nutrients on the growth of microalgae In microalgae the cell development or culture metabolism of auto trophic microalgae requires sunlight and some basic inorganic compo nents such as CO2 and metal salts while heterotrophic microalgae require some additional organic compounds and nutrients such as N and P. N is the main nutrient for microalgae growth accounting for more than 1 10 of the biomass and is used to synthesize nutrients for nucleic acids and proteins. Therefore the lack of this nutrient may lead to a decrease in biomass production in microalgae culture. P is another important nutrient for the growth of algae. It plays a key role in cell structure energy storage information transmission and metabolic pathways. It is an important compound for the growth of photosynthetic microorganisms because it affects the composition of biomass and is directly related to the content of carbohydrates and lipids. This nutrient is a part of DNA and RNA molecules accounting for about 1 of the dry weight of microalgae on average Díaz et al. 2022 Saratale et al. 2022 Han et al. 2021 . Trace metal ions are essential for the growth of microalgae such as Fe3+ Mg2+ Zn2+ Ca2+ Cu2+ and so on. These metal ions maintain the growth and metabolism of microalgae. Fe3+ is an important electron acceptor in the photosynthetic process of micro algae and plays a central role in nitrogen fixation photosynthesis and other metabolic processes. Adding appropriate Fe3+ to participate in the basic enzyme reaction of photosynthesis can increase the carbon flow in the direction of microalgae growth and lipid synthesis Pancha et al. 2015 . Mg2+ ions play an important role in different metabolic processes and physiological pathways of microalgae and are the main elements in microalgae culture medium. Mg2+ is a component of chlorophyll mol ecules and the level of Mg2+ in the medium directly affects the bio logical formation of chlorophyll Concas et al. 2021 . Ca2+ plays a key role in the signal transduction of microalgae cells. The transmission of Ca2+ signals in microalgae not only controls intracellular regulation but also regulates long-distance or even organic signal transmission and physiological responses Yang et al. 2022b . Heavy metals refer to metals with a density greater than 5 g cm3 including Cu Fe Zn Cd Cr etc. Microalgae have a variety of unique self-protection mechanisms to combat the toxicity of heavy metals such as heavy metal immobiliza tion gene regulation exclusion and chelation as well as antioxidants or reductases that reduce heavy metals through redox reactions. Micro algae can form cell protein-heavy metal complexes without changing their activity and organic metal complexes are further separated in the vacuole to help regulate the concentration of heavy metal ions in the cytoplasm thereby reducing their toxic effects. In addition heavy metals activate the biosynthesis of phytochelatins PCs thiol-rich peptides and proteins that interact with them to minimize the effects of heavy metals Leong and Chang 2020 . According to Fig. 1 the removal of heavy metal ions by microalgae includes two steps. The first step is to attach heavy metal ions to the cell surface called biosorption. Biosorption is a fast non-metabolic and reversible process that allows living and dead algae biomass to remove heavy metals mainly controlled by negatively charged functional groups on the cell wall. The negative charge on the cell surface is in that the presence of hydroxyl OH- carboxyl -COOH phosphate -PO4 amino -NH2 sulfhydryl -SH etc. which provides more binding sites for metal cations and al lows ion interaction. In addition to physical adsorption ion exchange chelation microprecipitation chemical adsorption and other phenom ena will also make heavy metal ions adhere to the cell surface. The second step is that heavy metals are internalized into cells through an energy-dependent process after being attached to cells which is called bioaccumulation . Since heavy metals are hydrophilic they require specific carrier molecules to allow them to enter the cell. Heavy metal ions are attached to the functional groups on the cell surface followed by intracellular bioaccumulation and compartmentalization of subcel lular organelles such as chloroplasts and mitochondria and ultimately detoxification by removing excess metals from the cells Tripathi and Poluri 2021 Kumar et al. 2015 . Most ions affect the growth and physiological metabolism of microalgae. The following introduces the effects of anions and cations on the growth of microalgae and the mechanism of physiological metabolism and further explains the effects of anions and cations on the physiology and biochemistry of microalgae. 2.2.1. Effect of anions on the growth of microalgae 2.2.1.1. HCO3 . Both inorganic carbon and organic carbon can be used to culture microalgae but CO2 in inorganic carbon is the main carbon source for culturing microalgae because CO2 is easier to obtain in the air. Microalgae require a certain concentration of CO2 during photosyn thesis so microalgae contain a CO2 concentration mechanism CCM to increase the concentration of CO2. CO2 in the air exists in the form of HCO3 CO3 2 and CO2 in the water. HCO3 can enter the cell through a series of transporters and is converted into CO2 by carbonic anhydrase CA to increase the concentration of CO2 around ribulose-1 5- bisphosphate carboxylase RuBisCO so that microalgae can effi ciently fix carbon and convert it into other organic matter such as car bohydrates and lipids. The utilization of these two carbons by microalgae is largely related to extracellular CA. CA is an essential enzyme that catalyzes the reversible conversion of HCO3 to CO2. Only algae that can use HCO3 can express CA. CA catalyzes the continuous supply of HCO3 to CO2 to active transporters. The affinity of microalgae to HCO3 is higher than that of CO2 but the main carbon species entering the cytoplasm is CO2. The expression of exogenous CA is also greatly affected by pH and CO2 concentration Fal et al. 2023 Ighalo et al. H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 5 2022 Tarafdar et al. 2023 . CO2 and HCO3 are the main forms of ab sorption and fixation of microalgae cells. CO2 can be converted into HCO3 by alkaline solution as a carbon source for microalgae growth. This method eliminates the disadvantage of slow dissolution of CO2 and the supply of carbon sources is sufficient to meet the needs of rapid growth of microalgae. It has been reported that in some cases the car bon removal efficiency can reach more than 90 when microalgae is cultured in a solution containing bicarbonate ions while the carbon utilization rate is low when microalgae is cultured directly with CO2 Zhu et al. 2022 . Agbebi et al. 2022 studied that the use of bicar bonate solution as a carbon source and the regulation of the pH of the medium solution can increase the activity of RuBisCO and CA increase the content of chlorophyll a and increase the biomass of chlorella. Most inorganic carbon exists in the form of HCO3 at normal pH in microalgae culture. There are many known CO2 transport pathways in eukaryotic microalgae cells including CO2 diffusion and active transport of CO2 and HCO3 Zheng et al. 2018 . 2.2.1.2. PO4 3-. The absorption of phosphorus by microalgae is mainly based on inorganic phosphorus while inorganic phosphorus in water mainly exists as sulfate ions Miao et al. 2022 . Some microalgae can also utilize inorganic phosphorus IP and organic phosphorus OP at the same time. The enzyme systems contained in microalgae such as nuclease and alkaline phosphatase AKP have been shown to enable microalgae to utilize OP. AKP is considered to be the most common enzyme that uses OP which can decompose OP and release IP to pro mote the growth of microalgae Xing et al. 2023 . The absorption of phosphorus by microalgae includes two main processes extracellular adsorption and intracellular uptake. Extracellular adsorption mainly depends on extracellular polymeric substances EPS secreted by microalgae. EPS is located on the surface of microalgae cells and is mainly composed of proteins and carbohydrates. The positively charged amine group in EPS protein can be complex with negatively charged phosphate so that EPS has a strong adsorption capacity for phosphate. As the main extracellular phosphorus pool EPS plays a key role in phos phorus absorption. In addition phosphorus can be transported through the cell membrane and in contact with intracellular polymeric sub stances IPS which contain a variety of phosphorus-containing com pounds including phospholipids phosphorylated proteins nucleotides and polyphosphates. The absorption of intracellular phosphorus by IPS is mainly through biomass assimilation and polyphosphate formation. During the growth of microalgae IP can be transported to IPS for metabolism and converted into OP. When exposed to a continuous high phosphorus concentration in the external environment microalgae can absorb more phosphorus than required for cell metabolism and growth and excess phosphorus is stored in cells in the form of polyphosphate. The role of EPS and IPS in the process of phosphorus uptake by micro algae cannot be ignored Wu et al. 2021 . However the most common form of phosphorus in wastewater is phosphate ion which has high solubility and activity. It can be converted into H2PO4 HPO4 2 and then absorbed by microalgae through phosphorylation. It is found that microalgae can absorb phosphate ions in landfill leachate well for their growth. When phosphorus is sufficient phosphate ions enter cells through transporters and are involved in the synthesis of RNA DNA polyphosphates phospholipids proteins and adenosine triphosphate ATP . In the case of phosphorus deficiency excess phosphorus will accumulate in vacuoles in the form of acid-insoluble polyphosphate AISP and be stored in the form of polyphosphate particles for future internal use. After AISP is degraded into Pi it is used to transfer to its cellular phosphorus compounds to maintain the viability of microalgae under phosphorus deficiency Janpum et al. 2022 Su 2021 Khanzada 2020 . 2.2.1.3. NO3 . Nitrate is one of the most common water pollutants. To utilize nitrate ions microalgae must convert nitrate ions into ammo nium ions. The conversion process includes two steps that is NO3 is absorbed into the cell where it is reduced to NO2 by cytoplasmic nitrate reductase NR and NO2 is then transferred to the chloroplast where it is reduced to NH4 + by nitrite reductase NiR Dang et al. 2022 . Ni trogen sources have no inhibitory effect on microalgae in high concen trations of nitrate ions and microalgae have a better affinity for NO3 than NH4 + Praveen et al. 2018 . Fig. 2 shows the absorption principle of NO3 and NH4 + by microalgae and its advantages and disadvantages Qin et al. 2022 . 2.2.2. Effects of cations on the growth of microalgae 2.2.2.1. Cu2+. Cu is an essential nutrient for aquatic organisms and is of great significance to the photosynthesis of microalgae. The adsorption of Cu2+ by microalgae cell membrane is fast while the absorption of Cu2+ by microalgae cells is relatively slow. At low Cu2+ concentration the transport of copper ions will be limited by diffusion and the uptake of Cu2+ ions by microalgae will be controlled by kinetics. Once Cu2+ is internalized by microalgae thiol groups in the cytoplasm will be oxidized resulting in a decrease in the ratio of reducing and oxidizing glutathione which in turn affects spindle formation and cell division limiting cell growth. High concentrations of Cu2+ can inhibit the photosynthesis process induce oxidative stress inhibit the growth of Fig. 1. Adsorption of heavy metal elements by microalgae Tripathi and Poluri 2021 . H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 6 microalgae cells and even cause the death of microalgae cells mainly for two reasons i Causing changes in the chloroplast structure of microalgae ii Excessive Cu2+ replaces magnesium ions in chlorophyll molecules resulting in changes in fluorescence quantum yield and chlorophyll absorption spectra affecting the structure of chloroplasts thereby affecting photosynthetic efficiency reducing photosynthesis and reducing glucose synthesis efficiency Pascual et al. 2022 Li et al. 2021a Zhu et al. 2020 . 2.2.2.2. Fe2+ Fe3+. Fe is an important element required for the growth of microalgae. It is one of the elements involved in the enzymatic re action of photosynthesis in photosystem I PSI and photosystem II PSII . It is an essential trace element for microalgae growth nitrogen metabolism and chlorophyll synthesis. Fe deficiency will reduce the photosynthetic activity and growth rate of microalgae but a high con centration of Fe will also hurt microalgae. Studies have shown that Fe3+ concentration of 2 mg L has a positive effect on most microalgae but negative effects are usually observed when Fe3+ concentration exceeds 40 mg L. Fe2+ can change the lipid structure of microalgae. Lin et al. studied the effect of Fe2+ on the yield and composition of fatty acid methyl esters FAME in Scenedesmus rubescens-like microalgae. High or low Fe2+ concentration has a certain inhibitory effect on ammonia consumption and FAME accumulation. When the concentration of Fe2+ was 1 mg L the FAME yield of microalgae was the highest which had a significant impact on biodiesel production. In the case of low Fe con centration microalgae adapt to the absorption of Fe and show a high affinity for Fe ions. Compared with Fe3+ the bioavailability of Fe2+ is lower Polat et al. 2020 Lin et al. 2012 . Although Fe is essential for all aerobic organisms a large amount of Fe2+ is toxic because a large number of H2O2 and Fe2+ spontaneously reacts in cells called Fenton s reaction producing a large amount of OH and Fe3+ causing changes in the valence state of Fe resulting in increased reactive oxygen species ROS which in turn harms microalgae cells Zada et al. 2021 Carb o et al. 2023 . Fe has been shown to promote the expression of specific genes including enzymes related to lipid synthesis. When microalgae grow under high Fe concentration conditions significant overexpression of genes related to metabolic enzymes acetyl-CoA carboxylase ACCase and ribulose triphosphate carboxylase NTPase involved in lipid syn thesis can be observed Concas et al. 2021 . 2.2.2.3. Zn2+. Zn is an enzyme cofactor of RNA polymerase RNAP superoxide dismutase SOD and CA in microalgae.
