The change in Zn2+ concentration will affect the fatty acid content and the accumulation of protein and chlorophyll in microalgae. Zn2+ can also replace magnesium ions in chlorophyll thereby changing the composition of chlorophyll and inhibiting photosynthesis. High concentrations of Zn2+ can affect the content of glutathione GSH and malondialdehyde MDA and the activity of SOD in microalgae thus affecting the biomass production and nutrient removal ability of microalgae. Koppel et al. 2019 studied the absorption of metal elements by two Antarctic marine microalgae cells. When the concentration of other metal ions is constant the intracellular zinc concentration of the two microalgae is positively correlated with the growth rate indicating that the increase of intracellular zinc con centration will increase the growth rate Li et al. 2022a . Zhou et al. 2018 studied the effect of Zn2+ concentration on the growth biochemical composition and photosynthetic performance of Spirulina platensis. The results showed that Zn2+ could destroy the uptake of cal cium by microalgae and calcium was an essential element for adenosine triphosphatase activity in cell division. The toxicity of Zn2+ could also destroy the structure of proteins in microalgae cells. The direct binding of Zn to thiols is an important detoxification mechanism which can protect sensitive cell sites from metal stress by acting as a buffer for excessive metal leading to the active accumulation of metal in cells. Li et al. 2023 studied the accumulation and detoxification mechanism of Zn2+ in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii and found that Zn2+ was mainly adsorbed on the binding sites of cell wall and EPS when the concen tration was lower than 3 mg L. When the concentration was higher than 3 mg L intracellular GSH was synthesized in large quantities Fig. 2. The absorption principle of NO3 and NH4 + by microalgae and its advantages and disadvantages Qin et al. 2022 . H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 7 scavenging H2O2 O2 and organic free radicals and transported to vesicles to offset the toxicity of Zn2+. 2.2.2.4. Cd2+. Cd is a non-essential toxic element for microalgae. The negative groups such as phosphoric acid on the surface of microalgae cells complex with free Cd2+ and then microalgae metabolize phos phorus free radicals into the extracellular microenvironment and combine with complexed Cd2+ to form a stable phosphate precipitate. The CH C O and COO in the aliphatic groups of lipids or proteins and carboxylates and the -PO4 P O and P OH in the free phosphate groups of phosphates and phospholipids can all be complexed with Cd2+ Xia et al. 2023 . Liu et al. 2023 studied the mechanism of pollutant removal and the toxic reaction of tetrabromobisphenol A and Cd2+ on Chlorella sorokiniana indicating that Cd2+ below 1 mg L can promote the growth of microalgae and Cd2+ can up-regulate DNA replication-related genes in microalgae thereby promoting cell prolif eration. The addition of Cd2+ can stimulate the photosynthesis of microalgae which provides a basis for the production of poly saccharides. The reducing end of the polysaccharide can act on free radicals to produce antioxidant activity. At the same time the hydroxyl group in the polysaccharide has a high affinity for divalent cations and can bind to Cd2+ to reduce the damage of Cd2+ to cells. Cd can easily bind to sulfhydryl carboxyl and phosphate functional groups in the cell membrane of microalgae thereby generating a net negative charge on the surface of microalgae cells. Cd2+ is transported in cells through ion channels or transporters that are constitutively present on the cell membrane. Tripathi et al. 2023 studied the physiological and biochemical effects of cadmium on cadmium-tolerant microalgae Sce nedesmus sp. IITRIND2 . Studies have shown that cadmium can increase the production of microalgae lipids and EPS. However excessive con centration of cadmium will change the physiological activity of micro algae cells resulting in inhibition of growth and damage to photosynthesis. The main functional groups of microalgae in the process of Cd2+ adsorption were determined to include OH C O CH CH2 -P O PO4 3 and PO4. Among them the phosphate groups PO4 -P O and phosphate PO4 3 play a major role in improving the adsorption capacity of microalgae for Cd2+ Wang et al. 2021 . 2.2.2.5. Cr3+ Cr6+. Cr mainly exists in three main forms in nature uncharged metal form Cr trivalent form Cr3+ and hexavalent form Cr6+ Hedayatkhah et al. 2018 . Cr6+ is more toxic than Cr3+. The removal of Cr by microalgae cells is not only through adsorption but also through biological mechanisms such as the reduction of Cr6+ to Cr3+ by enzymes to reduce toxicity. GSH released by Chlorella under Cr6+ stress will reduce Cr6+ to Cr3+. Most of the Cr6+ in microalgae cells is accu mulated through organelles heat-stable proteins HSPs and particles Daneshvar et al. 2019 . Studies have shown that microalgae can not only produce sufficient biomass and accumulate a large amount of lipids under Cr stress but also repair hexavalent chromium at a toxic concen tration 1 mg L in the human body Hedayatkhah et al. 2018 . Kafil et al. 2022 showed that Chlorella can change the composition and content of FAME in microalgae under Cr6+ stress to improve the quality of biodiesel. When low concentrations of heavy metals such as trivalent chromium and hexavalent chromium are added to the medium micro algae cells will have a toxic excitatory effect which will interfere with the homeostasis of microalgae and initiate a series of repair and main tenance mechanisms. For example through the activation of transcrip tion factors and kinases the expression of cytoprotective and repair proteins is increased but as the concentration increases the growth of microalgae is limited or dead. In summary low concentrations of heavy metals can be absorbed and utilized by microalgae participate in the synthesis of enzymes and proteins related to microalgae cells and pro mote the growth and metabolism of microalgae while high concentra tions of heavy metals can seriously threaten the growth of microalgae cells and even lead to death. 2.2.2.6. Mg2+. Mg is an essential element for the growth and develop ment of microalgae. It is the most abundant free cation in the cytoplasm. It is the core atom of the chlorophyll skeleton molecule of microalgae and controls the activity of several photosynthetic enzymes. Each chlorophyll molecule requires one Mg2+ to synthesize which is essential for the formation of chlorophyll. And many enzymes such as RNA po lymerase ATPase protein kinase phosphatase glutathione synthase and carboxylase require Mg2+ to function. Mg deficiency in microalgae hinders cell division and chlorophyll synthesis. Mg deficiency leads to a significant decrease in photosynthetic rate which ultimately damages cell growth. In addition Mg is a cofactor of malic enzyme which can convert malic acid into pyruvate in the transfer dehydrogenase cycle providing essential NADPH for lipid accumulation during fatty acid synthesis. Therefore Mg2+ promotes the growth and lipid accumulation of microalgae Daneshvar et al. 2018 Kong et al. 2020 . Salman et al. 2023 studied the effect of Mg2+ concentration on the biomass and physiological changes of Chlorella vulgaris 5 mg L Mg2+ was the optimal concentration for biomass production and 15 mg L Mg2+ was the optimal concentration for protein and carbohydrate production. The bioaccumulation mechanism of Mg2+ is the result of the interaction of the metabolic process and the mass transfer process. Hydrodynamics controls the external transport of Mg2+ from solvent to microalgae while cell physiology and their growth limitations control biochemical processes. Environmental stress such as a high concentration of Mg2+ induces the production of excessive ROS and activates a series of anti oxidants to defend against ROS by oxidizing cellular components such as SOD which acts on the detoxification of ROS. Esakkimuthu et al. 2016 studied that the growth of Scenedesmus obliquus was stagnant at about 0.8 g L when the concentration of Mg2+ was 150 mg L and above. Although the growth rate did not increase significantly in the case of excessive Mg2+ supply the lipid content of Scenedesmus obliquus changed dramatically with the change of Mg2+ supply which was more than 3 times higher than that of the control group. 2.2.2.7. Ca2+. There are two sources of Ca2+ in the cytoplasm of microalgae. One is that extracellular Ca2+ enters the cytoplasm through transporters on the cell membrane and the other is that Ca2+ in the intracellular calcium pool is released into the cytoplasm. Ca2+ can participate in the composition of cell structure and can also be used as a signal molecule to participate in the biotic and abiotic stress responses of cells. Calmodulin CaM calcineurin B-like protein CBL and calcium- dependent protein kinase CDPK are three types of Ca2+ sensors which can bind Ca2+ to regulate a series of downstream physiological and metabolic activities. Ca2+ directly activates NADPH oxidase to produce ROS by binding to the enzyme. In addition Ca2+ and CaM complexes activate nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide kinase NAD ki nase and further provide substrates to NADPH oxidase resulting in increased NADPH content. On the other hand ROS can regulate Ca2+ in the cytoplasm by activating calcium channels. In plants there is a crosstalk between ROS and calcium signaling pathways in response to different environmental stresses and different stimuli induce cells to produce different Ca2+ signals. Yang et al. 2022b studied that Ca2+ was involved in the regulation of TAG metabolism in microalgae under heat stress. Ca2+ entered microalgae cells through channel proteins promoted the expression of CaM and CDPK genes and then activated downstream transcription factors to promote the synthesis of TAG in microalgae cells. Ca2+ can up-regulate the activity of intracellular antioxidant enzymes such as SOD and peroxidase POD and alleviate excessive ROS by activating Ca2+ signal transduction. In addition calcium-regulated cyclic electron flows not only effectively reduce the damage of ROS to the photosynthetic system but also provide ATP for the biosynthesis of TAG Zhang et al. 2017 Shim et al. 2020 . Tang et al. 2022 studied the effect of Ca2+ on the performance growth and extracellular properties of microalgae-bacterial symbiotic systems for wastewater treatment and showed that Ca2+ content also significantly H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 8 affected the growth of microalgae. Low concentration of Ca2+ can pro mote the growth of microalgae and the removal of pollutants in water. The presence of Ca2+ can improve extracellular secretions and promote flocculation performance but it also leads to a decrease in the removal rate of pollutants in water. 3. Efficient lipid production of microalgae 3.1. Lipid production mechanism of microalgae Lipids in microalgae can be divided into polar and non-polar types. Polar lipids are mainly some lipids that constitute cell structure such as phospholipids and sterols are the main components of cell membranes and some polar lipids play a key role in signaling pathways as in termediates or precursors such as inositol lipids and sphingolipids. Non- polar lipids are mainly storage lipids most of which exist in microalgae in the form of TAG Sibi et al. 2016 . Microalgae with a high content of non-polar lipids were selected as candidates for biodiesel production. Lipid metabolism of microalgae is a complex project involving multiple enzymes Xie et al. 2020 including glycolysis TAC cycle β-oxidation and other physiological and biochemical processes which generally include lipid synthesis carbon chain extension liposome transport storage and so on. Fig. 3 shows the metabolic pathway of lipids in microalgae. At present it is believed that TAG synthesis in microalgae is mainly completed on the chloroplast membrane and endoplasmic re ticulum that is FFA are synthesized in the chloroplast and then the FFA are transported to the cytoplasm to further synthesize TAG on the endoplasmic reticulum. The main sites of fatty acid synthesis are chlo roplasts. First acetyl-CoA is catalyzed by ACCase to form Malonyl-CoA and then transferred to the fatty acid synthesis pathway FAS to form C16 and C18 long chains after many cycles Ananthi et al. 2021b . The acyl chain is then cut off by related enzymes to release the fatty acids and transfer them to the endoplasmic reticulum for further processing. The production and transfer of acetyl-CoA is A key regulatory step in the fatty acid synthesis and oxidation process and ACCase is a key rate-limiting enzyme in the fatty acid biosynthesis pathway and plays an important role in controlling lipid synthesis. Under nutritional restric tion or environmental stress half of the total lipid content is synthesized de novo while the rest of the accumulated lipids are produced from the recycling of existing fatty acids Chowdhury et al. 2019 . The synthesis site of TAG is mainly the endoplasmic reticulum and the synthesis pathway of TAG is mainly formed by the Kennedy pathway. The carbon-chain fatty acyl-Coenzyme A Acyl-CoA and glycerol-3-phosphate acyltransferase GPAT are the most important precursors which undergo a series of transformations to form TAG after being utilized by multiple acyltransferases Chhandama et al. 2021 . The mechanism of microalgae accumulation of lipids is to convert CO2 into microalgae s biomass through microalgae photosynthesis thus fixing carbon elements and then converting microalgae s carbon sub stances into lipids through induced reactions. All kinds of environmental stress and genetic metabolism regulation can promote the production and accumulation of TAG in microalgae. These stresses lead to a meta bolic imbalance in microalgae cells inhibit most of the basic metabolic processes and activate the expression of lipid metabolism synthesis pathways and related enzymes Xing et al. 2021 . In this chapter various stress regulation methods used by microalgae will be reviewed to achieve efficient lipid production of microalgae. 3.2. Method of efficient lipid production by microalgae Microalgae is considered to be the most promising raw material for biodiesel production because of its rapid growth rate and efficient lipid accumulation ability. Environmental stress and genetic metabolic regulation have been used to increase the lipid content of microalgae during the culture stage. Environmental stress such as nutrient limita tion light intensity temperature pH and CO2 can accumulate lipids and multiple coupling environmental stress can also better increase lipid accumulation. The stress of environmental factors slowed down cell proliferation which could be replaced by the two-stage culture method and the biomass and lipid content could be improved. Although envi ronmental stress is a simple and effective way to promote lipid pro duction and accumulation a large number of studies on genetic and metabolic regulation such as genetic engineering have the unique ability to precisely control the targeting mechanism in cells to induce increased lipid accumulation. 3.2.1. Environmental factor stress 3.2.1.1. Nutrient limitation. Nutrient limitation is considered to be an effective strategy for microalgae lipid production. The provision of nu trients such as N P C Mg Ca and Fe to the microalgae culture medium is an important nutrient for the metabolic pathways related to micro algae cell division growth photosynthesis and lipid accumulation Liyanaarachchi et al. 2020 . Mg contributes to the synthesis of plant Fig. 3. Mechanism of intracellular lipid accumulation in microalgae Khoo et al. 2023 . H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 9 proteins which constitute a part of certain enzymes such as enzymes involved in carbon fixation and metabolism during photosynthesis. Mg acts as an enzyme activator such as activating ACCase an enzyme that promotes fatty acid biosynthesis Srinuanpan et al. 2018 . Ca is an integral part of the cell wall and cell membrane structure which pro motes coordination between cells and environmental stimuli by acting as an intracellular messenger Esakkimuthu et al. 2016 . N and phos phorus P are the main elements of ribose protein and DNA in cells. N and phosphorus P deficiency can seriously affect intracellular meta bolism. Under nutrient deficiency or limitation conditions microalgae accumulate more lipids and carbohydrates to cope with adverse envi ronments and the degradation of nitrogen-containing compounds such as chlorophyll and protein leads to more carbon and energy available for lipid accumulation Shi et al. 2020 . P affects the carbon flow be tween starch and lipid synthesis pathways by inhibiting the activity of ADP glucan pyrophosphorylase AGPase a key enzyme in the first step of starch synthesis Shahid et al. 2020 . Srinuanpan et al. 2018 studied the effect of nutrient limitation on the lipid content of two microalgae. When P was limited the lipid content of Scenedesmus obli quus SIT06 and Micractinium reisseri SIT04 was 40.3 and 30.5 respectively. When N was limited the lipid content increased signifi cantly reaching 56.8 and 36.6 respectively. It is worth noting that N limitation can better increase the lipid content of microalgae than P limitation. Omar Faruque et al. 2020 showed that the increase in the C N ratio in algal cells under N stress reduced protein synthesis and carbon was stored as intracellular carbohydrates and lipids. Lipid accumulation in algal cells under N stress activated the activity of acetyl-CoA and acetyl-CoA carboxylase to recalibrate the distribution of starch and lipids. Dong et al. 2020 found that algae cells preferentially synthesize starch. With the prolongation of stress time starch gradually degrades and the degraded carbon skeleton is mainly used for lipid synthesis. Microalgae tend to synthesize neutral lipids to produce energy to reduce oxidative damage caused by stress conditions. 3.2.1.2. Light conditions. As a photosynthetic autotrophic organism light plays a key role in the growth biochemical composition and lipid accumulation of microalgae. In the photoreaction stage of photosyn thesis microalgae use light to decompose water into oxygen protons and electrons. In the dark reaction stage protons and electrons are used to reduce CO2 to starch through the Calvin cycle. Starch can be decomposed and metabolized to form fatty acids and TAG Khoo et al. 2023 . The light-driven photooxidation process is directly related to carbon fixation through the Calvin cycle. Higher light intensity produces more heat dissipation. When the optimal irradiance is achieved any further increase in light intensity will damage microalgae cells for photoinhibition. The optimal light intensity for the growth of most microalgae is in the range of 200 400 μmol m2 s Shekh et al. 2022 . Photorespiration is related to the oxygenase activity of the RuBisCO enzyme. Under strong light the accumulation of oxygen O2 will lead to an increase in the local O2 CO2 ratio thereby reducing the activity of carboxylase and increasing the activity of oxygenase. Excessive elec trons are generated in photosystem II that react with the oxygen pro duced by photosynthesis leading to the formation of oxygen free radicals which affect the growth and lipid accumulation of microalgae Sousa et al. 2012 . Light is the energy source required for the photo synthesis of microalgae. Light intensity wavelength and photoperiod are important parameters for optimization to increase lipid content. Chin et al. 2023 optimized the light intensity nitrogen concentration and culture volume parameters to improve the lipid content of micro algae. Under the optimized conditions of light intensity of 135 μmol m2 s nitrogen concentration of 5 g L and culture volume of 5 L it was found that Chaetoceros muelleri and Isochrysis galbana produced up to 43.4 dry weight lipid content and required fatty acid characteris tics including high concentrations of saturated fatty acids and mono unsaturated fatty acids of which oleic acid ratio was as high as 27.7 which was selected as a promising candidate for microalgae biodiesel. Ren et al. 2020 studied the effects of different light sources on the growth and lipid accumulation of Scenedesmus sp. When the photoperiod was 6 18 h the biomass concentration was 3.2 g L and the lipid content was as high as 40.3 . Sirisuk et al. 2018 studied the effects of wavelength stress on the biomass and lipid content of three microalgae using blue green and red light-emitting diodes LEDs . After green LED irradiation the maximum lipid content of Nannochloropsis salina Iso chrysis galbana and Phaeodactylum tricornutum reached 49.4 63.3 and 62.0 of dry weight respectively. 3.2.1.3. Temperature. Temperature affects the photosynthetic rate growth and lipid accumulation of microalgae. Below the optimum growth temperature temperature increase has a positive effect on photosynthesis and cell division. If the temperature change exceeds the optimal range it may lead to overgrowth inhibition or death of microalgae cells. Different microalgae have different tolerance ranges to temperature. The thermophilic microalgae growing on the wooden structure of the cooling tower of the thermal power plant in central Mexico can survive at temperatures up to 40 C based on the heat- resistant molecules that make up their cells and their metabolism is based on heat-stable enzymes Covarrubias et al. 2016 . Higher tem peratures increase the production of biomass especially carbohydrates and lipids which may be related to the involvement of the thermophilic enzyme system in sucrose production while lower temperatures generally reduce the activity of carboxylases. Most microalgae survive at an ideal temperature of 20 30 C Barati et al. 2019 . Converti et al. 2009 studied the effects of temperature and nitrogen concentration on the lipid content of Nannochloropsis oculata and Chlorella vulgaris. When the temperature increased from 20 C to 25 C the lipid content of N. oculata increased from 7.9 to 14.9 and when the temperature increased from 25 C to 30 C the lipid content of C. vulgaris decreased from 14.7 to 5.9 . When the nitrogen concentration in the medium was reduced by 75 the lipid content of N. oculata and C. vulgaris increased by 2 3 times. Chaisutyakorn et al. 2018 studied the effect of temperature on the lipid content of marine microalgae Chaetoceros sp. FIKU035 Tetraselmis suecica FIKU032 and Nannochloropsis sp. FIKU036 which were cultured at different temperatures of 25 40 C. The results showed that the lipid content of all microalgae decreased with the in crease in temperature. The lipid content of marine microalgae FIKU035 was as high as 66.7 1.3 mg L day and 61.4 2.9 mg L day at 25 C and 30 C. Temperature determines the activity of enzymes and enzyme activity is the key to regulating lipid accumula tion. Therefore culture temperature has a direct impact on microalgae lipid production Sachdeva et al. 2016 . 3.2.1.4. pH. The pH affects many physiological mechanisms related to the growth and metabolism lipid accumulation and ion absorption of micro algae cells Khalil et al. 2010 . The pH determines the solubility and availability of CO2 and other essential nutrients as well as the ac tivity of intracellular and cell wall-related enzymes Juneja et al. 2013 . In the closed medium the pH fluctuates during the day and night. The consumption of bicarbonate and CO2 by photosynthesis during the day will make the pH of the medium alkaline while the CO2 produced during night respiration will make the pH acidic. Acidic pH interferes with cell nutrient absorption and cell meta bolism. Alkaline pH reduces the affinity of microalgae to CO2 in creases the flexibility of the mother cell delays the completion of the cell cycle and interferes with the cell division process Vadlamani et al. 2017 . Owing to the sensitivity of photosynthetic organs and related enzymes to extreme pH conditions deviating from the optimal pH will affect photosynthetic efficiency and it is crucial to maintain the pH of the culture within the optimal range. Most H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 10 microalgae species grow best near neutral pH 7.0 7.6 but algae such as Chlorella can survive in a wide pH range Juneja et al. 2013 . Song et al. 2023a found that the microalgae strain Parachlorella kessleri R-3 can accumulate a large amount of biomass and lipids in a wide pH range of 3 11 and the pH of the medium can be gradually adjusted to near neutral during culture. Under the initial pH of 7 the maximum biomass of microalgae was 6.9 g L the lipid content was 45.1 and the lipid productivity was 340.9 mg L day. The change in pH of the medium will change the lipid accumulation of micro algae. Compared with the lipid content of the control group at pH 7.0 Chlamydomonas reinhardtii showed higher lipid accumulation at pH 7.8 which was three times that of the control group Ochoa-Al faro et al. 2019 . 3.2.1.5. CO2. Among the atmospheric pollutants CO2 is considered to be the most important one that causes the greenhouse effect. Microalgae can absorb the largest environmental perpetrator CO2 in the culture process to combat climate change which makes microalgae the best candidate for biodiesel production Tarafdar et al. 2023 . Like all plants CO2 affects the growth and lipid accumulation of microalgae by affecting photosynthesis. Microalgae can use solar energy to combine water with CO2 to produce biomass. Similar to the optimal light in tensity and temperature there is an optimal CO2 concentration which is beneficial to the metabolic activity growth and lipid accumulation of microalgae. Microalgae need an appropriate amount of dissolved CO2 during the growth process. For photosynthetic microalgae CO2 ensures the carbon supply of photosynthesis Barati et al. 2022 . Mohsenpour and Willoughby 2016 studied the effect of the combination of blue light and 15 CO2 on the lipid content of microalgae. When the CO2 ventilation increased from 5 to 15 the lipid content of microalgae increased by six times. Khan et al. 2022 found that total lipid content increased from 8.0 to 22.0 of dry biomass under 15 CO2 venti lation. Too little CO2 will lead to lipid reduction over slow metabolism and too much CO2 will cause damage to the growth and lipid production of microalgae. This is because the unused CO2 in the culture will be converted into carbonic acid H2CO3 reducing the pH of the culture resulting in acidification of the medium and changing cell growth and metabolic pathways Sibi et al. 2016 . Faruque et al. 2020 studied the changes in lipids in Scenedesmus dimorphus under CO2 concentration and N P ratio. When the ratio of nitrogen to phosphorus N P was 1 1 6 CO2 was introduced. The maximum lipid content was 31.6 of biomass dry weight. The results showed that the lipid accumulation in micro algae biomass could be increased by a favorable NP ratio and appro priate CO2 supplement. With the continuous increase of global CO2 emissions we must combine CO2 to cultivate microalgae. Microalgae transform into high-value compounds by absorbing carbon sources and ultimately achieve a win-win goal of protecting the environment and high biomass content. 3.2.1.6. Salinity stress. Salt is involved in the physiological and biochemical pathways of microalgae growth reproduction and fatty acid metabolism. Appropriate salt addition will increase the lipid con tent of microalgae Pei et al. 2022 . Salt stress causes osmotic pressure differences in microalgae cells causing stress response and forcing microalgae to adapt to new environments and change their metabolism. At the same time salt stress also affects the oxidative stress and fatty acid metabolism mechanism of microalgae cells thereby increasing lipid accumulation Elloumi et al. 2020 Song et al. 2022a . Teh et al. 2021 pointed out that the addition of an appropriate amount of NaCl could promote lipid accumulation in microalgae. When the salinity increases from 5 to 30 ppt the carbon distribution may be transferred from starch to lipid synthesis. Under high salt stress lipid content increased and starch and protein content decreased which was due to the up-regulation of ACCase the key enzyme responsible for lipid synthesis and the down-regulation of AGPase the key enzyme responsible for starch synthesis . Lipid content increased first and then decreased and lipid content reached a maximum of 63.5 at a salinity of 15 ppt. Another study Can et al. 2016 also found that with the increase in NaCl concentration lipid production first increased and then decreased and reached a peak at 2.75 M NaCl with a lipid production rate of 39.7 4.5 . Pancha et al. 2015 studied the physiological and biochemical changes of microalgae Scenedesmus sp. CCNM 1077 induced by salt stress. In the single-stage culture process when 33 mM NaCl was added the lipid content was 33.1 . In the two-stage culture process compared with the single stage 400 mM NaCl stress for 3 days resulted in 24.8 lipid containing 74.9 neutral lipid and higher biomass. In future research we can try to use the medium configured by seawater to cultivate freshwater algae because the ocean accounts for the vast majority of the world. Seawater contains a large amount of NaCl and has high salinity which is used to stress the cultivation of freshwater algae to observe growth and oil production. 3.2.1.7. Heavy metal stress. Microalgae has a great ability to absorb heavy metals. Low concentrations of heavy metals have a great impact on the physiological and biochemical processes of microalgae such as growth photosynthesis lipid content and fatty acid composition. Heavy metals may induce the formation of ROS resulting in oxidative damage to proteins lipids and thiol peptides and activate the antioxidant system Xing et al. 2023 activate the protective mechanism of microalgae change the activity of reactive oxygen scavenging enzymes and the ac tivity of enzymes related to secondary metabolites such as increasing TAG to protect microalgae cells from oxidative damage Aravind et al. 2022 . Some heavy metals such as Cu Zn Fe Mn Ni and Cr affect the growth and lipid accumulation of microalgae cells. Xie et al. 2021 found that metal ions can affect the growth rate and lipid content of microalgae such as trace element Fe3+ which can participate in the enzymatic reaction of photosynthesis. Mg2+ affects various key meta bolic processes and physiological pathways of microalgae and is an important component of chlorophyll structure. Cu and zinc Zn are the most abundant heavy metals found in industrial wastewater Martí nez-Macias et al. 2019 . Hamed et al. 2022 Chlorella sorokiniana and Scenedesmus acuminatus added Cu2+ and Zn2+ to the culture medium respectively the lipid content increased and the removal rate of Cu2+ and Zn2+ also increased. Song et al. 2023b studied the cell growth lipid production and Cr6+ removal of Parachlorella kessleri R-3 at pH 3.5 and 15 C. It was found that a low concentration of Cr6+ 0.5 2 mg L promoted the growth of algae and higher than 5 mg L of Cr6+ inhibited the growth. The lipid content reached a maximum of 61.0 at 5 mg L Cr6+ and the removal efficiency of Cr6+ was the highest at 0.5 mg L Cr6+ treatment reaching 91.0 . It showed that microalgae were suit able as heavy metal adsorbents and raw materials for biodiesel pro duction. Dammak et al. 2022 added different concentrations of toxic metals such as Ni Cr and Co to the medium of Tetraselmis sp. and studied the effects of these metals on lipid synthesis by binary mixed design. The results showed that in the optimal binary mixture of 6 mg L Ni 54.5 and Cr 45.5 the lipid content reached up to 31.0 of the cell s dry weight. However high concentrations of heavy metals can also lead to adverse consequences such as the production of reactive oxygen species. Negative effects such as inhibition of chlorophyll syn thesis and enzyme activity Song et al. 2022b . 3.2.2. Genetic and metabolic regulation The above environmental factor stress has been shown to promote lipid accumulation in microalgae but it also brings many drawbacks such as slowing cell proliferation and inaccurate regulation to increase lipid content. Genetic and metabolic regulation may solve this problem. At present a large number of techniques such as genetic modification and metabolic regulation engineering are being studied for this appli cation. They have the unique ability to accurately control the targeting mechanism in cells to induce increased lipid accumulation without H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 11 affecting other changes Mulgund 2022 . Using the understanding of lipid metabolism pathways they are manipulated to produce valuable molecules such as overexpressing important rate-limiting enzymes in lipid metabolism or controlling lipid synthesis with the help of genetic engineering. 3.2.2.1. Microalgae-bacteria. Bacteria are prokaryotes with small size simple structure rapid metabolism and rapid reproduction which are widely distributed in land sea and lakes Yu et al. 2022 . There are many relationships between bacteria and microalgae in aquatic envi ronments including mutual benefit symbiosis and parasitism. Bacteria can produce nutrients CO2 and other substances by decomposing organic matter in the environment which can be utilized by microalgae. Microalgae produce oxygen through photosynthesis for bacterial con sumption thus forming a mutually beneficial symbiotic relationship. The low efficiency of the traditional microalgae monoculture lipid production process limits the development of microalgae biodiesel. Microalgae-bacteria consortium can not only produce a large amount of biomass and lipids but bacteria can greatly increase the biomass and lipid productivity of microalgae through carbon exchange Chen et al. 2019 . Zhao et al. 2014 used landfill leachate to culture a high-density microalgae-bacteria consortium. Up to 90.0 of total nitrogen in landfill leachate was removed and the maximum lipid productivity and carbon fixation were 24.1 mg L day and 65.8 mg L day respectively. Zhou et al. 2020 screened highly efficient heterotrophic ammonia-oxidizing bacteria FN5 from urban sewage treatment systems which had the best effect on promoting the growth of lipid-rich micro algae Chlorella pyrenoidosa . The biomass and lipid content were 14.8 and 13.6 higher than those in the blank control experiment without FN5 respectively. The biomass and lipid content of microalgae reached 0.4 g L and 39.0 respectively after the Chlorella pyrenoidosa-FN5 consortium was cultured in urban sewage. Gao et al. 2022 studied a new type of microalgae-bacteria coupled reactor that combines acid-producing fermentation and microalgae culture for microalgae mariculture and wastewater treatment. Volatile fatty acids VFAs pro duced in the dark chamber are migrated to the light chamber for microalgae utilization thereby alleviating the feedback inhibition of pH drop and acid-producing fermentation. In the fatty acid biosynthesis pathway ko00061 under mixed nutrient culture conditions three high-abundance acetyl-CoA carboxylase genes and eight downstream functional genes were up-regulated which contributed to fatty acid production and TAG synthesis. Shen et al. 2022 studied the co-culture of three microalgae and three bacteria with different inoculation ratios. The results showed that the best promotion effect was 1 1 co-culture of Chlorella pyrenoidosa and Rhodobacter capsulatus and its lipid produc tivity was 2.8 times that of the control group. Stable isotope labeling proteomics iTRAQ analysis showed that light and bacteria PSB played a positive role in the TCA cycle and uronic acid cycle of micro algae but the utilization of CO2 and photosynthesis decreased indi cating that PSB promoted the metabolism of organic carbon utilization and weakened the utilization of inorganic carbon in microalgae. Microalgae-bacteria symbiosis can not only enhance the growth and lipid production of microalgae but also promote the removal and transformation of nutrients. 3.2.2.2. Genetic engineering. Microalgae use sunlight as an energy source for metabolism and synthesize and accumulate lipids by using atmospheric CO2 as a carbon source. Unfortunately microalgae lipid productivity is very low and usually accumulates in the cytoplasm which requires the use of genetic engineering to enhance microalgae lipid synthesis. Genetic engineering such as gene overexpression and mutation breeding can improve the defects of slow growth low lipid content and poor environmental adaptability of wild-type microalgae to improve the feasibility of biodiesel production from microalgae. Table 1 shows the application of genetic engineering to lipid production in microalgae. The expression and non-expression of various lipid synthesis-related genes can increase the lipid production level of microalgae Brar et al. 2021 . Lin et al. 2018 showed that the exog enous MLCA gene i.e. 678 bp with the highest catalytic activity was applied to overexpress in Chlorella vulgaris and the biomass protein content and lipid accumulation of the algae were increased. The lipid content reached 1.1 g L which was 2.2 times that of the wild type and accelerated carbon capture and fixation. Genetic changes in microalgae may contribute to the development of high-yield oleaginous strains but they have some disadvantages such as high production costs low suc cess rate of transformation and unstable genetic characteristics Alishah Aratboni et al. 2019 . Transcriptional regulation is another way to in crease microalgae lipids. Just as the co-expression of multiple enzymes involved in lipid synthesis can increase lipid accumulation transcrip tional regulation can lead to the control of metabolic flux because transcription factors can control multiple regulatory points in targeted metabolic pathways. For example the first key step in fatty acid biosynthesis is the conversion of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA catalyzed by ACCase Su et al. 2023 . These successes demonstrate the potential of genetic engineering in lipid production but the unknown threat makes the transition from laboratory to commercial genetic engineering more challenging than it seems. Because the environmental impact is uncertain it is a great risk to release genetically modified microalgae into the outdoor environment. Therefore we must establish a compre hensive process to analyze the potential threat of microalgae genetic engineering to humans and the natural environment so that we can have a more in-depth study of this. 3.2.2.3. Microbial contamination. The combined culture of microalgae and microbial systems can not only produce more biomass and lipids but also consume more nutrients to better treat wastewater. The study of Table 1 Application of genetic engineering to lipid production in microalgae. Species Genetic engineering Performance Reference Chlorella pyrenoidosa Differentially expressed genes were up-regulated under the action of plant hormones Lipid content was 3.7 times that of the control Yang et al. 2023a Chlamydomonas reinhardtii CRISPRi-mediated phosphoenolpyruvate carboxylase CrPEPC1 mutant gene Lipid yield was increased by 94.2 4.2 compared with wild-type Kao and Ng 2017 Chlorella pyrenoidosa Mutant mutagenized by ARTP atmospheric and room temperature plasma . Lipid productivity was increased by 16.9 and showed good genetic stability Cao et al. 2017 Chlorella pyrenoidosa 60Co-γ irradiation mutagenesis Lipid content increased by 20.8 and high saturated fatty acid contenta Wang et al. 2018 Chlorella Vulgaris Cas9 with sgRNA designed on omega-3 fatty acid desaturase fad3 gene Lipid productivity was up to 46.0 compared with the control group Lin and Ng 2020 Nannochloropsis gaditana Homolog of fungal Zn II 2Cys6-encoding genes Lipid content was increased by a factor of 2 and the growth was not affected Ajjawi et al. 2017 Nannochloropsis oceanica The bZIP-family regulator NobZIP77 enhances the transcription of diacylglyceryl acyltransferase genes in the absence of nitrogen Lipid production doubled compared to the control groupa Zhang et al. 2022a a The experimental values of all experiments were very similar with no signif icant difference p-values for 98.0 Ahmed et al. 2023 . Cost-benefit analysis shows that the use of nanoparticles may reduce the overall production cost of microalgae biodiesel by 2.5 4 times which improves the prospects of the commercial feasibility of a microalgae biodiesel system based on nanotechnology Rana and Pra japati 2022 . Nowadays magnetic nano-catalysts are more popular than bulk nano-catalysts for their advantages of no mass transfer resis tance fast deactivation and high recovery rate in the separation process. Functionalized magnetic nano-catalysts are more attractive for biodiesel production. Further research and development of nano-catalysts with high activity and selectivity for industrial scale should be carried out. 4.5. Preparation of microalgae biodiesel by non-catalytic reaction In the process of microalgae biodiesel production the addition of catalysts has brought many disadvantages to us. It is necessary to develop a new process that allows simultaneous treatment of microalgae biomass without using catalysts. The emerging process method that meets all the above standards is the supercritical method. The super critical process fluid has high diffusion and dissolution ability at high temperatures and pressure to convert lipids into biodiesel in one step without using catalysts which greatly reduces the energy consumption of the process. Another emerging process is the ILs method. ILs have a large number of anion and cation combinations which have the ad vantages of relatively high chemical and thermal stability non- flammability low volatility low melting point and recyclability and are called green solvents . ILs can dissolve stubborn biopolymers by destroying the hydrogen bonds of lignin and cellulose in the cell wall and catalyze to increase biodiesel yield. In contrast the supercritical method and the ionic liquid method simplify the product purification stage and are more environmentally friendly. 4.5.1. Preparation of microalgae biodiesel by supercritical method The traditional process is energy-consuming and costly requiring a long reaction time and additional catalyst separation and recovery steps. In addition the disposal of the catalyst is also harmful to the environ ment. Therefore Kusdiana and Saka introduced a supercritical trans esterification process for the synthesis of biodiesel. Supercritical fluids are fluids whose temperature and pressure are above their critical points. These fluids have high diffusivity and solubility and their den sity can be adjusted by changing temperature and pressure. The main advantages of the supercritical process are i High temperature and high pressure 240 290 C and 9.3 30 MPa successfully destroyed the cell wall ii Since no catalyst was usually added the purification step was not required after the process iii Water and FFA can be present in large quantities in wet algae biomass which can improve the efficiency of supercritical conversion process Jazzar et al. 2015 . The supercrit ical fluid SCM process is an advanced efficient environmentally friendly and low-energy biodiesel conversion technology but the diffi culty of heat recovery for commercial use is still the disadvantage of the technology Qadeer et al. 2021 . Rathnam and Madras 2019 studied using Shizochitrium limacinum microalgae as raw material to prepare biodiesel by supercritical methanol. The reaction was carried out at 270 C and 20 MPa and the biodiesel yield reached more than 90.0 in only 40 min. Rathnam et al. 2020 also studied the synthesis of fatty acid ethyl ester FAEEs in supercritical ethanol and supercritical ethyl acetate using dried microalgae as raw materials. Fig. 4 shows the effects of time and temperature on the conversion of Schizochitrium limacinum microalgae FAEEs from ethanol and ethyl acetate. The pressure was maintained at 20 MPa. The transesterification of ethanol reached 95.0 at 593 K and the biodiesel yield of ethyl acetate also reached more than 60.0 at 653 K. At the same time the pseudo-first-order kinetics and Arrhenius equation were used to evaluate the rate constant and activa tion energy of the two systems. The activation energies of ethanol and ethyl acetate systems were 67.1 and 78.5 kJ mol respectively. Compared with the ethyl acetate system the reaction rate of ethanol is higher. However the use of supercritical methanol or ethanol trans esterification is not economically feasible and consumes a lot of energy. Some cosolvents or solid catalysts can be appropriately added to improve this shortcoming. Nowadays there are also many fluids used to improve the efficiency of the biodiesel process. For example CO2 as a process fluid has a high diffusion rate and high solubility. Supercritical CO2 SC CO2 extraction of microalgae lipids has the advantages of low viscosity low tension high emission and easy separation. Khorram dashti et al. 2021 studied the effect of SC-CO2 on Chlorella vulgaris on biodiesel production. The fatty acid content extracted by the SC-CO2 method was the best at 370 bar and 40 C. Taher et al. 2015 used the SC-CO2 method to extract lipids from Nannochlorpsis sp. and converted them into biodiesel. The results showed that the yield of biodiesel was 35.0 higher than that in the traditional method. 4.5.2. Preparation of microalgae biodiesel by ionic liquid method In recent years the production of biodiesel from microalgae cata lyzed by ILs has become a new environmentally friendly production route. ILs were used as solvents and catalysts for the sustainable pro duction of biodiesel by microalgae respectively. ILs are organic salts H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 16 that are liquid at room temperature. Salts are amphoteric and mainly composed of an organic cation and an inorganic or organic anion. The second chapter also mentions the content of anions and cations. Due to their chemical properties when ionic liquids contact cells they destroy the cell wall and membrane resulting in lipid release. The non-volatility and thermal stability of ILs makes them a viable alternative to volatile organic solvents. Owing to the low vapor pressure fast reaction time and strong recovery and reuse ability of ionic liquids their activity may not be reduced even after repeated use Lozano et al. 2020 . Mal ekghasemi et al. 2021 synthesized four types of tetrabutylphospho nium carboxylate ionic liquids for the preparation of biodiesel by in-situ transesterification of Chlorella vulgaris. The main candidate ionic liquid catalyst was tetrabutylphosphonium formate. The yield was as high as 98.0 2.5 after optimization using the response surface. The reus ability of the ionic liquid was confirmed and the loss between recycling was less than 2 . Brønsted acidic ionic liquids can convert FFA and TAG into biodiesel without pretreatment which helps to reduce the pro duction cost of biodiesel Deshpande et al. 2022 . Khiratkar et al. 2018 prepared two Brønsted acidic ionic liquid catalysts containing benzimidazole and imidazolium cations and two alkaline ionic liquid catalysts. The results showed that the benzimidazole-based Brønsted acidic ionic liquid catalyst BBAIL catalyzed biodiesel yield was the highest reaching 96.0 and the catalyst could be recycled. In addition the addition of some more advanced ionic liquids such as supported ionic liquids and ionic liquid enzyme catalysts improves the catalytic active sites of microalgae biodiesel. Cheng et al. 2022 synthesized a novel efficient bifunctional catalyst by modifying the metal-organic framework IRMOF-3 with Brønsted acidic ionic liquid 1-butylsulfo nate-3-methylimidazolium bisulfate BSO3HMIm HSO4 IL . Through the acid-base reaction between the sulfonic acid group of ILs and the amino group of IRMOF-3 to form a chemical bond ILs are fixed on the IRMOF-3 skeleton. The bifunctional catalyst exhibited acid-base syner gistic catalysis and the synergistic effect of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid which could effectively catalyze the esterification and trans esterification of microalgae lipids. Under the optimal reaction condi tions the biodiesel yield was 98.2 . Since the strong ionic bond the catalyst has good reusability and the catalytic efficiency can still reach 85.5 after 6 cycles. Loading ILs can increase the surface area between the reactant and the catalyst and hydrophobic ILs are also excellent cocatalysts that bind to the enzyme which reduces the possibility of enzyme inactivation. Binary ILs mixtures have been used to develop one-step systems. The mixtures are hydrophobic with anions and cat ions and a long alkyl side chain providing a special reaction medium for biodiesel synthesis. It also can dissolve cellulose biomass with hy drophilicity. The dried Chlorella vulgaris was incubated in an appropriate binary mixture of ILs at 110 C. After cooling at 60 C it was converted into biodiesel by immobilized lipase for lipid extraction. Biodiesel production can be as high as 100.0 within 2 h at 60 C Ong et al. 2021 . Nonetheless ILs like any other catalysts are not intrinsically green and environmentally friendly. In particular the most utilized SFILs which bear an acidic -SO3H functionalized group in the cation of ILs are of extremely strong acidity and thus corrosive which could cause serious equipment corrosion. In addition high cost and ILs recovery are also major obstacles to its industrial application. The research and design of efficient and low-cost IL combined with microwave and ultrasonic-assisted technology is an option to achieve a more environ mentally friendly and sustainable biodiesel production route. 4.6. Microalgae catalytic conversion of biodiesel method summary Microalgae biodiesel production technology has been widely studied and applied for 50 years. Lipid TAG reacts with methanol or other alcohols to form FAAEs and glycerol under the action of a catalyst which is called a transesterification reaction. In the traditional two-step transesterification process lipid extraction and transesterification are divided into two steps to produce biodiesel. Due to the complexity of the traditional transesterification process the in-situ transesterification of the one-step process has become more popular in recent years. 4.6.1. Two-step transesterification method The traditional two-step transesterification method for biodiesel production has been applied for decades and the research is relatively mature including two steps namely lipid extraction and trans esterification Leung et al. 2010 . First the dehydrated and dried pre treated microalgae is broken by mechanical force or chemical solvent to extract lipids from biomass. Then lipid TAG and methanol undergo a transesterification reaction under a catalyst to form FAAE. However the traditional two-step transesterification process is not economically feasible. The dehydration drying and lipid extraction process consumes a lot of energy and cost accounting for 3 15 of the total production cost of microalgae biodiesel Fasaei et al. 2018 . The process also re quires the use of a large amount of solvent and requires the use of powerful machinery equipped with heating and stirring capabilities wasting a lot of energy and raw materials. In addition some downstream technologies such as centrifugation and extraction have the disadvan tages of high energy consumption and low processing capacity which limits the commercialization of these methods. Therefore in-situ transesterification was introduced as a one-step process to eliminate the two-stage lipid extraction and transesterification reaction process. 4.6.2. In-situ transesterification method In-situ transesterification ISTE is a one-step process that uses oily raw materials to extract lipid and catalyze the conversion to FAAEs Ideris et al. 2022 Kim et al. 2019 . In the in situ transesterification Fig. 4. Effect of time and temperature on the conversion of FAEEs from Schizochitrium limacinum microalgae using a ethanol and b ethyl acetate Rathnam et al. 2020 . H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 17 process methanol has dual functions as a chemical solvent and reactant for lipid extraction thereby reducing the input of chemical solvents. This technology eliminates expensive and tedious cell destruction and drying steps minimizes lipid extraction and solvent recovery steps greatly reduces the energy consumption of the process and reduces initial investment and indirect costs Goh et al. 2019 . Lem oes et al. 2016 investigated the production of FAEE from Chlorella sp. by in-situ transesterification and then compared it with the conversion of FAEE by extraction and transesterification extraction-esterification . The results showed that in situ transesterification increased the yield of FAEE compared with the extraction-esterification process and confirmed that in situ transesterification was an effective environmentally friendly and green approach. In-situ transesterification is considered to be a major improvement in the commercial production of biodiesel from microalgae. 4.7. Preparation of microalgae biofuels by thermochemical conversion method Thermochemical conversion process is one of the most preferred technologies for biomass value-added which has the advantages of high conversion efficiency and low capital cost. Microalgae biomass ther mochemical conversion technology mainly includes gasification lique faction and pyrolysis. Gasification is a thermochemical reaction that uses oxygen or oxygen-containing substances in the air as gasification agents to convert the combustible part of biomass fuel into combustible gas under high-temperature conditions mainly hydrogen carbon monoxide and methane which can recycle a large amount of crop waste and reduce environmental pollution. Liquefaction and pyrolysis can convert algal biomass into low molecular weight bio-oil and high energy density bio-crude oil respectively. Hydrothermal liquefaction HTL is a process of converting wet algae biomass into liquid biofuels at a tem perature of 200 450 C a pressure of 4 35 Mpa and in the presence of water. Compared with the traditional pyrolysis process it does not require expensive and tedious pre-drying of biomass has lower tem perature requirements requires less energy consumption and can pro cess different biomass at the same time. However the main limitations of HTL are the possibility of corrosion coke and tar formation blockage and reactor interruption. Co-liquefaction is also a thermochemical pro cess including the production of high-yield and high-quality bio-oil from a variety of biomass. The difference between liquefaction and co- liquefaction is that single raw material liquefaction and multi-raw ma terial co-liquefaction. It can customize the composition of bio-oil for downstream applications and can make full use of the various biomass obtained to control the composition and properties of bio-crude oil. Pyrolysis is the thermal degradation of biomass by heating under anaerobic conditions and the production of bio-oil by heating at me dium and high temperatures 350 700 C or in the presence of cata lysts. Bio-oil not only has a high bio-oil yield but also contains high hydrocarbons and octane numbers. The main limitation of pyrolysis is the existence of high oxygen and high water content in the pyrolysis liquid. The pyrolysis liquid can tolerate the addition of some water but before the phase separation occurs the amount of water added to the liquid is required. In other words adding a small amount of water can reduce the viscosity which is useful but adding too much water will reduce the calorific value which means that more liquid is needed to achieve the required amount Bridgwater 2012 . During the pyrolysis process the pipeline engine and turbine are blocked by the formation of tar with a boiling point above 360 C and low H C molar ratio. It is necessary to reduce the formation of tar and promote the normal reac tion through higher reaction temperature and the presence of a catalyst. The bio-oil obtained from the above process has unsatisfactory charac teristics such as water content high sulfur nitrogen and oxygen con tent high viscosity and long-chain hydrocarbons which limits its application as a biofuel. It needs to be further upgraded to become a viable biofuel. It can be upgraded by hydrogenation supercritical fluid SCFs and catalytic cracking to improve the stability of bio-oil reduce its aging potential reduce its oxygen content reduce its viscosity and improve the quality of bio-oil Arun et al. 2021 2022 . 5. Application prospect of microalgae biodiesel The research on microalgae biodiesel production mainly focuses on one or several steps of the whole microalgae to biodiesel process microalgae screening culture harvesting drying lipid extraction and catalytic conversion to biodiesel. The production of biodiesel from microalgae is roughly divided into four steps i Microalgae production algal strain screening and microalgae culture ii Harvest solid-liquid separation iii Extraction of high additional compounds such as lipids destruction of the cell wall and lipid extraction iv Lipid trans esterification to produce biodiesel catalyst and catalytic conversion method selection . Microalgae with high biomass and high oil yield were screened. A low-cost green and efficient method was proposed to stimulate microalgae to accumulate more lipids and environmentally friendly and efficient catalysts and catalytic methods were used to produce high-yield and high-quality microalgae biodiesel. Microalgae have been proven to be a promising and attractive raw material for biofuel production as their short growth cycle high biomass yield and lipid content good carbon sequestration capacity high value-added products and environmental sustainability which can be applied in different fields such as food feed nutritional drugs pharmaceuticals and biofuels Caporgno and Mathys 2018 . Microalgae biodiesel can be used as a green alternative fuel for petrochemical diesel. When mixed with diesel A20 D80 the thermal efficiency was the highest and hy drocarbon HC carbon monoxide CO particulate matter PM and smoke emissions were less Arun et al. 2021 . Nevertheless microalgae biodiesel faces many challenges in its production and commercialization Nazloo et al. 2022 . Although many advances have been made in laboratory-scale research a series of challenges such as production economic feasibility technological improvement and method innova tion and environmental pollution control need to be considered in the commercialization process i The cost of microalgae cultivation is high and a lot of time and resources e.g. water are needed for cultivation. In the process of microalgae harvesting a large amount of energy is consumed which is energy intensive ii Genetic engineering is a suit able method to enhance microalgae biomass accumulation. However more safety guidelines are needed for transgenic microalgae and their environmental sustainability and stability iii Due to the obstinate nature of microalgae cell walls and composition lipid extraction has always been one of the main factors restricting the production of microalgae biodiesel. Additional steps and chemical reagents are required to destroy cells to release lipids used for biodiesel production in vivo iv The addition of catalyst accelerates the catalytic conversion of biodiesel by microalgae but the expensive catalyst and the economic and environmental problems caused by some toxic catalysts need to be further studied v Microalgae biodiesel production rate is low and vulnerable to pollution by other substances thereby reducing the yield and quality of biodiesel the scale of microalgae cultivation is small and it is difficult to meet the global fuel market demand. The production transportation and use of microalgae biodiesel require a lot of invest ment to be properly implemented. The increase in capital and operating costs is the biggest bottleneck for commercialization. Environmental and cost considerations are also important topics for further research. At present it is still in small-scale production in the laboratory. The key technologies for large-scale production of biodiesel include the devel opment of efficient and economical microalgae culture systems the optimization of process parameters to further strengthen the bioengi neering photobioreactor culture system and the determination of high growth rate and oil production. Optimal culture conditions as well as advanced technologies for microalgae biomass separation and harvest ing. The cultivation of microalgae should focus on screening a variety of microalgae that are resistant to pests and diseases and can accumulate H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 18 lipids in large quantities through genetic engineering technology to develop active substances in food pharmaceutical and animal feed at the industrial level and increase the yield of high-value products Bhushan et al. 2020 Kadir et al. 2018 Gaurav et al. 2023 . The po tential economic value and environmental safety issues in the main production processes of microalgae biodiesel including microalgae culture microalgae harvesting lipid extraction and biodiesel catalytic conversion deserve further discussion and research to find the most suitable production model to achieve high efficiency economic feasi bility and environmental sustainability. 5.1. Economic value The economic analysis of microalgae biodiesel production is based on the estimation of capital investment operating costs and benefits. In addition to the sale of biodiesel the economic value of residual biomass and glycerol by-products is considered. Branco-Vieira et al. 2020 analyzed the production of biodiesel by microalgae. Under the facility scale of 15.247 ha the final production cost of biodiesel was estimated to be 0.33 euros L and the final production cost of biomass was 2.01 euros kg. It can produce about 1811 tons of dry microalgae biomass and 171 705 L of biodiesel. Considering the remaining biomass and glycerol by-products the production of microalgae biodiesel is an investment recovery period of 5 10 years. In addition to improve the maximum profit it is necessary to consider the local actual situation consider the location of the production plant and give priority to the use of local resources low-energy technologies and renewable energy in the plant facilities to reduce the final cost of biodiesel production. Ianda et al. 2022 studied the development of sub-Saharan countries Guinea- Bissau and found that local energy was scarce. Considering the demand production and economic conditions of Guinea-Bissau the production cost and economic feasibility of biodiesel were simulated. The com mercial simulation software Aspen Plus V12.0 was used to conduct a technical and economic assessment of biodiesel production in Guinea-Bissau. The simulation showed that 2 103 m3 of biodiesel was produced each year and the total manufacturing cost algae culture and industrial processing was estimated to be about USD 0.9 kg. This cost is very competitive compared to diesel at local gas stations in Guinea-Bissau and the entire biodiesel supply chain is optimistic. Guinea-Bissau does not have an oil refinery and the demand for bio diesel is small compared to sub-Saharan African countries such as South Africa Mozambique Nigeria and Senegal. Therefore the production of biodiesel from nano-green algae growing in the runway pool is a very promising measure to ensure the technical and economic feasibility of biodiesel production in the country. It should be recommended to establish a production base near Bissau the capital of Guinea-Bissau the country s economic center to facilitate the logistics of resources that provide feed for the cultivation of microalgae runway systems and to reduce the logistics costs of biodiesel distribution and sales. As part of the biorefinery process microalgae are planted harvested extracted lipids and converted into biodiesel. A technical and economic analysis of this process was carried out to estimate the cost of microalgae biodiesel production. The price of producing a ton of algae can range from 150 to 6000 depending on the different culture methods used. Under the scale of annual oil production of 500 tons of C. vulgaris the production cost of lipid per kilogram of heterotrophic culture of C. vulgaris is 7.5 and the production cost of lipid per kilogram of phototrophic culture is 480. The operating cost of a phototrophic culture is 65 times that of a heterotrophic culture. This result is attributed to the slow growth rate of Chlorella in the light culture mode so additional water supply and en ergy input of the light source are required. Although the heterotrophic culture of C. vulgaris has better economic feasibility than phototrophic culture the production cost of extracting lipids from microalgae is not competitive with the production cost of edible crops and petroleum diesel. The most commonly used methods for microalgae cultivation are open culture systems open pool and channel systems and closed systems such as photobioreactors . The open pond system facilitates large-scale farming and economic feasibility while the closed aquacul ture system is more convenient in terms of quality control and mainte nance of aquaculture conditions. Compared with the open system the closed system needs more funds to run. In open ponds and photo bioreactors triglycerides were sold at 8.52 gallon and 18.10 gallon respectively with a return of 10 . For large-scale production the cost of open pond aquaculture is low but the biomass productivity is low the water demand is large and the operating cost is increased. Due to the huge amount of drainage the centrifugal process consumes a lot of en ergy and cost. The flocculation process is considered to be more effective because it uses less energy and has a lower initial investment. The cost of producing a gallon of biodiesel ranges from 5 to 22 per gallon. Compared with photobioreactors it is economically feasible to synthe size carotene from Dunaliella salina cultured in open ponds. However because astaxanthin has a high market price in the photobioreactor culture of Haematococcus pluvialis the extraction of astaxanthin from pigment 18 makes the process profitable. Residue biomass can also be used as animal feed through simple processing and the price of animal feed varies from 1384 to 5066 per ton Kim et al. 2022 Mariadhas et al. 2023 . Although the above shows that microalgae biodiesel has great commercial potential commercial production and research are still in its infancy. The cost of microalgae biodiesel is several times higher than that of traditional lipid production Kumar et al. 2022 . The price of microalgae biodiesel cultured from the light-fed mode in open ponds and closed photobioreactors maybe 2.5 times and 4.1 times higher than that of gasoline diesel respectively Lam et al. 2019 . Some obstacles and challenges need to be overcome to expand the production and commercialization strategy of microalgae biodiesel. The economic value of microalgae biodiesel production is summarized below which provides a basis for the economic feasibility of microalgae biodiesel production. i In the process of microalgae cultivation can fix CO2 in the at mosphere and reduce the economic investment required for the treatment of greenhouse gas CO2. ii In the process of microalgae harvesting flocculation sedimenta tion technology can reduce the operating cost of the harvesting process and the cost requirement of dynamic cross-flow filtration for pre-concentrated microalgae biomass is lower than that of centrifugal technology Yang et al. 2023b . iii In the process of microalgae lipid extraction it is essential to use lipid extraction methods with low energy consumption low cost and high efficiency. Zou et al. 2021 studied the lipid extraction of microalgae by buoyancy ball method and ultrasound-assisted solvent extraction BBUASE . Firstly the microalgae biomass was harvested by the buoyant-bead flotation method and then the surface-layered polymeric microspheres were pretreated by ultrasound and the lipid was extracted by hexane isopropanol solvent. In addition liquid carbon dioxide lCO2 has been shown to successfully extract lipids from microalgae slurry in contrast to saving energy by operating at lower pressures and tempera tures Lee et al. 2023 . iv In the process of catalytic conversion of biodiesel by microalgae the in-situ transesterification process is used to produce biodiesel in one step which can effectively improve the yield reduce the cost and simplify the required process equipment. v In the production of microalgae biodiesel saturated fatty acids and monounsaturated fatty acids are the main components of microalgae biodiesel. Fatty acids help prevent cardiovascular diseases cancer and inflammatory diseases in humans Caporgno and Mathys 2018 . Natural by-products such as carotenoids crude proteins carbohydrates and astaxanthin have a positive impact on human health. For example they are used as nutri tional supplements dietary additives and pharmaceutical com ponents. Microalgae-derived compounds such as peptides have H. Liu et al. Journal of Cleaner Production 436 2024 140538 19 antioxidant antihypertensive immunomodulatory anticancer hepatoprotective and anticoagulant activities. Astaxanthin as an important antioxidant and nutritional health compound is widely used in dietary supplements and cosmetic raw materials. It has the functions of anti-aging anti-tumor and prevention of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular diseases Li et al. 2021a Chhandama and Rai 2023 . The production of biodiesel products and derived compounds from microalgae has great potential and economic value. 5.2. Environmental safety To meet the huge demand for fossil energy potential environmental safety must be assessed based on its environmental consequences and the energy needs of biodiesel production. The whole-process life cycle approach LCA from cradle to grave was used to analyze the environ mental impact and energy demand from microalgae to the obtained biodiesel and sensitivity analysis was performed to explore the impact of each process on the LCA system under given conditions quantifying the list of interventions related to environmental issues throughout the life cycle Kumar and Pal 2023 Karthikeyan et al. 2020 . In the long run microalgae will be a more desirable raw material. It shows higher competitive performance in terms of CO2 emissions and energy and can be used to treat wastewater. It not only reduces soil groundwater pollution but also helps to improve biodiesel production. Pollutant assimilation and CO2 biosequestration in wastewater protect the envi ronment and ultimately contribute to the circular economy and envi ronmental sustainability. Compared with petrochemical diesel and the first two generations of biodiesel microalgae production of biodiesel can improve environmental benefits Kumar et al. 2022 Ahmad et al. 2023 . If the production of microalgae biodiesel can be expanded on a large scale the environmental pollution caused by lipid and coal com bustion will be greatly reduced and bring a lot of economic benefits. However although many advances have been made in laboratory-scale research energy consumption and environmental pollution in industrial production are still challenges in the future. i In the process of microalgae culture it can also grow in harsh environments high salt heavy metals etc. . It can be cultured in industrial wastewater or metallurgical slag leaching solution to reduce toxic heavy metals to improve water quality and a large amount of CO2 may bring ecological risks to the environment Wang et al. 2019 Yu et al. 2023 Marouˇsek et al. 2023 Yin et al. 2020 . ii During the microalgae harvesting process emerging compounds biocoagulants bioflocculants that can be used during the har vesting of suspended microalgae were proposed which can maintain the cell structure and do not introduce toxicity into the harvested microalgae biomass Kurniawan et al. 2022 . iii In the process of microalgae lipid extraction the use of chemical reagents may hurt agriculture and drainage safety. Solvents pollute the environment such as chloroform and hexane which are highly toxic solvents and have a great impact on the envi ronment and human health. Therefore solvents with less harm to human and environmental safety are used instead of them. 2- methyltetrahydrofuran 2-MeTHF and cyclopentyl methyl ether CPME solvents are some of the most promising solvents to replace chloroform and hexane de Jesus et al. 2020a Jesus and Filho 2020b . iv In the process of microalgae-catalyzed biodiesel the supercritical method does not require the use of a catalyst which is an envi ronmentally friendly method for the conversion of microalgae biodiesel. 6. Conclusion In the era of industrialization the depletion of fossil fuels and the excessive emission of greenhouse gas CO2 prompt people to turn their attention to microalgae biodiesel. Microalgae are ubiquitous and diverse photosynthetic organisms in nature. They contain high-value com pounds such as lipids and polysaccharides and have outstanding ap plications in carbon dioxide emission reduction and biodiesel energy production. However how to ensure the efficient production of micro algae biodiesel under economic and environmental problems is currently a difficult problem. In this paper the methods of improving the oil production of microalgae growth and the yield of microalgae biodiesel are analyzed and summarized and the following conclusions are drawn. i Various environmental stresses such as light temperature pH heavy metals and nutrients promote the growth and oil produc tion of microalgae. Under optimal conditions the biomass of microalgae can be increased by more than two times and the lipid content can be increased by up to three times. In contrast heavy metal stress can not only increase the biomass accumula tion of microalgae but also help to remove heavy metals and play an environmental remediation role. ii HCO3 PO4 3 Cu2+ Fe3+ Zn2+ Mg2+ and other anions and cat ions promote the growth of microalgae by participating in the photosynthesis and physiological metabolism of microalgae and control lipid synthesis by overexpressing key rate-limiting en zymes in lipid metabolism and other genetic engineering. The two-stage culture mode can simultaneously improve the growth and oil production of microalgae. iii The addition of various catalysts improves the catalytic conver sion rate and yield of biodiesel. The optimized conditional yield can basically reach 90 . Among them heterogeneous nano- catalysts are superior to other traditional homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts due to their large specific surface area high catalytic activity high stability improved active sites high biodiesel conversion rate and reusability. The supercritical method and the ionic liquid method are environmentally friendly and feasible because they do not use catalysts. iv From the perspective of economic benefits and environmental safety the use of microalgae biodiesel to replace traditional fossil fuels can not only protect the ecological environment and reduce the damage to the environment but also microalgae biodiesel is a renewable carbon-neutral energy. However in the current com mercial production process of microalgae biodiesel it is difficult to compete with fossil fuels in terms of economic issues such as investment operating costs and benefits. It is also necessary to consider the environmental risks caused by the use of too many biochemical catalysts and genetic metabolic engineering. v The future research direction of microalgae biodiesel is to breed microalgae with rapid growth and high lipid content optimize culture conditions and processes make full use of the mode of biorefinery in photobioreactor engineering and adopt large-scale production to reduce production costs in combination with local conditions. The biomass content of microalgae is greatly improved by using heterotrophic culture mode or combined with solid waste utilization such as industrial wastewater culture. The development of more environmentally friendly cheap and efficient catalysts and catalytic methods such as the study of functionalized magnetic nano-catalysts. Because the lipid accu mulation process and regulation mechanism in microalgae are very complex it is necessary to further study the regulation mechanism of lipid metabolism pathways and carry out genetic engineering modification based on the combination of lipid synthesis and metabolic pathways and regulation mechanisms. In short the main research direction of microalgae biodiesel is to H. Liu et al.
