A. Udayan et al. Bioresource Technology 344 2022 126406 4 results in a beneficial energy balance. Due to this fact phototrophic cultivation is most commonly practiced for the growth of microalgae. The lipid content of microalgae can vary between 5 and 60 during phototrophic cultivation Cruz et al. 2018 depending on the species used. But the intensity of light and proper supply of CO2 should be assured in this type of cultivation. Technically this method is used in the outdoor environment for the cultivation of microalgae generally to in crease the productivity of lipids by supplying 2 5 CO2 in the air and also to use industrial flue gases Yu et al. 2020 . For phototrophic cultivation it is important to select and characterize the strains of microalgae based on their photosynthetic activity growth rate and biomass productivity. The design and construction of cultivation sys tems are very important. Photoperiod also is very important in open cultivation systems as the irregular distribution of light intensity influ ence the biomass concentration Zheng et al. 2012 . Long cultivation periods and self-shading are the major limitations of this method. Mi crobes such as Calothrix sp. Chlorella sp. and green-non sulfur bacteria which utilize light as an energy source for photosynthesis are being used in phototrophic farming to produce pigments and secondary metabolites Amadu et al. 2021 . 2.2. Heterotrophic cultivation Heterotrophic microalgae cultivation was done in the dark making use of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources. It eliminates the requirement of light Mohamed et al. 2011 and nitrogen sources may be organic or inorganic as per the strain used. Therefore the problem related to the limitation of light can be avoided of this method of cultivation and the yield was found significantly superior to photo trophic cultivation Huang et al. 2010 . It also reduces the requirement of the surface-to-volume ratio of the bioreactor thus making the design of the bioreactor easier. It has been reported by Xu et al. 2006 that improvement of 40 lipid content of Chlorella protothecoides after altering the culture from phototrophic to heterotrophic Xu et al. 2006 . Although this mode of cultivation has the advantage of a short period of cultivation indicating high productivity but has a limitation in obtaining high amounts of value-added products and the presence of organic substrates is susceptible to microbial contamination and also may lead to high cost Hempel et al. 2011 . Several strains such as Chlorella vulgaris Chlorella protothecoides Crypthecodinium cohnii and Schizochytrium limacinum can be cultivated under this mode Vuppala dadiyam et al. 2018 . Some species of microalgae cannot grow under phototrophic conditions required some organic carbon in the absence of light. Light limitation problem is avoided with heterotrophic cultivation and has resulted in useful microalgal biomass production. Due to the more cell density harvesting cost generally decreases in this system of cultivation Iasimone et al. 2020 . The heterotrophic culture can also be combined with plant fermentation technology and facilities that reduce the production cost Venkata Mohan et al. 2015 . In heterotrophic culture important carbon source is glucose although some researchers use the cellulose hydrolysis product El-Sheekh et al. 2012 . Some algae can also grow well in presence of glycerol as a carbon source which can preserve the cell osmotic balance and is not harmful in high concen trations. These researchers also informed that some microalgae could multiply with composite carbon sources Kong et al. 2021 . Some of them combined microalgae cultivation with factory effluent and use factory wastewater to reduce the cost. Dramatic cost can be reduced after using factory sewage which is reached in nutrients. Many micro algae may be grown in carbon-rich sewage under alternating light or dark conditions or in the wastewater with the introduction of organic nutrients from outside Zhan et al. 2017a . For example Chlorella pro tothecoides cultured with waste-activated sludge hydrolysate might potentially grow well and produce lipid Cho Park 2018 . Overall heterotrophic culture may hasten cell growth rate more biomass and lipid accumulation compared to phototrophic culture and may be blended with wastewater treatment to reduce the cost. 2.3. Mixotrophic cultivation In this process of cultivation carbon dioxide and organic carbons are simultaneously comprehended by microalgae and both chemo heterotrophic and photoautotrophic metabolism go on concurrently. Microalgae growing under this environment can survive in both pho totrophic as well as heterotrophic conditions Mansa et al. 2018 . This type of cultivation is the two-stage mode where the first stage can be related to heterotrophy because of more content of initial organic car bon. After evacuating the organic carbon at a certain level photosyn thesis was persuading therefore the algae undertake to assimilate CO2 photoautotrophically that indicating the beginning of the second stage. The disadvantages of the autotrophy system can be controlled in a mixotrophic system and it has combined the advantages of autotrophy and heterotrophy. Zhan et al. 2017 communicated that the cell growth rate of Chlorella vulgaris was just about the total of autotrophy and heterotrophy when cultured under mixotrophic mode with light and acetate as carbon source Zhan et al. 2017a . In this cultivating condi tion microalgae can not only spread heterotrophically with organic carbon but also swallow inorganic carbon and turn out oxygen through photosynthesis that put together the overall CO2 emission lower under mixotrophic cultivation mode than under heterotrophic cultivation mode. The mixotrophic cultivation is different from heterotrophy as the precious pigments and photosynthetic carotenoids for example β-carotene could be protected in illuminated conditions even though the energy conversion efficiency is lower under mixotrophic cultivation due to photosynthetic losses Alkhamis Qin 2016 . In general the characteristics of photosynthesis are different under mixotrophic cultivation than autotrophy and heterotrophy Sirohi et al. 2021b . The respiration rate is enhanced in mixotrophic cultivation as compared to the autotrophic condition. The net photosynthetic rate and respiratory rates were found almost 1.5 times higher. Moreover the photosynthetic pigment content and photosystem activity also differ under mixotrophic conditions. However the change in photosynthetic pigments was dependent on the species of microalgae and the organic carbon source Benavente-Valdes et al. 2016 . 2.4. Photoheterotrophic cultivation Microalgae growing under this condition require light and they use organic compounds as a source of carbon. The main difference with the mixotrophic cultivation is in mixotrophic cultivation light and organic and inorganic carbon source is used as a source of energy while under photoheterotrophic systems light is used for energy fix fixation of ni trogen and organic matter as a carbon source without CO2 Chen et al 2011 . Although photo-heterotrophic culture requires organic carbon and light it is rarely employed to generate microalgal biomass for the production of value-added products. 3. Systems of microalgal cultivation An open system is widely used for the production of microalgae in the industry due to the economy for large-scale production. Normally an open pond is used with a very simple design. Normally ground tanks with depth up to 0.5 m and a paddle agitator are used for stirring. The concern culture media is usually chemical substances or biogenic com pounds and when necessary microelements may be supplemented. At mospheric air is used through a simple diffusion process for carbon dioxide. The major advantage of an open system is simple and inex pensive but it has high water losses due to evaporation lower biomass yield and susceptibility to contamination. The system is only victorious with strict isolation and unlimited access to water. In respect of eco nomic terms this type of system is the most reasonable choice. Many closed systems have been developed so far but none of them are cost- effective. Table 3 exhibits the merits and demerits of a different sys tem of cultivation of microalgae. A. Udayan et al. Bioresource Technology 344 2022 126406 5 3.1. Open ponds Open ponds are considered the oldest and simplest method for the large-scale cultivation of microalgae. It is widely used in the industry because of its low maintenance cheaper construction low energy de mand easily scale up and low operational costs Tan et al. 2020 . Natural lakes and ponds are considered open ponds and artificial water bodies like circular and raceway ponds are also constructed for indus trial applications. However despite the large cultivation area the major disadvantages of open ponds are low cell concentration and difficulty in the harvesting process. Moreover problems such as rainwater runoff will affect the growth of microalgae by changing conditions such as salinity and pH along with the turbidity caused by the erosion of river banks Stark O Gara 2012 . The major drawback of the open pond systems is the contamination by bacteria and protozoa which makes the end product to be toxic and unstable. Because of the open nature of the cultivation system it is very difficult to control temperature and light intensity which primarily affects the growth rate of microalgae Ugwu Aoyagi 2012 . The first artificial pond used for the large-scale cultivation of microalgae is circular ponds and the name came from the circular shape of the culture tank. The tank has a dimension of 30 70 cm depth and 45 m width with a rotating agitator placed at the center of the tank. An agitator is used to provide proper mixing and prevention of sedimen tation of microalgal cells Costa et al. 2019 . The designing of open pond cultivation systems is limited because the large size will exhibit strong water resistance which creates more strain on the agitator Moreno-Garcia et al. 2017 . Currently worldwide more than 70 companies cultivate Chlorella in open pond systems with the largest producers located in Taiwan Tan et al. 2020 . Raceway pond is another type of open pond system used for the in dustrial cultivation of microalgae which is mainly composed of a series of the closed-loop channel of 30 cm depth and a mechanical paddle wheel which helps in the circulation of microalgal biomass for uniform distribution of nutrients and prevention of cell sedimentation Tan et al. 2020 . Raceway ponds have been considered as the best open pond cultivation system because of their energy efficiency Rogers et al. 2014 . Columbus Algal Biomass Farm located in the United States suc cessfully produces 520 metric tons of dried microalgal biomass during 2 years of operation without any technical problems White Ryan 2015 . Table 4 shows the companies involved in commercial microalgal biomass production using different reactors. 3.2. Photobioreactors Photobioreactors are used for the culture of phototrophs in a closed system which does not permit the direct exchange of materials between the cells and environment Tan et al. 2020 and is effectively capable of overcoming several disadvantages of open pond systems. Photo bioreactors do not need large space because of the compact design in comparison with open ponds and photobioreactors provide highly controlled growth conditions for microalgal culture and reduce the chances of contamination by maintaining an axenic culture of micro algae Posten 2009 . The controlled growth environment can result in higher metabolic efficiency and biomass production per unit substrate Tan et al. 2020 . However photobioreactors consist of many design problems because the practical usage is very limited and it is uneco nomical in industrial perspectives Gupta et al. 2015 . The design of photobioreactors consists of high capital and operational costs. Different types of photobioreactors are available in the market based on their design and mode of operation. Tubular photobioreactors are made up of long transparent glass or plastic tubes that are arranged in vertical horizontal helix or slanted positions for maximum sunlight capture Mishra et al. 2019 . An Airlift system or mechanical pump is given for the circulation of microalgae within the photobioreactor. Poor mass transfer efficiency because of the presence of long tubes is the major disadvantage of tubular photobioreactors which can cause dif ferences in the substrate concentration and product yield. Large-scale tubular photobioreactors are widely used in Germany and Israel for the commercial cultivation of Haematococcus and Chlorella Torzillo Chini Zittelli 2015 . Vertical column photobioreactors consist of a transparent vertical cylinder tube and a sparger. The sparger allows the homogenization of the microalgal culture and uniform distribution of carbon dioxide and oxygen between the cells Mohan et al. 2019 . Vertical column photo bioreactors have a good gas liquid mass transfer in comparison with other systems because of the smaller bubbles created by the sparger Mohan et al. 2019 . Moreover the simple construction parameters result in easier operating procedures and low energy demand. But the major disadvantage of the system is the low light capture due to the cylindrical shape which reduces the photosynthetic efficiency of microalgal cells. Another disadvantage is the construction cost and cleaning difficulty in large-scale operations Huang et al. 2017 . 40 L capacity vertical column photobioreactor has been used for the culti vation of Chlorella zofingiensis in China Huo et al. 2018 Flat plate photobioreactors are made up of rectangular-shaped compartments with a depth of 1 5 cm using transparent material and mixing is provided through an airlift system Tan et al. 2020 . Flat late photobioreactors provide maximum capture of light with a low buildup of oxygen which provides the highest photosynthetic efficiency in comparison with other photobioreactors Yan et al. 2016 . The major disadvantage of the flat plate photobioreactor is the stress damage of the cells due to the design provided for aeration. Efforts were made to improve the working efficiency of flat plate photobioreactors by devel oping twin layers a flat-plate and plastic photobioreactors Vo et al. Harvesting techniques For the commercialization of microalgal products it is very impor tant to harvest the microalgal biomass effectively in a low-cost manner. The effectiveness of microalgal harvesting mainly depends on achieving high biomass production with low operation cost maintenance and energy. Most of the harvesting stages are costly followed by downstream processing. The selection of specific harvesting methods will mainly depend on the end products and should consider the cell size and den sity cell damage salt concentration and moisture content. During harvesting it is important to avoid the chances of contamination and the possibility of culture medium recycling should also be taken into consideration. The currently available methods are based on chemical biological mechanical and electrical technologies Fig. 1 . For low-cost biomass harvesting methods combination of two or more methods can be employed. The significant downstream processing carrying the combined effects of flocculation followed by sedimentation with centrifugation could be employed to minimize the cost of processing. Biological methods are also considered as a low-cost method because of the low operational cost along with different mechanical processes. Different methods used for microalgal biomass harvesting have been discussed below. 4.1. Centrifugation Centrifugation is a rapid process used at both laboratory and com mercial scales to separate biomass from suspension. It is also efficient for dewatering microalgae-thickened biomass Najjar Abu-Shamleh 2020 .The forces in the act during the process may cause cell damage the intensity of which depends upon the strain and operating conditions Singh Patidar 2018 . The recovery rate of this process is more than 95 and it can be used for any microalgae species for achieving a 10 20 concentration of the recovered solids Fuad et al. 2018 . Industrially it is a preferred harvesting method however being quite energy-intensive it adds considerably to the process and operational expenses and hence is mostly used for bioactive compounds like phar maceuticals Hidayah Mat Yasin et al. 2019 . Energy consumption of about 50 75 kW is required for the recovery of 12 25 biomass by centrifugation Najjar Abu-Shamleh 2020 . Fixed wall e.g. hydrocyclone and rotary wall e.g. centrifugal de canters disc centrifuges and tubular centrifuges are the two types of systems that are used for centrifugation Mathimani Mallick 2018 . The hydrocyclone is cylindrical equipment where the input microalgae culture is fed at the top from an angle and the cells move downward through the vessel in a cyclonic motion larger and denser particles dragging towards the bottom outlet. Decanter centrifuges are horizontal conical tubes that rotate at high speed and create separation based on differences in the specific weight of particles. The biomass moves to the sides further collected through a helical thread Najjar Abu-Shamleh 2020 . The disc centrifuge consists of a vertical stack of thin conical metal discs in which the culture is poured at the core of the stacked cylinder. The rotation of the cylinder causes the biomass to move out wards and then to the bottom whereas the culture liquid moves to the center. Tubular centrifuge lacks a draining system and is generally used in laboratory studies. Table 5 shows the comparison of different types of centrifuges used for the harvesting of microalgae As already mentioned centrifugation is efficient for high-value products such as pharmaceuticals and it is not cost-effective for low- value products which can be processed in an integrated system like biofuels from microalgae. Centrifugation is an energy-intensive process which is the major disadvantage for efficient biofuel production for large-scale applications Wang et al. 2015a . Moreover the initial in vestment of centrifuge is very high which makes the process cost high Monte et al. 2018 Okoro et al. 2019 . It has been reported that the investment cost of centrifuge can reach up to 30 of the cost and the increased capital cost can be problematic for large-scale applications Alam et al. 2017 together with the cost of labor Fasaei et al. 2018 . Therefore automation is indeed necessary to reduce the labor cost which needs more intensive research. Moreover the high maintenance cost and service charges of centrifuge equipment are the major barriers that prevent the expansion of centrifugation technology for large-scale industrial applications of microalgae. Centrifugation is not practically feasible to operate in saline environments Najjar Abu-Shamleh 2020 . In addition the requirement of high strength and corrosion- free alloys for the construction of centrifuge makes it more expensive. The other factor critical for centrifugation is the destruction of the microalgal structure due to the shear stresses and gravitational forces Morais Junior et al. 2020 which depends on the cell wall structure and type of microalgae used. Therefore finding the optimum rotational speed specific to each microalgae is very important to keep the cells of microalgae intact Michels et al. 2016 . 4.2. Flocculation Flocculation is an effective process for biomass recovery in which the microalgae cells are flocculated by some organic inorganic flocculants or bio flocculants or by altering the pH of the system Fig. 2 Matter et al. 2019 . Flocculation is the process of aggregation of smaller par ticles to form large flocs with the assistance of flocculating agents Branyikova et al. 2018 . The flocs are then decanted over time. Inor ganic flocculants include chemicals such as aluminum sulfate or ferrous sulfate Branyikova et al. 2018 . Such inorganic flocculants are effective but they are expensive and their high dose application can adversely impact the quality of final products a limitation considered particularly when the product is to be used for food and feed. Flocculation results in biomass recoveries as high as 100 although the product quality is impacted by inorganic and organic flocculants as their used concentra tion can range between 50 and 600 mg L Laamanen et al. 2016 . Organic flocculants like starch and chitosan display efficient recovery rates at relatively lower concentrations with lesser adverse impacts on the environment and microalgae biomass Lee et al. 2015 . Removal of excessive flocculants from the medium requires an additional separation process to decrease the negative effects on biomass and products. The use of magnetic nanoparticles is an emerging technology being inves tigated for optimizing the flocculation process Wells et al. 2017 . Microalgae flocculation mechanisms in general are similar to those used for water treatment plants Pugazhendhi et al. 2019 . The use of inorganic metal salts for microalgae recovery is possible but not pref erable since the recovered biomass reportedly consists of a high con centration of metals from the salts which even after lipid and carotenoids extraction remains in the biomass residue Matter et al. 2019 . Alkali such as NaOH is often used to adjust the pH of the system which further enhances the activity of flocculants Ummalyma et al. 2017 . The combination of flocculation with other conventional recov ery methods like sedimentation or filtration increases the overall re covery efficiency. The microalgae lipid content besides pH is also influenced by the species and culture parameters. While considering the effect of pH alkalization to pH 10 improves flocculation and after efficient flocs are formed the pH is re-shifted to 8 by washing the cells with an ammonium format solution. Inorganic salts can be removed by this isotonic solution with the maintenance of both cells and lipid content Liu et al. 2013 . Bio flocculation utilizes the flocculating potential of microorganisms like bacteria without the need for chemical flocculants. Microalgal bio flocculation with the help of microbes requires additional substrate for bacterial growth Nguyen et al. 2019 . Exopolymeric substances released by microbes are also used for flocculation Yang et al. 2020 . Auto flocculation is an economically feasible process in terms of energy and process cost. In this process microalgae cells flocculate at high pH more than 9 in the presence of Ca2+ and Mg2+ Ummalyma et al. 2017 . The process is induced by CO2. The addition of alkali usually 1 M NaOH solution can also induce auto flocculation achieving more than 90 recovery efficiencies Singh Patidar 2018 . The pH of the cultivation media becomes basic as microalgae utilize CO2 from the media during photosynthesis. This high pH in turn neutralizes the negative charges present on the surface of microalgae cells causing them to flocculate Okoro et al. 2019 . The addition of NaOH however is not preferred industrially as it alters cell composition and process control becomes tedious. 4.3. Sedimentation Sedimentation is a simple economic and energy-efficient recovery process that uses gravity for cell separation Fasaei et al. 2018 . The process is energy efficient as energy consumption of less than 0.1 kWh m 3 can result in 1 to 3 final solid concentration Leite et al. 2020 . The sedimentation rate is affected by the size and density of particles such that particles with small density or size differences sedi ment very slow Mennaa et al. 2019 . In such cases the addition of flocculants is done to increase the recovery efficiency up to 90 due to the electrostatic attraction caused among the suspended cells floc for mation with the assistance of charged flocculants Fuad et al. 2018 . Different flocculation methods used for the separation of microalgae. A. Udayan et al. Bioresource Technology 344 2022 126406 8 In comparison with different types of sedimentation processes sedimentation of microalgae using high pH 9 12 using a low-cost base such as NaOH is considered more effective. The inorganic salt will co- precipitate and interact with negatively charged microalgal cells by the principle of neutralization during alkaline conditions which facili tate the sedimentation process of microalgae Lei et al. 2018 Leite et al. 2020 . The effect of high pH on microalgae cultivation has been widely studied by many researchers Mathimani Mallick 2018 Morais Junior et al. 2020 Singh Patidar 2018 Ummalyma et al. 2017 . But the harvesting of microalgae cultivated in wastewater needs more research in large-scale cultivation systems because the compounds present in wastewater can be hindered with the sedimentation efficiency Leite et al. 2020 Mennaa et al. 2019 . However more research is needed to understand the optimum parameters affecting sedimentation under alkaline conditions. The available studies only focused on ex periments performed in beakers stirred with a specific velocity using stirring equipment. But these results cannot be reproduced in large volumes of microalgal culture because the sedimentation rates can be changed depending upon the equipment and the culture volume Leite et al. 2020 . Thus more critical research is needed to enable the scale-up process. 4.4. Filtration Filtration is a solid liquid separation technique when a suspension is passed through a membrane the solid retains while the liquid passes through filter pores Mo et al. 2015 . This causes collection of micro algae biomass even low-density microalgae over the membrane which can be further recovered. Filtration can be performed either through dead-end flow or through tangential flow. Ultrafiltration micro filtration nanofiltration and reverse osmosis fall under tangential flow or cross-flow systems Castro-Munoz Garcia-Depraect 2021 . The different membranes used for separation vary in their pore sizes as microfiltration membranes have a pore size between 0.1 and 10 µm ultrafiltration between 0.01 and 0.1 µm and nanofiltration membrane between 0.01 and 0.001 μm Roy 2019 . Microalgae cells greater than 70 μm in diameter are suitable to be recovered by dead-end filtrations while smaller cells are recovered by tangential flow filtration. Microfiltration and ultrafiltration membranes are better at recovering microalgae biomass Diaz-Montes Castro- Munoz 2019 . However these membranes are energy-intensive as they require high pressure to promote flow across them owing to their smaller pore sizes Bilad et al. 2014 . Ultrafiltration at low pressure consumes 3 10 kWh 3 energy giving 15 to 60 L m2 ha of permeate fluxes Castro-Munoz Garcia-Depraect 2021 . Moreover filtration membranes also suffer from fouling which is a condition in which membrane pores clog by solids due to continuous use over time. Mem brane fouling hinders the smooth operation of the filtration membrane increasing the operating costs as well as process time. To reduce clog ging and improve process efficiency filtration is usually performed after other recovery methods like coagulation and flocculation. Tangential flow filtration systems are simple and efficient and can operate contin uously for the separation of biomass Zhao et al. 2017 . The perfor mance of each filtration method depends upon membrane pore size membrane material size of particles to be retained and pressure requirement Das et al. 2019 . 4.5. Magnetic separation In this process the separation is based on tagging a non magnetic substance like cells with magnetic particles that show paramagnetic movement with the help of a magnetic field. The cells are therefore isolated from the medium in an external magnetic field Rakesh et al. 2020 . The binding between cells and magnetic particles can be enhanced by coating with silica or cationic polyelectrolyte resulting in better aggregation of the cells. This method is the most widely accepted modern microalgal biomass harvesting method in terms of simple cost- effective and energy-efficient properties Wang et al. 2014 . Different types of magnetic nanocomposites were developed and efficiently used for harvesting microalgal biomass given in Table6. For efficient large-scale harvesting of microalgae using magnetic nanoparticles a systematic separation system is indeed necessary. The high gradient magnetic separation system HGMS has been used in industries in the past decades Hu et al. 2014b . The development of high gradient magnetic fields of 104 T m efficiently provides energy to harvest magnetic from the solution and it is commonly used by many industries Hu et al. 2014a . But large-scale industrial magnetic sepa rators are not suitable for the separation of microalgal cells because of the specific properties and cell wall characteristics of microalgae which is different from the industrial process Wang et al. 2015b . Hu et al. 2014 developed a magnetic separator that can be used to effectively harvest microalgae Hu et al. 2014a . However the industrial separa tion of microalgae using these methods is very costly. The total har vesting cost of microalgae from fishpond was US 0.13 cubic meter of treated pond water. Large-scale harvesting of microalgal biomass using magnetic separation is very costly therefore it is indeed necessary to decrease the cost of the process. More research on the downstream processes following the magnetic separation including the extraction of the specific products and the reusability of magnetic particles are necessary to make the separation process more efficient. 4.6. Dissolved air flotation Dissolved air flotation DAF is inverted sedimentation or a variation of flotation in which the liquid medium is sparged with air or gas bub bles generated at high pressure such that the solid particles attach to them and move towards the liquid surface from where they are recov ered Torres et al. 2017 . This method is often aided by flocculation Table 6 Application of magnetic nanoparticle for the separation of different microalgae. Chitosan magnetic nanoparticle 97 Toh et al. 2014 A. Udayan et al. Bioresource Technology 344 2022 126406 9 which causes aggregation of particles and increases the process yields Zhang et al. 2016 . In case DAF is performed after flocculation some water is recycled and saturated with pressurized air. The rate of recir culation determines the number of bubbles generated 5 15 at 400 650 kPa Torres et al. 2017 . Recovery of some microalgae species like Scenedesmus quadriculata Tetraselmis sp. and Chlorella sp. has been investigated by DAF with estimated energy consumption around 7.6 kWh m-3and final solids concentration between 3 and 6 Zhu et al. 2018 . Use of an air injector and a high-speed stirrer or continuous air flow through a porous material cause bubble formation in DAF which subsequently interacts with charged surfaces of cells and attract them to the surface Torres et al. 2017 . This process is simple to operate in little space and time and shows the capacity to treat large volumes of microalgae cultures which makes DAF an effective process for micro algae recovery Fasaei et al. 2018 . Even though DAF has been studied for microalgae harvesting its large-scale use is hindered by the energy costs associated with the requirement of high pressure. The selection of a harvesting process is often hindered by the costs associated with energy consumption e.g. high recoveries are achieved by filtration and centrifugation at a large scale but the use is limited by high energy requirements. The energy cost also depends upon the product economics. The combined use of two or more methods can be an effective approach to diminish energy limitations Fasaei et al. 2018 . The selection of an appropriate harvesting method besides process economy also depends upon the final product. The use of chemical substances and metals in the process like flocculation and magnetic separation often alters the product and biomass characteristics. Hence given a biorefinery it is necessary to select a method that reduces the chances of product and cell contamination even if it suffers from a little higher energy expenditure. 4.7. Electrochemical technologies The traditional coagulation flocculation methods cause the charge neutralization or formation of networks because of the pH change or treatment with polyvalent metal ions. Electrochemical technologies for microalgal biomass harvesting are a new approach that is mainly based on the concept of electrocoagulation electroflocculation and electro floatation. Electrochemical technologies are considered as a cheap innovative and efficient method for biomass harvesting from micro algae in comparison with other methods which need complex opera tional parameters and costly chemicals Misra et al. 2014 . Electrocoagulation EC involves the generation of metal ions because of the oxidizing metal electrodes which create the destabiliza tion of colloid suspension and subsequent coagulation of microalgal biomass Hattab 2015 . In this process either direct current DC or low-frequency alternating current AC can be used which causes the oxidation of the anode and subsequent electrocoagulation process. The major concern of EC is the electrode depletion which requires periodic replacement which can be replaced with suitable inexpensive material like non sacrificial carbon electrodes Guldhe et al. 2015 . Another disadvantage of this process is the contamination of harvested micro algae due to metal depletion of the electrode which affects the cost- efficiency. To avoid market value depreciation dewatering methods that do not involve trace metals can be used. Electrochemical technologies have demonstrated the high potential and efficiency of microalgal biomass harvesting. Electrolytic floccula tion for 1 h has resulted in 85 95 microalgal biomass recovery with a current supply of 5 V Hattab 2015 . Similarly electrolytic floccu lation for 3 min in Dunaliella salina cultures has shown 97.4 biomass recovery efficiency Zenouzi et al. 2013 . In electrofloatation bubbles generated by the electrolysis of water are used to attach the microalgal cells in suspension and raise them to the surface of the reactor Geada et al. 2018 . Cathode used in this method will be created using an inert material that is electrochemically nondegradable which overcomes the problems of contamination and electrode replacement Geada et al. 2018 . The combination of electrocoagulation and floatation ECF is considered an efficient alternative to traditional microalgal harvesting methods because of its simple mode of operation and ability for scaling up Geada et al. 2018 . In this process sacrificial electrode generates coagulating ions which are capable of destabilizing microalgal cells and these cells aggregate and create flocs that can be trapped by the microbubbles produced as a result of electrofloatation Gao et al. 2010 . Several researchers have investigated the application of ECF for har vesting microalgae from drinking or wastewater Alfafara et al. 2002 Azarian et al. 2012 Gao et al. 2010 but additional studies are required for more efficient harvesting. ECF can also be used as a continuous microalgal cultivation and harvesting method Kim et al. 2012 . In this process one electrode is considered as sacrificial and the other one is a non-sacrificial electrode and continuous microalgae harvesting is ach ieved by polarity exchange Kim et al. 2012 . Operation of ECF depends on different factors such as current density electrode material tem perature pH heavy metals etc. Hattab 2015 The electrophoresis technique can also use for the harvesting of microalgae where no additional chemicals are required. In this process a suitable electric field is applied and as a result the dispersed particles will move relative to a fluid. The microalgal cultivation media is rich in monovalent sodium and potassium ions and the negative charge of microalgae created will move the cells towards anode when subjected to a direct current electric field Uduman et al. 2010 . In the anode compartment negatively charged algae lose charge results in the agglomeration and floc formation Uduman et al. 2010 . Metal ion contamination during the process can be solved by using the non- sacrificial electrode. Dielectrophoresis can also be used for harvesting microalgal cells where a mixture of two or more microalgae species with different electric conductivities or dielectric properties Geada et al. 2018 . Chlamydomonas reinhardtii cells were harvested using dielec trophoresis using alternating current with minimum cell damage Sus cillon et al. 2013 . C. vulgaris cells were also harvested using the dielectrophoresis technique Deng et al. 2013 . However future research is needed to establish efficient electrochemical technologies for the harvesting of microalgal cells with minimum contamination and low cost. 5. Post-harvest processing Post-harvest processes include drying of the biomass to remove re sidual moisture content. Various methods are used for drying including solar spray drying freeze-drying cross flow and vacuum-shelf drying Babar et al. 2020 . Drying can increase biomass shelf life and ease the extraction of lipid or other substances. A particular method is selected based on the final moisture content desired and the properties of the product. Most of the drying methods can minimize the water content to 4 from 55 to 90 which is the moisture content range of wet biomass Show et al. 2015 . Energy consumption operational costs and air temperature are similar in convective spray and rotary drying pro cesses. Energy consumption ranges between 5 and 6 kWh kg while the air temperature depends upon the final product usually ranging be tween 50 and 120 C Show et al. 2015 . Solar drying requires low cost and low energy investment however the outcome heavily depends upon sun availability and drying time. Freeze drying on the contrary is extremely energy-intensive and consumes 22 kWh kg biomass Show et al. 2015 . The high energy expense could be attributed to the low pressure and temperature treatment that is provided to cells during this process ensuring biomass preservation without cell disruption. Microalgae-based biorefineries showcase the immense potential for the efficient utilization of microalgae as a source of bioenergy and biomaterials. Many biorefineries utilize microalgae biomass cultivated by wastewater thus also promoting microalgae-based bioremediation. Depending upon the cultivation conditions pretreatment and process ing methods the biomass and associated bioactive compounds can be A. Udayan et al. Bioresource Technology 344 2022 126406 10 used for the manufacturing of high-value metabolites. These include biofuels and bioenergy like biodiesel bioethanol biogas hydrochar etc. and bioactive metabolites like nutraceuticals pigments antioxi dants etc. 6. Challenges associated with mass culturing of microalgae and future perspectives Culturing of microalgae at a large scale for lipids nutraceuticals bioenergy production etc. suffers from some major challenges. For successful product recovery from microalgae achieving higher growth and biomass production are indeed necessary. But mass cultivation of microalgae often results in decreased growth biomass production and end-product formation. Phototrophic cultivation of microalgae is ad vantageous due to the possibility of its establishment in the open where CO2 is obtained from the environment and nutrients from aquatic hab itats however regions that receive varying sunlight with fluctuating intensity are not suitable to establish such a cultivation system limiting its utilization. The primary challenge is the availability of light when the cultures are specifically phototrophic as the extent of light penetration into the cultivation system might hinder the productivity Biondi et al. 2017 . As a result of low light penetration photobioreactors might show low biomass concentration thus affecting both microalgae cultivation as well as harvesting costs. Penetration of light and therefore photosyn thesis are also hindered in cases where biomass concentration increases in photobioreactors. This occurs due to mutual shading caused among cells particularly cells of the top layer shade the cells beneath creating a dark zone with very little or no light penetration. This could result in the concentration of biomass as low as 2 4 g L which can be reportedly increased if the optical path of the culture is shortened Cuaresma et al. 2009 . Moreover costs associated with downstream processes are affected by the dilute nature of autotrophic cultures and the inability to optimize simultaneous recovery of the different microalgal components Klok et al. 2013 . Both the open and closed cultivation systems have their respective benefits and drawbacks. Open systems possess greater economic feasibility but chances of contamination are high Moreno García et al. 2017 . In contrary closed systems give proper control over process parameters like temperature pH etc. But initial setup cost is high and the system is also inhibited by poor control of light supply. Conventional closed bioreactor systems flat plate stirred tank etc. being used for microalgal cultivation Kumar et al. 2011 display poor light to biomass conversion. Besides reduction in the optical path high surface area to volume ratio and flash light effect or photoperiod also increase the penetration of light and absorption in the photobioreactors Xue et al. 2013 .In the case of culture systems involving light dark cycle L D cycle the precise control of the illumination frequency is compromised in cases where the cultivation systems require mixing. This is because the mixing causes random motion of microalgae cells which in turn results in fluctuation in the amount of light dark fre quency reaching each cell. Moreover the microalgae cultivation system with mixing possesses certain drawbacks. Such systems cause cell damage due to the high shear force that comes into the act through turbulent mixing of cells and also the mixing devices employed increase the usage of energy and price Liao et al. 2014 . Heterotrophic and mixotrophic microalgae cultures are better suited for cultivation in closed systems as they can grow in low light or even dark conditions with higher productivities. However in such cases the culture is often supplemented with organic carbon substrates due to the unavailability of environmental CO2 thus increasing the production costs. Glucose is the preferred source of carbon in growth media but in mixotrophic cultures high initial glucose concentration adversely impacts lipid accumulation in cells Cheirsilp Torpee 2012 . Contrarily another study showed that exhaustion of glucose along with phosphate depletion under mixotrophic conditions ceased the culture growth after four days Kumar et al. 2014 . Another drawback in the mass culturing of microalgae is the need for huge amounts of water and nutrients which makes the process economically less feasible Tan et al. 2021 . The high water content of microalgae culture more than 98 leads to poor accumulative properties of cells which as a result do not coagulate and create difficulty in cell harvesting Chen et al. 2011 . The light electrons captured by the microalgal photosystem are used as energy for the generation of organic compounds while remaining electrons get involved in catabolic reactions or are dissipated Janssen et al. 2019 . Imbalances in metabolic pathways due to nutrient depletion can either obstruct the growth process or alter the electron flux leading to a decline in the biomass concentration. Efficient large-scale microalgae cultiva tion thus requires enough supply of water and nutrients along with control on the feed-stock related costs. This all together creates one of the major challenges for commercial-scale cultivation. Water reuse re duces the need for water and nutrients to 84 and 55 respectively Yang et al. 2011 . But it should be noted that before reuse of the harvested water with nutrients in it the water should be treated to remove soluble algal products metabolites released by microalgal cells during cultivation as the presence of these metabolites in reused su pernatant reportedly restrains the growth of subsequent microalgal cells Zhang et al. 2013 . Microalgae cultivation can also be obstructed because of the considerable culture pH shifts caused due to absorption of all dissolved CO2 by the cells during day and its release during night Ying et al. 2015 . Moreover excess O2 accumulation during day can also lead to photo oxidation and cell death. The utilization of wastewater for microalgae cultivation has also been suggested as a way to ease out excess water usage. However before use for microalgal cultivation wastewater is needed to be supplemented with nutrients and pre-treated to remove other microbes which if remain can compete with microalgae for nutrients. Pretreatment by autoclaving and filtration have been performed for microbial removal among which autoclaving might disrupt the nutrient load of wastewater too and particulates are not completely removed by autoclaving which can obstruct light utilization by microalgal cells during photosynthesis Ramsundar et al. 2017 . Moreover such additional pretreatments cause an unnecessary increase in energy consumption time system complexity and overall process costs. The level of nitrogen and the stage of growth are the main parame ters deciding the route of microalgal metabolism and so the depletion of nitrogen at the early or late stage of culture is reported unfavorable for microalgae growth and increase in biomass. Even though most lipid accumulation is favored by late depletion of nitrogen Gifuni et al. 2018 different classes of lipids accumulate under different light and nitrogen conditions. Considering the overall molecules involved in microalgal metabolism high metabolite accumulation happens in the late stationary phase or nitrogen depleted conditions Gifuni et al. 2018 . 7. Conclusions Techno-economic considerations are the key roadblocks in the commercialization of microalgae-based products because of high initial investment for cultivation and harvesting. However combating the challenges during each step would substantially reduce the cost of product development from microalgae. This review gives insights on the comprehensive outlook of existing harvesting methods for microalgal biomass recovery also the various methods and their challenges with an emphasis on the cost factor. Requirement of high energy and more time are the major challenges associated with physical methods to dewater more volume of microalgal culture which points out the need for an effective harvesting technique. Udayan et al.', 'Vol. 0123456789 Environment Development and Sustainability REVIEW Exploring the potential and progress of microalgae biomass production harvesting and pre treatment for sustainable biofuel production a comprehensive review Aman Singh Rajpoot1 Vikas Shende2 Hussain Mohamed Chelladurai1 Gaurav Dwivedi3 Tikendra Nath Verma4 Tushar Choudhary1 Received 20 April 2023 Accepted 4 January 2025 The Author s under exclusive licence to Springer Nature B.V. 2025 Abstract The demand for energy resources is rising as a result of energy consumption increasing faster than population growth. The high productivity the significant lipid concentrations of microalgae and their ability to grow in adverse environments make them very attractive as feedstocks for biofuels. In this review the authors discuss microalgae potentials as third-generation biofuels which include the different cultivation systems culture modes alimentation modes and harvesting technologies for microalgal biomass production before biofuel generation. A comprehensive literature review is conducted to identify relevant studies on microalgae by taking several academic databases to ensure a broad coverage of the literature and focusing on the studies of the last decade to ensure that the review includes the most recent advancements and trends in the field. The extracted data were then analysed to identify common trends innovations and gaps in the current research. The findings reveal that microalgae attain a lipid content of almost 10 40 a yield capacity of 58.7 136.9 kl ha and a heating value of 32.73 41.0 MJ kg. The combination of multiple harvesting methods effectively increases the capacity compared to when used individually as shown by both an increased harvest rate and a reduction in energy consumption. Additionally pre-treatment methods including mechanical thermal and enzymatic approaches optimize the conversion of microalgal biomass into various biofuels. Despite these advancements the transition from laboratory to commercial scale faces challenges including strain selection seasonal variations and cost-effective pre-treatment processes. The commercialization of microalgae-based biofuels will lead to a sustainable and low-carbon future with potential applications extending to food pharmaceuticals and cosmetics. Future research should focus on optimizing cultivation conditions harvesting methods and pre-treatment techniques to enhance the economic viability and environmental sustainability of microalgal biofuel production. These fossil fuels provide about 95 of the world s energy needs. Ardebili Khademalrasoul 2018 . Emissions of harmful greenhouse gases and pollutants such as particulate matter carbon monoxide unburnt hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides pollute the environment and endanger human life. However if emissions are not reduced carbon dioxide levels which are currently at about 420 ppmv parts per million volume are predicted to reach 500 ppmv by 2050 Caspeta et al. 2013 Gür Science 2022 . Fossil fuel depletion and its harmful climatic implications encourage the search for alternative fuels. Many nations have recognized the necessity of biofuel and are preparing to produce it and combine it with current transportation fuels in order to minimize their reliance on fossil fuels. As developing countries produce a large volume of organic waste they are considered as a primary raw source for biofuel production Khan et al. 2022 . Microalgae have become a promising option for producing biofuels in the current search for sustainable energy sources thanks to their abundant lipid content and fast growth rates. Studies have found that incorporating a mixture of up to 20 is advantageous without any modifications or alterations to fuel engines Lahane Subramanian 2015 Rajpoot et al. 2024a . The global concerns about climate change and energy security have triggered the urgent need for renewable energy solutions and viable and sustainable alternatives. Feasibly microalgae have a number of benefits over their conventional oil crop counterparts such as higher lipid production per unit land area and the ability to grow in a variety of environments including on infertile land or wastewater. The potential is to reduce probably millions of tons of greenhouse gas emissions and significantly reduce the need for fossil fuels Rajpoot et al. 2024b . Fossil fuels and biofuels come from extinct organisms and are also used to power generators cars and other devices in addition to producing heat and energy. Since fossil fuels and biofuels release large amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere their continued use has a negative impact on the environment. Although fossil fuels and biofuels share many characteristics Table 1 also identifies some important distinctions. Microalgae microscopic photosynthetic organisms have gained attention for their potential to produce biofuels such as biodiesel and bioethanol. Compared to terrestrial plants used for biofuels microalgae yield substantially higher amounts of lipids per unit area and time making them more efficient and sustainable. Different generations of biofuels have been developed over the last two decades for biofuel production Rajpoot et al. 2023a . There are currently four generations of biofuels produced from different sources first- second- third- and fourth-generation biofuels. Table 2 shows the four generations of biofuels. Research is presently being conducted on the third and fourth generations of biofuels. Solar fuels electro fuels biomass from marine algae and other genetically modified raw materials will be used to produce fourth-generation biofuels Moravvej et al. 2019 . Third- generation biofuels are produced from microalgal biomass. Edible and non-edible biomass are used to make the biofuels of the first and second generations respectively. The use of food crops for biofuel production which has an impact on human food sources is the main drawback of first-generation biofuels. However farming land is needed for second-genera- tion biofuels which puts food crops and their resources in competition. There are very few usable first- and second-generation biofuels due to their negative environmental effects. A. S. Rajpoot et al. Table 2 continued Biofuel Generation Feedstock source Processing method Advantages Disadvantages References 4th generation Genetically modified algae biomass solar fuels electro fuels etc Genetic modification transesterification biochemical thermochemical electrochemical High lipid content High yielding High carbon dioxide absorption capacity Higher production rate Economic for long period of time Technology not ready High initial cost Abdullah et al. 2019 Exploring the potential and progress of microalgae biomass The potential for third-generation biofuels to significantly contribute to the world s energy requirements has been highlighted by the environmental consequences and climate change caused by first- and second-generation biofuels Paramasivam et al. 2021 . 2 Research gap objectives and methodology 2.1 Research gap and objectives Based on the literature survey limited review articles have been reported in similar fields without considering all three aspects i.e. cultivation harvesting and pre-treatment of microalgae biomass for biofuel production incorporating the different parameters at each stage. The objective of the present review article is to comprehensively examine the current state-of-the-art in microalgae. A brief introduction and novel comparison have been made among various parameters and recent developments associated with microalgae including different cultivation and harvesting methods operating conditions pre-treatment methods with their current feasibility status advantages challenges etc. The review aims to highlight the advantages and limitations of various methodologies identify key research gaps and challenges and propose future directions for advancing the commercial viability and sustainability of microalgae-derived biofuels. The study s specific objectives include To identify and evaluate the effective microalgae strains for biofuel production. To analyse and compare different cultivation systems and their efficiencies. To assess innovative harvesting and pre-treatment methods that can reduce costs and energy usage. To explore the potential for integrating microalgae biofuel production with other technologies and industries. To provide a comprehensive overview of the environmental and economic viability of microalgae-based biofuels. 2.1.1 Methodology of the review The present study was conducted in a systematic and structured manner to ensure a full overview of the literature on microalgae-based biofuel generation. The methodology aimed to select the relevant studies. A thorough search of peer-reviewed journal articles confer- ence proceedings and reports was undertaken utilizing databases such as PubMed Scopus and Web of Science. The search was constrained to papers between 2010 and 2024 focus- ing on key terms such as cultivation and harvesting of microalgae biomass for biofuels microalgae conversion processes microalgae biofuels biofuel production technolo- gies renewable energy biomass pre-treatment etc. Studies covering biofuel produc- tion strategies problems or technological advancements were included. Excluded mate- rials involved studies focusing on unrelated elements of microalgae such as their use in food or pharmaceuticals. Relevant data from the selected research was extracted including information on biofuel production processes procedures problems and current advance- ments. Special emphasis was devoted to emerging trends and their potential scalability for industrial applications. A comparison analysis was undertaken to analyze the efficiency performance and economic feasibility of several biofuel production systems. The assess- ment also critically analyzed the limitations of the processes and technologies mentioned A. S. Rajpoot et al. including potential environmental implications and difficulty in scaling up production. Current barriers faced by the sector such as energy efficiency cost and sustainability were analyzed. Based on the findings gaps in the current literature were identified and relevant future study directions were noted. Emphasis was placed on overcoming existing hurdles and investigating technologies that could make biofuel production from microalgae more viable and sustainable. The methodology of the review is represented in the process flow chart of Fig. 1. 3 Microalgae growth and metabolism Various feedstocks have been researched and tested for their use as biofuels. Table 3 shows some of the potential bio feedstocks from the three generations of biofuels with their respective characteristics which shows how microalgae fit into the picture as the top priority for the production of biofuels. Using microalgae biofuel is advantageous in that it may be produced at any time of year on any land that is suitable or unsuitable for farming. As a result microalgae have a higher oil yield than any other crop and have no environmental impact. For example microalgae can be used for wastewater treatment carbon capturing reducing water salinity etc. Daneshvar et al. 2022 Su 2021 . Also microalgae cultivation does not require any extra chemical compounds for its growth. It has the ability to grow quickly with an oil content of 20 60 . Compared to other bio feedstocks microalgae exhibits an oil extraction efficiency of over 91 Deshmukh et al. 2019 . Since microalgae produce more energy per hectare than other feedstocks they contribute to a reduction in the amount of land used. Microalgae generally consist of 7 23 lipids 4 57 carbohydrates and 6 71 proteins depending on the species culture metabolisms and techniques used Praja- pati et al. 2013 . The main component of microalgae that are used to produce biofuels is lipid. For growth microalgae need carbon dioxide water sunlight and a few other nutrients like phosphorus potassium and nitrogen Yaakob et al. 2021 . S. Rajpoot et al. light intensity photoperiod salinity and medium pH impact microalgal growth Parjik- olaei et al. 2013 . The process known as the Calvin-Benson cycle fixes inorganic CO2 into 3-carbon molecules called glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate or G3P which are then absorbed into lipids starch sugars or other molecules necessary for the development of cells Beer et al. 2009 . During photosynthesis glucose is produced which is then used to make lipids proteins and carbohydrates Okoro et al. 2019a . Table 4 displays the variables that influence the microalgae development. In their natural state microalgae are either heterotrophic autotrophic or mixotrophic. They can grow in both freshwater and saltwater and they can have one or more cells. An estimated 80 000 species are believed to exist on Earth of which about 40 000 have been identified and studied Khan et al. 2018 . The microbes are able to multiply more quickly because of their greater surface-to-volume ratio. Microalgae cells are typically tiny with sizes ranging from a few micrometres to several meters such as giant kelp Zhu et al. 2018 . The surface of microalgae cells is negatively charged Huang et al. 2020 . Because of their ease of suspension in the medium microalgae cells are kept from aggregating. The by-products of microalgae cultivation include animal feed protein food supplements biofuels bioethanol biodiesel bio-oil and bio-hydrogen and more. Furthermore biodegradable plastic can be made from the polysaccharides found in algae Rajpoot et al. 2022 . Table 5 displays the lipid content and lipid productivity of some microalgae species that are either widely used or have the potential to be a competitive substitute for the manufacture of biofuel. To meet the commercial demand some systems need to be developed. Two primary methods for microalgal cultivation systems for biofuel production are open systems and closed systems Ananthi et al. 2021b . S. Rajpoot et al. is simpler to construct and maintain. Highly effective systems for treating wastewater are open systems like tanks scrubbers raceway ponds etc. The development of microalgae farming is however often hampered by a number of issues including easy contamination insufficient use of light the requirement for vast areas of land water evaporation pond collapse and a lack of control over growth parameters. Table 6 shows the requirements for open and closed microalgae cultivation systems. 4.1.1 Open pond system Open ponds have built-in raceways or circular configurations. Open raceway ponds are the most widely used microalgae cultivation technology. Although previously plastic-covered earth-lined ponds were also utilized they are typically constructed of concrete. Compared to photobioreactors they are less costly to build and run. To provide better sunlight and achieve a high growth rate of microalgae cells the race- way pond system Fig. 2a is constructed to be of the horizontal shallow raceway type around 20 to 30 cm deep separated by vertical partitions in a multiple-loop configuration Paul et al. 2021 . It contains a specially constructed paddlewheel for mixing the biomass and recirculating it around the loop. It contains baffles as well to direct the flow and pre- vent sedimentation during the cultivation cycle. For shallow open ponds enough sunlight penetration is required Raeisossadati et al. 2019 . The circular pond Fig. 2b is an addi- tional kind of open pond system where the culture is mixed and moved by a central pivot spinning agitator Lee et al. 2018 . The cell suspension circulates at a speed of 0.2 0.5 m s inside the channels which are normally coated with an inert plastic layer and propelled by rotary blades propellers or pumps. The machine collects the cells extracts the suspension periodically and returns the additional liquid to the pond. Utilizing non-arable and marginal land is one of the main advantages of the open sys- tem. Compared to photobioreactors open systems require less energy and maintenance. Raceway ponds have the ability to produce more net energy than photobioreactors since their overall energy input is lower Rodolfi et al. 2009 . Currently open systems raceway type or open circular ponds tanks account for around 95 of microalgae production. The rate of CO2 fixation in these systems is limited to 20 50 by microalgae due to which these systems cannot be considered as an effective CO2 bio-fixation method. Another Table 6 Requirements of open and closed microalgae cultivation Xiaogang et al. 2020 Requirements factors Open system Closed system Space High Low to medium Mixing Poor Uniform Water Very high Low Microalgae cell density Low High Energy demand Low High Oxygen Low High Carbon dioxide High Low Initial cost High Very high Productivity Low High Harvesting cost High Low Operation cost Low High Contamination risk Very high Low to medium Exploring the potential and progress of microalgae biomass limitation of open pond systems is low productivity. In open systems productivity is directly impacted by unpredictable seasonal factors Paul et al. 2021 . In open ponds envi- ronmental conditions are largely uncontrollable. Low productivity in open ponds is attrib- uted to various factors such as light restriction caused by culture density and CO2 transfer rate. The rapid contamination of open-pond systems by undesirable species further restricts the system s wider application. As a result a few species are grown in open ponds. Some of these species include Chlorella Daniella salina Spirulina etc. Kumar et al. 2021 . 4.1.2 Closed systems The culture of microalgal species is done in closed systems called photobioreactors PBRs which use closed tubular reactors and artificial light. Reduced light route and increased light intensity are the basic operating principles of the majority of photobioreactors. This system maintains the ideal conditions for the growth of a particular microalgae strain while preventing contamination of the microalgae culture. They re typically employed for high- value products that can t be grown in open systems. Gaseous exchange inside the system requires mixing Ananthi et al. 2021b . In this system mechanical stirring and pumping or airlift mixing are frequently employed. Mixing is useful in phototrophic systems because it makes simultaneous mixing and aeration possible. Because they use different combinations of light sources to increase photoperiod and enhance low light intensities brought on by solar variation photobioreactors are more adaptable. Artificial light has the potential to increase microalgal biomass productivity by maintaining photoperiod and light intensity Lau et al. 2022 . Optical cell density which can be used to accurately estimate the dry weight of biomass is a characteristic of the growth rate of microalgae in PBRs Busnel et al. 2021 . The best photobioreactors for large-scale culturing are tubular ones Fig. 3a . Tubu- lar PBR is typically constructed using straight glass or plastic tubes arranged in helical vertical slanted or horizontal configurations. Solar collectors are typically composed of plastic glass with a diameter ranging from 10 to 60 mm which allows light to permeate Fig. 2 Cultivation systems used for microalgae cultivation a open raceway ponds b open circular ponds A. S. Rajpoot et al. dense cultures Zuccaro et al. 2020 . Usually a degasser is employed which periodically extracts extra oxygen from the culture. High oxygen levels lead to decreased productiv- ity due to photooxidative stress. In order to create mixing inside the reactor turbulence is used. Another type of reactor that has dominated microalgae production in the last decade is the flat-panel PBR reactor Fig. 3b . To maximize the amount of sunlight captured it is shaped like a cube and composed of translucent or semi-transparent materials including plastic bags glass plexiglass and polycarbonate. Flat plate photobioreactors achieve high cell densities due to their large surface areas which help in capturing sunlight. The dense microalgae cultures are fed through flat panels SundarRajan et al. 2019 . Flat-plate reactors are preferred for large-scale cultivation due to their high photosynthetic efficiency but they have high mixing and installation costs Suparmaniam et al. 2019 . Photobioreactors enable the length of the light path to be optimized resulting in enhanced biomass productivity and preventing contamination of the atmosphere Lau Fig. 3 Cultivation systems used for microalgae cultivation a closed tubular bioreactor b closed flat- plate bioreactors Exploring the potential and progress of microalgae biomass et al. 2022 . Long tube lengths lead to excessive oxygen accumulation CO2 depletion and pH variations. The productivity of biomass is negatively impacted by each of these conditions. When compared to open systems photobioreactors are thought to be a useful tool for overcoming contamination and low production Arutselvan et al. 2022 . The primary disadvantage of numerous photobioreactors is their elevated energy usage. Artificial lighting raises electricity consumption and capital expenses Nwoba et al. 2019 . It has been suggested that light-emitting diodes be used instead of fluorescent lights because they are more affordable. Energy can be saved by lighting interior culturing system components with optical fibers exposed to the sun. The benefits and limitations of open and closed microalgal cultivation techniques are displayed in Table 7. 4.2 Microalgal cultivation modes The technique known as the microalgae cultivation method refers to a way of setting up a system that will encourage or boost the growth of both new and existing microalgae cells. For microalgal cultivation systems there are three different kinds of modes of operation batch semicontinuous and continuous. Batch culture is a well-established technology that allows microalgae to be cultivated in a variety of freshwater and marine habitats Iglesias et al. 2019 . Because of nutrient absorption batch cultures are unable to maintain stable nutrient levels which leads to lower biomass output Sutherland et al. 2020 . Several studies have shown that biofuel may be produced by continuously or semi- continuously cultivating microalgae Peter et al. 2022a . Biomass is periodically harvested in semicontinuous culture by adding fresh culture medium El Ouaer et al. 2020 . In contrast nutrients are continuously separated and the nutritional medium is provided at the same time when microalgae are produced continuously Solmaz et al. 2020 . The continuous culture method minimizes downtime because the established cell withdrawal will be replaced simultaneously with a new medium input. Continuously growing microalgae have a better possibility of being used to manufacture biofuel on a pilot scale Cheirsilp Torpee 2012 . Table 8 contrasts the benefits and drawbacks of batch semicontinuous and continuous modes. When algal growth in batch and semicontinuous cultures was compared semicontinuous cultures outperformed batch cultures Huo et al. 2020 . Significant disadvantages of semicontinuous and continuous modes include high starting costs and unstable functioning over the long run. Consequently the development of a culture mode appropriate for the majority of microalgae species with high growth rates and productivity is necessary. 4.3 Microalgal alimentation modes Diverse species of microalgae have different modes of metabolism Fig. 4 such as auto- trophs heterotrophs and mixotrophs Ray et al. 2022 . 4.3.1 Autotrophic cultivation Through photosynthesis microalgae in autotrophic culture directly convert inorganic car- bon into organic matter. As a result of their shared ability to be photosynthetic that is to absorb light energy and use CO2 for growth and cultivation microalgae species most frequently use the autotrophic cultivation mode of metabolism. By employing solar light to capture CO2 from the atmosphere and gas from industrial waste this cultivation method A. S. Rajpoot et al. S. Rajpoot et al. for microalgae can somewhat reduce pollution. Consequently this technique of microalgae cultivation is economical and ecologically benign. In phototrophic culture microalgae can accumulate lipids from 5 to 68 depending on the strain Ananthi et al. 2021b . The concentration of microalgal lipids rises in more nitrogen-limited environments Yuan et al. 2019 . When cultivated in a photoautotrophic environment Chlorella sp. has the maximum lipid content weighing 0.179 g L d Cheirsilp Torpee 2012 . Cultivating microalgae close to power businesses that emit large amounts of CO2 is preferred since it lowers global CO2 emissions through autotrophic growth. Because there is less chance of contamination photoautotrophic microalgal cultivation can be carried out outdoors in raceway ponds and open ponds on a large scale. Due to the low biomass concentration in these settings the main problem in this technique is the high expense of microalgae culture Verma et al. 2020 . For the photoautotrophic mode to be used commercially for an extended length of time significant research and funding are needed. 4.3.2 Heterotrophic cultivation Heterotrophic culture is the process of growing microalgae without sunlight. It is the method via which organic carbon is used to fuel microalgal growth in the absence of light energy. With the exception of the addition of organic carbon heterotrophic cultivation is comparable to autotrophic cultivation. Chlorella protothecoides and other microalgae were able to transition from phototrophic to heterotrophic growth and attain a forty percent increase in lipid content Ananthi et al. 2021b . For the development of microalgae the most prevalent organic carbon sources are glucose lactose fructose galactose sucrose and glycerol. This technique s primary disadvantage is that it requires organic carbon sources which increases the risk of contamination Oliveira et al. 2021 . Moreover using organic molecules as a source of carbon and energy raises the cost of cultivation considerably. In photoautotrophic mode microalgae convert CO2 into organic compounds by utilizing sunlight to break down an inorganic carbon source while in heterotrophic mode microalgae rely on the metabolism of organic substances present to supply a carbon source and energy. Higher lipid Fig. 4 Autotrophic heterotrophic and mixotrophic metabolisms in microalgae cultivation Exploring the potential and progress of microalgae biomass content microalgae are developed by heterotrophic culture. These microalgae are more prone to contamination though particularly in systems of open production. Although photoautotrophic farming produces less lipid it is more environmentally benign Chew et al. 2018 . Microalgal cultivation in a heterotrophic mode is more advantageous than in a photoautotrophic mode because microalgae can develop in dark environments which means that their surface-to-volume ratio needs are substantially lower than those of the photoautotrophic mode and hence increased cell mass is obtained due to the higher energy density of the given carbon source than CO2 in the photoheterotrophic mode Hu et al. 2018 . 4.3.3 Mixotrophic cultivation Microalgae grown in a mixotrophic environment obtain their energy from both light and organic matter and their carbon from CO2 and organic carbon. This enables the algae to carry out photosynthesis and take up organic nutrients from the environment. Mixotrophic processes involve both autotrophic and heterotrophic systems. Both the respiratory and photosynthetic metabolisms are active during mixotrophic growth which involves the simultaneous absorption of CO2 and organic carbon Pang et al. 2019 . For this mode a closed bioreactor with a light source is utilized because using organic chemicals will contaminate. More lipid and biomass are produced by mixotrophic microalgae cultivation than by heterotrophic microalgae culture Cheng et al. 2022 . The needs benefits and drawbacks of microalgal culture in various cultivation modalities are listed in Tables 9 and 10 which presents a comparative analysis of the biomass concentration carbohydrate content and fat content of different metabolisms. 5 Microalgae harvesting Using a range of downstream techniques harvesting is an essential process that extracts algal biomass from the algal growing culture. The small size and colloidal stability of microalgal cells make the extraction of microalgal biomass a difficult and costly process. The kind of biomass recovery is determined by the density of the biomass slurry. Tech- niques for harvesting biomass include gravity sedimentation filtering centrifugation and others. Various techniques for capturing microalgal biomass are displayed in Fig. 5. 5.1 Thickening methods 5.1.1 Gravity sedimentation The process of gravity sedimentation involves allowing a concentrated microalgae slurry to settle and separating the denser microalgae cells from the clear liquid called supernatant Nie et al. 2018 . Larger and denser cells descend more quickly than smaller ones with size and density having a major influence on the rate of settling Fig. 6a . When the end product like biofuel has a low market value gravity sedimentation is the best method for harvesting microalgae because it is highly effective for a wide range of microalgae species and notably energy-efficient. Stokes law explains the principles governing the sedimenta- tion rate. It establishes a relationship between the settling velocity and the size density A. S. Rajpoot et al.
