The friction and collision gener- ated between the beads shear the outer membrane of microalgae cells thereby extracting intracellu- lar lipids and other compounds. The efficiency of this method depends on bead size biomass con- centration temperature agitation speed and time Roux et al. 2017 . Bead milling is considered as the most efficient membrane disruption technique but it is highly energy intensive and hence chal- lenging to scale up Dong et al. 2016 . b Ultrasound assisted extraction This method uti- lised ultrasonic waves ranging from 20 to 50 kHz which damage the cells and allows mass transfer to the external system supporting extraction of lipids. Mostly horn and bath sonicators are used to disrupt cells by ultrasound. Ultrasound waves can disrupt cell structure by two mechanisms viz. cavitation and acoustic streaming. Cavitation is the growth and collapse of microbubbles caused by alternate cycle of high and low pressure during sonication of liquid cultures while acoustic streaming accelerates proper mixing Khanal et al. 2007 . Localised heat shocks are generated by transient cavitation which creates pressure on cells to rupture the outer membrane Brujan et al. 2001 . The process of ultra-sound assisted lipid extraction proves to be less time con- suming and generates relatively low temperatures as compared to microwave or autoclave assisted extrac- tion processes thereby preventing thermal denatura- tion of bioactive molecules Kumar et al. 2015 . c Microwave assisted extraction Microwave assisted extraction of lipids was first reported in 1980s from seed soil and food Ganzler et al. 1986 and was found to be more efficient and economical than other conventional methods. Microwaves are electromag- netic radiation of frequency from 0.3 to 300 GHz which can generate intracellular heat and pressure resulting in formation of water vapour within the cells. This in turn results in electroporation effect which breaks cell membrane rendering efficient extraction of intracellular compounds from micro- algae cells Amarni et al. 2010 . The microwave assisted heating uses a non-contact heat source which can penetrate into the biomaterials interact with polar molecules like water in the biomass and heat the whole sample uniformly. The co-solvent system of ethanol and chloroform can be used for the extraction of lipids mediated by microwave. Biodiesel Microalgae is categorised as 3rd generation feedstock for biodiesel production. As compared to other energy crops apparatus Mahmood et al. 2017 . The authors in this study reported that lipid extraction by renew- able bio-based solvents was more efficient as com- pared to petroleum derived solvents like hexane. The solvent polarity plays a key role in the lipid extraction process. The combination of polar and non- polar solvents improves the efficiency of lipid extraction as the polar solvents can penetrate cell wall and making intracellular non polar lipids available to the non-polar solvents Li et al. 2014 . b Supercritical CO2 extraction The super critical sol- vent extraction generally uses CO2 as solvent under varied extraction pressure and temperature and yields solvent free crude lipid Taher et al. 2014 . Tang et al. 2011 reported yield of 33.9 of lipids extracted from Schizochytrium limacinum using supercritical CO2 and under the optimum conditions of tempera- ture 40 °C and pressure 35 MPa. Optimization of the parameters of supercritical CO2 extraction process is essential as it affects the yield of lipid extraction which varies among different microalgae strains. c Ionic solvent extraction Ionic liquids ILs are salt solutions containing an organic cation and an inorganic anion which are liquid at temperature range of 0 140 °C. ILs are non-flammable and have no detectable vapour pressure which makes them pollution free Kumar et al. 2017 . The ionic solvent liquid extractions are favourable method for the extraction of microalgal lipid because of their non-volatility and thermal stability. Ionic liquid-methanol mixture shows the higher extrac- tion efficiency. The dipolarity of the ionic liquid impacts the extraction yield and serves as green solvent for the lipid extraction from microalgal lipid Kim et al. 2012 . Salvo et al. 2011 has reported a single step process of lipid extraction using IL 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium which lyse the microalgal cells forming an upper hydrophobic lipid phase. Hydrogen bond acidity and polarity of ILs are the key parameters that need to be consid- ered for efficient lipid extraction from microalgae Kim et al. 2012 . The solvent free method such as supercritical CO2 extraction might be clean and promising approach for more yield of lipid but remain at the laboratory scale. The solvent extrac- tion methods are used commercially with com- paratively higher yield of lipid than mechanical methods Kumar et al. 2015 . B Mechanical methods of lipid extraction a Bead Milling This method utilised small glass beads with agitation to disrupt the cell microalgae 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 Page 15 of 29 378 microalgae have higher growth rate high lipid content and can be cultivated in non-arable land. These advantages have attracted microalgae as the most potential feedstock for bio- diesel in recent times. The methods of conversion of lipid or oil into biodiesel can be categorised as esterification trans- esterification and interesterification Sandoval et al. 2017 . a Esterification Non-edible oils waste cooking oil and animal fats are some of the biodiesel feedstock which contain high free fatty acid FFA content. FFA con- tent can be quantified by titration based methods where oils are hydrolyzed by solvents ethanol diethyl ether and titrated against alcoholic KOH solution. The value is expressed as fatty acids or as acid number mg KOH g . Individual FFA can also be determined by gas or liquid chromatography after its conversion to methyl esters. These FFA can be converted to esters by esterification reaction in the presence of methanol and strong acid catalyst as shown below. The esters thus formed can be subsequently used to produce biodiesel fatty acid methyl ester by alkaline transesterification process Mathimani et al. 2015 . Esterification reaction R1 alkyl group of fatty acid chain C O R1 OH + CH3OH R1 OCH3 O + H2O Cat. b Transesterification This is the most commonly and widely used process for biodiesel production. Transes- terification reaction basically converts high molecular weight triglycerides into three molecules of esters and glycerol in the presence of excess alcohol and catalyst acid or base . It is a series of reaction where one ester is transformed into another by the interchange of the alkoxy moiety. This reaction is reversible hence addi- tion of excess alcohol is required to shift the reaction equilibrium towards product side. Due to low cost and higher reactivity methanol is preferred for this reac- tion but other alcohols such as ethanol propanol amyl alcohol butanol also shows good reactivity. Microalgae lipids consist of triglyceride chains which undergoes transesterification reaction in three steps yielding di- glyceride in first step followed by formation of mono- glyceride in second step and subsequently forming fatty acid methyl ester as the final product and glycerol as the byproduct in third step Thao et al. 2013 El-Sheekh et al. 2016 .The overall reaction can be represented as 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 378 Page 16 of 29 c Interesterification Interesterification is an alternative route of biodiesel production which occurs in the pres- ence of simple esters such as methyl acetate instead of methanol. Fatty acid methyl ester biodiesel is the main product of this reaction along with the by-product triacetin. Triacetin acts as a blending agent in fuel with several other applications which increases its market value as compared to glycerol. Investigators found that 20 blending of triacetin to biodiesel is favourable for present IC engines. This makes overall interesterifi- cation process economically attractive and viable as compared to transesterification process. The overall interesterification reaction can be represented as The conversion of lipids to the biodiesel is affected by the reaction parameter such as alcohol lipid ratio reaction time and temperature stirring and catalyst conversion. Increase in the alcohol volume enhances the yield of the biodiesel. Simi- larly the reaction temperature and time remains directly pro- portional to the biodiesel yield. The catalyst such as strong acid H2SO4 drives the reaction forward and increase the rate of reaction Thao et al. 2013 Cao et al. 2013 . The choice of catalyst is based on the free fatty acid FFA con- tent of the lipid. The recovery of biodiesel is an important step after the transesterification. The biodiesel produced can be dissolved in hexane whereas glycerol is miscible in water thus the addition of hexane and water to the reaction mixture forms two layers. Upper layer contains biodiesel dissolved in hexane whereas excess alcohol glycerol and other impurities gets separated with water at bottom layer. Repeated water wash is given to biodiesel till its pH becomes neutral to remove catalyst molecules from the biodiesel Mathimani et al. 2015 El-Shimi et al. 2013 . The addi- tion of hexane along with the reaction mixture significantly increases the yield of biodiesel as post transesterification the biodiesel synthesised gets dissolved in hexane and facilitates the recovery of biodiesel Sánchez et al. 2012 Dianursanti et al. 2015 . Transesterification of triglycerides in the presence of methanol and catalyst results in the production of bio- diesel and glycerol as the byproduct. Glycerol forms the major byproduct of biodiesel industries which remains in its crude form. Pure glycerol has intensive applications in food pharma cosmetic and polymer industries but indus- trial crude glycerol contains many contaminants and requires multiple purification steps to make it suitable to be used in product based industries. Bioconversion of this waste glyc- erol to numerous value-added products can be a possible source of additional revenue and financial viability and sus- tainability for biodiesel industry. Pigments and vitamins Microalgae are rich source of nutrition and can be consid- ered as bio-based crop for future Draaisma et al. 2013 . Microalgae derived pigments have wide applications in vari- ous industries including pharmaceutical cosmetic food and nutraceutical. These photosynthetic pigments can be catego- rised into three major classes viz. chlorophylls phycobilins and carotenoids xanthophylls and carotenes . Chlorophylls and carotenoids are hydrophilic while phycobilins are hydro- phobic and are fat-soluble. Various environmental factors effect production efficiencies of microalgae pigments such as light temperature salinity pH metal stress nutrient sup- plement and limitation Verma et al. 2009 . Various spectral portions of light such as blue-red red-far red blue-green green red and blue red act as photo-morphogenic signals and directly effects pigment composition in microalgae Kagawa et al. 2007 . Light intensity stimulates pigment accumulation in microalgae. Cyanobacteria prefers low light intensities and hence favours the production of phyco- biliproteins Pagels et al. 2019 whereas Spirulina produces higher phycoerythrin and phycocyanin under higher light 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 Page 17 of 29 378 intensity 135 mmolphotons m2 sec Madhyastha et al. 2007 . Similarly carotenoids such as β-carotene and asta- xanthin content in Dunaliella salina and Haematococcus pluvialis respectively is highly enhanced by increasing the light intensity Pisal et al. 2005 . This was interpreted by various authors that intense illumination results in excess photo oxidation leading to oxidative stress thereby generat- ing oxygen radicals which in turn increase the production of pigments Salguero et al. 2003 . Microalgae like Haematococcus pluvialis Chlorella vul- garis Dunaliella salina and the Spirulina platensis are being cultivated for vitamin extraction. Microalgae pigments like carotenoids chlorophyll and phycobilliproteins can be used as precursors of vitamins Paolicelli et al. 2011 . Spirulina sp. is rich in carotenoid pigments which act as precursors for vitamin A and can be extracted with the help of organic solvents after saponification of algal biomas with ethanolic KOH Mathimani et al. 2018 . Provitamin such as alpha tocopherol phylloquinone gamma-tocopherol retinol can- thaxanthin phytofluene and lutein can be extracted from Tetradesmus obliquus by supercritical fluid extraction with the use of CO2. Edelmann et al. 2019 extracted riboflavin niacin folate and vitamin B12 form commercial microal- gae powder. Riboflavin and niacin were extracted with acid water whereas folate and vitamin B12 were extracted with extraction buffer. Although algae being major reservoir of vitamins and pro-vitamins more than 90 of commercial- ised β-carotene is produced through chemical synthesis. Vitamins and pigments are high value products which can add surplus revenue to the biorefinery concept. Therefore detailed evaluation of the factors extraction procedures and reactor configuration is very much essential for commercial production of microalgae pigments and vitamins within a biorefinery approach. Proteins Microalgae also serve as the source of essential amino acids for human nutrition and can benefit in fighting malnutrition and other health issues Edelmann et al. 2019 Raja et al. 2007 . Proteins from microalgae are extracted through enzy- matic hydrolysis and chemical extractions. Some new tech- niques assisted by microwave and ultrasound pulsed electric fields are also applied for extraction of proteins Christaki et al. 2011 . The algal protein extracted chemically with acid or alkali treatment is precipitated by centrifugation or by three phase partitioning TPP . Few process utilised a com- bination of two three methods such as acid base treatment followed by ultrasound. Kadam et al. 2017 . Ultrasound mediated protein extraction generates cavitation at liquid solid interface which exerts pressure on the microalgae cells and force them to break out. The extraction with deionized water allow cell lysis by osmotic shock and eases the protein extraction from the algal cell whereas the enzymatic extrac- tion uses polysaccharidase to extract the proteins from algal cells. The protein extraction from algal species is greatly affected by pH of extraction medium. The isoelectric point of proteins 6 enhances the protein solubility and stability subsequently enhancing crude protein yield from microalgae Soto-sierra et al. 2018 . The low cost feasible technique for efficient protein extraction can be mediated by simple stir- ring or ultrasonication followed by three phase partitioning Chia et al. 2019 . The protein extraction from microalgal cells is also affected by the pretreatment method applied for rupturing of cells via autoclave sonication and high pressure homogenization Parimi et al. 2015 . Other products Microalgae biomass has also been explored extensively for production of various other biobased products that can add value to the algae biorefinery model. Microalgae biomass are rich in various biomolecules such as proteins vitamins lipid minerals and pigments which can provide essential nutritional value to animal or aqua feed. It therefore acts as a potential alternative which has the ability to replace fish oil or feed thus driving towards sustainable aquacul- ture. Apart from providing nutrition microalgae biomass also acts as immunostimulant thereby improvising immu- nity of aquatic animals Shah et al. 2018 Charoonnart et al. 2018 . Several authors have studied the application of vari- ous microalgae strains in aquaculture such as Chlorella vul- garis Arthrospira platensis Ascochloris spp. Phaeodacty- lum tricornutum Pakravan et al. 2017 Sharma et al. 2019 Sorensen et al. 2016 . Microalgae based biofertilizer is another product that could be channelized in the microalgae biorefinery approach to validate zero waste circular bioeconomy concept. Apart from the key bioactive compounds microalgae biomass contains high NPK content making it suitable as organic manure or biofertilizer with a potential to replace the cur- rent chemical fertilizers. Recently Khan and co-authors have studied biofertilizer potential of Chlorella minutissima and concluded to contain 1.15 P 5.87 N and 0.28 K which is better than available organic fertilizers Khan et al. 2018 . Moreover application of algal biomass as manure to soils would not result in volatilization of nitrogen as ammonium or loss due to leaching as only 5 of algal nitrogen is avail- able as mineral N Khan et al. 2018 . Other key products that has been explored by various authors are bioethanol biohydrogen DHA which has been detailed in Table 3. Products from delipidified microalgae residue Lipid extraction from microalgae biomass is an inten- sive process which generates surplus amounts of residual 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 378 Page 18 of 29 biomass which is termed as delipidified microalgal residue DMR . Although lipid is completely extracted from these residues but it still acts as a rich source of carbohydrates proteins minerals and other essential elements that could be precisely utilised for development of sustainable algal bio refinery. High market price of biodiesel could be counter- poised by adding revenue from other co-products produced from by-products of the process such as DMR. Effective use of DMR for energy recovery and other value added compounds would justify the sustainability of microalgal biorefinery approach. DMR has been reported to be an excel- lent feedstock for production of biofuels such as biohydro- gen biomethane and bioethanol. It is also a promising raw material for biopolymer production. In this section we have reviewed the potential of DMR to energetic and other value added compounds considering their potential to improve the economics of the microalgal biorefinery from wastewater. Biohydrogen After lipid recovery DMR is still a rich source of carbo- hydrates and proteins which acts as organic substrate for various hydrogen producing microbes. DMRs undergo harsh oil extraction process and hence are expected to be directly converted to hydrogen or other fuels. But recent studies have showed that DMRs require pretreatment to make the cellular carbon accessible to microbial flora for production of H2 or methane. Studies also proved that pretreatment procedures like chemical mechanical and thermochemical are benefi- cial for improved H2 production from DMRs. Yang et al. 2011a b investigated various pretreatment methods on DMR of Scenedesmus and concluded that thermo-alkaline pretreatment at 100 °C and 8 g L NaOH resulted in a three- fold increase in the yield of H2 to 45.54 mL g-volatile solid VS . Pretreatment resulted in improved solubilisation of carbohydrates and proteins ranging from 38 to 49 and 28 to 58 respectively. Subhash and Mohan 2014 have reported biohydrogen production from DMB of mixed microalgae using acidogenic consortia of bacteria. They have utilised untreated and acid treated extract slurry and solid DMR to achieve specific hydrogen yields of 4.9 3.3 3.0 and 2.4 mol kg COD of DMR extract slurry solid and untreated DMB respectively. Maurya et al. 2016 have reviewed the entire process and reported various strategies to valorize de-oiled algal biomass in order to shape a sustainable algal biorefinery. Biomethane Biomethane is a major component of biogas which is pro- duced by anaerobic digestion of organic wastes. The effi- ciency of biogas production from organic waste depends on the C N ratio of the feedstock. DMR has high C N ratio which makes it suitable for growth of methanogenic microbes for production of high methane content biogas. Numerous studies have been reported on biomethane pro- duction from microalgal biomass including deoiled biomass Bohutskyi et al. 2015 Cheng et al. 2016a b Quinn et al. 2014 Kinnunen et al. 2014 Zhao et al. 2014 . These authors have optimised various process parameters for methane pro- duction from deoiled biomass of different algal strains such as Nannochloropsis salina Auxenochlorella protothecoides Chlorella variabilis Chlorella sorokiniana. These studies resulted in enhanced biomethane production with a yield ranging from 140 to 380 ml CH4 g-volatile solids. Biom- ethane has a high calorific value and can add value to the biorefinery process. Biogas containing 70 methane could be directly used for cooking thermal and lightning purposes. This makes it a promising value added product of microalgae biorefinery. Bioethanol Recently bioethanol has gained enormous exposure due to attractive government policies demanding for blending of ethanol with gasoline ranging from 15 E15 to 85 E85 . Although a variety of feedstocks are available but majority of current bioethanol supplies are from corn and sugarcane which are food crops and hence they are termed as first gen- eration biofuels. Bioethanol production from food crops is not favourable since this may result in food shortages and price hikes particularly in a developing nation like India. This has paved the way towards search for alternate sources as feedstock in order to reduce the operational cost. Reports on bioethanol production from algal biomass are available and delipdified biomass which is a byproduct of algal indus- tries acts a potential source for bioethanol production. After lipid extraction the left over biomass is rich in complex sugars in the form of carbohydrates which can be hydro- lyzed to simple sugars by saccharification. The sugar hydro- lyzates are fermented with the most commonly used yeast strain Saccharomyces cerevisiae to produce ethanol Alam et al. 2019 Kim et al. 2020a b . Enzymatic hydrolysis of raw or pretreated DMR has resulted in sugar yields ranging from 37 to 43 w w Pancha et al. 2016 . Bioethanol yield from DMR after saccharification and fermentation has been reported by various researchers which range from 0.14 to 0.26 g g DMR Cheng et al. 2016a b Mirsiaghi et al. 2015 Goo et al. 2013 Lam et al. 2014 . Biopolymer Delipidified biomass acts as an excellent source for biopoly- mers such as polyhydroxybutyrate PHB polyhydroxyal- kanoate PHA which has attracted a great deal of attention 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 Page 19 of 29 378 due to their biodegradability chemical-diversity biocom- patibility and their production from renewable carbon resources. Kumar et al. 2020 reported production of 0.43 g PHB g dry cell weight. The current methods for commercial production of PHA PHB utilise pure strains defined medium under aseptic conditions which adds to the overall cost of the process thereby increasing the market price. The production cost can be reduced by utilising feedstock which are cheaper and renewable. DMR contains surplus amounts of complex polysaccharides like cellulose starch and other nutrients. Studies are reported on application of pretreatment methods physical chemical thermal and enzymatic that breaks the complex molecules into simple easy to hydrolyze sugars. These simple molecules can be utilised by pure or mixed microbial cultures for production of biopolymers. Pure cul- tures belonging to species Pseudomonas Acaligenes Azo- tobacter Bacillus and Cupriavidus necator has the ability to convert organic sugars to PHA PHB and accumulate intra- cellularly. Mixed cultures obtained from activated sludge wastewater streams household garbage municipal solid waste etc. acts as a good source of inoculum and substrate for accumulation of intracellular biopolymers Salehizadeh et al. 2004 . Various reports have been reported for produc- tion of biopolymers PHA PHB by using DMR derived sug- ars Kumar et al. 2018a b Chandra et al. 2019 . Apart from bacterial species few microalgae and cyanobacteria species also have the ability to accumulate PHA PHBs intracellu- larly such as Chlorella fritschii Scenedesmus almeriensis Phaeodactylum tricornutum Neochloris oleobundans and Calothrix scytonemicola. Another approach of bioplastic production is by blending raw or deoiled microalgae bio- mass with other bio or petroleum based polymers or addi- tives Cinar 2020 . Other products Delipidified algae biomass are the left over residue generated after extensive solvent treatment of raw algae biomass to extract lipid. The utilisation of deoiled biomass is essential in order to successfully implement the zero waste biorefin- ery approach. After the lipid is extracted algae biomass still contains some amount of polysaccharides proteins and other essential elements which defines its potential to be used in aqua and animal feed. Reports suggest that deoiled biomass of Haematococcus pluvialis when fed to shrimps showed high growth rate and low feed conversion ratio as compared to the control Ju et al. 2012 . In another study Patterson and et al. replaced 10 of fish meal with defatted algae biomass based on Navicula sp. and Nannochloropsis salina and observed no significant reduction in growth rate of Red drum fish as compared to control diet Patterson et al. 2013 Shah et al. 2018 . Another possible utilisation of defatted algae biomass is its application as biofertilizer. It has been used as a replacement of chemical fertilizer for the growth of Zea mays L and also reported to improve the organic carbon of barren soil Maurya et al. 2016 . Apart from this delipidified biomass can be converted to syngas bio-oil and bio-char through thermochemical conversion process such as gasification and pyrolysis Bui et al. 2016 . Challenges and recent developments Microalage biorefinery has received enormous limelight in recent times. Significant advantages have been identified in the microalgal biorefinery approach and its integration into the circular bioeconomy. Apart from the developments and increased popularity it has come across various bottlenecks. The main issue lies in downstream processing that accounts for 40 of the total cost mainly due to impossibility of simultaneous recovery of multiple products of microalgal biorefinery. In recent times algae have been proved to be a promising source for transportation fuels like biodiesel bioethanol and biohydrogen. It serves as an economical feedstock and hence algae cultivation has gained attention in recent times. However it has various limitations which arise in respect of product recovery scaling up extraction methods viability of large scale harvesting methods and energy consumption. Conventional methods of extraction have various limitations with the selection of appropriate solvents for efficient extraction of value added products from microalgae biomass. The selected solvent should not only provide high yield of products but also need to be economi- cal and environmental friendly. This has been overcome by introduction of various new technologies such as microfiltra- tion and ultrafiltration for proficient extraction of high value products from microalgae. In addition the algae cultivation should adhere to the regulations set by the Food and Drugs Administration FDA agency in order to ensure the safety of the use of algae extract for human consumption. Large scale cultivation of microalgae are constrained by various other challenges among which the major hurdles we would like to discuss are Low productivity of microalgae biomass High cost of cultivation and harvesting techniques Contamination of biological pollutants Purification of high value products To increase the productivity of microalgae biomass few strategies could be considered. In this review we recom- mend using wastewater as the nutrient source for mass cul- tivation of microalgae in order to develop a cost effective process. Further use of native microalgae species which is acclimatised in wastewater are found to produce maxi- mum biomass and lipid content along with efficient nutrient 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 378 Page 20 of 29 removal Chen et al. 2015 . Mixed cultures microalgae are more favourable over monocultures in terms of high bio- mass higher nutrient removal from wastewater making it a more cost effective and easy to operate process Chen et al. 2015 . Another approach to improve productivity is mutagenesis or genetic engineering of native species of microalgae. Random mutagenesis of microalgae native strains have shown to improve biomass yields in Nannochlo- ropsis oceanica by 19 . Similarly screening of high cell density HCD strains after insertional mutagenesis followed by continuous subculture resulted in HCD strains showing 50 to 100 higher biomass yield as compared to the wild variants Bosnjakovic et al. 2020 Thung et al. 2018 . Various cultivation and harvesting techniques of micro- algae biomass have been discussed in detail in the previous sections of this review. Further Table 2 provides a compara- tive discussion of various cultivation and harvesting meth- ods. Although each method has its own pros and cons but from this review we can conclude that open raceway pond is more favourable for wastewater based large scale cultivation of microalgae biomass under non-sterile conditions. How- ever the conventional paddlewheel design can be optimised and upgraded to achieve high biomass productivity. Chen and co-authors have recommended a two-stage cultivation strategy with a nutrient-sufficient and a nutrient-limited stage to enhance simultaneous production of biomass and lipid content. Another approach to boost biomass yields is to consider mixotrophic cultivation a combination of pho- totrophic and heterotrophic cultures. This type of cultiva- tion not only minimises the production costs but also results in higher biomass production due to high conversion ratios of sugars to lipid by the heterotrophic cultures Zhou et al. 2012 Chen et al. 2015 . Similarly efficient and low cost harvesting techniques need to be considered for an economical algal biorefinery. The previous sections of this review have discussed various harvesting techniques and their advantages and disadvan- tages have also been listed in Table 2. Although centrifu- gation and filtration are widely used methods to harvest microalgae biomass at commercial level but these meth- ods add to the overall cost of production. An alternative to these methods is the advanced flocculation methods such as bio-flocculation by using genetically modified microbial strains which needs to be further investigated in order to develop an efficient symbiotic consortia that can help in improved sedimentation of algal biomass. Bio-flocculation is a low cost and environment friendly technique Bosnjako- vic et al. 2020 . Co-culture of algae-bacteria or algae-fungi have boosted algae biomass yields and lipid content. Co- culture of Chlorella vulgaris and bacteria Mesorhizobium sangaii resulted in formation of large flocs which settle down easily and can be harvested efficiently Wei et al. 2020 . This method resulted in 1.5 times higher biomass yield as compared to pure algal culture. Microalgae Chlorella soro- kiniana formed flocs with bacterial cultures Comamonas flocculans Melaminivor jejuensis which showed greater sedimentation rates. This resulted in improved biomass pro- ductivity of 102.25 0.35 mg L day while productivity with pure algal culture is only limited to 78.00 3.89 mg L day Kim et al. 2020a b . Another major hurdle which impedes mass production of microalgae biomass is contamination by biological pol- lutants. Large scale cultivation of microalgae in open ponds takes place under non-sterile conditions and hence very much prone to contamination by other microbes such as bacteria fungi zooplanktons or protozoa which lives in a symbiotic system. Grazing of zooplanktons mostly ciliates can clear up dense culture of microalgae species Dunaliella salina in 2 days. Bacterial species of Bacillus Pseudomonas Flavobacterium having lytic activity can destroy microalgae cells either via direct cell-to cell contact or by secretion of extracellular toxic compounds Wang et al. 2013 . Ciliated protozoa Colpoda steinii is another predator species which can clarify cyanobacterial cultures of Synechocystis sp. in 3 days. This predator species can form highly resilient cysts which acts as a major threat to Synechocystis cultivation. Therefore researchers have shown that cultivation of Syn- echocystis under non-sterile condition is possible only if carried out under partial anoxic environment which highly inhibits growth of Colpoda steinii Troschl et al. 2017 . The challenges imposed by biological pollutants can be over- come by considering few approaches to control them Wang et al. 2013 . Filtration with silk mesh or net is one approach to remove large size cells of protozoa or zooplanktons. Chemical additives such as ammonia formaldehyde pes- ticides and hydrogen peroxide can be used for disinfecting the microalgae cultures. Another alternative proposed by some researchers is the optimization of growth conditions like temperature pH salinity light etc. which promotes microalgae growth and inhibits proliferation of biological pollutants. The microalgae biorefinery approach utilise microalgal biomass for the production of biofuels and many value added products. These value added products need to be in highly pure form and hence it undergoes a number of purification steps to obtain a product with desired market value. This in turn lowers the final yield and also add up to the processing cost. Process integration in order to reduce the purification steps can be considered to reduce the processing cost. Several other challenges that need to be considered are growth rate and stability of microalgae cultures market potential of various products product loss due to degra- dation of light or temperature sensitive compounds like pigments. Complete utilisation of all residues and waste streams to some or other value added application or prod- ucts is essential to generate revenue in order to make the 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 Page 21 of 29 378 entire process economical. Lastly in order to evaluate the sustainability of the biorefinery approach life cycle assess- ment along with economics of all the proposed products of the biorefinery need to be carried out. In conclusion more efforts should be performed to reduce product loss and mini- mise energy costs while heading towards an environmental friendly large scale downstream processing for the extraction of high value compounds from microalgae. Techno economic feasibility of the microalgae based biorefinery model Any new process or technology developed in a bio-based economy will be feasible if it answers these questions in positive a. Is the developed technology feasible i.e. all the intermediate production steps from substrate to end-product are feasible b. Is it economically sustainable and profitable i.e. the products developed are produced at a lower value than its selling price c. Is it environmentally friendly and sustainable i.e. the developed technology has environmen- tally acceptable and friendly impact and is not harmful to the environment at any level Thomassen et al. 2018 . Biorefineries these days are looking for valorising mul- tiple products out of a single biomass feedstock to pursue circular bio economy and zero waste processes. Since micro- algae being a potential substrate for biofuels such as biom- ethane biohydrogen biodiesel and bioethanol owing to its capability of higher fixation of CO2 high biomass growth rate ability to store carbon in form of carbohydrates and lipid and different value added products viz. carbohydrates pigments proteins and biopolymers has led the attention towards the possibility of a microalgae based biorefinery Suali and Sarbatly 2012 Banu et al. 2020 . Moreover due to high protein content microalgal biomass can be used as aquafeed animal feed and poultry feed Ozcimen et al. 2016 Sharma et al. 2019 . Upstream and downstream approaches are two phases of a microalgal biorefinery. Some processes have been devel- oped for employment of microalgae for biofuels and its derived products that would expand the commercial market for microalgae derived products and will speed up the inte- gration of microalgae into mainstream biorefinery option Lopez Barreiro et al. 2014 . The rising idea of circular bioeconomy as a necessary factor in the currently devel- oped technologies applies to microalgae based processes also and therefore need to be critically reviewed before commercialization. At first microalgae biorefinery looks a promising approach in order to replace a lot of chemical based processes and products including fuels however a key drawback of producing biofuels and other derived value added products from microalgae is high production costs and economically unfeasible prices Show et al. 2015 Dasan et al. 2019 . Though microalgae have higher yield per unit area its growth rate and quality i.e. its biochemical composition in low-cost open cultivation systems vary rapidly due to vari- ation in the environmental parameters based on their taxo- nomical classes and species Fu et al. 2019 . Therefore a wide range of closed photobioreactors have been developed which are preferred over open cultivation systems for attain- ing maximum productivity with minimum risk of culture crashing. However most of the photobioreactors developed are still economically unfeasible for production of low-value end products from microalgae Hallenbeck et al. 2016 . Moreover high energy input is required during cultivation harvesting and drying steps leading to requirement of low- cost photobioreactors and downstream processes for achiev- ing feasible and economic microalgae based biofuels and value added products extraction system Dasan et al. 2019 . However microalgae despite showing huge potential and being studied for more than five decades there are only few corporations and industries involved in its commercial scale cultivation majorly due to high capital and operational expenses. Techno-economic analysis from cradle to gate is a potential means for having clarity on research priorities and estimating the economic and environmental feasibility of microalgae productions. Various researchers have per- formed techno-economic approaches for microalgae based production systems. Since most of the studies conclude that biodiesel obtained from microalgae is economically not fea- sible researchers are now focussing on the viability of multi product biorefinery exploring the possibility of concurrent production of biofuels along with other value added prod- ucts from microalgae Ramalingam and Sen 2020 . Differ- ent scenarios basic intermediate advanced and alternative of microalgae based production systems were developed by Thomasen et al. 2016 for producing 170 tonnes of microal- gae annually. Microalgae production pathways were ranged from a base case using commercially available technolo- gies to an improvised case with novel modern innovative processes. Open systems were considered for microalgae production in basic and intermediate scenarios while pho- tobioreactors were considered in advanced and alternative scenarios. Economic analysis revealed that capital expendi- ture was 400 higher in establishment of photobioreactor facility than open ponds and only the scenarios opting for open ponds were found economically feasible. It was also observed that if the culture medium was recycled the profits can be increased up to 4 times. Thomassen et al. 2018 in another study compared the potential of microalgae biorefin- eries in Belgium and India. The study was conducted based on an environmental techno-economic assessment for micro- algae based biorefinery options in India and Belgium. It was concluded through the study that the scenario in India has 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 378 Page 22 of 29 high economic stability with net present value of 40 million for a project life of 10 years while Belgium was observed to have lesser environmental impact. The critical factors observed during the study for feasibility apart from inclu- sion of a medium recycling step were β-carotene content and price algal concentration and electricity usage during upstream processes. Identification of such factors lead to guidance in technology development and reduces the time for establishment of microalgae biorefineries. Microalgae plant was designed to produce Chlorella vul- garis using 227 million L d 1 wastewater and later produc- ing bio-oil from the microalgae Juneja and Murthy 2017 . 28 211 tonnes of microalgae and 10 million L should be produced from the designed plant at the capital expenditure of 105 million and operating expenditure would be 17.88 million. An interesting observation during this study was the emission of green house gases during biodiesel production was 6.2 times lesser as compared to conventional diesel. Sensitivity analysis revealed that lipid content and plant size are two critical parameters in determining the price of biodiesel. An extensive comparative study was conducted at Uni- versity of Aveiro UA Portugal and National Renewable Energy Laboratory NREL USA to determine the sustain- ability of different conversion pathways and establish an integrated algal biofuels production model supported by both UA and NREL Dutta et al. 2016 . Processing technolo- gies assesses were solvent extraction transesterification and purification for biodiesel UA and fermentation distillation and hydrodeoxygenation for renewable diesel NREL . Min- imum fuel selling price were found to be 10.55 GGE gas- oline gallon equivalent for UA and 4.35 GGE for NREL case study. This analysis proved the significance of valori- zation of co-products leading to addition of revenue there by reducing the final fuel selling price. It also showed that cultivation of microalgae contributes towards 50 of emis- sions and biofuels processing technology of UA requires upgradation to achieve optimum results. The lipid extraction process has extreme issues leading to major contribution to greenhouse gas emissions and therefore stresses upon the recovery of solvent so as to reduce the emissions. Due to economic and technical uncertainties hovering over microalgae based biorefineries it is necessary to study the extent of impact of each critical parameter. Brownbridge et al. 2014 performed a global sensitivity analysis using high dimensional model representation method. The order of sensitivity for biodiesel production cost to critical input parameters is as follows algal lipid content annual areal microalgal productivity production capacity of plant car- bon price increase rate. It was also observed that return on investment is extremely sensitive to microalgal lipid content as compared to other parameters considered in the study. Biodiesel cost for a large scale plant having annual capacity for 1 00 000 tonnes biodiesel was found to be in range of 0.8 1.6 per kg. Barlow et al. 2016 showed similar results of sensitivity analysis proving algal productivity to be the most critical parameter for biodiesel fuel price. It also showed that use of wastewater for microalgae cultivation significantly reduced the environmental issues and reduced the cost of nutrient media to an extent. Xin et al. 2016 also carried out microalgae cultivation in photobioreactor facility using wastewater and cost of microalgal biomass was estimated to be 0.33 kg which was significantly lower as compared to microalgae produced through commercial media in terms of operational expenditures. Technical and economic feasibility of photobioreactor based microalgae cultivation facility for annual production of 37.85 million litres of biofuels was performed by Batan et al. 2016 . It was observed that 63 of total investment was shared by operational expenditures followed by 30 of capital investment and 7 land cost. Among the direct capital expenditures maximum share of 33 and 32 is represented by harvesting and lipid extraction systems respectively. 30 of direct capital investment is shared by cultivation systems and its accessories such as CO2 supply utility supply system pumps and pipelines. Indirect capital expenditures include warehouse office spaces contingency and land costs contributed upto 50 of total direct and indi- rect capital expenditures. Hydrotreating segment used for conversion of microalgae to biodiesel shared only 5 of capital expenditures. In operational expenditures 96 of the expenses were shared by cultivation harvesting and lipid extraction while the biodiesel hydrotreatment represented only 4 . Further breakdown of operational expenditure revealed that solvent cost for lipid extraction shares maxi- mum expense of 29 followed by 22 of nutrient and 16 of power charges. Ozcimen et al. 2018 presented two sce- narios for production of β-carotene and biodiesel from Chlo- rella vulgaris in photobioreactor system respectively. It was observed that the capital and operational expenditure were almost similar in the two scenarios however scrutinising the revenues led to the critical evaluation of importance of selling price in success of any given model. Average selling price of β-carotene was considered to be 1370 kg while biodiesel price was 0.82 kg proving that the designed sys- tem is more suitable for β-carotene production and capital investment and operating expenditures must be reduced to a significant extent in order to make biodiesel economical. Khanum et al. 2020 also proposed similar microalgal biorefinery scenarios where β-carotene was co-produced along with biodiesel and compared with a scenario where only biodiesel was produced from microalgae. Cost anal- ysis confirmed that the total investment for coproduction scenario was much higher than the scenario in which only biodiesel was produced however the revenue was hiked up to 37 million year. On the other hand only production 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 Page 23 of 29 378 of biodiesel showed loss of 345 million per unit while the co-production of β-carotene attained profit of 120.7 million per unit proving that valorization of co-products overcomes the inefficient economy resulting from a single product biorefinery. Prommuak et al. 2013 also suggested a model for coproduction of lutein along with biodiesel from Chlorella vulgaris for economic feasibility. Togarchetti et al. 2017 summarised that a each step involved has strong impact on the energy demand there by affecting the cost- economics of the whole biorefinery model b variation in microalgal productivity and location has vital role in the sustainability of the whole process. Based on the existing research work being carried out in the field of microalgae biorefinery modelling prima facie it signals towards the success of a multiproduct biorefinery model producing a bouquet of value added products using wastewater as a nutrient source will lead to a successful model for replacement of fossil based refineries and chem- ical-based products. However still a target-based approach is required to reduce the cost associated with cultivation and harvesting practices as they are the major contributors in the microalgae based processes. Dairy effluent treatment and microalgae biomass production A case study In this case study a pilot-scale high volume V-shape pond HVVP of size 2m 2m has been used for cultivation of microalgae species Ascochloris sp. ADW007 by utilising raw dairy wastewater for simultaneous production of bio- mass and treatment of dairy effluent for clean water produc- tion. This V-shaped reactor was indigenously fabricated at Sardar Patel Renewable Energy Research Institute SPRERI and was found to be more efficient then open raceway ponds in terms of higher surface to volume ratios low land foot- print and low cost Kumar et al. 2020 . This reactor has a capacity to cultivate maximum of 3000 L of culture at a time and continuous aeration is provided through poly- vinyl chloride pipes for uniform circulation and exposure of cells to light. In this study 100 raw dairy wastewater RDW is used for microalgae cultivation without any addi- tional nutritional supplements which resulted in biomass and lipid yields of 1.44 0.03 g L and 34.98 0.21 in 7 days Kumar et al. 2018a b . Apart from generation of microalgae biomass this study resulted in removal of 95.1 of COD and 92 of fluoride from RDW generating clean water which meets the standards of Indian Central Pollution Control Board Type E water designated for irrigation usage. This study was further extended by performing techno-eco- nomic analysis by considering three different scale-ups of dairy effluent generation plants viz. small 0.25 MLD medium 0.5-MLD and large 1.0-MLD over different project life times 10 20 and 30-yrs Kumar et al. 2020 . It was concluded that the 1 MLD plant considered for 20 y seemed to be most feasible in terms of 118 of internal rate of return IRR and with only 1.9 y of payback period. In this plant a calculated annual biomass production of 504 tons was achieved at 0.482 kg along with generation of approximately 240 000 m3 of treated clean water. This study Fig. 4 Schematic of the integrated process for production of microalgae biomass and other products using dairy waste water carried out at SPRERI 3 Biotech 2021 11 378 1 3 378 Page 24 of 29 also interpreted that HVVP is one of the competent micro- algae cultivation system in terms of cost and area efficiency. Apart from dairy effluent treatment this integrated process developed at SPRERI has utilised the biomass for production of lipids aquafeed and biodiesel as shown in Fig. 4 Sharma et al. 2019 . The ongoing research further targets various other products from both raw and de-lipidified algae biomass thereby satisfying a sustainable biorefinery concept. Conclusion The potential of microalgae to utilise the nutrients of waste- water enables it as a promising third generation feedstock for establishment of a sustainable and economical biorefin- ery. Use of wastewater for microalgae cultivation not only dilutes the overall cost economics but also acts as an efficient process of bioremediation. Economic assessment of current large-scale processes with a single product or two products system from microalgae deem it unfeasible. The possibil- ity of producing multiple bio-based products from a single microalgae strain has attracted the attention of researchers to optimise and streamline the material and energy balances. This review has highlighted the entire process of microalgae cultivation using wastewater and focussed on production of multiproducts from both raw and de-oiled microalgae resi- due with an approach of circular bioeconomy generating zero waste. The major products that could be targeted from raw algae biomass include lipid and biodiesel which are high volume low value products. Therefore to make algae based biorefinery more economical generation of low volume high value products is essential which includes vitamins proteins DHA carbohydrates etc. Moreover valorization of de-oiled algae residue to bio-based products provides an additional route of revenue generation within the established biore- finery. However low biomass productivity and inefficient multiproduct downstream processing techniques seem to be the major challenges that has hindered the establishment of economical microalgae biorefinery. This issues can be addressed by extensive research in producing genetically modified fast growing microalgae strains and design of simple and cost-effective downstream processing technolo- gies to reduce the overall production cost. Hence in-depth focussed investigation on few of these challenges would surely lead to commercialization of microalgae biorefinery in near future.
